posts.title: Welcome to Ghost
posts.markdown:
You're live! Nice. We've put together a little post to introduce you to the Ghost editor and get you started. You can manage your content by signing in to the admin area at `<your blog URL>/ghost/`. When you arrive, you can select this post from a list on the left and see a preview of it on the right. Click the little pencil icon at the top of the preview to edit this post and read the next section!

## Getting Started

Ghost uses something called Markdown for writing. Essentially, it's a shorthand way to manage your post formatting as you write!

Writing in Markdown is really easy. In the left hand panel of Ghost, you simply write as you normally would. Where appropriate, you can use *shortcuts* to **style** your content. For example, a list:

* Item number one
* Item number two
    * A nested item
* A final item

or with numbers!

1. Remember to buy some milk
2. Drink the milk
3. Tweet that I remembered to buy the milk, and drank it

### Links

Want to link to a source? No problem. If you paste in a URL, like http://ghost.org - it'll automatically be linked up. But if you want to customise your anchor text, you can do that too! Here's a link to [the Ghost website](http://ghost.org). Neat.

### What about Images?

Images work too! Already know the URL of the image you want to include in your article? Simply paste it in like this to make it show up:

![The Ghost Logo](https://ghost.org/images/ghost.png)

Not sure which image you want to use yet? That's ok too. Leave yourself a descriptive placeholder and keep writing. Come back later and drag and drop the image in to upload:

![A bowl of bananas]


### Quoting

Sometimes a link isn't enough, you want to quote someone on what they've said. Perhaps you've started using a new blogging platform and feel the sudden urge to share their slogan? A quote might be just the way to do it!

> Ghost - Just a blogging platform

### Working with Code

Got a streak of geek? We've got you covered there, too. You can write inline `<code>` blocks really easily with back ticks. Want to show off something more comprehensive? 4 spaces of indentation gets you there.

    .awesome-thing {
        display: block;
        width: 100%;
    }

### Ready for a Break? 

Throw 3 or more dashes down on any new line and you've got yourself a fancy new divider. Aw yeah.

---

### Advanced Usage

There's one fantastic secret about Markdown. If you want, you can write plain old HTML and it'll still work! Very flexible.

<input type="text" placeholder="I'm an input field!" />

That should be enough to get you started. Have fun - and let us know what you think :)

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/m2rsgfOxjaA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

posts.title: How to Make The Perfect BBQ Apron
posts.markdown:
Created by: Grainline Studio ###Steps 1. Trace the Pattern and Cut the Fabric 2. Make the Pocket 3. Sew on the Pocket 4. Hem the Sides and Bottom 5. Fold the Curved Facings 6. Pin and Sew on the Facings 7. Flip Apron Over and Press 8. Sew Each Edge of the Facings 9. Make the Strap 10. Thread Through Your Strap ###Materials: * 1 3/4 yards of self fabric * 1/2 yard of contrast fabric (Try Kaufman Big Sur Canvas ) * Pattern Download * Thread ##Step 1

![Apron Materials](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.1.jpg)

Cut out pattern pieces, trace onto your fabric and then cut your fabric. ##Step 2

![Apron Pocket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.2.jpg)

We are going to start the apron by sewing on the pocket! Press 1/4 inch around the edges of your pocket piece on all four sides. Fold over the top of your pocket piece 1 inch and press. Now sew as close to the bottom folded edge as possible. ##Step 3

![Apron Pocket Sew On](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.3.jpg)

Pin your pocket fabric to your self fabric. Sew around the 2 side edges and the bottom edge as close to the outside of the pocket as you can. ##Step 4

![Time to Hem](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.4.jpg)

Hem the top of your apron, the sides and the bottom. ##Step 5

![Make Your Curved Facings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.5.jpg)

Fold over the ends of your curved facings 1/2 inch and press. Then fold over the outside edge of the curved facing 1/4 inch. ##Step 6

![Pin and Sew Your Curved Facings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.6.jpg)

Pin these pieces to the arm curves of the self fabric. Make sure the raw edges of the self fabric and the facings are the edges that are being pinned together. Now sew them! ##Step 7

![Press Your Curved Facings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.7.jpg)

Press the seam open, turn the whole facing piece to the back of your apron and press. ##Step 8

![Attach Your Curved Facings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.8.jpg)

Sew along each edge of your curved facing, making a channel. ##Step 9

![Let's Make the Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.9.jpg)

Now for your strap! Sew the three pieces together and press your seams to one side. Fold over the end pieces and all along the side edges of the strap 1/2 inch and press. Now fold the strap in half and press + pin as you go. Sew the strap closed as close to the edge as possible. ##Step 10

![Insert the Straps](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/No.11.jpg)

Thread each end of your straps through the arm channels of your apron making a loop at the top. Try it on.. tie a bow.. youâ€™re done!

![BBQ Time!](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/bbq_3.jpg)

posts.title: Toiletry Bag for Dad Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by Blue Susan Makes

![Toiletry Bag for Dad](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/PicMonkey%20Collage2_resized.jpg)

\* Finished Dimensions 7" tall x 11" wide X 4" deep ####Materials * 1/2 yard quilting cotton or lightweight canvas for the exterior (We used Kaufman Essex Yarn Dyed Linen) * 1/2 yard quilting cotton for the lining (We used Reel It In Lures Green) * 1/2 yard ByAnnie's Soft and Stable for Interfacing * (2) 14" Zippers * 1 package of coordinating extra-wide double fold bias tape * Pattern Download * Thread * Quilt binding clips (optional) * Fabric marking pen #####Cutting- From the exterior fabric cut: * 1 strip 3 Â¾â€™â€™ x 19 Â¼â€™â€™ for the Bottom Panel * 2 strips 2â€™â€™ x 14 Â¾â€™â€™ for the Zipper Panels * 2 Side Panels from the Side Panel pattern piece * 1 Zipper pocket from the Zipper pocket pattern piece * 1 strip 2â€™â€™ x 11 Â½â€™â€™ for the Pocket trim * 1 rectangle 5 x 7â€™â€™ for the Handle #####Cutting- From the lining fabric cut: * 1 strip 4â€™â€™ x 19 Â¼â€™â€™ for the bottom panel * 2 strips 2â€™â€™ x 14 Â¾â€™â€™ for the zipper panel * 2 Side Panels from the pattern piece * 1 Interior pockets with the Interior pocket pattern piece (cut this on the fold) * 1 Zipper pocket from the Zipper pocket pattern piece #####Cutting- From the soft and stable cut: * 1 strip 4â€™â€™ x 19 Â¼â€™â€™ for the bottom panel * 2 strips 2â€™â€™ x 14 Â¾â€™â€™ for the zipper panel * 2 Side Panels from the pattern piece * 1 Zipper pocket from the Zipper pocket pattern piece *1 strip 1 Â¼â€™â€™ x 7â€™â€™ for the handle ####Step 1: Assemble and Quilt the Layers Layer the lining, exterior, and interfacing Bottom Panel pieces together with the interfacing sandwiched in the middle and the wrong sides of the other fabrics facing toward it. Sew a basting stitch along the long sides of the panel and treat it as one piece. Assemble the layers of the two Zipper Panels, two Side Panels, and Zipper Pocket in the same way.

![Assemble the Layers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/03-DSC_9276_resized.jpg)

Quilt one Side Panel and the Zipper Pocket panel as desired. I chose to stitch a 1-inch grid. You can use a fabric marker and a ruler to draw out the stitch lines or just â€œeyeballâ€ it like I did using the markings on my sewing machine as a guide. Leave the 2nd Side Panel piece un-quilted and sew a basting stitch around the edges. Mark the center points on the top, bottom, and sides of each piece using a fabric marker.

![Quilt the Layers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/02-DSC_9272_resized.jpg)

####Step 2: Make the Zipper Pocket Place a zipper along the top edge of the Zipper Pocket with the teeth front facing the exterior side. Position the zipper stop Â½'' away from the right side. Let the edge of the zipper tape hang over the edge of the pocket piece a little bit. Using a zipper foot on your sewing machine, sew along the zipper tape about 1/4 inch away from the edge.

![Add the Zipper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/04-DSC_9284_resized.jpg)

Fold the Zipper Pocket away from the zipper, flip the pocket over so you can see the zipper tape. Topstitch about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the edge of the zipper tape, enclosing the raw edge.

![Sew on the Zipper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/1-DSC_9291_resized.jpg)

Take the Pocket Trim piece and fold the sides toward the center with wrong sides together. Leave a small gap between the raw edges and press.

![Pocket Trim](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/07-DSC_9304_resized.jpg)

Lay one edge of the Pocket Trim along the upper zipper tape with the right side of the fabric facing the zipper front. Let the zipper tape extend slightly over the trim. Stitch in place with a 1/4'' seam allowance.

![Attach the Pocket Trim](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/08-DSC_9307_resized.jpg)

Carefully press the trim away from the zipper and wrap the folded edge around to the back, enclosing the zipper tape. Topstitch 1/8'' away from the seam, making sure you sew through the trim on the back as well

![Place the Zipper Pocket Peice](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/09-DSC_9318_resized.jpg)

Place the Zipper Pocket piece on top of the non-quilted Side Panel. Pin in place and Topstitch along the top edge of the Zipper Pocket Trim.

![Pin in Place](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/11-DSC_9339_resized.jpg)

Baste the sides and bottom of the Zipper Pocket to the Side Panel. Be careful as you sew over the zipper teeth. Use the hand wheel to walk the machine through the zipper teeth to avoid breaking the needle. Slide the zipper slider toward the center and trim the excess zipper tape.

![Make Interior Pocket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/16-DSC_9370_resized.jpg)

####Step 3: Make the Interior Pocket Fold the interior pocket piece along the fold line and press. Sew along the folded edge 1/8'' away from the edge.

![Pocket Lining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/1-DSC_9387_resized.jpg)

Place the pocket on the lining of the quilted Side Panel. Baste the sides and bottom in place. Sew a divider line in the center. I put a pin at the top of the pocket, flipped it over and stitched the divider line along the center quilting line. Remember to backstitch at the top of the pocket.

![Making Lining Pockets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/23-DSC_9407_resized.jpg)

####Step 4: Make the Zipper Panel Center the remaining zipper along the edge of a Zipper Panel with teeth facing the exterior side. Let the edge of the zipper tape hang over the edge of the panel piece slightly. Using a zipper foot, sew along the zipper tape about 1/4 inch away from the edge.

![Make Zipper Panel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/12-DSC_9346_resized.jpg)

Fold the Zipper Panel away from the zipper. From the zipper tape side topstitch about 1/8â€™â€™ from the edge of the zipper tape.

![Make another Zipper Panel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/13-DSC_9349_resized.jpg)

Repeat for the other side of the zipper and the remaining Zipper Panel piece and trim excess zipper tape.

![Finished Zipper Panel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/14-DSC_9359_resized.jpg)

Place one end of the Zipper Panel piece on top of one end of the Bottom panel piece with exterior sides together. Cut a 5 inch piece of Bias Tape. Open the folds and pin it to one side of the lining. Stitch with a 1/8â€™â€™ seam allowance.

![Attach the Bias Tape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/18-DSC_9374_resized.jpg)

Refold the bias tape to enclose the raw edges. Stitch along the bias tape about Â¼ â€™â€™ away from the edge. Repeat for the other end of the Zipper Panel and Bottom Panel making a loop. Press the seams away from the zipper panel.

![Sew on the Bias Tape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/19-DSC_9379_resized.jpg)

Lay the loop flat and center the zipper panel. Mark the center and side points with a marking pen or pins. Make sure to leave the zipper about halfway open.

![Finished Zipper Panel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/20-DSC_9384_resized.jpg)

####Step 5: Make the Handle Fold the Handle piece in half lengthwise and press with wrong sides together to mark the center.

![Handle Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/24-DSC_9413_resized.jpg)

Open the fold and press the raw edges toward the center but leave about a 1/4'' gap in the center. Lift one side and slide in the remaining small strip of interfacing.

![Fold the Handle Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/25-DSC_9417_resized.jpg)

Refold all folds and press. Topstitch along each side 1/8â€™â€™ from each edge and in the center, as desired.

![Sew the Handle](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/27-DSC_9425_resized.jpg)

Place the handle about Â¼â€™â€™ below the zipper panel on the side closest to the zipper pull. Baste in place. And pin or clip down so it stays out of the way during final construction.

![Attach the Handle](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/02-DSC_9097_resized.jpg)

####Step 6: Sew the Bag Together Baste the Bias Tape to the edges of the zipper panel. Open the folds of the tape fold the end toward the inside about Â½ â€˜â€™. Finger press and line up the edge of the tape with the edge of the zipper panel with the right side of the Bias Tape facing the lining. Sew with a basting stitch about 1/8â€™â€™ from the edge. When you reach the beginning, overlap the bias tape by about 1â€™â€™ and trim.

![Baste the Bias Tape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/PicMonkey%20Collage_resized.jpg)

Repeat for the other side. It should look something like this.

![Repeat the Other Side](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/05-DSC_9120_resized.jpg)

Pin or clip a side panel to the zipper panel with exterior sides together. Start by matching top, bottom, and side seam centers and place a clip at each point. Then clip the corners. Make sure the top of the zipper panel is next to the opening of the pockets so they are right side up. Sew around the sides using a seam allowance. Check that the bias tape is laying flat and out of the way as you sew. Keep the needle in the down position each time you stop to re-position the bag. Donâ€™t worry if the stitch line is a little wobbly, just make sure youâ€™ve caught all the layers in the stitches.

![Clip it Together](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/06small-DSC_9121_resized.jpg)

Refold the Bias Tape to enclose the seam and topstitch through the layers about Â¼ â€˜â€™ away from the edge.

![Sew the Bias Tape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/09-DSC_9153_resized.jpg)

Turn bag Right side out and push out the corners. Work the seams open and pinch the seams together to press the sides if necessary.

![All Done!](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/17-DSC_9253_resized.jpg)

**Now, wrap it up and give it to your dear old dad!**

Make sure the top of the zipper panel is next to the opening of the pockets so they are right side up. Sew around the sides using a seam allowance. Check that the bias tape is laying flat and out of the way as you sew. Keep the needle in the down position each time you stop to re-position the bag. Donâ€™t worry if the stitch line is a little wobbly, just make sure youâ€™ve caught all the layers in the stitches.

Refold the Bias Tape to enclose the seam and topstitch through the layers about Â¼ â€˜â€™ away from the edge.

Turn bag Right side out and push out the corners. Work the seams open and pinch the seams together to press the sides if necessary.

Now, wrap it up and give it to your dear old dad!

posts.title: U.S. Map Quilt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by Flamingo Toes Blog This US Map Quilt is perfect to take along on a road trip! It's covered with a fun map of the US - all appliqued in scrappy, colorful prints. You could even add a little line of embroidery to remember your trip by, or decorate the map with little hearts for places you've visited!

![US Map Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%202_resized.jpg)

It would be a fun gift for someone who loves to travel too! ####Materials: * We used Riley Blake Calico Days for the states * 1 Pink Calico Days Fat Eighths Panel (for states) * 1 Mint Calico Days Fat Eighths Panel (for states) * 1 Nutmeg Calico Days Fat Eighths Panel (for states) * 1 yard Calico Days Plaid Mint (for states and binding) * 1/2 yard Calico Days Red Plaid (for states) * 1/4 yard Calico Days Strawberry Mint (for states) * 2 yards Kona Cotton (for front) * 2 yards Calico Days Chicks Yellow (for back) * Batting * 5 yards Lightweight Fusible Webbing * Thread * Printable US Map ####Step 1 Begin by printing out your US map. You'll be making a grid of paper that is 7 across and 4 down. The states will overlap just a bit, trim off the white portion along the edges and tape the map together.

![Print Your Map](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%206_resized.jpg)

####Step 2 Cut apart the states. I cut down the center of the thick black line, but you can do it any way you'd like. Begin cutting out your states. To do this, I recommend cutting a piece of fusible webbing a little larger than the state you're cutting out. Cut out a fabric piece as well. Fuse the webbing to the back of the fabric.

![Cut out the States](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%207_resized.jpg)

Cut out your state, making sure that the wrong side of the pattern faces the right side of the fabric so that the state is the correct orientation.

![Washington Cut Out](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%208_resized.jpg)

Continue cutting out your states, varying your fabrics as you go, for a cute scrappy look. Leave Alaska and Hawaii as one piece on the paper until you have your fabric fused. That way you can keep track of your little islands more easily.

![United States](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%209_resized.jpg)

####Step 3 Cut your top fabric to 60" long. You'll leave the width at 45" - so your top piece will be 45" x 60". Lay out your re-taped paper map and then lay your top fabric over the top, centering the fabric over the map. Place Alaska and Hawaii in the bottom left corner. ####Step 4 Begin removing the paper backing from the states and laying them over the top fabric, lining up all your edges as close as you can. It's ok if they overlap just a bit. Iron all the states in place. I did this on my kitchen island - it is granite and can take the heat. ####Step 5 Once your states are all fused down, you can start the applique! Using a medium zig zag stitch, sew between and around all the states.

![Sew your States](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%2010_resized.jpg)

This will take a bit but I promise it will be worth it! It's so fun to see the states all sewed in place. ![All States are in Place](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%2011_resized.jpg) ####Step 6 Make a sandwich by laying your backing fabric wrong side up, then your batting, then your top fabric, right side up. Smooth out all the wrinkles, then pin everything together. Quilt everything together however you'd like. I outlined each state, and the entire map, then filled in the rest of the area with a free motion quilting.

![Add Some Free Motion Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%2012_resized.jpg)

####Step 7 Now onto binding! Cut out 2 1/2" strips of binding from the mint plaid fabric - you'll need 5. Sew the strips together, then press them in half.

![The Binding](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%2013_resized.jpg)

Bind your quilt in whatever method you normally use. **Once your quilt is all done, you can pop it in the wash so it gets all soft and crinkly!**

![Completed Map Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Customer%20Appreciation%202016/US%20Map%20Lap%20Quilt%204_resized.jpg)

posts.title: Perfect Pool Tote Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: A Crafty Fox This giant pool tote avoids the hassle of multiple bags since itâ€™s big enough to fit everything you need! Made with oilcloth and a vinyl lining, you wonâ€™t have to worry about sand or mildew and the wide straps keep the weight of the bag from digging into your arm. Add in that you can make it in just a few simple steps, and youâ€™ll have your favorite bag made in no time! ####Materials: * 1 yard (we used Oilcloth [Scottish Plaid Yellow](https://www.fabric.com/buy/0338953/oilcloth-scottish-plaid-yellow?cm_mmc=Blog-_-Links-_-pool_tote_tutorial-_-oil_cloth_scottish_plaid)) * 1 yard Vinyl (we used Galaxy Turquoise) * 1 1/2 yards Essex Linen (we used Leathered) * 2 1/2 yards Pellon 70 Peltex Sew-In Ultra Firm Stabalizer * General Sewing Supplies * Printable Instructions ####Step 1: Cutting Out Your Bag From Your Plaid Oilcloth, fold corner up to form a giant triangle. Cut two 17.5â€ x 25â€ outer panels along the bias (for bias plaid). Fold vinyl in half and cut a 17.5â€ x 25â€ piece with the 25â€ piece ON THE FOLD. This piece will need to be slightly larger than the plaid to finish the bag.

![Fold and Cut](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/1_1.jpg)

From your yarn dyed linen cut four strips 9â€ x 41â€. Trim selvedges and sew 2 strips together along the 9â€ edge. Repeat with the remaining two strips.

![Cut 4 9"x41" Strips](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/1_2.jpg)

From remaining piece of linen, cut a 9â€ x 12.5â€ piece for pocket panel. From Oilcloth scrap, cut a second 9â€ x 12.5â€ piece for pocket lining.

![Cut Your Pocket Panel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/1_3.jpg)

From your Peltex, cut two 3â€ x 80â€ strips. With remaining scraps, cut a 8 - 1/4â€ x 12â€ pocket panel insert. ####Step 2: Creating Your Handles Take your long strips of yarn dyed linen, and fold them in half to make a strip 4.5â€ x 80â€. Press well and starch if necessary. Insert long strips of Peltex and wrap one side of the linen over the edge of the peltex. Press. Fold remaining raw edge under, press, and using a walking foot, stitch edges closed with a 1/8â€ seam allowance.

![Make Your Handles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/2_1.jpg)

With your pocket right sides out, insert peltex, press, and fold edges over as in the handles and stitch shut. Add horizontal quilting 1/2â€ apart as before to stabilize and add texture to your bag. ####Step 4: Attaching Handles & Pocket to Outer Panels Fold outer plaid panel in half with the 17.5â€ ends lining up. Create a slight crease. Fold pocket in half with 9â€ edges lining up. Create a crease. Line up the creases and with the pocket 4â€ from the top of the bag, stitch the pocket down on the sides and the bottom.

![Attach the Pocket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/4_1.jpg)

Next, youâ€™ll attach your handles by overlapping them 1/2â€ over the pocket on each side, with the ends lining up with the bottom of the bag and the handle curved over the top. Starting 1.5â€ from the top of the bag, stitch down towards the bottom 1/8â€ from each edge. Using your first panel as a guide, attach straps to second panel.

![Attach the Handles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/4_2.jpg)

####Step 5: Assembling Your Bag With right sides together, sew the sides and bottom of the outer panels together. With fabric folded, and the right sides together, sew the sides of the lining together.

![Sew Outer Panels Together](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/5_1.jpg)

With both the lining and the bag exterior, very carefully cut a 2.5â€ square from the two bottom corners.

![Cutting Corners (Literally)](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/5_2.jpg)

Folding the cut edges so that the side seam lines up with the fold, pin and stitch with a 1/2â€ seam allowance so that you have a nicely boxed corner. Repeat with all remaining corners.

![Pinch, Flatten, Sew](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/5_3.jpg)

After repeating these steps with your exterior, press seams flat & turn your exterior bag right side out. Insert your lining inside with wrong side out. Line up seams and corners. Your lining should be about 3/4â€ taller than your exterior. Fold the lining so that the cut edge of the lining fabric is flush with the cut edge of the exterior. Fold over again so that a clean fold is all that is visible. Using binding clips, secure fold all the way around the bag, making sure handles are out of the way.

![Bind and Secure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/5_4.jpg)

####Final Thoughts & Tips for Working with Vinyl Working with vinyl & oilcloth can be really rewarding with just a few tips! First, never iron the shiny side of vinyl. I generally use a pressing cloth whenever I work with shiny fabrics. Using a walking foot is a must! This will keep these layers moving evenly through your machine. Always sew with the softest side down. This will keep your feed dogs happy and prevent the vinyl from getting stuck as is goes through your machine.

![Time for the Beach](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Perfect%20Pool%20Tote%20Bag%20Pattern%20-%201_resized.jpg)

posts.title: Mermaid Tail Blanket Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created By: Sweet Julia Boutique This fun tutorial gives you step-by-step instructions to create a mermaid tail for your little mermaid and a matching tail for her doll Free Pattern Available HERE (add to cart, checkout and download) ####Materials for Cotton Version * 2 1/2 yards of quilting cotton for main blanket (we used Michael Miller Fairy Frost Spice) * 2 yards of quilting cotton for tail and cuffs (we used Michael Miller Fairy Frost Mermaid) * 1 1/2 yards of coordinating Minky fabric (59" wide) * General sewing supplies ####Materials for Minky Version ######(if using fleece or minky, with no lining) * 1 yard of Minky for top band/cuff and tail (we used Minky 2 Tone Dot Turquoise) * 1 1/4 yards of Minky for the main blanket piece (we used Minky Cuddle Chevron Blush/White) * General sewing supplies

![Mermaid Tail Blanket for Child and Doll](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/IMG_8966_resized.jpg)

####Step 1 Once you have your fabric and pattern pieces ready, proceed to cut. ######For Child Blanket: * 2 top blanket cuffs: 18" x 23" * 2 main blanket pieces: 36" x 23" (or 45" x 23" for an older child) * 2 lining blanket pieces: 36" x 23" (or 45" x 23" for an older child) ######For Doll Version (15" or 18" dolls): * 2 top blanket cuffs: 7" x 8.75" * 2 main blanket pieces: 12" x 8.75" #####Step 2 Once you have those pieces cut and ready, proceed to cut the tails on the fold.

![Cut the Fins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Tailcut_resized.jpg)

Then, take your main blanket pieces and fold widthwise, right sides together. Place your cut out piece on the bottom edge - NOT on the fold side.

![Cut the Tail](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Maincut_resized.jpg)

![Another View](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Maincut2_resized.jpg)

After all your pieces are cut, you should have this: (plus a second set of main blanket pieces for lining)

![Cut Pieces](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/IMG_8833_resized.jpg)

####Step 3 With fabric right sides together, stitch your top blanket cuffs together at both short ends, creating a loop. Iron seams open and bring raw edges together, wrong sides together in a loop. Set aside.

![Blanket Cuff](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step1_resized.jpg)

####Step 4 With fabric right sides together, stitch the main blanket pieces together at the long/curved sides. Press seams open (only if you are using quilting cotton).

![Lining the Tail](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step2-1_resized.jpg)

Sew lining pieces right sides together and trim seam allowance to 1/4".

![Sew in Tail Lining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step2-2_resized.jpg)

####Step 5 Turn main blanket lining right side out, keep main blanket outer piece inside out and insert into lining. Baste lining and main fabric together along the top and bottom. Do not baste shut, but around, your blanket top and bottom will remain open. Basting helps keep these layers together.

![Turn Inside Out](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step3_resized.jpg)

Step 6: Sew Tail pieces right sides together, leaving top open. Clip seam allowance with pinking shears. Turn right side out and press (press only if using quilting cotton).

![Clip Fin Pieces](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step4-1_resized.jpg)

![Sew Fin Pieces Together](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step4-2_resized.jpg)

####Step 7 (optional) Using a disappearing ink pen or chalk mark your tail to add decorative stitching, top stitch along the edges if desired. I chose decorative design # 81 on my Bernina 350PE since it looks good on both sides. Stitch your decorative design following the lines you drew.

![Add Some Detail](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step5-2_resized.jpg)

####Step 8 With main blanket piece inside out insert tail at the bottom, with all raw edges matching and right side of blanket touching tail. The tail will be sandwiched inside the bottom of the main blanket piece.

![Insert the Fin...](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step6-1_resized.jpg)

![...into the Tail](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step6-2_resized.jpg)

####Step 9 Pin all layers of fabric together and sew. Finish with your serger or zig zag stitch if desired.

![Sew the Fin to the Tail](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step7_resized.jpg)

####Step 10 Turn your tail right side out. Match the raw edges of your cuff/band piece to the raw edges of the top of the blanket, making sure side seams match. Pin and sew around the top. Finish with a serger or zig zag stitch.

![Clip on the Cuff](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step8-1_resized.jpg)

![Sew on Your Cuff](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/Step8-2_resized.jpg)

**Enjoy your mermaid tail! For a doll version, follow the same steps but omit lining if desired and finish raw sides with a serger instead.**

![Finished Mermaid Tail Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Mermaid%20Tail/IMG_8983_resized.jpg)

(if using fleece or minky, with no lining)
  • 1 yard of Minky for top band/cuff and tail (we used Minky 2 Tone Dot Turquoise)
  • 1 1/4 yards of Minky for the main blanket piece (we used Minky Cuddle Chevron Blush/White)
  • General sewing supplies

Step 1

Once you have your fabric and pattern pieces ready, proceed to cut.

For Child Blanket:
  • 2 top blanket cuffs: 18" x 23"
  • 2 main blanket pieces: 36" x 23" (or 45" x 23" for an older child)
  • 2 lining blanket pieces: 36" x 23" (or 45" x 23" for an older child)
For Doll Version (15" or 18" dolls):
  • 2 top blanket cuffs: 7" x 8.75"
  • 2 main blanket pieces: 12" x 8.75"
Step 2

Once you have those pieces cut and ready, proceed to cut the tails on the fold.

Then, take your main blanket pieces and fold widthwise, right sides together. Place your cut out piece on the bottom edge - NOT on the fold side.

After all your pieces are cut, you should have this: (plus a second set of main blanket pieces for lining)

Step 3

With fabric right sides together, stitch your top blanket cuffs together at both short ends, creating a loop. Iron seams open and bring raw edges together, wrong sides together in a loop. Set aside.

Step 4

With fabric right sides together, stitch the main blanket pieces together at the long/curved sides. Press seams open (only if you are using quilting cotton).

Sew lining pieces right sides together and trim seam allowance to 1/4".

Step 5

Turn main blanket lining right side out, keep main blanket outer piece inside out and insert into lining. Baste lining and main fabric together along the top and bottom. Do not baste shut, but around, your blanket top and bottom will remain open. Basting helps keep these layers together.

Step 6: Sew Tail pieces right sides together, leaving top open. Clip seam allowance with pinking shears. Turn right side out and press (press only if using quilting cotton).

Step 7 (optional)

Using a disappearing ink pen or chalk mark your tail to add decorative stitching, top stitch along the edges if desired. I chose decorative design # 81 on my Bernina 350PE since it looks good on both sides. Stitch your decorative design following the lines you drew.

Step 8

With main blanket piece inside out insert tail at the bottom, with all raw edges matching and right side of blanket touching tail. The tail will be sandwiched inside the bottom of the main blanket piece.

Step 9

Pin all layers of fabric together and sew. Finish with your serger or zig zag stitch if desired.

Step 10

Turn your tail right side out. Match the raw edges of your cuff/band piece to the raw edges of the top of the blanket, making sure side seams match. Pin and sew around the top. Finish with a serger or zig zag stitch.

Enjoy your mermaid tail! For a doll version, follow the same steps but omit lining if desired and finish raw sides with a serger instead.

posts.markdown:
Created by: Lillyella Stitchery Itâ€™s time to get organized for back to school! Flex frame pouches are quick and easy to construct with no zippers required! This pattern uses a 3.5â€ flex frame, and is just the right size for eyeglasses or a cell phone, but also makes a great pencil pouch or carrying case for your rotary cutter. With a few simple adjustments, you can make a smaller version perfect for lunch money, loose change or small supplies of any kind. ####Materials ######(for tall pouch finished size 3.5â€ wide by 7.5â€ high) * 10" square quilting cotton for outer top (or patchwork/pieced variation, see options at end of pattern) (we used the Anna Maria Horner Loominous Collection for the regular pouch and Designer Essentials Solids 5" Charm Pack for the paper pieced pouch) * 5â€ x 8â€ faux leather for outer bottom * 10â€ square quilting cotton for lining * 10" square cotton batting * 10" Square Pellon Interfacing (we used Pellon SF 101 Shape Flex) * One 3.5" flex frame * Flex Frame Pattern Download * Pencil Pouch Pattern Download * Thread * General Sewing Supplies ** If not using Shape Flex, only substitute a feather weight interfacing. Other interfacings will add too much bulk to the top and affect the functionality of the frame. #####Cutting your Materials * From the outer top fabric, cut two pieces 4â€ wide by 6.5â€ high. The top will be folded over about 1.25â€ so place any focal images below 1.5â€ down from the top. * From the Pellon Shape Flex interfacing, cut two pieces 4â€ wide by 6.5â€ high. Fuse to the wrong side of the outer top pieces. * From the outer bottom material, cut two pieces 4â€ wide by 3.5â€ high. * From the lining material, cut two pieces 4â€ wide by 9.5â€ high. * From the batting, cut two pieces 3.5â€ wide by 9â€ high. ####Assembling the Pouch #####Step 1 Begin by piecing the outer top and bottom pieces together. Line one outer top and one outer bottom piece up along the bottom 4â€ edge of the outer top fabric, right sides together. Sew using a 1/4â€ seam. Repeat for second set of outer fabrics. You may need to use a leather/denim needle depending on the thickness of your material.

![Line Top and Bottom Pieces](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigA-V2_resized.jpg)

Press the outer top fabric up and top stitch along the seamed edge (Fig A). Be careful when pressing not to hit the leather/vinyl with your iron. Set your outer pieces aside. Next, center your batting pieces on the wrong side of your lining pieces and spray baste or pin in place (the batting will be 1/4â€ smaller on all sides). Quilt a few lines to secure the batting to the lining (Fig A). This will not be visible as itâ€™s inside the pouch, but helps prevent bunching when turning the piece later. NOTE: If you do not want/need your pouch padded (such as if you will be using it for pencils vs. eyeglasses), you can eliminate the batting and instead use Shape Flex interfacing on the lining pieces. #####Step 2 After the outer and lining pieces are prepared, take one of each and, on the wrong side of the fabric, mark lines 2.25â€ down from the top on all pieces (Fig B). Place your two outer pieces right sides together and sew using a scant 1/4â€ seam starting at one marked line stitching down around the bottom and back up to the other marked line (Fig B left). Be sure to back stitch very well at the start and stop as there will be some tension on this area. Go slowly through the seam where the top and bottom sections are pieced to ensure your tension is tight. Hand crank through or stitch over twice if needed.

![Mark 2.25" Down](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigB-V2_resized.jpg)

Next, place your two lining pieces right sides together and sew in the same manner using a heavy 1/4â€ seam, leaving a large gap in the bottom for turning the piece later (Fig B right). Leave most of the bottom open, just turn each corner and sew a few stitches, back stitching well each time you start and stop. #####Step 3 Now itâ€™s time to sew the outer pieces and lining together. Place the two pieces with the top openings towards each other and line up the top flaps as shown in Figure C (both will be wrong side out). You will match one outer piece to one lining piece on each side. Pin securely to keep them lined up and in place.

![Sew Pieces Together](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigC-V2_resized.jpg)

One at a time, sew around the edge using a 1/4â€ seam beginning just above your previously marked line and ending just above the other, once again back stitching well at the beginning and end (Fig D left). Repeat on the other set of flaps.

![Sew Around Edge](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigD-V2_resized.jpg)

#####Step 4 You are now ready to turn your entire piece through the gap left in the bottom of the lining. Begin by carefully rolling down your lining piece until you are able to start pulling the outer piece through the opening. Work slowly and carefully and donâ€™t forget about the flaps. Use a thin blunt tool to help with all the corners. Keep working until your outer and lining are both right side out as shown in Figure E (center).

![Roll Down Lining Piece](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigE-V2_resized.jpg)

The next step is to stitch up the opening in the bottom of your lining. Tuck the raw edges inside and pin to secure. Stitch close to the edge by machine or hand. You can now turn the lining into the pouch. Start by turning the bottom in and slowly continue to roll the lining into itself. A package of bias tape happens to be the perfect size to help push it all the way down inside (Fig E right). #####Step 5 One more step and youâ€™re all done! Give the piece a good press, avoiding the bottom leather and making sure to press the top flaps nice and flat. Pull one flap back and pin to keep it out of the way. Fold the other flap down to where the side seams start, and pin to hold in place. Hand stitch the flap to the lining along the inside bottom edge of the flap. Be sure your needle is only going through the lining fabric and not through the outer fabric (Fig F).

![Insert the Frame](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/FigF-V2_resized.jpg)

Once both flaps are stitched down, you are ready to insert your frame. Slide both sides in at the same time, pushing slowly and adjusting the fabric as needed if the ends catch a bit. Once through, push the fabric back a bit so you can easily close the frame ends together and insert the provided pin (Fig F). Press the metal flaps down over the ends using a pair of pliers or flat head screwdriver and youâ€™re finished! #####Variations: If preferred, you can use just one fabric for the outside of your pouch, instead of adding a bottom accent, or you can create a patchwork design. If using one solid fabric, cut two pieces 4â€ wide x 9.5â€ high of your outer fabric and the Shape Flex interfacing. If using a canvas or heavy fabric, you do not need the interfacing. If creating a patchwork design for the exterior, fuse a piece of Shape Flex interfacing to the back after piecing and then trim to size. Trim to 4â€ wide x 6.5â€ high if piecing with a bottom accent, or trim to 4â€ x 9.5â€ if creating one solid patchwork exterior.

![No Bottom Accent](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Pouch%20Open.jpg)

To create the Pencils Pattern pouch shown, download the free pattern above and follow the directions included in the PDF. The height of this pouch can also easily be modified by adding to or subtracting from the height of your pieces. Just be sure to add or subtract equal amounts to the outer, lining, interfacing and batting pieces.

![Pencil Pouch](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Pencils%20Hero%20Full.jpg)

To create the smaller coin pouch shown above (finished size 3.5" x 3.5"), cut your pieces as follows: * Outer top fabric and Shape Flex: 4â€ wide x 3.5â€ high * Outer bottom accent: 4â€ wide by 2â€ high * Lining Fabric and Shape Flex: 4â€ wide by 5â€ high

![Coin Purse](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Coin%20Hero%20Crop.jpg)

Follow all the same assembly instructions provided above. Regardless of the height of your pieces, the cutting width will always be 4â€ when using a 3.5â€ frame and the same construction method will apply. **Happy Sewing!**

posts.title: Sweet Sewing Shelves Applique Quilt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Flamingo Toes Blog

![Sweet Sewing Shelves Applique Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Pretty-Sewing-Room-Quilt_resized.jpg)

September is National Sewing Month! This sweet Sewing Shelves Applique Quilt is the perfect addition to your sewing studio, or as a gift for your favorite seamstress.

![Sewing Applique Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Sewing-Room-Quilt_resized.jpg)

It's all decorated up with sewing room shelves that hold all kinds of fun things for your sewing room! A cute floral sewing machine, thread, fabric and even little flowers!

![Sewing Shelves Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/CloseUp.jpg)

This quilt is perfect for a fat quarter bundle or even as a stash buster. Let's get started! #####Materials: * Fat Quarter Bundle - We used the Robert Kaufman Woodland Clearing Collection * 2 yards of fabric for the shelving * 2 yards for backing * 1 yard for binding * 2 1/2 yards for front (we used Quilter's Linen Print White) * Batting * 3 yards Fusible Webbing * Thread * Sewing Shelves Pattern #####Project Prep Cut out your white fabric and shelf pieces first. You'll need: Out of white: 2 pieces 6" x 60" for side pieces 2 pieces 2 1/2" x 12 3/4" 2 pieces 2 1/2" x 4 1/2" 1 piece 16 1/2" x 27 1/2" (for top shelf piece) 2 pieces 15 1/2" x 27 1/2" (for middle and bottom shelf pieces) 1 piece 6" x 27 1/2" Fabric for shelves: 2 pieces 2 1/2" x 42" 3 pieces 2 1/2" x 27 1/2" Fabrics for bolts on lowest shelf - one from each fabric - 11" x 2" 8 pieces 1 1/2" x 1" for bolt ends Print out your pattern pieces and decide what prints you'd like on each piece. Cut slightly larger pieces of fabric than each pattern and iron fusible webbing to the wrong side of the fabrics. Cut out each of the pattern pieces.

![Quilted Sewing Machine](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Fabric-Sewing-Machine-Pattern_resized.jpg)

Sew each of the horizontal shelf pieces to the bottom sides of the white shelf pieces. For each shelf, lay out the applique pieces and fuse them in place. Trace your detail stitching in place on all the shelves.

![Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Sewing-Quilt-Shelf_resized.jpg)

Take each shelf and do any detail stitching first using free motion stitching. For example, the lines on the pincushion, the pins, the detailing on the lettering. Once you have all your detail stitching finished, zigzag all the applique pieces in place using a small zigzag stitch.

![Quilted Sew](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Free-Motion-Lettering_resized.jpg)

For the flowers, sew little free motion stitching lines in a star shape, then sew little circles at the end of each spoke.

![Quilted Flowers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Applique-Flowers-for-Quilt_resized.jpg)

Once you have your shelves all appliqued, assemble your quilt top. Sew each of the shelves together top to bottom. Under the lowest shelf, sew the 6" x 27 1/2" white rectangle. For each of the vertical shelves, sew a 2 1/2" x 12 3/4" white piece to one side and a 2 1/2" x 4 1/2" piece to the other side. Sew these strips on each side of the center shelves. Sew the 6" x 60" pieces on each side of the vertical shelves. Your quilt top is all finished!

![Quilted Front](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Sewing-Room-Quilt-Top_resized.jpg)

Quilt and bind your quilt in whatever what you'd like. I straight stitched around all appliques and the shelving, and did a free motion meandering quilting in all the white spaces. Now you can show off your cute new sewing shelves quilt!

![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/Sewing%20Room%20Quilt/Sweet-Sewing-Shelves-Quilt-with-Free-Pattern_resized.jpg)

posts.title: Tips for Sewing Faux Fur
posts.markdown:
By: The Sara Project

![Stylish Faux Fur](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/IMG_2374_resized.jpg)

Are you ready for cool weather sewing like I am? Nothing feels more luxurious and cozy than the feel of furâ€¦ faux fur! A fur coat is a glam way to layer for cooler days. This fallâ€™s fashion trends definitely include fur: animal prints, textures, and even beautiful jewel toned colors. Best of all, you can find all of these fur trends here on fabric.com. I have some tips to share to make your faux fur sewing projects a success. Sewing with faux fur is really so simple if you know the right way to work with it. Donâ€™t fear the fur!

![The Sara Project Faux Fur](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/FullSizeRender_resized.jpg)

#####Materials: * 2 yards of Faux Fur (we used Forest Fox Platinum) * Sharp Scissors * Clover Awl * One package of 10 wonder clips * Schmetz Universal Needle (90 works best) * Pins * Pattern Before you begin, there are a few things to do. First, find the direction of the hairs (or nap) by using your hand to brush the fur along the grain, you want to make sure the fur tips are going in the direction of the natural flow of the fur.

![Find the Faux Fur nap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur1_resized.jpg)

Next, I like to draw an arrow on the knit backing of the faux fur, showing the natural direction the fur is going. This helps when you are getting ready to place and cut out your pattern pieces. You want to make sure your fur is going in the correct direction when cutting your pattern out.

![Draw an Arrow point the Direction of Fur](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur2_resized.jpg)

Next, lay out your pattern pieces, and lightly pin them to the wrong side (knit backing of your faux fur)

![Pin your Pattern](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur3_resized.jpg)

Using a straight edge, like a ruler, trace your pattern directly onto the wrong side of your fabric. I just used a regular pen. (You wonâ€™t be able to see the markings at all when finished). You will need to cut one pattern piece out at a time on a single layer of your faux fur fabric.

![Use a Ruler](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur4_resized.jpg)

![Trace Your Pattern](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur5_resized.jpg)

Now itâ€™s time to cut! When cutting your fur, make sure to just barely snip through the knit backing layer of your fur. This can take some time, go slow. If you were to cut straight through your fur, you would get a blunt fur edge along your seams, which would change the length of the fur at the seam. Start slowly, and you will find you get a feel for it as you go. (It helps to practice on a scrap piece first!).

![Cut Slowly and Carefully](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur6_resized.jpg)

As you cut, you will notice the different directions of the fur as you cut through the different angles of your pattern. Hereâ€™s an example of some of my pieces while cutting.

![Example of Cuts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur8_resized.jpg)

![Example #2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur9_resized.jpg)

Once you have all your pattern pieces cut out, itâ€™s time to pin. I recommend using Wonder Clips to pin your two pieces together. They do a really good job of securing the pieces, and keeping the fur from popping back up. Regular pins slipped out, and didnâ€™t hold the hairs down in the seam. When pinning your fabric and lining pieces together, use your finger as you pin to brush the fur inside the seam. Again, take your time. Use your Wonder Clips to clip your two pieces together as you go. You donâ€™t want any fur coming out of your seam allowance. (When pinning along the bottom hem edge of your projects, it can be tricky getting all the hairs inside the seam because they want to point downwards. Do the best you can, itâ€™s okay if a few pieces are poking out).

![Use Wonder Clips 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Tutorials/fur%20coat/fur11_resized.jpg)

By: The Sara Project

Are you ready for cool weather sewing like I am? Nothing feels more luxurious and cozy than the feel of furâ€¦ faux fur! A fur coat is a glam way to layer for cooler days. This fallâ€™s fashion trends definitely include fur: animal prints, textures, and even beautiful jewel toned colors. Best of all, you can find all of these fur trends here on fabric.com.

I have some tips to share to make your faux fur sewing projects a success. Sewing with faux fur is really so simple if you know the right way to work with it. Donâ€™t fear the fur!

Materials:
  • 2 yards of Faux Fur (we used Forest Fox Platinum)
  • Sharp Scissors
  • Clover Awl
  • One package of 10 wonder clips
  • Schmetz Universal Needle (90 works best)
  • Pins
  • Pattern

Before you begin, there are a few things to do. First, find the direction of the hairs (or nap) by using your hand to brush the fur along the grain, you want to make sure the fur tips are going in the direction of the natural flow of the fur.

Next, I like to draw an arrow on the knit backing of the faux fur, showing the natural direction the fur is going. This helps when you are getting ready to place and cut out your pattern pieces. You want to make sure your fur is going in the correct direction when cutting your pattern out.

Next, lay out your pattern pieces, and lightly pin them to the wrong side (knit backing of your faux fur)

Using a straight edge, like a ruler, trace your pattern directly onto the wrong side of your fabric. I just used a regular pen. (You wonâ€™t be able to see the markings at all when finished). You will need to cut one pattern piece out at a time on a single layer of your faux fur fabric.

Now itâ€™s time to cut! When cutting your fur, make sure to just barely snip through the knit backing layer of your fur. This can take some time, go slow. If you were to cut straight through your fur, you would get a blunt fur edge along your seams, which would change the length of the fur at the seam. Start slowly, and you will find you get a feel for it as you go. (It helps to practice on a scrap piece first!).

As you cut, you will notice the different directions of the fur as you cut through the different angles of your pattern. Hereâ€™s an example of some of my pieces while cutting.

Once you have all your pattern pieces cut out, itâ€™s time to pin. I recommend using Wonder Clips to pin your two pieces together. They do a really good job of securing the pieces, and keeping the fur from popping back up. Regular pins slipped out, and didnâ€™t hold the hairs down in the seam. When pinning your fabric and lining pieces together, use your finger as you pin to brush the fur inside the seam. Again, take your time. Use your Wonder Clips to clip your two pieces together as you go. You donâ€™t want any fur coming out of your seam allowance. (When pinning along the bottom hem edge of your projects, it can be tricky getting all the hairs inside the seam because they want to point downwards. Do the best you can, itâ€™s okay if a few pieces are poking out).

As you are sewing your pieces together, use your awl to gently push any fur pieces that have popped out of the seam edge back into the seam.

When sewing two pieces of fur together, use your fingers and your awl to gently push the hairs inside the seam as you again clip them together with your Wonder Clips.

I also found it helpful to use my awl to gently pull out any pieces of hair that may have gotten caught in the stitching after sewing two pieces together. (Especially in that hem edge I talked about earlier). This will help give your coat a really beautiful, full look around the seams and hem when finished.

When prepping your sleeves, make sure to gently push the fur down with your finger as you sew in your ease stitches as shown below:

Thatâ€™s all there is to it. With these simple tips, you can sew your very own gorgeous faux fur coat. Stay warm and happy sewing!

posts.title: Cosmetic Pouch Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Anyone with basic sewing skills can make this adorable cosmetic pouch! #####Materials * Sewing Machine * Zipper foot * Two coordinating fabrics (We used these!) * All-Purpose Zipper (10â€ or longer) * Coordinating all-purpose thread * Interfacing ######Optional: * Rotary Cutter * Ruler or seam Gauge * Marking tool * Cutting mat * 6.5â€x24â€ acrylic ruler #####Step 1

![Cosmetic Pouch Tutorial](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag1.jpg)

Cut 2 10â€x10â€ squares out of each fabric. You will have 4 total, 2 for the outside and 2 for the inside. Cut 4 10x10 squares out of interfacing. Apply interfacing according to directions to each piece. #####Step 2

![Cut two 2x2 Squares](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag2.jpg)

Cut two 2â€x2â€ squares out of the bottom corners of each piece of Fabric #####Step 3

![Sew on Your Zipper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag3.jpg)

Attach zipper. Take one outside piece of fabric (the pink floral one in our photos) and put the top edge against one edge of the zipper, right side down. With your zipper foot in place, sew the fabric to the zipper tape with the zipper foot flush against the zipper teeth. Repeat with the other side. For the lining fabric, repeat the same steps but on the wrong side of the zipper. The right side of the lining fabric will face the wrong side of the zipper tape. You now have all of the fabric pieces attached to the zipper.

#####Step 4 Top stitch from the right side on either side of zippers. #####Step 5

![Arrange Your Pieces](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag5.jpg)

Arrange your pieces so that your main fabric pieces are right sides together and your lining pieces are right sides together, with the zipper flat in the middle. #####Step 6

![Open Zipper Halfway](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag6.jpg)

Open the zipper half-way. Using a Â¼â€ seam allowance, sew around the sides of the pouch, leaving an opening at the bottom of the lining pieces. Ignore the cut out squares for now. #####Step 7

![Box the Corners](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag7.jpg)

Box the corners by opening the cut outs and centering the seams in the middle so the lines match and sew using a Â¼â€ seam allowance. #####Step 8

![Finished Cosmetic Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Cosmetic%20Bags/Project_cosmeticBag8.jpg)

Using the opening you left in the lining, turn the bag right-side out. Your bag is now mostly complete. #####Step 9: Stitch up the opening in the lining by hand or by machine and **enjoy your cute new cosmetic bag!**

posts.title: Cornhole/Bags Beanbag Set Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Regulation cornhole bags measure roughly 6x6 inches and weigh 15 to 16 oz. The bags are traditionally filled with corn, which breaks down as the bags are used, creating a dust that helps the bags slide on the cornhole board. If insects or mildew are concerns, use plastic pellets in lieu of corn.

![Cornhole6_resized](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cornhole%20Bags/Cornhole6_resized_social.jpg)

#####Materials * 2 yds. of Broadcloth Fabric (Choose from NFL or Collegiate) * Coordinating thread * Scissors (we recommend this amazing pair!) * Iron (we recommend this one) * 14 cups whole corn * Funnel #####Step 1

![Cornhole6_resized](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cornhole%20Bags/step_1.jpg)

Cut 16 7â€™â€™x7â€™â€™ squares Note: this allows for a Â½ inch seam allowance on all sides. If you prefer a 5/8 inch seam allowance (like most commercial patterns), make your squares7 Â¼ inches #####Step 2

![Cornhole6_resized](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cornhole%20Bags/step_2.jpg)

With the right sides together, sew around three sides of the squares and halfway across the fourth using a half-inch seam allowance. Then, turn the bag right side out, making sure the corners are neat. Press using lots of steam. Ensure the opening is turned under neatly, then press well to make closing the bag easier. #####Step 3

![Cornhole6_resized](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cornhole%20Bags/step_3.jpg)

Using a funnel, fill each bag with 1 Â¾ cups of whole corn. If using popcorn or plastic pellets, fill the bags until each one weighs approximately 16 oz. Pin the opening closed. #####Step 4

![Cornhole6_resized](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cornhole%20Bags/step_4.jpg)

Carefully stitch the bag closed approximately 1/8 inch away from the edge. Go slowly to make sure to not run over a corn kernel! Once the opening is sewn shut, continue the edgestitching all the way around the bag, pivoting at the corners. Finally, carefully sew a second row of stitches 1/8 inch inside the first row. Trim your threads. Now youâ€™re ready to play!

posts.title: No-Sew Fleece Blanket
posts.markdown:
#####Materials ######Large Throw * 3 yds. football fleece * 3 yds. coordinating fleece * Scissors (we recommend this amazing pair!) * Index card or 3'' x 5'' cut-out ######Small Throw * 1.5 yds. football fleece * 1.5 yds. coordinating fleece * Scissors (we recommend this amazing pair!) * Index card or 3'' x 5'' cut-out #####Step 1

![step1](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Fleece%20Blanket/step_1.jpg)

If your fleece contains a selvage, trim it off. Then, spread out your coordinating piece of fabric, ensuring the soft side is facing down. Next, spread out your piece of football fabric and lay it soft-side up on top of your coordinating piece. Line the two pieces and trim where necessary to ensure both pieces are the same size. Smooth the fabric to remove any bumps. #####Step 2

![step2](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Fleece%20Blanket/step_2.jpg)

Set your index card or 3â€™â€™x5â€™â€™ cut-out on one corner of your fleece. Cut around the card to create a missing rectangle from the corner, ensuring youâ€™re cutting through both pieces of fabric. Repeat on all four corners. #####Step 3

![step3](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Fleece%20Blanket/step_3.jpg)

Starting at one corner, create a 1â€™â€™ wide cut measuring the length of the rectangle that youâ€™ve just created. Be sure to cut through both pieces of fabric. The cuts on the shorter side of your blanket will be longer than the cuts on the longer side, depending on the dimensions of the rectangle you cut in Step 2. Continue cutting 1â€™â€™ strips around the circumference of the two fleece pieces, creating an even fringe on all sides. #####Step 4

![step4](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Fleece%20Blanket/step_4.jpg)

Starting at a corner, tie the base of one strip of the football printed fleece to the base of one strip of the coordinating piece of fabric. Double knot the strips to ensure a secure blanket. Note: to prevent the fleece pieces from puckering, hold the strips taut as you work your way around the blanket. Repeat on all sides until each strip is knotted.

Here are two easy ways to make the perfect throw pillow for your home! The first method uses an invisible zipper and invisible zipper foot. The second uses an envelope closure. ![Materials](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Pillows/Project_pillow1.jpg)

Cut two pieces of fabric the measurements of your pillow form +1â€ for seam allowances. Our pillows were 18â€ square so we cut 2 19â€ squares out of our Fabric. If you like, finish the edges of your fabric now with a serger. You can also finish them later with pinking shears. #####Step 2

![Attach Your Invisable Zipper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Pillows/Project_pillow10.jpg)

#####Step 3

![Sew Your Edges](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Pillows/Project_pillow2.jpg)

Open the zipper halfway, so you can turn the pillow inside-out when youâ€™re through. Sew around the open edges of the two squares of fabric, right sides together. When you get to the edges by the zipper, pull the zipper away you can sew up the corners.

![Sew Your Edges 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Project%20of%20the%20week%20/Pillows/Project_pillow3.jpg)

#####Step four Trim the excess zipper edges off â€“ if you cut off the zipper stop, make sure you sew across the zipper tape so that your zipper head doesnâ€™t come off. Cut the corners diagonally next to the stitching. Turn inside out and stuff with your pillow-form. ####Envelope Closure Pillows We used [these fabrics!](https://www.fabric.com/collection/european-100percent-linen?cm_re=CustomerAppreciation-_-PillowProduct_Linen-_-5.3.16) #####Step one Cut one piece of fabric the size of the pillow form plus 1â€ for seam allowance. On one 17â€ side of each of the back pieces, fold the edge over to the wrong side .5â€and press and then again another .5â€ and press again. Top stitch these pieces on the front side of the folded edge

posts.title: How to Sew a Blind Hem
posts.markdown:
Created by: Tie Dye Diva Patterns A blind hem is a great skill for any seamstress to have in her repertoire. You never know when youâ€™ll have that special project that needs an invisible hem. Blind hems are perfect on any garment made from medium to lightweight fabric with a 1â€³ or deeper hem. Today we will show you how to sew a blind hem by hand as well as on your domestic sewing machine.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/TieDyeDiva-16.jpg)

######Materials: * Garment needing a hem. We used the Tie Dye Diva Potato Chip Skirt pattern in Kaufman Corduroy 21 Wale and the Tie Dye Diva Everyday Top pattern in Liberty of London Tana Lawn * Seam gauge or ruler * Iron * Thread * Hand sewing needle or domestic sewing machine with a blind hem function. #####Step 1: Press Folded Hem Prepare garment to the point of sewing the hem. This is just a sample piece of fabric here, but youâ€™ll work on your actual garment. Fold and press the hem as directed in your pattern. I have used a hem folded up 1/2â€³ then another 1â€³. This is the narrowest hem that works well with a blind hem.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_1.jpg)

#####Step 2: Prepare Hem for Stitching Baste hem 3/8â€³ from the upper edge (this measurement may vary depending on your blind hem foot so check your instructions, but somewhere between 3/16â€³ and 3/8â€³ is good). Itâ€™s OK to use contrasting thread here, youâ€™ll be removing it.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_2_1.jpg)

Fold Hem to the right side along basting stitches. Do not iron.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_2_2.jpg)

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_2_3.jpg)

#####Step 3: Sewing the Blind Hem Thread your machine with thread that closely matches your fabric (weâ€™re still using contrasting thread for easier visibility for you) and select the blind hem stitch. Refer to your sewing machine manual for help selecting the stitch and proper sewing foot. When sewing a machine blind hem, most stitches will be sewn into the folded area of the hem while the zig-zag stitch will just barely bite into the hem folded along the basting line.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_3_1.jpg)

Hereâ€™s what it looks like sewing on my machine. Your Blind hem foot may look different.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_3_2.jpg)

Flip the hem back down and press well. Remove your basting stitches.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_3_3.jpg)

From the inside of the garment.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_3_4.jpg)

Beautifully invisible from the outside.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/skirt_3_5.jpg)

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/TieDyeDiva-17.jpg)

Now letâ€™s move on to sewing a blind hem by hand. A hand-stitched blind hem is especially helpful on very delicate fabrics. Itâ€™s perfect for this light weight Liberty lawn. #####Step 1: Press Folded Hem This step is exactly the same as a machine-stitched blind hem. Prepare garment to the point of sewing the hem (Weâ€™re again using a fabric scrap and contrasting thread for easier visibility â€“ you will sew on your finished garment with matching thread.) Fold and iron the hem as directed in your pattern. I have used a hem folded up 1/2â€³ then another 1â€³. This is the narrowest hem that works well with a blind hem. Pin the hem in place.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%201_1.jpg)

#####Step 2: Sewing the Blind Hem Thread your hand sewing needle with a length of all-purpose thread about 18â€³-24â€³ in a color closely matching your fabric. Using a single strand of thread, knot one end. Secure the knot inside the top edge fold of your hem.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_1.jpg)

Here I have unfolded the hem to secure my knot. Next take a TINY bite of fabric just above the folded hem, this should just be a couple threads of the fabric. I have taken a slightly larger stitch merely for visibilityâ€™s sake.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_2.jpg)

Now, run the needle into the folded edge of the hem for about 3/8â€³.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_3.jpg)

Repeat these two steps to complete the hem. Here I have loosened the thread so you can see the flow of stitches.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_4.jpg)

In matching thread, this hem is simply stunning and invisible.

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_5.jpg)

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/top%202_6.jpg)

Give it a nice press to set the stitches and youâ€™re done!

![Blind Hem Hero 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blind%20Hem/TieDyeDiva-5.jpg)

posts.title: Kaufman Kona Color Chart Mini Quilt
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com We have an exciting (mini) finish to share with you! We got in this awesome panel last week, the Robert Kaufman Kona Digital Printed Color Chart. This thing makes my color-loving heart go pitter-patter, just look at these selvedges!

![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kona%20Cotton%20Card/in_machine.jpg)

The little squares of Kona color look almost pixelated, and the panel even features the 2016 Kona color of the year, Highlighter, in the bottom right corner.

![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kona%20Cotton%20Card/sku.jpg)

I wanted to make something with it, rather than frame it or just keep it in the stash, but I wanted to keep it simple. I thought it would be best to showcase as much of the panel as I could, so a simple wall hanging/mini quilt is what I landed on. Something you could hang on the wall of your sewing room for inspiration or reference. It will especially come in handy when deciding sashing colors! #####Materials: * 1 Kona Cotton Color Chart panel * 1.5 yards Kona Cotton in Jet Black * .5 yard Kona Cotton in Kale * 26"x48" piece of cotton batting The construction is quite easy; I just cut a backing out of Kona Jet Black the same size as the panel, even the selvedges, and four 2.5â€ strips from my binding fabric (Kona Kale). I didnâ€™t bother with cutting them on the bias since the quilt wonâ€™t get any use.

![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kona%20Cotton%20Card/closeup.jpg)

I made a quilt sandwich with the panel, a scrap of batting, and the jet black Kona, and basted with pins and got to quilting. I like using grey quilting thread when I want a neutral, because white can be hard to match and darker colors give too stark of a contrast. I had some Aurifil Silver on hand and it worked perfectly. I popped my walking foot on the shank of my machine, adjusted my stitch length to 3.5, and quilted in the horizontal rows Â¼â€ from the edge of the little Kona squares. When that was done, I trimmed and squared up the edges and did a machine binding. I trimmed the selvedge edges to about 3/8â€ from where I wanted the binding to stop before sewing it on. Itâ€™s so bright and cheerful!

A Â¼â€ seam allowance has been included around the pieces- make sure to cut on the dashed lines and not the solid lines! ######Step Two Grab your markers or colored pencils. To keep track of what fabric goes where, itâ€™s helpful to color the template of the whole house (and itâ€™s fun to color). ######Step Three Start sewing! Fabric can be cut as you go, or you can pre-cut some pieces. I found that I generally cut 1 Â½â€, 2 Â½â€, and 3â€ strips. The windows also lend themselves great to fussy cutting, add a few skulls, spider webs, or spooky cats. ![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Haunted%20House%20Quilt/Img_3.jpg)

######Step Four With everything sewn and trimmed, itâ€™s time to assemble the house and hill. Example: Sew B1 to B2 to B3 to B4 to B5, sew B6 to the bottom of that section, then sew B7 to the side, and finally sew B8 to the bottom * A1 + A2 * (((B1 + B2 + B3 + B4 + B5) + B6) + B7) + B8 * C1 + C2 * D1 + D2 * (((E3 + E4 + E5 + E6 + E7) + E2 + E8) + E9) + E1 * ((G1 + G2) + G3 + G4 + G5) + G6 * (((i1 + i2) + i3 + i4) + i5 + i6) + i7 + i8 * ((J3 + J4 + J5 + J6 + J7 + J8) + J1 + J2) +J9 * Hill1 + Hill2 + Hill3 + Hill4 + Hill5 Once all the individual sections are sewn together, the house can be put together in the following order- press seams open or to the side with the least resistance. Example: Sections A, B, and C have been assembled, sew section B to C, then attach A to the top * A * B + C * D * (F + G) + E * (H + i) + J * K + L

![Completed Sewing Room Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Haunted%20House%20Quilt/Img_CloseUp_1.jpg)

######Step Five Add the background and ground fabric. Press seams to the side. Sew a 21 Â½ x 16 Â½â€ rectangle of background fabric to the top of the hill. Between the house and hill sew a 30 Â½ x 3â€ strip of background fabric, connecting the house to the hill. Sew a 36 x 3â€ strip of ground fabric to the bottom. ######Step Six Time for the applique! Raw-edge applique works well for this project, with either a blanket stitch edge or free-motion quilting to sew the edges down. Follow the fusible webbing directions for attaching to fabric. Cut out the fence (a precision knife is helpful for this one), clouds, moon, and grave markers. Place and iron onto the quilt top. Then either embroider or sew around the edges. ######Step Seven Make your quilt sandwich and quilt with your desired pattern. I was recently introduced to continuous bias binding and itâ€™s a huge time (and fabric) saver, I highly recommend it. Using the continuous bias binding method, cut a 22â€ square piece of fabric, to make 2 Â½â€ binding strips. Now all you need to do is find the perfect spot to display your Witchâ€™s House!

This is a great project for quilting beginners, and the block youâ€™re using is very versatile and can easily be adapted to other patterns. #####Materials: * Â¾ Yard Black Fabric (for cat and back of pillow- we used this one) * Â¾ Yard Orange Fabric (for background- we used this one) * 20â€ square of batting * 18" pillow form * Marking pen or tailorâ€™s chalk * Quilting Thread (we used this one) *seam allowance is 1/4â€ unless otherwise specified Cut your pieces out as follows: #####Cut Your Fabric: ######Black: * (1) 6.5â€x6.5â€ * (2) 3.5â€x3.5â€ * (2) 15â€x19â€ ######Orange: * (1) 6.5â€x3.5â€ * (2) 9.5â€x7â€ * (2) 5â€x19.5â€ We will begin with the flying geese block. The orange fabric will be our background (goose) and the black fabric will be our cat ears (sky). The point usually faces north, but weâ€™ll be flipping it for our catâ€™s ears, so keep that in mind if your fabric is directional.
