posts.title: Metallic Ombre Pineapple Mini Quilt
posts.markdown:
Created by: My Wandering Path This mini pieced wall hanging has it all: a fresh, modern take on a totally on-trend design; lots of texture, thanks to the half-square triangle (HST) block construction; and just enough of the metallic fabric to make it really pop. I created my own pattern for this project, using 2.5â€ squares to make half-square triangles. ####Materials: * 1 FQ each of Robert Kaufman Essex Metallic Linen (we used camel, sand and oyster) * 1 FQ each of Kaufman Essex Yard Dyed Linen (we used black) * 1 FQ of a backing fabric of your choice (We used Timeless Treasures Plume) * Batting

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/Essex%20Metallic%20Linen-2_resized.jpg)

####Project Prep #####Step One Cut the metallic linens and black linen into 2.5â€xWOF strips, and subcut each strip into (10) 2.5â€ squares. You wonâ€™t need that many, but itâ€™s always nice to have an extra or two!

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics_1_resized.jpg)

#####Step Two Cut the remaining Oyster metallic linen into 2.5â€ strips on the bias to use as your binding. (If youâ€™ve never made bias or quilt binding before, here's a great tutorial for cutting the bias strips. You wonâ€™t need a bias tape maker though; after your strips are cut and stitched together, just fold the strips in half lengthwise, aligning the raw edges together, and press with a hot steam iron.) #####Step Three: Pair your 2.5â€ squares into the following 2-square units: * 1 unit â€“ Camel + Black (1 Camel square + 1 Black square) * 3 units â€“ Camel + Camel ([1 Camel square + 1 Camel square] x 3) * 2 units â€“ Camel + Sand ([1 Camel square + 1 Sand square] x 2) * 2 units â€“ Sand + Sand ([1 Sand square + 1 Sand square] x 2) * 1 unit â€“ Sand + Black (1 Sand square + 1 Black square) * 1 unit â€“ Sand + Oyster (1 Sand square + 1 Oyster square) * 3 units â€“ Sand + Black ([1 Sand square + 1 Black square] x 3) * 2 units â€“ Oyster + Oyster ([1 Oyster square + 1 Oyster square] x 2) * 1 unit â€“ Black + Black (1 Black square + 1 Black square)

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-3_resized.jpg)

####Making the HST Blocks #####Step Four Glue baste your 2-square units together, drawing a thin line of glue from one corner of a square to the opposite corner. Heat set the glue using a hot, dry iron.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-11_resized.jpg)

#####Step Five Stitch the squares together by sewing a scant Â¼â€ seam on each side of the glue line.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-13_resized.jpg)

#####Step Six Cut your squares in half along the glue line

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-16_resized.jpg)

#####Step Seven Press the seams of your HST blocks to one side; trim squares to 2â€.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-17_resized.jpg)

####Piecing the Pineapple Block I prefer to piece in blocks, rather than strips. I also prefer to glue baste, nest, and â€œspinâ€ my seams, all of which I learned from tutorials by Cristy Fincher from Purple Daisies Quilting. (For Cristyâ€™s excellent tutorial on nesting and spinning seams, click here) Nesting and spinning seams when piecing blocks has helped me create more accurate seams and perfect points; it also creates flatter blocks, which in turn are easier to quilt. #####Step Eight Lay out your HST blocks in the following pattern to create your pineapple:

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-20_resized.jpg)

#####Step Nine Begin piecing your blocks, using your preferred method. Since I like to piece in blocks when I can, rather than strips, I create 2-block units first. Apply a thin line of glue along one edge of a block, place the â€œpartnerâ€ block on top (right sides together and raw edges aligned), and heat set the glue with a hot, dry iron. Stitch the two blocks together using a scant Â¼â€ seam. I leave about a Â¼â€ space at the start and end of my seamâ€”I donâ€™t sew completely end to end. This will allow me to spin my seams as I piece more blocks together.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-24_resized.jpg)

#####Step Ten After stitching each set of 2-block units, press the seams to one side. I alternate the pressing direction by row, beginning by pressing the seams of the bottom row blocks to the right. The row above that gets pressed to the left, then the next row to the right, and so on. Because the seams are pressed to alternating sides, as we build our units from two blocks to four blocks, our seams will nest and spin. Hereâ€™s a picture of the wrong sides of my 2-block units, so you can see how Iâ€™ve pressed the seams in alternate directions.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-25_resized.jpg)

#####Step Eleven Youâ€™ll begin to nest your seams when you start piecing two sets of 2-block units together to create a 4-block unit. You can see in this picture how the pressed edges of the center seams for these two 2-block units meet in the middle. This is nesting your seams.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-26_resized.jpg)

#####Step Twelve Follow the same procedures to piece two 2-block units into 4-block units: glue baste, heat set, and stitch using a scant Â¼â€ seam.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-28_resized.jpg)

#####Step Thirteen After youâ€™ve stitched all your 2-block units together, itâ€™s time to press the seams open. This time, youâ€™ll spin your seams. Make sure the four seams are pressed so that they rotate around the centerâ€”think of them going either clockwise or counterclockwise. (My seams always end up spinning counterclockwiseâ€”I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s typical or because Iâ€™m left-handed!) To do that, youâ€™ll have to press your most recent seam in opposite directions from the center. That little Â¼â€ you left unstitched at the start and finish of each seam will allow the center to open up and flatten out, and youâ€™ll get a lovely little 4-square â€œblockâ€ in the very center of your spinning seams.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-29_resized.jpg)

#####Step Fourteen You may want to starch your blocks as you press them open. #####Step Fifteen Continue piecing your blocks together until your pineapple is complete. #####Step Sixteen Add the sashing, beginning with the left and right side sashings. #####Step Seventeen Create a sandwich using your fabric backing on the bottom (wrong side up), batting in the middle, and pieced pineapple on top (right side up). I spray baste each layer, rather than using pins, to keep the layers from shifting. #####Step Eighteen Quilt the layers together using your favorite method. I machine quilted my pineapple using straight-line quilting. I donâ€™t have a walking foot for my vintage sewing machine and it still looks great, so even if you arenâ€™t a regular quilter with all the regular tools, you can still quilt a project this size! #####Step Nineteen Trim the edges of your quilted block so that they are neat and straight. Pin your stitched and pressed quilt binding onto the front of your quilted piece, raw edges aligned. Machine stitch the binding using a scant Â¼â€ seam.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-38_resized.jpg)

#####Step Twenty Hand stitch the binding to the back of your quilted piece. Here you can see that I added a couple of fabric triangles to the back in the top left and right corners; Iâ€™ll use these to hang my pineapple on the wall. I used a couple of those extra fabric squares and some fabric glue to put them on, and hand stitching the binding will strengthen them.

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/My%20Wandering%20Path_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Tutorial%20Pics-33_resized.jpg)

Thatâ€™s it! Youâ€™re all done with your modern metallic ombre pineapple. The pineapple is a symbol of hospitality, especially for us Southerners, and I canâ€™t wait to hang this one in my foyer! I hope youâ€™re inspired to make one for yourself!

![Pineapple Mini Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Mini%20Quilt/MWP_Metallic%20Ombre%20Pineapple_Hero%20Pics%20Rd%202_8_resized.jpg)

Create a sandwich using your fabric backing on the bottom (wrong side up), batting in the middle, and pieced pineapple on top (right side up). I spray baste each layer, rather than using pins, to keep the layers from shifting.

posts.title: No Sew Plaid Blanket Scarf Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com If youâ€™re in a part of the world where Fall is behaving like itâ€™s supposed to, the leaves are falling, the air is crisp, and youâ€™re surrounded by pumpkin spice everything. Even though itâ€™s 86 degrees in Georgia this week, we still love fall, and canâ€™t get enough of it. And for me, that means flannel plaid for days. So pick your favorite yard dyed plaid flannel and jump right into this no sew project! ####Materials: * 1.5 yards of 44" wide yard dyed flannel plaid (we used this hunter navy print) * Scissors * Seam Ripper Weâ€™re making a square blanket scarf, so weâ€™re getting 1 Â½ yards to make a square. If youâ€™d rather a rectangle, get as much or as little as you like. If youâ€™re using 60â€ wide fabric, make sure to get 2 yards for a larger square. The quality of the flannel will impact how long you can make your fringe and how easy it is to make your fringe. If you want a long fringe, I recommend Kaufman Mammoth Flannel, which is thicker and of a nice quality. For all projects that are going to be washed sometime in the future (which I hope you plan on doing), pre-wash your fabrics to shrink it before you start working on them. ####Step One: Trim up Two Sides Pick two sides that come together at a corner. They will be a selvedge edge and a cut edge. The selvedge edge will have a lot less stray threads that have unraveled.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1783.JPG)

On the cut edges, pick a line of plaid that continues down the length and trim along it as neatly as possible.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1787.JPG)

Now, trim the selvedge edge in the same fashion. Pick a line of plaid that extends past the dense selvedge. If you leave the selvedge on, those edges wonâ€™t fringe properly.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1789.JPG)

####Step Two: Square up Your Fabric Square up your fabric by folding the two edges you just trims into a right triangle at the corner, with the edges as even as possible, all the way to the other, untrimmed edges.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1790.JPG)

The excess will extend either on the top or bottom of your piece.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1793.JPG)

Cut the excess off, following a line of the plaid. It doesnâ€™t have to be exactly square, but pick the line of plaid closest to the matching edge. Trim the other edge also, picking a plaid line as close to the other as possible, so that theyâ€™re mostly even.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1795.JPG)

####Step Three: Make the Fringe This step will be the longest step, but itâ€™s super easy. Sit down in front of the tv with your seam ripper and start fringing! Start at one edge. With your seam ripper, pick one thread and follow it all the way down to the other side and remove it. Try not to cut it. If it breaks, find the break and continue on.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1807.JPG)

You can also do it a couple of threads at a time but this can get messy. You might want to try it when you become more confident with it.

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/IMG_1804.JPG)

Keep pulling out threads until you have the size of fringe you want, and repeat with the other three sides. I stopped at about Â½â€. You can make it as long or short as you want. ####Four: Wearing your Blanket Scarf Your scarf is ready to wear! Here's how we love to wear ours:

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/step_1_looking_down.jpg)

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/step_2_looking_down.jpg)

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/step_3.jpg)

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/step_4.jpg)

![Blanket Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blanket%20Scarf/hero.jpg)

posts.title: Log Cabin Blanket Sew-Along Week 1: Choosing Fabrics
posts.markdown:
Happy Friday and welcome to Week 1 of the fabric.com Log Cabin Sew-Along! In case you missed the announcement last week, hereâ€™s a quick recap: Over the next several weeks, weâ€™ll be hosting a quilt-as-you-go log cabin blanket sew-along here on the Fabric.com blog. Today weâ€™re kicking off the sew-along with a discussion on choosing fabrics and yardage requirements. Then weâ€™ll review the quilt-as-you-go method and start our blankets. Letâ€™s start by going over what youâ€™ll need for the sew-along! #####Quilt-as-You-Go Log Cabin Sew-Along Fabric Requirements This quilt-as-you-go log cabin quilt is a lap-sized quilt that finishes at approximately 55â€x55â€. My version features nine different fabrics for the body of the quilt (three solids and six plaids), plus a contrasting sashing and binding.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/table.png)

*Please note that for my quilt, I am not overly concerned about pattern matching for my plaid logs. My strips are a little wonky, and Iâ€™m OK with thatâ€¦but if you like your plaids to match perfectly and your lines to be super straight, more power to youâ€”and maybe get a little extra fabric! **Using wider width fabric allows us to cut not only the strips for the log cabin piecing, but also three 15â€ squares for block backings from each plaid fabric. If you choose a plaid that is less than 58â€ wide, please make sure to order extra fabric. Or, if you decide to use a different fabric entirely for the back of your blocks, youâ€™ll need enough fabric to cut 16- 15â€ squares. #####Choosing Your Fabrics I had a hard time narrowing down my fabric choices for this project! There are just so many fun plaids available right now. I really wanted to incorporate a variety of plaids in my quilt, but I also wanted to figure out how to keep it from being visually overwhelming. So I decided to create my log cabin blocks using a mix of solids and plaids, arranged like this:

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/block.png)

Did you know that Fabric.com has a design wall feature? Itâ€™s a great way to visualize how your fabric choices will look together before you commit to buying them! I definitely made good use of the design wall when I was trying to decide on my final fabrics.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_design%20wall%20screenshot.png)

I chose three solid colorsâ€”green, blue, and redâ€”and a coordinating light/medium plaid and dark plaid for each of the solids. Each log cabin block will feature a solid and one of the plaids on the front, while the other coordinating plaid will be used for the backing fabric for that block. (In other words, if I use a light-value green plaid for the â€œlogsâ€ of the block, the dark-value green plaid will be the backing fabric for the block, and vice versa.) Mixing solids and plaids for the log cabins helps tame the riot of plaid on the front of the block, especially with all of that directional piecing. But having a large square of plaid for the back of the block is not as overwhelming and also helps to disguise the quilting lines!

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_1.jpg)

For my green colorway, I chose this amazing Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel Herringbone in Basil, Yarn Dyed Navy/Green/Oat Plaid for my medium-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Green Plaid for the dark-value plaid.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_2.jpg)

Isnâ€™t this herringbone flannel gorgeous? I think itâ€™s my favorite! Itâ€™s so soft and the herringbone pattern is the perfect touch.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_3.jpg)

For the blue colorway, I chose Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel in Navy (no herringbone pattern on this one), Yarn Dyed Blue Navy and White plaid for my light-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Navy/Green/Red plaid for my dark-value plaid.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_4.jpg)

And for the red colorway, I opted for this Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel in Maroon, Yarn Dyed Red/White/Black plaid for my light-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Red Plaid for my dark-value plaid. I hemmed and hawed over what to use for the contrasting sashing and binding, until I had a stroke of inspiration and decided to go with this swoon-worthy Robert Kaufman Dotted Chambray.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_5.jpg)

It complementsâ€”not competes withâ€”the plaids, and the lighter texture will be better to work with on the binding than those flannels.

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_6.jpg)

The batting I will be using is Quilter's Dream wool batting, which is available in a variety of sizes (in case you want to have a little extra left over!). This is my first time using wool batting, so Iâ€™m excited to see how it turns out! #####Single Nap vs. Double Nap Single nap or double nap: it sounds like the kind of decision Iâ€™d love to make in the middle of the day, but it actually refers to how flannel fabric is finished. The woven fabric is napped, or brushed, on either one or both sides. Thatâ€™s what gives flannel fabric that softness we love! Itâ€™s OK if you choose single-napped flannels for this project (several of the fabrics I chose are single napped), as long as you pay close attention when piecing your blocks and make sure the soft and cozy napped side is facing out! #####Looking for More Fabric Inspiration? Fabric.com has a ton of plaid flannels to choose from. Click here to see just a few of the styles available right now! I wanted to leave you with a little sneak peek of how the finished blocks will look. My cat decided he wanted his 5 minutes of blog fame too!

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_7.jpg)

![Sew Along Pt 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%202/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%201_post%20pic_8.jpg)

Next week, weâ€™ll cut our fabric and learn about the quilt-as-you-go method. I hope youâ€™ll join us! Donâ€™t forget to share your fabric choices on Instagram (#fabriclogcabinsewalong) and Facebook. (Did you use the Fabric.com design wall? Take a screenshot to post!) See you next week! #####The fabric.com Fall Sew-Along Schedule * Introduction (October 14): Join us for a fall sew-along * Week 1 (October 21): Choosing fabrics and yardage requirements * Week 2 (October 28): Cutting your fabric and quilt-as-you-go method overview * Week 3 (November 4): Sewing check-inâ€”show us your progress! * Week 4 (November 11): Joining your blocks and binding your quilt Be sure to post your inspiration, fabric pulls, and progress on Instagram using the hashtag #fabriclogcabinsewalong.

posts.title: DIY Denali Flannel & Leather Vest
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com With the weather cooling down, all I want to make is outerwear with amazing design details. Thatâ€™s where the Seamwork Denali vest comes in. This pattern is about a year old, from one of their menswear issues, and features all the details I wanted for a standout piece. Denali features an optional contrasting yoke that I knew would make this vest something special. It closes with snaps, and can be made out of quilted fabric for extra body. I decided to give this vest as an early holiday gift to my dad (who agreed to model it for this blog post).

![Vest](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vest/IMG_1817_edit.jpg)

Iâ€™ve seen Denali made with anything from the standard flannel, to ripstop nylon for extra durability. Colette recommends wovens or sturdy knits. It would be perfect in a twill or canvas as well, with contrast faux leather or coating yoke. I used Kaufman Shetland Flannel for the outside and lining, and Telio Perfection Fused Faux Leather in brown for the contrasting front yoke. The Flannel was really soft and amazing to work with â€“ I think I like it just as much as Kaufman's Mammoth Plaid, which would work very well for this too.

![Vest](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vest/Capture%20One%20Catalog32934.jpg)

The Perfection Leather is aptly named! It's really soft and versatile- I can't wait to use it again. These Western snaps gave the vest just the rugged touch I was looking for â€“ and they were a lot easier to put in with these heavy duty snap pliers.

![Vest](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vest/Capture%20One%20Catalog32930.jpg)

There were a few small changes I made in what fabrics were used for the different pieces. Instead of using the contrast fabric for the inside of the pockets, I used the main fabric for that as well. I didnâ€™t like the look of having the lining peek through on the edge, since the method used is sewing them right sides together and turning before topstitching onto the vest front. I also didnâ€™t quilt my fabrics at all, and from what I can tell that didnâ€™t make a difference in the end product. I topstitched everything, but the only stitches you can see are on the leather yoke. The rest of the topstitching faded into the background of the flannel.

![Vest](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vest/Capture%20One%20Catalog32929.jpg)

As some more experienced sewists will know, sewing with leather or faux leather can be tricky. Some of your machines will come with a non-stick or rolling foot. I recommend purchasing one for your sewing arsenal if you havenâ€™t already. You can get generic ones on Amazon.com, or go directly through your sewing machine dealer for one especially for your machine. Canâ€™t wait? If you have a walking foot, that will also make things easier. If youâ€™re still having trouble, try sewing with a layer of tissue paper in between the leather and your sewing machine foot. That can help things glide along..

![Vest](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vest/IMG_1818.JPG)

Happy fall and happy sewing!

I decided to give this vest as an early holiday gift to my dad (who agreed to model it for this blog post).

Iâ€™ve seen Denali made with anything from the standard flannel, to ripstop nylon for extra durability. Colette recommends wovens or sturdy knits. It would be perfect in a twill or canvas as well, with contrast faux leather or coating yoke.

I used Kaufman Shetland Flannel for the outside and lining, and Telio Perfection Fused Faux Leather in brown for the contrasting front yoke. The Flannel was really soft and amazing to work with â€“ I think I like it just as much as Kaufman's Mammoth Plaid, which would work very well for this too.

The Perfection Leather is aptly named! It's really soft and versatile- I can't wait to use it again. These Western snaps gave the vest just the rugged touch I was looking for â€“ and they were a lot easier to put in with these heavy duty snap pliers.

There were a few small changes I made in what fabrics were used for the different pieces. Instead of using the contrast fabric for the inside of the pockets, I used the main fabric for that as well. I didnâ€™t like the look of having the lining peek through on the edge, since the method used is sewing them right sides together and turning before topstitching onto the vest front.

I also didnâ€™t quilt my fabrics at all, and from what I can tell that didnâ€™t make a difference in the end product. I topstitched everything, but the only stitches you can see are on the leather yoke. The rest of the topstitching faded into the background of the flannel.

As some more experienced sewists will know, sewing with leather or faux leather can be tricky. Some of your machines will come with a non-stick or rolling foot. I recommend purchasing one for your sewing arsenal if you havenâ€™t already. You can get generic ones on Amazon.com, or go directly through your sewing machine dealer for one especially for your machine.

Canâ€™t wait? If you have a walking foot, that will also make things easier. If youâ€™re still having trouble, try sewing with a layer of tissue paper in between the leather and your sewing machine foot. That can help things glide along..

Happy fall and happy sewing!

Knowing what seam allowances are and how execute an accurate seam allowance is arguably the most important part of sewing (aside from selecting the perfect fabric). Without an accurate seam allowance, your project can end up too large, too small, or tooâ€¦ disastrous. Whether you primarily quilt, sew garments, or home dÃ©cor â€“ they all use seam allowances. The 3/8â€ seam is usually the first line, the 5/8â€ the second. Your machine may be different. A Â¼â€ seam is primarily used in piecing quilts. 5/8â€ is the standard seam allowance for sewing apparel. And youâ€™ll see a 3/8â€ seam allowance in various sewing circles, including garments and other sewing projects. Always check your pattern or tutorial for seam allowances before starting! You can get yourself into some seriously hot water if you donâ€™t, or at least some quality time with your seam ripper. #####1/4": For an accurate Â¼â€ seam, you will need a good Â¼â€ piecing foot. The 3/8â€ marking on my machine is the first one. Keep your fabric on that line for an accurate seam, and donâ€™t stray!

Happy Sewing!

posts.markdown:
Created by: My Wandering Path Blog Happy Friday and welcome to Week 2 of the fabric.com Log Cabin Sew-Along! In case you missed the announcement a couple of weeks ago, hereâ€™s a quick recap: Over the next several weeks, weâ€™ll be hosting a quilt-as-you-go log cabin blanket sew-along here on the Fabric.com blog. Today weâ€™ll be cutting into our yummy flannel fabrics and starting to sew! Here's a quick recap of my fabric choices: For my green colorway, I chose this amazing Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel Herringbone in Basil, Yarn Dyed Navy/Green/Oat Plaid for my medium-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Green Plaid for the dark-value plaid. For the red colorway, I opted for this Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel in Maroon, Yarn Dyed Red/White/Black plaid for my light-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Red Plaid for my dark-value plaid. For the blue colorway, I chose Robert Kaufman Shetland Flannel in Navy (no herringbone pattern on this one), Yarn Dyed Blue Navy and White plaid for my light-value plaid, and Yarn Dyed Navy/Green/Red plaid for my dark-value plaid. Finally, for the sashing and binding I chose this Robert Kaufman Dotted Chambray and for batting I used Quilter's Dream wool batting. #####Quilt-as-You-Go Log Cabin Sew-Along Cutting Instructions Donâ€™t be alarmed when you look at the chart below! I promise, this will be one of the easiest cutting sessions youâ€™ll ever have. Before you dive into the specifics, here are a couple of tips: 1) If youâ€™re using the same fabrics I am, youâ€™ll only use the solid flannels for log cabin strips. You can go ahead and start by cutting your fabric into 2Â½â€ x width of fabric (WOF) strips and subcutting those strips according to the chart below. 2) Weâ€™ll use the plaid flannels for our block backing fabric as well as for log cabin strips. Start by cutting the three 15â€x15â€ pieces for the block backings, then cut the rest of the fabric into 2Â½â€xWOF strips before subcutting those strips according to the chart below. (That way, youâ€™ll be sure to have enough for your backing pieces!) 3) For the sashing and binding, I found it easier to cut the binding strips (on the bias) first, and then cut the sashing strips (not on the bias). Itâ€™s easy to cut the fabric for this sew-along because all of our log cabin strips will be cut at 2Â½â€ wide. By starting with those 2Â½â€xWOF strips, itâ€™s quick to subcut them into the various lengths for the log cabin pieces. (And itâ€™s easy to remember the length of the log cabin strips because they increase in 2â€ increments from 2Â½â€ to 14Â½â€.)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_1.jpg)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/table.png)

#####Letâ€™s Start Quilting! (First, let me say that obviously I am not the inventor of the quilt-as-you-go log cabin block! There are lots of great tutorials for the quilt-as-you-go method. This quick overview is adapted from Rachel at Stitched in Color and you can find her original tutorial here.) Finally! We have all your fabric strips and backing blocks and batting blocks cut. Now we can get to the good part! Hereâ€™s how the construction and quilting of our flannel log cabin blocks will work: Weâ€™ll start by quilting our center block, and then one by one, stitch and quilt each log, spiraling out from the center. So if we look again at the diagram from last week, Iâ€™ve numbered the logs in the order that they are added to the block:

![Sew Along Pt 3](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/block.png)

#####The Quilt-as-You-Go Log Cabin Block Decide on the backing fabric for your block. Take a 15â€ x 15â€ square of that fabric, place it wrong side up (the â€œsmoothâ€ side, if youâ€™re using single-napped flannel), spray with a little basting spray, and place a batting square on top of it. Press firmly so that your backing fabric isnâ€™t wrinkled and the batting is well adhered to the fabric. Decide if you want the last, longest (14Â½â€) log of your block to be a solid or plaid. Whichever fabric you decide, you will use for your first (center) block. (I plan to mix it up in my quilt!)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_2.jpg)

Take a 2Â½â€ x 2Â½â€ square in the fabric you just chose (Fabric 1 for the rest of the instructions), place it right side up (the â€œsoftâ€ napped side, if youâ€™re using single-nap flannel) in the center of your batting square, and quilt away! I like to quilt my center block in a spiral pattern. (I find that the flannel sticks nicely to the batting so that I donâ€™t have to pin the logs down before stitching, but thatâ€™s up to you! I do try to keep the fabric smooth and steady.)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_3.jpg)

Take a 2Â½â€ x 2Â½â€ square in the OTHER fabric youâ€™re using for this block (Fabric 2) and place it on top of the square you just quilted, right (napped) sides together (RST). Stitch the new log to the center block with a Â¼â€ seam along the right edge.

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_4.jpg)

Open up the newly attached log and finger press or carefully press with an iron on low heat. (Be careful not to burn the batting!

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_5.jpg)

Quilt the newly attached log. (I think straight-line quilting approximately Â¼â€ apart and running the length of each log is probably the best and easiest choice!)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_6.jpg)

Turn your block a quarter-turn counterclockwise. Take a 4Â½â€ strip of Fabric 2 and place it on top of your first two logs, RST and having raw edges even. Stitch the new log to the first two logs with a Â¼â€ seam along the right edge. Open up the newly attached log and finger press or carefully press with an iron on low heat.

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_7.jpg)

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_8.jpg)

Quilt away! Turn your block a quarter-turn counterclockwise and repeat the stitch-press open-quilt process with a 4Â½â€ strip of Fabric 1. And thatâ€™s it! Just keep turning your block a quarter-turn counterclockwise before adding the next log. You will finish with just one 14Â½â€ strip. #####Trimming Your Finished Blocks After youâ€™ve quilted down your last (14Â½â€) strip, itâ€™s time to square up and trim your block! The final size of your trimmed block will vary with your stitching accuracy. I love the quilt-as-you-go method because itâ€™s very forgiving. If my seams arenâ€™t a perfect Â¼â€, itâ€™s not going to throw my entire project off. If my quilting or my strips get a little wonky, itâ€™s OK. That also means that my finished blocks are a little smaller than yours might be. The original tutorial I learned from results in 14Â½â€ x 14Â½â€ (trimmed) blocks, but mine ended up being 14â€ square after trimming. So measure your finished, untrimmed block and see what size you can trim down to. It will be between 14â€- 14Â½â€.

![Sew Along Pt 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%203/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%202_post%20pic_10.jpg)

See you next week! #####The fabric.com Sew-Along Schedule * Introduction (October 14): Join us for a fall sew-along * Week 1 (October 21): Choosing fabrics and yardage requirements * Week 2 (October 28): Cutting your fabric and quilt-as-you-go method overview * Week 3 (November 4): Sewing check-inâ€”show us your progress! * Week 4 (November 11): Joining your blocks and binding your quilt Be sure to post your inspiration, fabric pulls, and progress on Instagram using the hashtag #fabriclogcabinsewalong. I love the quilt-as-you-go method because itâ€™s very forgiving. If my seams arenâ€™t a perfect Â¼â€, itâ€™s not going to throw my entire project off. If my quilting or my strips get a little wonky, itâ€™s OK.

posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com This versatile lap blanket is perfect for keeping you warm on chilly fall or winter nights. Itâ€™s so easy even beginners can complete this easy blanket in no time!

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_7046_edited.jpg)

####You'll Need: * 1.5 yards Organic Sherpa Fleece * 1.5 yards 44â€ Flannel fabric for the front (we used this Mammoth Flannel in Scarlet from Robert Kaufman) * Thread (we used this one) This blanket would also be a great holiday gift for someone special! My beagle, Harper, has really been enjoying it...

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_9900.JPG)

Let's get started! First and foremost, pre-wash both of your fabrics.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1863.JPG)

Lay your flannel out so that you can see it all, and straighten out the cut edges by finding a line of plaid and cutting along that from selvedge to selvedge on each side. Trim your selvedge edges in this same way.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1879.JPG)

Now, lay your Sherpa down (fuzzy side up), and lay your cut flannel piece on top of it. If the flannel is too large, you will have to cut it down some more. If not, you will have to trim your Sherpa to fit. With the Sherpa on the bottom and the flannel on the top, trim around to match the Sherpa to the flannel.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1870.JPG)

Make sure the sherpaâ€™s selvedges (they resemble terry cloth) were cut off in this process. They should have been, but if they werenâ€™t, trim to match. You should have two matching pieces of fabric.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1880.JPG)

Make sure right sides are together (this flannel doesnâ€™t have a wrong side, but the Sherpa does), and pin copiously. Pin around the edges every few inches and in the middle every few inches as well. We donâ€™t want our fabrics to shift, and the Sherpa can be a little stretchy.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1874.JPG)

Once all your edges and middle are pinned, you can bring your blanket-in-progress over to your sewing machine. Starting around the middle of one edge at a 5/8â€ seam allowance, sew around each edge. When you get to a corner, stop about 5/8â€ from the edge, lower your needle, and pivot your blanket so that the next edge is now facing you. Continue sewing around the edge until you are about 5-10 inches from where you started. Backstitch (reverse your stitching for a few stitches) to secure your end. This is so you will have a place to turn your blanket right side out.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1881.JPG)

Trim all four corners so that your corners will be sharp when turned out. See how youâ€™re almost to your corner when cutting?

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1883.JPG)

Turn your blanket right-side-out, making your corners as sharp as possible. Flatten your blanket so that the edges are even and smooth. In the same way as we sewed the two pieces together, we are going to sew around the edges of the blanket to give it a nice finish. This time, turn your stitch length to 3.5 because weâ€™re topstitching.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_1884.JPG)

With a 5/8â€ seam allowance, stitch around all the sides. Start at the beginning of the opening and remove the pins as you go. Pivot at the corners as you did before. When you get back to where you started, backstitch, and youâ€™re done! Trim any excess threads, and you have a cozy lap blanket that anyone would treasure.

![Sherpa Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sherpa%20Fleece%20Blanket/IMG_6981_edited.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.title: Easy Bright Side Panel Quilt
posts.markdown:
Created by Nikki Johnson of fabric.com We always need a little reminder to look on the bright side, right? Today weâ€™re going to show you how to make a super easy panel quilt thatâ€™s perfect for adding a spot of color to your favorite room. This would make a perfect holiday gift, too!

![Shibori Frames](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_7051_edited.jpg)

####Materials: * 1 Bright Side Panel (or browse all of our quilt panels and tweak these instructions slightly depending on the size) * 1 package throw sized batting * 1 yard white background fabric for borders * Â¼ yard yellow background fabric for corners * Â½ yard light green fabric for binding * (4) 1 yard cuts of 4 different fabrics for pieced back. I used these four, but any four will do. You can also use 3 yards of a non-directional fabric or 4 yards of a directional fabric for the back if youâ€™d prefer a 1-fabric backing. I wanted to do a back that was a little more interesting, since the front is so simple: Bright Side Doily Light Yellow Bright Side Meadow Yellow Bright Side Meadow Pine Green Bright Side Floral Pistachio Shop the whole Bright Side Collection here. #####You will also need standard quilting supplies: * Fabric Shears * 6.5â€ x 24â€ acrylic ruler * Rotary Cutter * Cutting Mat: The bigger the better. this one is a good size and has nice markings. * Materials for basting: We love this one or this one or even this one . * And of course, youâ€™ll need a high quality thread for quilting and piecing. Aurifil is my favorite, and gives a superb finish every time. The minute I saw this bright and happy collection, I knew that a quilt was in its future. It may be fall, but this optimistic little panel adds a spot of brightness that is evergreen. The finished size of this quilt is approximately 52â€ x 60â€, a nice throw size. Use a Â¼â€ seam allowance throughout.

![Shibori Frames](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/nikkiQuiltFront.jpg)

For the front of the quilt: ####Prepare your fabrics * Cut (4) 8.5â€ x WOF (width of fabric) strips from your border fabric. * Sub-cut two of these into 8.5â€ x 36.5â€ strips. 36.5â€ is the panel measurement, so these will match those sides. * Cut the selvedges off the other two strips

![Shibori Frames](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1957.JPG)

Cut the selvedges off the panel. The panelâ€™s sides and the two strips that the selvedges were removed from should now be the same length.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1952.JPG)

Make sure your panel edges are straight, if they arenâ€™t, straighten them. With the panel folded (selvedge edges together), place your acrylic ruler on the fold as close to the edge as possible, and cut off any excess. It should be a minute amount.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1954.JPG)

Cut your yellow corner fabric into one 8.5â€x WOF strip. Sub-cut into (4) 8.5â€ squares. ####Assemble your quilt top Stitch the two 8.5â€xWOF border strips onto each side of the panel (the WOF sides) with right sides together. Press the seam allowances towards the panel.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1961.JPG)

For each 8.5â€x36.5â€ strip, sew two of your yellow corner pieces onto the short side, right sides together, so they match. Press the seam allowances towards the yellow side.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1959.JPG)

Now sew these assembled strips (right sides together) onto the top and bottom of your panel. With the way we pressed the seams, they should nest when sewing, like so:

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_1964.JPG)

See how the borders on the side are pressed towards the panel, and the top border is pressed towards the yellow square? This means that the seam will almost click into place for a perfect seam at the corners. Now that your quilt top is assembled, press your remaining seams open. Pressing this way, with the borders so they nest, and the rest open, will reduce the bulkiness of the seams and make for easier quilting. ####Assemble your backing I used a pieced backing to this quilt; you can do this many different ways, as long as your back is a bit longer and wider on each side than your top. Cut each of your four fabrics into 30â€ x 34â€ rectangles (or you can just sew them all together without cutting and trim later when youâ€™re basting your quilt). Sew them in pairs, sewing one rectangle to the other, short ends and right sides together. Press these seams in opposite directions so they nest, and then sew the long sides together. Press this seam open.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_7072_edited.jpg)

####Baste your quilt I wonâ€™t go into all the specifics of basting a quilt, there are many methods. My favorite is spray basting, which you can get on Amazon . Itâ€™s a little pricey, but it will last for a few quilts, and itâ€™s so much faster. You can also pin baste with curved basting pins. This is a rather slow method, but itâ€™s a bit more stable and very tried and true. However, you have to stop as you quilt to remove them. Or, tack baste with a special tacking gun. Theyâ€™re like the tacks you find on your clothes when you buy them that attach the price tags. A very handy tool and relatively inexpensive for how long it will last you. The important part when basting is to make sure your batting is larger than your quilt top, and your back is larger than your batting. This will give you some wiggle room when quilting. The quilt â€œsandwichâ€, as itâ€™s called goes quilt top, batting, and then backing. Make sure that the wrong sides of your back and top are facing the batting. You can see here that the batting is larger than the top, and the back is larger than the batting, even though this is after quilting. See how the top has warped a little with the quilting? Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important for the batting to be larger.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_2008.JPG)

####Quilt as desired You can quilt this however you want. I used some random free motion quilting to go around the pretty words and flowers in the center of the panel and then used loopy free motion flowers around the rest of it. You can also hand quilt, or use straight line quilting. Free motion quilting takes some special tools and a LOT of practice to get good at it, but its SUPER fast.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_2007.JPG)

####Square up your corners Using a rotary cutter, mat, and ruler, trim the excess batting and backing. Square up your corners, using the corner of your ruler and a rotary cutter.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_2009.JPG)

####Bind your quilt I decided to use a straight binding instead of a bias binding for this one. Itâ€™s faster and easier, and I havenâ€™t had a problem with using a straight binding in terms of durability. If you prefer a bias binding, then make your bias binding as desired. For a straight binding, cut (6) 2.5â€xWOF strips from your light green binding fabric. Sew these together at the ends, right sides together, so that you have one very long 2.5â€ strip. Bind your quilt in your favorite method.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_2010.JPG)

I machine bound it by sewing it to the back with a Â¼â€ seam allowance, and folding it over to the front to topstitch along the edges.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_2021.JPG)

And you have a completed quilt! Itâ€™s so cheerful, and a nice size for curling up on the couch. Itâ€™s a constant source of optimism, and a reminder to always look on the bright side of life.

![Bright Side Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bright%20Side%20Quilt/IMG_7053_edited.jpg)

For each 8.5â€x36.5â€ strip, sew two of your yellow corner pieces onto the short side, right sides together, so they match. Press the seam allowances towards the yellow side.

Now sew these assembled strips (right sides together) onto the top and bottom of your panel.

With the way we pressed the seams, they should nest when sewing, like so:

See how the borders on the side are pressed towards the panel, and the top border is pressed towards the yellow square? This means that the seam will almost click into place for a perfect seam at the corners.

Now that your quilt top is assembled, press your remaining seams open. Pressing this way, with the borders so they nest, and the rest open, will reduce the bulkiness of the seams and make for easier quilting.

Assemble your backing

I used a pieced backing to this quilt; you can do this many different ways, as long as your back is a bit longer and wider on each side than your top.

Cut each of your four fabrics into 30â€ x 34â€ rectangles (or you can just sew them all together without cutting and trim later when youâ€™re basting your quilt).

Sew them in pairs, sewing one rectangle to the other, short ends and right sides together. Press these seams in opposite directions so they nest, and then sew the long sides together. Press this seam open.

Baste your quilt

I wonâ€™t go into all the specifics of basting a quilt, there are many methods. My favorite is spray basting, which you can get on Amazon . Itâ€™s a little pricey, but it will last for a few quilts, and itâ€™s so much faster.

You can also pin baste with curved basting pins. This is a rather slow method, but itâ€™s a bit more stable and very tried and true. However, you have to stop as you quilt to remove them.

Or, tack baste with a special tacking gun. Theyâ€™re like the tacks you find on your clothes when you buy them that attach the price tags. A very handy tool and relatively inexpensive for how long it will last you.

The important part when basting is to make sure your batting is larger than your quilt top, and your back is larger than your batting. This will give you some wiggle room when quilting. The quilt â€œsandwichâ€, as itâ€™s called goes quilt top, batting, and then backing. Make sure that the wrong sides of your back and top are facing the batting.

You can see here that the batting is larger than the top, and the back is larger than the batting, even though this is after quilting. See how the top has warped a little with the quilting? Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important for the batting to be larger.

Quilt as desired

You can quilt this however you want. I used some random free motion quilting to go around the pretty words and flowers in the center of the panel and then used loopy free motion flowers around the rest of it.

You can also hand quilt, or use straight line quilting. Free motion quilting takes some special tools and a LOT of practice to get good at it, but its SUPER fast.

Square up your corners

Using a rotary cutter, mat, and ruler, trim the excess batting and backing.

Square up your corners, using the corner of your ruler and a rotary cutter.

Bind your quilt

I decided to use a straight binding instead of a bias binding for this one. Itâ€™s faster and easier, and I havenâ€™t had a problem with using a straight binding in terms of durability. If you prefer a bias binding, then make your bias binding as desired.

For a straight binding, cut (6) 2.5â€xWOF strips from your light green binding fabric. Sew these together at the ends, right sides together, so that you have one very long 2.5â€ strip.

Bind your quilt in your favorite method.

I machine bound it by sewing it to the back with a Â¼â€ seam allowance, and folding it over to the front to topstitch along the edges.

And you have a completed quilt! Itâ€™s so cheerful, and a nice size for curling up on the couch. Itâ€™s a constant source of optimism, and a reminder to always look on the bright side of life.

Flip the block over and place a back sashing strip on the backside of your block, along the same edge and having raw edges even (so the folded edge of the strip is NOT along the raw edge of the block).

Use clips to secure the three layers and remove those temporary pins from the front of the block. (I think this works better than pins!)

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_4.jpg)

Stitch through the three layers along the raw edge using a Â¼â€ seam.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_5.jpg)

Now, press out the front sashing strip. Here Iâ€™ve pressed out the front sashing and have laid my second block next to the first to decide how I want to orient the next block:

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_6.jpg)

Flip the second block over to the left and align the right edge of the block with the right raw edge of the front sashing strip. The block and sashing should be right sides together.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_7.jpg)

Use clips to secure the two layers and stitch along the raw edge using a Â¼â€ seam. Now your two blocks are joined in the front by a narrow sashing!

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_8.jpg)

Next we need to secure the back sashing. Hereâ€™s what the back will look like after youâ€™ve finished stitching the front sashing:

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_9.jpg)

Press the back sashing over the space between the two blocks.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_10.jpg)

Handstitch the sashing to the back of your second block, just like you would handstitch a quilt binding.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_11.jpg)

I am loving how this dotted chambray sashing looks against the plaid flannel! What do you think?

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Log%20Cabin%20Sew%20Along%20Pt%205/Fabriclogcabinsewalong_Week%204_post%20pic_12.jpg)

After youâ€™ve joined all your blocks into rows (you should have four rows of four blocks each), youâ€™ll follow the same process to join the rows together. Use the bias cut strips to make the binding and bind your quilt using your preferred method. Iâ€™m still plugging away on my quilt-as-you-go log cabin blanket, but my kids have already started fighting over who gets to keep it! I canâ€™t wait to show yâ€™all the finished quilt. Stay tuned for the big reveal! How are your quilts coming along? We would love to see your progress! posts.title: No Sew Burlap Table Runner & Classic Linen Napkins
posts.markdown:
Created by Nikki Johnson of fabric.com Create some festive and timeless pieces for your Holiday tablescape with these two tutorials. An easier-than-pie no sew burlap table runner and some simple mitered corner napkins that will weather changing trends.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/christmasTable11.jpg)

####Materials: * 3-4 yards of red burlap (Shop our wide selection of burlap here) * 2 yards of linen (we used this one by Telio) * Coordinating thread for the linen * Standard cutting and sewing supplies

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1905.JPG)

####No-Sew Tassel Burlap Table Runner For a Thanksgiving table, replace the red burlap with brown, natural, or orange. When working with burlap, you donâ€™t cut it as you would normally. The weave is far too loose, and you would end up with an unraveled mess! On one cut edge of your burlap, snip into the selvedge with your scissors next to one of the threads so that you can get to that thread easier.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1907.JPG)

Pull on that thread you â€œfreedâ€ gently, gathering across the width of the burlap, until youâ€™ve pulled the whole thread out of the fabric.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1909.JPG)

Now youâ€™ve left a little channel running from selvedge to selvedge. If your channel doesnâ€™t run the whole width of the fabric, youâ€™ll need to pick a spot further in.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1912.JPG)

Cut down this channel so you have a nice, even edge.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1913.JPG)

Repeat on the other side, picking a spot that will give you the perfect length for your table runner. I aim for about 1 foot of overhang on each side of your table. Next, trim the burlap to be about 13â€ by the length youâ€™ve just cut. This gives you A LOT of extra burlap, but we needed it to get the length of the table. I started at the selvedge, and marked 13 inches from that.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1915.JPG)

Cut off the denser selvedge edge very carefully, following one thread the entire way. This is like what we did with pulling the thread, which you can do, but I find it simpler to cut it the whole way when weâ€™re working with such a long length. Repeat at your 13â€ marking as well. Now youâ€™ll have a very long 13â€ wide strip of burlap!

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1917.JPG)

Now we do some fun unraveling. Starting on the long sides, pull out each thread all the way down, so that youâ€™re creating a fringe. Stop when you achieve your desired look. I stopped at Â½â€ for the sides, since our ends will have a much longer fringe.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1921.JPG)

Repeat for the short ends. This time, I created a super long fringe (5â€), so that we can make tassels out of it.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1924.JPG)

To make the tassels, grab about 10 of those strings at a time. Some of mine were less than ten to even out the size of them, since I didnâ€™t have multiples of ten. Play it by ear.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1927.JPG)

Now make a simple knot right where your fringe begins.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1928.JPG)

Repeat until all of your fringe has been tasseled, and you are finished!

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1930.JPG)

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/christmasTable16b_square.jpg)

####Classic Mitered Corner Linen Napkins To make these classic napkins, all you need is a half yard of linen for 3 napkins, so determine how many napkins you want, and add Â½ yard for safety and shrinkage. Each napkin will start out as 18â€x18â€ squares, so cut out as many as you want to make. I made 8 napkins total for 8 standard place settings, but you can make as any or as few as you like.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/christmasTable1.jpg)

One tip for these- donâ€™t estimate, measure exactly for the most accurate results. For each napkin, fold over Â½â€ on each side and press for a nice crease.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1938.JPG)

Now fold over another half an inch so that is enclosed, and press again. Unfold so that you have only one fold on all sides. At each corner, make a mark like so, keeping it at a right angle and not going over the folded edges.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1940.JPG)

Fold your napkin at the corner, right sides together, so that you can see the marking on one side.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1941.JPG)

Sew along that line, and trim the excess. Repeat for all four corners.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1943.JPG)

When you turn this out, you will have a perfect mitered corner! Pin these edges down.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1945.JPG)

Sew along this edge about 1/8â€ from the fold for a lovely finish.

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/IMG_1946.JPG)

Now, fold as desired and add them to your gorgeous Holiday tablescape. Add some greenery and your favorite festive dishes for a welcoming holiday scene!

![Sew Along Week 4](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Burlap%20Table%20Runner%20and%20Napkins/christmasTable7.jpg)

posts.markdown:
Created by: The Sara Project Velvet is one of this seasonâ€™s biggest trends. You see it used with skirts, shoes, dresses, blazers, etc. and I just canâ€™t get enough! Fabric.com has a fabulous selection of stretch velvets, and Iâ€™m here to show you how to use them! I love stretch velvet because itâ€™s not very complicated to use. Basically, think of it as a knit fabric. The only thing you need to be aware of is the nap. When you pet the fabric, you can feel the fabric laying smoothly one way, and pushing against your hand (a little rough) the other way. With stretch velvet, you have to decide which way you want the nap to go for your project, the light hits it differently both ways. For this project, I decided to go against the nap. I recently came across a boho designer dress made in a stunning yellow velvet, and the rest was history. I knew I had to make my own version of the eye catching frock. I really love the different design elements to this dress, specifically its yokes, gathered waist and tiered prairie style skirt.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/Paulina_Mulberry-Alt.jpg)

I have a really fun tutorial planned for you that will walk you through how to make and draft your own pattern for this dress as well as a sew-along that take you through the entire process of sewing your dress together. Letâ€™s get started!

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3248.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3253.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3254.JPG)

12) Cut along this line. Add Â½â€ seam allowance along both the yoke and new bodice edge.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2837%29.jpg)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3255.JPG)

13) Repeat for back yoke and bodice. (steps 10-12). Label front and back yoke piece, we will cutting one front yoke and one back yoke on the fold. 14) It is important in pattern making to true your patterns. To do this, lay the front and back yokes on top of each other, and make sure they are the same. I had to add a little to one piece and subtract a little from the other. Do the same for you bodice front and back pieces too.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2836%29.jpg)

Total Waist Measurement x 1.5= Added Fullness Measurement (ex: 32 X 1.5=48) b. Added Fullness Measurement / 4 = How much fullness we are adding (ex: 48 /4=12) c. How Much Added Fullness / 4 pieces= total amount we need to add to F and B bodice pieces (ex: 12/4= 4â€ needed per piece). 17) To figure out how to space your slash and spread pieces, calculate: a. Front Bodice Waist Measurement / Fullness to Add= Spacing. b. Ex: 8 Â¼ / 4â€= 2â€ Spread 18) Mark this spacing measurement along your bodice piece. So I marked every 2â€ and then drew a perpendicular line to the top of my bodice piece. (photo: fullsizerender(45) ). 19) Next, we are going to cut along these lines one at a time. On tracing paper draw a straight horizontal line along the bottom as a reference. Cut along your spacing lines one at a time. So cut, tape, measure 1â€. Repeat adding 4 â€œ total. ![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2844%29.jpg)

21) Now we need to add the first section of our skirt, and we are going to add it directly to the front and back bodice pieces to make one whole piece. Draw a line from the side and center front seams using this new measurement we just made. (Mine was 16â€) and make the width the same as your bodice piece. Add Â½â€ seam allowance along the side seam for both pieces.

![Velvet](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3298.JPG)

a. Label your pattern pieces; we will cut one Front bodice on the fold and one Back bodice on the fold. 23) Now we are going to make the last two tiers of our dress. Tier 1: Waist Measurement x 2.7 / 2 = width x desired length. (ex: 40â€ width x 7â€ length) b. Tier 2: Waist Measurement x 4 / 2= width x desired length + 1â€ for hem). (ex: 56â€ width x 7.5â€ length) c. Draw out these two pieces, label each pattern piece, we will cut one of each tier on the fold. 24) Almost there guys! I promise itâ€™s worth it! Just a few more pieces to go. Next, we need to make our casing piece. This will go right along our waist on both front and back bodice pieces. So here is how you calculate this pattern piece: a. Measure across the waistline on your pattern that we marked. b. Subtract 1 Â½â€ from this measurement = (casing pattern width x 1 Â¼â€ length) c. Mine ended up being 11â€ x 1 Â¼â€ d. Draw this pattern piece (a rectangle). e. Repeat for back bodice piece. Label this pattern piece, we will cut one on the fold for the front and one on the fold for the back.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2843%29.jpg)

25) Now our neckband pattern piece (another rectangle): a. Using a tape measure, measure along your front and back neckline on your yoke pattern pieces. Multiply each measurement by 2 since we are only measuring half of each neckline. I ended up with 23â€. (13â€ Front and 10â€ for back)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3287%20%281%29.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3348.JPG)

11) Repeat for Back Bodice. 12) Next we will sew our final tier, tier 2 to the bottom of tier one. Again, sew basting stitches at Â¼â€ and Â½â€ along the top of tier two. Match center and ends for both pieces, lightly pull threads and evenly space gathers to fit, pin in place. Sew at Â½â€ using a stretch stitch, remove any visible threads on the right side.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3351.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2841%29.jpg)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3359.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3357.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3358.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3360.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3361.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2846%29.jpg)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3433.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2840%29.jpg)

20) Pin your neck band to your neckline, right sides together, pinning first at shoulder seams and front and back centers. Lightly stretch your neck band (not your neckline) to fit and pin the rest of your neckband in place.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/FullSizeRender%20%2839%29.jpg)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3439.JPG)

Wrap your Â¼â€ elastic around where your sleeve will end along your arm to where itâ€™s just fitted, and cut two pieces to this length. 22) Using my fingers and no iron, I folded each sleeve end in at Â¼â€ and then Â½â€. ![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3443.JPG)

23) Attach a safety pin to one end of your elastic, and insert it into your sleeve casing. Sew your two elastic ends together (make sure thereâ€™s no twisting inside your sleeve casing before sewing). Push the elastic into your casing completely, and edgestitch your opening closed.

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3446.JPG)

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3440.JPG)

Edgestitch using a straight stitch

![Velvet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Velvet%20Dress/IMG_3441.JPG)

25) Cut your cording in half exactly and insert your cording into your waist casing. Insert each piece like the letter U into each side, so two ends come out on each side. 1) First we are going to attach our casing to our front and back bodice pieces. Mark your waistline previously marked on your pattern along the front and back waist marking. I used pins to mark this line on my fabric.

2) Lightly fold and iron both ends of casing pieces in at Â½â€ wrong sides together. Top stitch to finish this edge.

3) Now, fold both long edges on each casing piece in at Â¼â€ on each side wrong sides together, lightly iron.

4) Line up your prepped casing along the pins marking your waist on your front and back bodice pieces. Pin in place.

5) Topstitch 1/8â€ away on either side of casing, leaving ends open. (Make sure to use a straight stitch)

6) Along the top of your front bodice piece, sew basting stitches at Â¼â€ and Â½â€, leave long tails on either end.

7) Gather along this top edge, lightly pulling your threads, and match up to your front yoke piece. Make sure to evenly spread your gathers. Before gathering I like to match up the centers of both pieces, and ends, (right sides together) pinning in place. Then I gather my long edge to fit. Either way works.

8) Sew the bottom of the yoke and top of front bodice pieces right side together at Â½â€ using a zig zag or lightning stitch. Remove any basting stitches you can see on the right side.

9) Repeat for back bodice and yoke.

10) Now we are going to sew tier one to the bottom of our front bodice piece. Again, sew basting stitched to the top of your tier one piece at Â¼â€ and Â½â€. Pin the pieces together RST at centers and ends, lightly pull threads to gather the long tier one edge to fit the bottom of your front bodice edge. Pin, and sew Â½â€ with a stretch stitch, and remove any visible basting stitches on front side.

11) Repeat for Back Bodice.

12) Next we will sew our final tier, tier 2 to the bottom of tier one. Again, sew basting stitches at Â¼â€ and Â½â€ along the top of tier two. Match center and ends for both pieces, lightly pull threads and evenly space gathers to fit, pin in place. Sew at Â½â€ using a stretch stitch, remove any visible threads on the right side.

13) Repeat for back bodice.

14) Next we need to sew our shoulder seams together. Pin front and back shoulders right sides together. Sew at Â½â€ using a stretch stitch: zig zag or lightening stitch.

15) Now itâ€™s time to sew in our sleeves. We are going to pin our sleeve cap into the armhole, right sides together. Match up your corners at the end of your cap and armhole, and the center of your sleeve to the shoulder seam. Sew at Â½â€using a stretch stitch.

16) With right sides facing, pin your side seams and sleeves together from sleeve hem to dress hem on both sides of your dress. Sew each side at Â½â€, with a stretch stitch.

17) Almost done! Now letâ€™s finish our neckline. Fold your neckline band in half along the fold, right sides together. Sew at Â½â€.

18) Now fold your neckband piece in half wrong sides together and pin in place instead of ironing.

19) Using pins, mark the front, back and sides of your neckband, quartering it. This helps keep it even when pinning it to the neckline.

20) Pin your neck band to your neckline, right sides together, pinning first at shoulder seams and front and back centers. Lightly stretch your neck band (not your neckline) to fit and pin the rest of your neckband in place.

Sew at Â½â€ using a stretch stitch. Trim your seam allowance, and topstitch along the neckline to keep the seam allowance laying down.

21) Now letâ€™s hem our sleeve. Wrap your Â¼â€ elastic around where your sleeve will end along your arm to where itâ€™s just fitted, and cut two pieces to this length.

22) Using my fingers and no iron, I folded each sleeve end in at Â¼â€ and then Â½â€. Pin this in place. Edgestitch around your casing using a straight stitch, making sure to leave about Â½â€ opening to insert your elastic. Repeat for your other sleeve.

23) Attach a safety pin to one end of your elastic, and insert it into your sleeve casing. Sew your two elastic ends together (make sure thereâ€™s no twisting inside your sleeve casing before sewing). Push the elastic into your casing completely, and edgestitch your opening closed.

24) Hem the bottom of your dress. Again, using my fingers, I folded my hem at Â¼â€ and then Â½â€ and pinned in place all the way around.

Edgestitch using a straight stitch

25) Cut your cording in half exactly and insert your cording into your waist casing. Insert each piece like the letter U into each side, so two ends come out on each side. Tie a little knot at the end of your cording once it is inserted.

You did it! I hope you enjoy your new dress! Thanks for following along!
