posts.title: Easy Floor Pouf Tutorial
posts.markdown:
This floor pouf is perfect for extra seating in dorm rooms, apartments and any living space where fashionable, functional, additional seating is needed. Super easy to make and surprisingly comfortable, the unique design creates a lumbar-supportive structure that anyone can enjoy. This is a great project for a beginner learning to master the zipper, or a quick project for a seasoned sewist. In our how-to video, we explain the step by step details to make your own. This Genevieve Gorder Flower Pops Basketweave Peacock Fabric is another great option for fabric choice to bring a bold prints and splash of color into any room! ####Materials: * Home Decor fabric of your choice (we created the two examples for this post using Genevieve Gorder Flower Pops Basketweave Peacock Fabric and Udder Madness Cow Upholstery Fabric in Milk) * Bean Bag Fill (1 bag will fill the Small size chair. The Regular size will require 1.5 bags) * 24â€™â€™ Upholstery Zipper * Upholstery Thread * Optional Liner Insert- Poly Cotton Broadcloth (1.5 yard for Small size chair, 2 yards for Regular size, 24â€™â€™ upholstery zipper and all purpose thread)

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/Materials.jpg)

#####Step 1 Cut your rectangles based on what size you desire: Small Size: 2 rectangles, 36.5â€™â€™ x 29.5â€™â€™ - This size is ideal for kids and tweens. Regular Size: 2 rectangles, 42.5â€™â€™ x 35.5â€™â€™ -This size is appropriate for seat-seekers of most sizes. #####Step 2 Finish the edges of the shorter sides of both rectangles if needed. Right sides together, sew a 3/4" seam allowance and finger press open. When sewing the seam, backstitch at 6 1/2" from each edge. If making the kids size floor pouf, backstitch at 3 1/2" from each edge. Reinforcing by backstitching is necessary because later when you open up part of the seam to reveal the zipper, the remaining seam still needs to be strong and not be able to be pulled apart.
Pin zipper within the seam allowance, and top stitch the zipper with a zipper foot. You can topstitch the zipper on the underside of the seam, or the top of the seam - whichever your preference. Use a seam ripper to open up the seam, revealing the sliding zipper.
You'll notice the seam opening for the zipper is a little shorter than the zipper length - this will allow a little pocket for the zipper pull to be tucked into once zipped, eliminating any urge to unzip and spill the beans! Pinned Zipper â€“ underside and top side of seam shown:

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/Step%202.1%20zipper%20pinned.jpg)

Top Stitch Zipper into seam:

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/Step%202.2%20Top%20stitch%20zipper.JPG)

Open up seam to reveal zipper using a seam ripper:

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/Step%202.3%20ripper%20zipper.JPG)

#####Step 3 Sewing wrong sides together, stitch 5/8â€™â€™ seam allowance along both long edges of the rectangles. #####Step 4 Join the side seams together in the center and sew along the remaining short end of the rectangle piece. This seam creates the vertical seam portion along the back of the cushion, which gives the seat structure.
Tip: Sewing from the middle out helps line up the seams perfectly.

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/Step%204.%20vertical%20seam.jpg)

#####Step 5 (Optional) Repeat Steps 1 -4 for a liner insert if desired. The liner insert is not required to complete the project, but recommended if you want to change or easily clean the exterior cover. #####Step 6 Pour your bean bag fill into the liner. Warning â€“ this is a 2 person job and should be done VERY carefully. Those beans are tricky, move quickly and love static electricity; the less you come in contact with them the better! Poof! Or should I say Pouf? Now take a seat, relax and enjoy!

![Cowhide Floor Cushion](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cowhide%20Poufs/cowhidePouf_3_square.jpg)

posts.title: Easy Retro Loominous Tie Quilt
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com Wrap yourself up in this amazingly soft and comfy quilt using Anna Maria Hornerâ€™s new Loominous 2 line of lovely yarn-dyes. This bohemian blanket takes all the hard parts out of quilting, leaving you with an easy project that brings you back to the 70â€™s, with modern flair. ####Materials: * (42) 12.5â€ squares of Anna Mariaâ€™s Loominous Collection or Loominous 2 Collection * 1 Twin Size Wool Batting: (This one or this one are great choices) * 4.5 yards 44â€ backing fabric (I used this one) * 1 skein of lightweight yarn (We used Paton's Baby Beehive Sport but you can use any fingering weight or sport weight yarn as long as itâ€™s washable). * Thread (we chose this grey one) * A large and sharp hand sewing needle

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2052.JPG)

For the patchwork squares on the front of the quilt, I used 10 yards of 10 different fabrics and used an average of 4 each. This has a fair amount of fabric waste, because youâ€™ll need a yard each if you want more than 3 squares out of each fabric. ######Some other fabric cutting options for the fronts: * 14 half yard cuts * 7-8 full yard cuts (depending on if youâ€™re fussy cutting or not) ####Assembling your quilt top This is a very simple quilt. The trickiest part will be the pressing. To create your patchwork top, weâ€™re going to use a Â½â€ seam allowance due to the looser weave of the fabric. First, determine your preferred layout. I like to lay them all out on the floor and play around with the color placement. Then, I take a picture of it and use that to reference during sewing.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_7249.jpg)

Youâ€™ll sew two squares together, and then another two. I then make patches of four, and then sew into columns of 2x6. Hereâ€™s a little pressing diagram for a block of four.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/Pressing%20Diagram%201.PNG)

Sew your first two blocks together, right sides together. Then press the seam to the RIGHT. Sew your second two blocks together, right sides together, then press that seam to the LEFT. Your seams should be nicely nested with that pressing technique.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2057.JPG)

See how the chartreuse blockâ€™s seam is pressed to the right? The one on the bottom will have its seam pressed to the left. Repeat this until you have 3 of these, and then make a column. In the end, you should have 4 columns. 3 of these columns will be 2x6, one will be 1x6. For the last column, you can just sew the blocks in segments of 2, and then all together. No need for squares here. Here is how we want to sew the quilt top. This diagram shows how to press your seams. The first column you will press your seams down, the second up, and so on.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/Pressing%20Diagram%202.PNG)

This will make sewing your columns together (still a Â½â€ seam allowance) a lot easier. Sew the first two columns together, then the second two, and then sew THOSE two together. ####Backing To make your backing, cut your 4.5 yards in half, and then sew together along the selvedge edges with a Â½â€ seam allowance. ####Sewing your quilt together Now weâ€™ll make the quilt! We want to make a sandwich a little different than we would a standard quilt. You will want to have your backing and quilt top pinned right sides together, and then the batting on top of your quilt top. Trim your batting and backing to fit your quilt top.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2063_edit.JPG)

Pin along the edges every few inches all the way around (1/2â€ seam allowance), and then sew along those edges, leaving an opening that is about 8â€ wide, backstitching when you begin and end.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2065.JPG)

Clip your corners, and then turn right sides out. Your batting should be in the middle now, with the right sides of your back and front facing outwards. Flatten our your blanket, making sure your corners are nice and pointed. ####Closing the opening Pin the opening closed that we used to turn the quilt. Using a small hand needle and thread, close up this opening with a ladder stitch. After burying your knot in the seam, follow the pictures to create a ladder stitch.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2066.JPG)

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2067.JPG)

Itâ€™s that simple, youâ€™ll end up with an invisible stitch once you tug on your working thread. Do this until the entire opening is closed.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2068.JPG)

####Tying your quilt With a doll needle and your thread, cut off a long length to work with. No need to make a knot. I tied at the corners and middle of each block, but you can do as many as you want. Just make sure you have no less than that amount. Insert your needle to the back and then back to the front without pulling through.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2069.JPG)

Pull your thread through, all the way to the end so thereâ€™s about an inch left. Cut off an inch to the other side, and make a knot with the two ends. Youâ€™ll want to double knot to make it extra secure.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2070.JPG)

Trim your ends if you have extra. Aim for about Â½â€-1â€ length on each tail.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2072.JPG)

Repeat until youâ€™ve tied off the whole quilt.

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_2073_edit.jpg)

And youâ€™re finished! Cuddle up and enjoy!

![Loominous Tie Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Loominous%20Tie%20Quilt/IMG_7099.jpg)

posts.title: Tips for Mixing & Matching Fabric in Your Home
posts.markdown:
Created by: Jessica Nickerson of House Homemade Hello fabric.com blog readers, I'm Jessica Nickerson, a wife and stay at home mom with a love of interior styling. I have a blog called House Homemade and also try to deliver daily home inspirations on Instagram @househomemade. My main goal is to share ways of having a polished, put together home on a small budget. I thrift, re-purpose and makeover anything that stands still for too long. For real, ask my family. I recently used a combo of fabric.com's home decor fabrics to change up our master bedroom. Here is the "before". It was totally fine but I'm on a color, contrast and pattern kick so the after makes me so happy!

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/IMG_4477.JPG)

This is the "after!"

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/chair%20and%20curtains.jpg)

shop diamond curtain fabric // shop cow chair fabric I've used fabric.com many-a-time in my own designs so I'm so honored they asked me to guest blog for them today. I hope I can help you make the task of fabric mixing and matching feel a little less overwhelming . When choosing fabrics, I look at scale, color and pattern. I'll try to break down these tips into 3 categories but really they are related and each works with the other to create a good pairing so let me try to explain. ####Scale Checking how big or small a pattern is online can be a little bit trickier than when you're seeing it at the store but look at the bottom of this amazing fabric. See the ruler? It shows you that on this fabric, each birdâ€™s wingspan is 8" wide. Sometimes I get out a ruler so that I can see just how big that will end up being. This can better help you to visualize the fabric in a space. It also can help determine uses for a certain pattern. You might not want something this bold to be the curtain pattern for 4 windows in a room, so you might decide to do use this fabric for a few throw pillows and something more subdued for the curtains. OR you might be awesome and bold and rock this fabric all over those windows and if that's the case, please invite me over to see them and hug them.

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/flock%20velvet.jpg)

####Pattern When I'm shopping for multiple fabrics I try to mix and match patterns that complement each other and not usually ones that are in the same family. For example, something geometric with stripes or hard angles works really well with something floral or more organic looking. A print that looks hand-drawn usually looks better with something more structured. ####Color I always try to pick something that comes across as more of a solid color paired with something more colorful when using multiple fabrics. You can see in each of my pairings (there are more at the end of this post), one simpler, less colorful fabric and another more bold. It lets them both shine without competing for attention. One fabric is usually more neutral than the other. In the pairing below, I marked some examples of why these would work well together in a space.

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/stripeslightsmall%20scale.png)

shop stripe fabric // shop floral fabric The striped fabric is so small scale that from afar it almost reads like a solid, working well with the bold floral fabric but letting shine. The fabric I chose for our bedroom is pretty eclectic. To me eclectic means, if you like it, choose it. I paired the vintage diamond geometric pattern with the organic, natural look of the cow print. Theyâ€™re in the same color family but the diamonds act a little more as the neutral to balance the two out.

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/1.png)

shop diamond fabric // shop cowhide fabric The next two fabrics are a little more straight-forward than my pick. The smaller scale, neutral diamond pattern works so well with the big, bold, colorful floral.

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/2.png)

shop diamond fabric // shop garden odyssey fabric The next one is a modern take on a throwback. The glam looking banana leaf is back in style and I love it with the tribal looking geometric. I feel like it would be an obvious choice to pull out the green in the leaf fabric so I love that the other, lighter fabric pulls out the less prominent aqua. Turquoise? Aqua? I was an art teacher. I should know the difference. Anyway, that's a tip in itself. When picking accent colors, go for the less obvious choice, it will make you look like more of a mixing wizard.

![House Homemade Mixing Matching](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Mixing%20and%20Matching/3.jpg)

shop banana leaf fabric // shop tribal geometric This next pair is one of my favorites. There is really not much indigo blue in our house but it's such a timeless pick and I love this pattern on this fabric. Paired with the striped, textured chenille is so dreamy and it's a great balance to the darkness that the blue fabric could bring to a room.

Hello fabric.com blog readers, I'm Jessica Nickerson, a wife and stay at home mom with a love of interior styling. I have a blog called House Homemade and also try to deliver daily home inspirations on Instagram @househomemade. My main goal is to share ways of having a polished, put together home on a small budget. I thrift, re-purpose and makeover anything that stands still for too long. For real, ask my family.

I recently used a combo of fabric.com's home decor fabrics to change up our master bedroom. Here is the "before". It was totally fine but I'm on a color, contrast and pattern kick so the after makes me so happy!

This is the "after!"

shop diamond curtain fabric // shop cow chair fabric

I've used fabric.com many-a-time in my own designs so I'm so honored they asked me to guest blog for them today. I hope I can help you make the task of fabric mixing and matching feel a little less overwhelming .

When choosing fabrics, I look at scale, color and pattern. I'll try to break down these tips into 3 categories but really they are related and each works with the other to create a good pairing so let me try to explain.

Scale

Checking how big or small a pattern is online can be a little bit trickier than when you're seeing it at the store but look at the bottom of this amazing fabric. See the ruler? It shows you that on this fabric, each birdâ€™s wingspan is 8" wide. Sometimes I get out a ruler so that I can see just how big that will end up being. This can better help you to visualize the fabric in a space. It also can help determine uses for a certain pattern. You might not want something this bold to be the curtain pattern for 4 windows in a room, so you might decide to do use this fabric for a few throw pillows and something more subdued for the curtains. OR you might be awesome and bold and rock this fabric all over those windows and if that's the case, please invite me over to see them and hug them.

Pattern

When I'm shopping for multiple fabrics I try to mix and match patterns that complement each other and not usually ones that are in the same family. For example, something geometric with stripes or hard angles works really well with something floral or more organic looking. A print that looks hand-drawn usually looks better with something more structured.

Color

I always try to pick something that comes across as more of a solid color paired with something more colorful when using multiple fabrics. You can see in each of my pairings (there are more at the end of this post), one simpler, less colorful fabric and another more bold. It lets them both shine without competing for attention. One fabric is usually more neutral than the other. In the pairing below, I marked some examples of why these would work well together in a space.

The striped fabric is so small scale that from afar it almost reads like a solid, working well with the bold floral fabric but letting shine.

I feel like it would be an obvious choice to pull out the green in the leaf fabric so I love that the other, lighter fabric pulls out the less prominent aqua. Turquoise? Aqua? I was an art teacher. I should know the difference. Anyway, that's a tip in itself. When picking accent colors, go for the less obvious choice, it will make you look like more of a mixing wizard.

shop banana leaf fabric // shop tribal geometric

posts.title: Reversible Vinyl Placemats Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Shannon McBride of fabric.com Vinyl placemats are ideal for function and style. This Heat N' Bond Iron-On Vinyl makes it possible for any cotton print fabric to become a laminated vinyl fabric. The goal was to have 8 double-sided placemats that I could use every day and for the holidays. My solution was to create 15 Â½â€™â€™ x 20â€™â€™ double-sided vinyl placemats with different fabrics on each side. I picked Amy Butler Lotus Wall Flower Cherry for all eight! I loved this fabric for my daily â€œholidayâ€ table since itâ€™s a coral red color; versatile enough for my desired modern Christmas look or for everyday use all year. These make great gifts, too! I chose Joel Dewberry Wander Cross Midnight for four reverse placemat sides, and Joel Dewberry Birch Farm Chrysanthemum Peacock for the other four reverse placemat sides. I love the option to have all eight the same, or mix and match depending on my mood and season.

![Vinyl Placemats](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vinyl%20Placemats/place%20red%201_resized.jpg)

####Supplies: * Upholstery Thread * Upholstery Machine Needles * Heat Nâ€™ Bond 3925 Flex Vinyl Matte * Fabric for 8 placemat fronts- 2 yds Quilting Cotton Fabric * Fabric for 4 reverse placemat backs â€“ 1 yd Quilting Cotton Fabric * Fabric for 4 reverse placemat backs â€“ 1 yd Quilting Cotton Fabric ####Step 1: Cut out your rectangles * Cotton Fabric â€“ (16) 17â€™â€™ x 21.5â€™â€™ * Vinyl laminate â€“ (16) 17â€™â€™ x 22â€™â€™ (the laminate is 22â€™â€™ wide, and itâ€™s better to have some overhang on the laminate to ensure full coverage on the fabric rectangles. ####Step 2: Iron your rectangles Follow the instructions included with the vinyl to iron-on laminate all sixteen pieces of cotton fabric. Some tips for iron-on-vinyl â€“ Make sure your cotton fabric is pressed smooth and free of any threads or foreign material, or else it will forever be preserved within the vinyl coating. Peel only the first 2 inches or so of the vinyl to start with. Apply it to one cotton print rectangle and leverage the grid paper backing to smooth onto the fabric, as shown here:

![Vinyl Placemats](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vinyl%20Placemats/placemat%20laminating%201-.jpg)

As the directions state, use the paper to iron on the vinyl, make sure the grid side of the paper is face up while ironing. The directions state to press for 8 seconds, then flip over and press 4 more seconds. Because this surface area is so large to laminate, I ironed in a slow figure-8 motion, let it cool, repositioned my paper, and continued down the length of the rectangle. Then flipped it over, used the paper as a barrier again and ironed in a figure-8 motion on the back as well. Each part of the fabric didnâ€™t get 8 full seconds of iron pressing, however, my method seemed to work, as the vinyl was successfully laminated. If you iron too long, the vinyl will start to melt and bubble. 10 Yards of Heat n Bond is actually about Â½ yard too much, as itâ€™s intended to test on a scrap piece of cotton first. Definitely test and find your best ironing groove first before tackling your sixteen placemat pieces.

![Vinyl Placemats](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vinyl%20Placemats/placemat%20ironing%20vinyl.jpg)

####Step 3: Sew 'em up! Use clips to hold in place. Pins cannot be used since it will leave a permanent hole in the vinyl fabric. Take two coordinating laminated rectangles and sew right sides together, Use a 5/8â€™â€™ â€“ Â¾â€™â€™ seam allowance, leaving a 12â€™â€™ opening along the length of the rectangle, in order to flip it inside out. The variation in seam allowance allows some forgiveness in order to maintain the rectangle shape. Remember, itâ€™s more important to not warp the rectangle than to have a perfectly matching seam allowance. ####Step 4: Flip 'em! Grade your seam allowance edges and clip your corners so that the seam allowance will lay nicely once flipped. Where the opening is, fold the edges down and iron with the grid paper so it will be easier to top stitch closed after flipping right side out.

![Vinyl Placemats](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vinyl%20Placemats/placemat%20opening%20grade%20clip-.jpg)

Using the 12â€™â€™ opening, flip the placemat right side out. Warning â€“ when you flip the placemat right side out- the vinyl will crinkle and crunch. The lovely smooth vinyl rectangles will be no more; it will have some texture due to the bends from flipping it inside out. Do not fret â€“ this is how this vinyl behaves. But itâ€™s OK. You can use the grid paper and iron the placemat again to smooth out a lot of the creases, but these placemats will not have a super-smooth appearance. A slight bummer, I know, but the function and style of these outweighs the creased texture developed during the making, trust me. ####Step 5: Topstitch 'em! Once you have your placemat flipped right side out, top stitch 3/8â€™â€™ from the edge. Now you have great looking placemats that have ultimate function. Theyâ€™re large enough to contain a mess from eating, crafts and other activities and easy enough to just wipe clean. Another tip for vinyl placemats: rub a few drops of water to the underside of the placemat and it wonâ€™t slide around on the table.

![Vinyl Placemats](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vinyl%20Placemats/placemat%20alternate%20table-.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.title: Fabric Wall Upholstery Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: House Homemade Blog Hello! I'm Jessica Nickerson. I share tutorials and tips for making a house a home on a budget over at House Homemade and try to provide daily decor ideas over on Instagram @househomemade. You can find my previous fabric.com post about pattern mixing here. I'm so happy to be back! I'm excited to show you today's project! I love the result, and don't worry, I'll tell you the things that you can anticipate and maybe avoid should you be crazy/awesome enough to staple fabric onto your walls.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/1%20and%2018.JPG)

Recently, over on my blog, I shared a before picture of our very sad, very boring hallway.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/2.JPG)

and made it better a few weeks ago by making this great picture ledge. It's good, but I wanted a little something else.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/3.JPG)

I read this article on ways to make a long hallway appear not so long. One of the ways mentioned was to paint the back wall a different color. It makes sense. The color brings your eye / your attention to the end of the hall, making it not seem so long. It's an illusion. Now, our hallway isn't crazy long or anything but it was boring and does deserve some cuteness. I was going to paint it but then got the chance to collaborate with fabric.com on another project and I thought a pattern would look amazing in this tiny little space. When I told them my idea was to upholster an accent wall, they were all for it!

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/4.JPG)

Here's what I used for this project: ####Materials: * 3 yards of medium weight fabric (I used this one) * An iron and ironing board * Staple gun * Staples * Xacto knife * Sharpies * Small screwdriver * Needle nose pliers (for mistakes...I only used them once) I measured my wall and luckily is was a bit narrower than the 54" wide fabric. You could try and match seams if you have a wider wall or look for a wider fabric while searching. We have 8ft ceilings so I ordered 3 yards of fabric to give me a little extra room to work. To start off, I ironed the seam that would be at the top of the wall. I wanted to make sure I started with a straight line and a straight pattern.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/5.JPG)

I wanted to be able to hide the staples at the top. So with another set of hands, courtesy of a sweet friend, we held the fabric where we wanted it, made sure it was centered on the wall, and stapled it from underneath, making sure the staples were right up against the fold and the crown molding.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/6.JPG)

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/7.jpg)

Next we cut away the excess fabric from the middle and used it for a cute throw pillow (just sayin').

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/8.jpg)

I pulled the fabric taut and started stapling above the door jamb. Before I started stapling down either side of the door I had to make a small cut in the excess fabric around the door trim to keep the fabric flush with the wall.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/9.JPG)

I definitely didn't want to cut too much so I just kept making small cuts and checking until the fabric was able to be stapled around the trim.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/10.jpg)

The sides are where I had a little bit of trouble, only because the space between the closet door and the side walls was so narrow that I couldn't lay my staple gun in there at a correct angle to get a flush staple. I took a picture of the angle of the stapler on the side sections. So, you'd only have this problem if you're upholstering a wall that is narrower than your staple gun is long. These sides are 4" wide. I stapled the sides down at this angle and then it was time to cut the excess fabric. I wanted to try and complete the wall with no trim around it. Just a clean cut line. This is where I ran into my next little problem. I couldn't cut the fabric as easily as I had hoped. I used an xacto knife and thought it would be so easy but I think the issue goes back to the angle in which I had to staple. Because I couldn't staple straight up against the cut edge, the fabric pulled a bit.

![Fabric Wall Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wall%20Covering/11.JPG)

I carefully cut down the sides and around the door then used a tiny screw driver to tuck extra little threads or edges back behind our trim.

Hello! I'm Jessica Nickerson. I share tutorials and tips for making a house a home on a budget over at House Homemade and try to provide daily decor ideas over on Instagram @househomemade. You can find my previous fabric.com post about pattern mixing here. I'm so happy to be back!

I'm excited to show you today's project! I love the result, and don't worry, I'll tell you the things that you can anticipate and maybe avoid should you be crazy/awesome enough to staple fabric onto your walls.

Recently, over on my blog, I shared a before picture of our very sad, very boring hallway.

and made it better a few weeks ago by making this great picture ledge. It's good, but I wanted a little something else.

I read this article on ways to make a long hallway appear not so long. One of the ways mentioned was to paint the back wall a different color. It makes sense. The color brings your eye / your attention to the end of the hall, making it not seem so long. It's an illusion.

Now, our hallway isn't crazy long or anything but it was boring and does deserve some cuteness. I was going to paint it but then got the chance to collaborate with fabric.com on another project and I thought a pattern would look amazing in this tiny little space. When I told them my idea was to upholster an accent wall, they were all for it!

Here's what I used for this project:

Materials:

  • 3 yards of medium weight fabric (I used this one)
  • An iron and ironing board
  • Staple gun
  • Staples
  • Xacto knife
  • Sharpies
  • Small screwdriver
  • Needle nose pliers (for mistakes...I only used them once)

I measured my wall and luckily is was a bit narrower than the 54" wide fabric. You could try and match seams if you have a wider wall or look for a wider fabric while searching. We have 8ft ceilings so I ordered 3 yards of fabric to give me a little extra room to work.

To start off, I ironed the seam that would be at the top of the wall. I wanted to make sure I started with a straight line and a straight pattern.

I wanted to be able to hide the staples at the top. So with another set of hands, courtesy of a sweet friend, we held the fabric where we wanted it, made sure it was centered on the wall, and stapled it from underneath, making sure the staples were right up against the fold and the crown molding.

Next we cut away the excess fabric from the middle and used it for a cute throw pillow (just sayin').

I pulled the fabric taut and started stapling above the door jamb. Before I started stapling down either side of the door I had to make a small cut in the excess fabric around the door trim to keep the fabric flush with the wall.

I definitely didn't want to cut too much so I just kept making small cuts and checking until the fabric was able to be stapled around the trim.

The sides are where I had a little bit of trouble, only because the space between the closet door and the side walls was so narrow that I couldn't lay my staple gun in there at a correct angle to get a flush staple. I took a picture of the angle of the stapler on the side sections. So, you'd only have this problem if you're upholstering a wall that is narrower than your staple gun is long. These sides are 4" wide.

I stapled the sides down at this angle and then it was time to cut the excess fabric. I wanted to try and complete the wall with no trim around it. Just a clean cut line. This is where I ran into my next little problem. I couldn't cut the fabric as easily as I had hoped. I used an xacto knife and thought it would be so easy but I think the issue goes back to the angle in which I had to staple. Because I couldn't staple straight up against the cut edge, the fabric pulled a bit.

I carefully cut down the sides and around the door then used a tiny screw driver to tuck extra little threads or edges back behind our trim.

I've seen this project done before, by masters I might add, and they completed their wall with trim around the edge. Since our little accent wall was so small I wanted to try and stay away from that. I used an orange and black sharpie to make the staples disappear into the fabric. I think it worked out pretty well. You might think this looks a little unfinished but you would never notice them unless you walked right up to it and looked for them.

I love how it transformed our boring hallway! It's colorful and adds a great pattern but it's also easily removable if we decide we don't want it anymore. Just pull out the staples and, because it's paneling, we might have to lightly sand, then paint! Love it.

If you pull out further into our living area you can see how the orange works so well with this great rug. And see the throw pillow behind the kitty? An added bonus!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Blue Susan Makes Hi sewing friends! This is Sarah from Blue Susan Makes. Today I'm happy to share with you a tutorial for a fun Pullover Toddler Bib. This style of baby bib has become a staple in my household. It goes on easily, is tough for my toddler to pull off, and provides great coverage for all those messy toddler meals. I recently sewed these up in several fun prints with things on them that he recognizes. It has been so fun to let him choose which one he wants to wear as he's been learning to talk. ####Pullover Toddler Bib Tutorial Finished dimensions: 9'' x 13'' with a 5 1/2 '' neck opening Fits toddler with a head circumference of 20 inches or smaller ####Materials: * 1/3 yd Print fabric, quilting cotton (we chose this adorable Michael Miller print and this polka dot in red) * 1/3 yd Minky Dimple Dot Cuddle fabric (we used this color) * 1/4 yd knit ribbing (we used this one) * Small bowl or circle template with a 5â€™â€™ diameter * Marking pen * Coordinating thread You can make 3 bibs with this much fabric! #####For each bib cut: * 1 rectangle 10â€™â€™ X 14â€™â€™ from the print fabric * 1 rectangle 10â€™â€™ X 14â€™â€™ from the Minky fabric * 1 strip 2 1/2" X 14" from the knit ribbing, if you have very stretchy ribbing you may need to shorten this length

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Cutting.jpg)

####Sewing: With right sides together lay the print fabric on top of the Minky fabric. The Minky tends to shift easily so press the 2 pieces together and smooth them out with your hands until it all lays flat. If the Minky doesnâ€™t line up perfectly donâ€™t worry too much. Place pins in the middle of the four sides to hold the minky fabric in place. Place the circle template or bowl in a corner and trace around it using the marking pen to create a curved corner. Repeat for each corner.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%201.jpg)

Cut along the traced line to trim the corners and sew around all the edges with a 3/8â€™â€™ seam allowance.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%202.jpg)

Clip notches into the seam allowance of each curve being careful to not clip into the stitches.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%203.jpg)

Draw a circle for the neck hole using the circle template or bowl. Position it in the center and about 1 1/2â€™â€™ from the top edge. Trace around the circle using a marking pen.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%204.jpg)

Cut out the neck hole along the marked line cutting through both fabrics carefully.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%205.jpg)

Turn the bib right side out through the opening. Using a warm iron, press the seams flat. If the iron is too hot the â€œdotsâ€ in the Minky fabric will flatten and disappear. To be safe just press along the edges of the bib from the printed fabric side only.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%206.JPG)

Topstitch around the edges of the bib about 1/4â€™â€™ away from the seam with a coordinating thread. Trim any Minky fabric that doesnâ€™t match up in the neck opening.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%207.jpg)

Fold the ribbing strip in half lengthwise. (There isnâ€™t usually a â€˜rightâ€™ side to ribbing). Sew the short ends together with a 1/4â€™â€™ seam allowance. At this point you can check to make sure the ribbing fits over your babyâ€™s head if youâ€™d like. Most ribbing has great stretch and recovery but if yours doesnâ€™t you may need to cut your ribbing strip longer. If you don't have a baby on hand, if the ribbing stretches as a little bigger than the cut neck opening, then it will be just fine.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/step%208.JPG)

Finger press the seam open and fold it in half widthwise so the seam is on the inside.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%209.JPG)

Divide the ribbing into quarters and place a pin at each point.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%2010.jpg)

Divide the neck opening into 4 quarters as well by folding it in half each way and marking the fold with a pin or marking pen.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%2011.jpg)

Match up the markings with the ribbing seam at the top and pin them with all raw edges together. Stretch the ribbing to meet the neck hole and pin as needed. It should look something like this.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%2012.jpg)

Sew the ribbing onto the neck hole with a 1/4â€™â€™ seam allowance. Stretch the ribbing as you go to match up the raw edges.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%2013.JPG)

Finish the seam using a wide zigzag stitch or serger to minimize fraying.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/Step%2014.JPG)

Thatâ€™s it! Hold it up and admire your work. Itâ€™s okay if itâ€™s not perfect, it was made with love and will do the job. This will be so well loved, you won't want to make just one.

![Pullover Toddler Bibs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Bibs/End%20Fence.jpg)

Happy Sewing! Did you like this tutorial? Come join me and find more free tutorials on my blog Blue Susan Makes, find me on Instagram @bluesusanmakes, and checkout all the fun handbags, patterns, and gifts for sale in my Etsy Shop. I am also hosting a yearlong Sewalong for my book. "Just for You:Selfish Sewing with Your Favorite SewCanShe Bloggers". You can find all the details here...we'd love to have you join us!

posts.title: Rifle Paper Catch All Sewing Caddy
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com Here at fabric.com, we have been absolutely in love with Rifle Paper Companyâ€™s fabric collection for Cotton + Steel. As is the standard for both of these amazing companies, their fabrics are quality and their designs are fabulous and modern. We used our favorite Rifle canvas print and one of our sewing patterns to create an adorable, super functional, and SUPER cute little caddy for sewing supplies, knitting supplies or just to hang around looking pretty!

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2188.JPG)

The By Annieâ€™s (as in Annieâ€™s Soft and Stable) Catch All Caddy pattern pattern is amazing. Bags can be tricky, and this pattern is laid out really nicely. There are cutting layouts, labels for your pieces that you can cut out, and VERY detailed instructions. Even a confident beginner can tackle this pattern with how each part of the bag is laid out in a step by step manner. I can say wholeheartedly and without reservation that the By Annieâ€™s line of patterns are thorough and informative- I highly recommend giving them a go. ####Hereâ€™s what youâ€™ll need for the project: * By Annie Catch All Caddy Organizer pattern * 1 yd main fabric (we used this floral canvas) * 1 yd lining fabric (we chose a Kona Cotton in navy) * 1 yd contrasting fabric (I only used two fabrics, so youâ€™ll need a bit more of the main and lining if youâ€™re going that route) * Coordinating Thread (this Aurifil is my favorite) * Soft & Stable * 1 yd Mid-weight fusible interfacing * 1 Â½ yards 1 1/2â€ strapping * 6â€x12 Â½â€ piece of cardboard of foam core * Wonder Clips If youâ€™re doing the pattern as written, you will also need one 9" zipper and four 1 1/2 â€œ rectangle rings. ####Let's Make It! You might have noticed that my bag looks a bit different. Hereâ€™s what I did to change things up and make the project a little faster and little more to my style: Probably the biggest time saving step was not quilting my main fabric to my lining fabric with the soft and stable in between. I just cut the pieces out that were too be quilted in the dimensions used after quilting instead of before. I basted these pieces together instead, with a scant Â¼â€ seam. Instead of making the handles from scratch and using hardware, I covered the top of the cotton webbing with bias tape and simply top stitched them down, sewing them to the front and back sides of the caddy before putting on the inside and outside pockets so the seams would be hidden.

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2185.JPG)

You can see the crease down the middle where I folded to get an even strip. Use the tutorial in the instructions for how to make double fold bias tape.

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2187.JPG)

I like the look and you donâ€™t have to get hardware or do any extra sewing! I cut my handles at 20â€ each. I also omitted the side pockets, and I used a different method of binding the unfinished edges.

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2188.JPG)

I sewed the binding to one side by machine, and brought it around to the front to hand stitch with an invisible ladder stitch. Iâ€™m pretty happy with the final product!

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2197.JPG)

It's good for knitting supplies, too.

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/IMG_2205.JPG)

####Alternate fabric choices This is such a versatile pattern, you can use all of your favorite prints for a bag youâ€™ll truly love. Here are some more combinations you might like: #####For the yarn enthusiast:

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/yarn_enthusiast.jpg)

Cat Lady Pouncy Ball Green // Cat Lady Friskers Lavendar #####For the Teacher:

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/teacher.jpg)

Picnic Canvas Apples // Kona Cotton Red #####For the Art Student:

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/art_student.jpg)

Design Basics Pencils // Paint Brush Strokes Sorbet #####For the Sewist on the run:

![Rifle Paper Sewing Caddy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rifle%20Sewing%20Caddy/sewist.jpg)

Trinket Spools // Kona Cotton Baby Pink Happy sewing!

posts.title: How to Sew an Underlining
posts.markdown:
Created by: Tie Dye Diva Patterns Today weâ€™re going to share with you a simple lining technique that can be used when sewing lightweight fabrics that are semi-transparent or need a bit of structure. With just a few extra steps, you can sew up those lovely fabrics youâ€™ve been avoiding because they might be â€œsee-through!â€ Underlinings are different from traditional linings in that they are considered a part of the main fabric after they are basted together. This makes them considerably easier to add to a pattern that doesnâ€™t call for a lining but your fabric does! ####Materials: * A garment sewing pattern that does not already include a lining (or you can remove the lining and substitute an underlining). We used Tie Dye Diva's Daffodil Top Pattern. * A lovely lightweight cotton fabric such as cotton lawn, voile, or dotted swiss for the main fabric. We used Liberty of London Tana Lawn Marble Hearts Bleach. * A lightweight lining fabric. We used Sheer Mist White cotton blend voile. * Pins * Thread * Sewing Needle 70/10 * Sewing Machine ####Step 1: Preparing Fabric Pre-shrink and press both of your fabrics. This precaution ensures your fabrics wonâ€™t shrink at a different rate and distort your finished garment.

![Sew an Underlining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/How%20to%20Sew%20an%20Underlining/Washed-Fabric.jpg)

####Step 2: Main Fabric Taking your main fabric, cut out the pattern pieces according to your patternâ€™s instructions.

![Sew an Underlining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/How%20to%20Sew%20an%20Underlining/Main-Fabric-Pieces.png)

####Step 3: Lining Fabric Taking your lining fabric, cut out the same pattern pieces again exactly as you did in Step 2.

![Sew an Underlining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/How%20to%20Sew%20an%20Underlining/Lining-Pieces.png)

####Step 4: Pinning Place each of your corresponding fabric pieces wrong sides together and pin all around.

![Sew an Underlining](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/How%20to%20Sew%20an%20Underlining/Pinning.png)

####Step 5: Basting After looking up the seam allowance given by your pattern, baste your layers together staying within that seam allowance.

posts.title: Sewing 101: Sewing With Sequins
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson of fabric.com Sequins can be seen everywhere lately, from fashionable apparel to home decor. Their glitz and glamour are adding sparkle to everything, and we at fabric.com are totally on board with sequins and the newest sequin craze â€“ Mermaid Sequins! We recently added a few more to our selection, and thought it would be the perfect time to show you how to work with them for your next project. Whether youâ€™re making a simple sequin pillow or a glamorous gown, these tips will help you tackle your project. Like the fabrics you see here? We used: 1) Starlight Sequined Mermaid Red Twinkle. This one would make an outstanding costume! Can you imagine how well those sparkly colors will light up?

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2301.JPG)

2) Starlight Sequined Mermaid Emerald. This one is the classic mermaid sequin to me, it would look right at home on a Siren in the depths of the ocean.

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2265.JPG)

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2268.JPG)

3) Telio Flashdance Mermaid Sequin Knit Ecru Gold. This one makes me think of a wedding. It would be just beautiful for bridesmaidâ€™s dresses, swags or table runners for your special day.

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2313.JPG)

4) Telio Flashdance Mermaid Sequin Knit Blue Black. This one is so stunning, with matte black on one side and a dark matte purple/blue on the other, it would look equally at home on a mermaid tail as a dragonâ€™s scales.

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2288.JPG)

When choosing the sequin fabric for your project, or the project for your sequins, keep in mind what youâ€™re looking for. Some sequin fabrics have a little stretch, like the Glitz Sequin & Mesh Collection and the Telio Flashdance Mermaid Sequin Knit Collection. This makes them a little easier to work with. You can make form fitting dresses, skirts, and costumes with ease. This comes from sewing the sequins onto a fabric with stretch. The Glitz are mesh fabrics, and the Flashdance is sewn onto jersey. Our Starlight Sequin Fabricsare sewn onto a polyester lining for a sturdier finished fabric with zero stretch. These can still be used for apparel, but youâ€™ll want to stay away from figure hugging dresses and skirts (it might be a little challenging to move in them!) Regardless of your sequin project, youâ€™ll want to use a lining for any garment. The back of the fabric is not comfortable against the skin, due to the threads that keep the sequins attached on the face side. The hardest part about sewing with sequins is that needles have a hard time sewing through them, so you have to clear the seam allowance free of them in order to sew properly. It is the safest method, with the best finished result. Itâ€™s also the easiest on your sewing machine and needles. However, weâ€™ll also show you how to sew something without clearing the seam allowance if you want to go that route. ####Preparing Your Seam Allowances For each method, mark your seam allowances before cutting so you donâ€™t go too far in. #####Method 1: This method keeps the line of stitching intact, which keeps the sequins in the rest of the line of stitching from coming out unexpectedly. Using a pair of scissors, lift a line of sequins up so that you can see their bases.

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2321.JPG)

The threads go through those little holes that you see there. You will want to cut the sequins so that those little holes are exposed, and you can work the rest of the sequin out. Those little suckers can be very stubborn!

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2323.JPG)

Continue until you have your desired area clear of sequins. #####Method 2: With a seam ripper and working from the back of the fabric, rip out the stitching in your desired area until there arenâ€™t any more sequins.

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2320.JPG)

Both of these are time consuming, but worth it if you are making something that you have to look at every day. If you donâ€™t clear the seam allowances, youâ€™ll end up with broken needles and jagged sequins from the right side of the seam. After you clear the seam allowances, sew in the method best for your fabric. For the sequin knits, you might want to use a jersey needle and a zig zag! ####Sewing Without Preparing Seam Allowances

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2328.JPG)

If you arenâ€™t planning to clear the seams, you CAN sew anyway. Be careful, however, because a lot of broken needles can occur, which can be a bit of a safety hazard! Needles breaking and flying off your machine can be very dangerous, so if youâ€™re going this route, be extra careful. Use a needle that is thin and sharp, not a heavy duty or denim needle, because they will get stuck in the sequins. Use a long stitch length and go slowly!

![Sewing With Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Sequins/IMG_2296.JPG)

If you can, try to stay in the channels between rows of sequins to minimize your contact with them and risk of needle breakage. Happy sewing with sequins!

posts.title: DIY Dip Dye Sweatshirt
posts.markdown:
Created by: Summer from @sevenpretty Hi friends! My name is Summer and I love to share my sewing on my Instagram account @sevenpretty. Today we are going to make a dip dye sweatshirt using a Telio bamboo rayon terry knit and Rit dye from fabric.com! This project was inspired by a sweatshirt that I came across online and actually purchased, but when it arrived I was disappointed by the low quality fabric and fit. Luckily, I can sew and knew I could make something just like it... but better! ####Supplies: * 2 yards of Telio Stretch Rayon Bamboo French Terry Knit * 1 box of Rit Dye Powder in Purple * 1 box of Rit Dye Powder in Tan * Thread * General sewing supplies I've worked with the Telio stretch rayon bamboo French terry from fabric.com before, and I absolutely love it. It is the perfect weight for anything from sweatshirts to joggers and the four way stretch makes it super cozy. It also washes great and doesn't pill even after many wears and washes. When the khaki color was restocked, I couldn't wait to get my hands on it for this project.

![Dip Dye Sweatshirt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Dip%20Dye%20Sweatshirt/Large_0395255.jpg)

####Let's Make It Before sewing with knits, I always prewash and dry the fabric. To make the sweatshirt, I wanted a drop shoulder pattern like my inspiration. I decided to use the free Hemlock tee pattern by Grainline Studio. I made a few modifications to make it more like a sweatshirt than a shirt. To make the modifications, I used a sweatshirt that fit me well for comparison, and lengthened the sleeves, shortened the body, and added 2.5 inch bands instead hemming. If you are not comfortable making minor modifications to patterns, you could easily use the Linden sweatshirt pattern by Grainline Studio.

![Dip Dye Sweatshirt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Dip%20Dye%20Sweatshirt/linden_pattern_grainline.jpg)

After I sewed up the sweatshirt, it was time for the scary part. The dye. I used the color formula guide available on the Rit Studio website to pick out my color and get the formula. I choose Neutral 1 #311 which mixed 1 tsp Tan and 1/8 tsp Purple per 1 cup of water, both colors are available at fabric.com here. I made my dye bath with 10 cups of water total, in a large pot with hot water. I got the entire sweatshirt wet and wrung it out first and then carefully placed the body in the dye bath about 2/3 as high as I wanted the color to go. I let it sit for a minute or two, kind of swirling the fabric around making sure it was coloring evenly. The color absorbed a few inches higher than the dye bath. Then I lifted the body out and left the bottom 1/3 in the dye bath for another minute to get a little darker. I carefully repeated the process with both sleeves at the same time.

![Dip Dye Sweatshirt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Dip%20Dye%20Sweatshirt/dipdye1.jpg)

![Dip Dye Sweatshirt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Dip%20Dye%20Sweatshirt/dipdye3.jpg)

After dying, I ran the sweatshirt under water in the sink until the water ran clear, then I put it right into the washing machine, followed by the dryer. If you want your colors darker, you could easily repeat the dying process. ####What I learned: The more solution the better. 10 cups was really the bare minimum. More would have been easier. Be careful but embrace the imperfections! I thought I had ruined the sweatshirt more than once, but this process is really forgiving. I accidentally touched the side of the pot that must have had a rogue color crystal on it and there was some color transfer onto the part of the sweatshirt that was left undyed. I ended up taking the dye higher than I originally planned to cover it up and other spots faded slightly after washing. I recommend using a Shout color catcher to collect any dye that may bleed during the first wash. In the end, I'm so happy with how this project turned out. I have a comfortable and unique sweatshirt that can be paired with anything from leggings and sneakers to a pencil skirt and heels.

![Dip Dye Sweatshirt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Dip%20Dye%20Sweatshirt/finished1.jpg)

Thanks for having me, fabric.com!

posts.title: Flamingos & Flowers Sewing Machine Cover Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Flamingo Toes Blog Hello Fabric.com readers! It's Bev from Flamingo Toes here with you today with a tutorial for this pretty new Sewing Machine Cover! Sewing Machine covers are great for keeping the dust off your machine when you're not using it - and this one has some great storage pockets on the side too. They are perfect for holding your scissors, seam ripper, a measuring tape - all the little tools you like to have handy when you're sewing.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover%20with%20Pockets.jpg)

I used the new Rifle Paper Co. line from Cotton + Steel for this - I couldn't resist those cute little flamingos. To add a little decoration to the front I created a simple Flamingo Embroidery design, I think it looks sort of like a flamingo cameo!

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Sweet%20Flamingo%20Embroidery.jpg)

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Flamingos%20and%20Flowers%20Sewing%20Machine%20Cover.jpg)

Let's get started on the tutorial! ####Materials: * 1/2 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Canvas Rosa Floral Natural * 1 yard Cotton + Steel Add It Up Party Hat * 1/2 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Lawn Flamingoes Ivory * 1/4 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Birch Periwinkle * 1 yard Fusible Fleece * 1/3 yard Trim for Side Pockets (optional) * 1 yard trim for around flamingo design * 9" x 9" piece of muslin * DMC Embroidery Floss - 3799, 352, 834, 500, 3810, 502, 3771 * 8" embroidery hoop * Marking pen * Flamingo Embroidery Pattern and Side Piece Pattern ####Cut out the following pieces: * 28" x 18" piece for main fabric * Two pieces 13" x 9" for outer fabric sides * Two pieces 9" x 12" for large pockets * Two pieces 5" x 9" for small pockets * From lining fabric cut: 28" x 18" and two 13" x 9" pieces * From lining fabric cut one 10" square for embroidery * From fusible fleece cut: 28" x 18" piece, two 12" x 9" pieces, 2 9" x 6" pieces, 2 5" x 4 1/2" pieces, one 9" circle Begin by tracing the embroidery design onto the Add it Up fabric.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Flamingo%20Embroidery%20Design.jpg)

Stitch the flamingo according to the pattern. If you need embroidery tutorials, check out my Embroidery Tips Page.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Flamingo%20Embroidery.jpg)

To create the little embroidery panel, remove the stitchery from the hoop. Along the line made from the hoop, sew the trim onto the fabric with the edging pointing in towards the center. Iron a 9" circle of fusible fleece to the wrong side of the stitchery. Place the 9" square of muslin on top of the stitchery so right sides are together. Sew all the pieces together, just inside your trim stitching line. Carefully cut a slit in the muslin, making sure you don't cut the stitchery underneath. Trim the seam to 1/4" and turn the stitchery right side out through the slit in the muslin. Press.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Flamingo%20Embroidery%20Design%20for%20Cover.jpg)

Press the 28" x 18" piece of fusible fleece to the wrong side of the 28" x 18" outer fabric piece. Fold the piece in half and mark the center. Place the flamingo embroidery in the center of the front half. Stitch in place just inside the edge.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Flamingo%20Design%20on%20Sewing%20Machine%20Cover.jpg)

For the small pockets, press the 5" x 4 1/2" fusible fleece to one end of the 5" x 9" fabric. Fold the fabric in half, wrong sides together. Sew the two side seams closed with a 1/2" seam allowance. Repeat for the other pocket. Turn right side out and press.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Small%20Pocket%20for%20Sewing%20Machine%20Cover.jpg)

Press the 9" x 6" piece of fusible fleece to one end of the large pocket piece on the wront side. Sew the small pocket in the center along the bottom edge, along each side seam. Sew the trim at the middle point of the fabric, so the top edge of the trim lines up the center point of the fabric. Fold the piece in half, wrong sides together and press.

![Sewing Machine Cover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20Machine%20Cover/Side%20Pockets%20for%20Sewing%20Machine%20Cover.jpg)

Created by: Flamingo Toes Blog

Hello Fabric.com readers! It's Bev from Flamingo Toes here with you today with a tutorial for this pretty new Sewing Machine Cover!

Sewing Machine covers are great for keeping the dust off your machine when you're not using it - and this one has some great storage pockets on the side too. They are perfect for holding your scissors, seam ripper, a measuring tape - all the little tools you like to have handy when you're sewing.

I used the new Rifle Paper Co. line from Cotton + Steel for this - I couldn't resist those cute little flamingos. To add a little decoration to the front I created a simple Flamingo Embroidery design, I think it looks sort of like a flamingo cameo!

Let's get started on the tutorial!

Materials:

  • 1/2 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Canvas Rosa Floral Natural
  • 1 yard Cotton + Steel Add It Up Party Hat
  • 1/2 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Lawn Flamingoes Ivory
  • 1/4 yard Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Birch Periwinkle
  • 1 yard Fusible Fleece
  • 1/3 yard Trim for Side Pockets (optional)
  • 1 yard trim for around flamingo design
  • 9" x 9" piece of muslin
  • DMC Embroidery Floss - 3799, 352, 834, 500, 3810, 502, 3771
  • 8" embroidery hoop
  • Marking pen
  • Flamingo Embroidery Pattern and Side Piece Pattern

Cut out the following pieces:

  • 28" x 18" piece for main fabric
  • Two pieces 13" x 9" for outer fabric sides
  • Two pieces 9" x 12" for large pockets
  • Two pieces 5" x 9" for small pockets
  • From lining fabric cut: 28" x 18" and two 13" x 9" pieces
  • From lining fabric cut one 10" square for embroidery
  • From fusible fleece cut: 28" x 18" piece, two 12" x 9" pieces, 2 9" x 6" pieces, 2 5" x 4 1/2" pieces, one 9" circle

Begin by tracing the embroidery design onto the Add it Up fabric.

Stitch the flamingo according to the pattern. If you need embroidery tutorials, check out my Embroidery Tips Page.

To create the little embroidery panel, remove the stitchery from the hoop. Along the line made from the hoop, sew the trim onto the fabric with the edging pointing in towards the center.

Iron a 9" circle of fusible fleece to the wrong side of the stitchery. Place the 9" square of muslin on top of the stitchery so right sides are together. Sew all the pieces together, just inside your trim stitching line.

Carefully cut a slit in the muslin, making sure you don't cut the stitchery underneath. Trim the seam to 1/4" and turn the stitchery right side out through the slit in the muslin. Press.

Press the 28" x 18" piece of fusible fleece to the wrong side of the 28" x 18" outer fabric piece. Fold the piece in half and mark the center. Place the flamingo embroidery in the center of the front half. Stitch in place just inside the edge.

For the small pockets, press the 5" x 4 1/2" fusible fleece to one end of the 5" x 9" fabric. Fold the fabric in half, wrong sides together. Sew the two side seams closed with a 1/2" seam allowance. Repeat for the other pocket. Turn right side out and press.

Press the 9" x 6" piece of fusible fleece to one end of the large pocket piece on the wront side. Sew the small pocket in the center along the bottom edge, along each side seam. Sew the trim at the middle point of the fabric, so the top edge of the trim lines up the center point of the fabric.

Fold the piece in half, wrong sides together and press.

Place a pocket piece on each of the side pieces so the bottom edges line up. Sew the sides together with a 1/4" seam allowance. This will baste the pockets to the side seams but also strengthen the seams.

Pin the edges of the main panel along the sides and top edge of the side pieces. You may have to ease the top a bit, just use lots of pins to hold it in place. Sew the seams with a 1/2" seam allowance. Turn right side out and press.

Sew the lining side pieces to the main lining piece. Leave an opening in one of the side pieces about 7" wide for turning. Place the lining and outside fabrics right sides together and sew around the bottom edge. Trim the seam.

Turn right side out through the opening in the lining and press. Top stitch the bottom edge, 1/4" above the seam. Hand sew the lining closed.

If you like, add a little ribbon bow to the bottom edge of the flamingo embroidery. And now you have a cute new cover for your sewing machine!

posts.title: Ruffled Top Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: The Sara Project Hey everyone! Sara from thesaraproject.com, and back with another great sewing tutorial for you! Here in Utah, the weather has just hit the 70â€™s, and Iâ€™m in full blown spring mode. As I have been making plans for my spring wardrobe, Iâ€™ve noticed that ruffles are having a HUGE moment in the fashion world right now, and Iâ€™m obsessed. Iâ€™m excited to incorporate this trend into todayâ€™s tutorial! Iâ€™ve taken a woven shirt pattern, and altered the pattern to add in two rows of ruffles that run vertically down the front and back sides of the shirt. Itâ€™s super simple and super chic. I decided to use a gorgeous Liberty fabric for my top because letâ€™s be honest, Liberty is the essence of spring! Letâ€™s begin!

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/styled3.jpg)

####Materials: * Fabric: According to the amount required on your pattern plus a little extra depending on how long your ruffle panels are. I used this gorgeous floral lawn from Liberty of London, and you can shop fabric.com's full selection of lawn here. * Woven shirt pattern (I used the Onyx Shirt by Paprika Patterns). Look for a loose fitting woven shirt that doesnâ€™t have side darts. Some other good options are the Scout Tee by Grainline Studio, or even the Archer Button Up Shirt also by Grainline Studio). * Clear ruler * Tracing paper * Tape, scissors and pins! ######Letâ€™s begin by altering your paper pattern to add in the ruffle panels. ####Step 1 On the front bodice pattern piece, decide how far over you want your ruffles to be from the center front. I decided on 5â€ for my top. Mark this on your pattern piece and draw a vertical line all the way from the shoulder to the bottom hemline of the pattern piece. (You can see my line highlighted in blue).

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/Ruffle1.jpg)

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle2.jpg)

####Step 2 Cut along this line we just drew. Make sure to label your pieces, bodice front and bodice front side panel.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle3.jpg)

####Step 3 Tape some tracing paper along each inside edge of the blue line just cut and tape. Using a ruler, measure a Â½â€ from each side of the bodice front and bodice front side panel to add a seam allowance to both front bodice pieces.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle4.jpg)

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle5.jpg)

####Step 4 Repeat steps 1-3 for the back bodice piece. ####Step 5 Mark 1â€ from the bottom hemline on the bodice front/back side panel; this is where we will pin the end of the ruffles, leaving enough room for the bottom hem.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle6.jpg)

####Step 6 Using the tracing paper, now we need to draw out our ruffle panel pieces. I decided to do a double ruffle, the front layer being less wide than the back layer. I also slightly decreased the width on both pieces from the middle of the panels to the hem/bottom edge. a. To figure out how long your panels should be, line up your front and back bodice pieces at the shoulder and measure along the side of edge of both panels. Multiply this number by 2 and you have your length measurement. b. To decide on the width, play around with how wide you would like your panels to be on your shirt. I decided to make my widest panel 3â€ wide, and tapered it to 2 Â½â€ at the bottom. My front layer with the smaller width is 2â€ tapered to 1 1/2â€. Once you decide on your width, make sure to add another 1â€ to both panels width for your seam allowance. You can either draw out the whole length and width of the pattern piece or cut it in half and make sure to cut the pattern out along the fold line going along the grainline to save yourself some time! (This is where you can have some fun. You could do one ruffle panel instead of two, or even make a wider ruffle for a more dramatic look.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle7.jpg)

######Now that our pattern pieces are all ready, letâ€™s start sewing! ####Step 1 Pin the bodice front and back at the shoulder seams right sides together and sew.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle8.jpg)

####Step 2 Next, we need to prep the ruffle panels. Start by finishing the outside edge length wise by ironing the raw straight edge (if you tapered your panels like I did) in Â¼â€, and then again at Â¼â€. Repeat for the bottom edges. Topstitch 1/8â€ along the bottom and one side folded edge to finish. Repeat for all ruffle panel pieces. On the other side of the ruffle panel (unfinished inside edge), sew two rows of basting stitch at Â¼â€ and Â½â€, lengthening your stitches to about 4.0, leaving the thread tails long for gathering.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle9.jpg)

####Step 3 Once your ruffle panels are all prepped, pin the center of the panel to the shoulder seam, and the bottom edges to the edge of the front and back bodice piece (remember to end 1â€ above the hemline).

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle11.jpg)

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle10.jpg)

####Step 4 Now gently pull on the gathering stitches and evenly space gathers to fit the front and back bodice edge, pinning in place. Repeat to other side.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle12.jpg)

####Step 5 If you are doing to layers of ruffle, repeat for the second ruffle layer, pinning directly on top of the first layer of ruffle. Baste the layers to the bodice front and back using a Â½â€ seam allowance. (3 layers in total).

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle14.jpg)

####Step 6 Now pin and sew the shoulder seams of the front and back bodice side panels right side together. Next, pin the inside edge to the bodice front and back pieces, on top of the two ruffle layers.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle13.jpg)

####Step 7 Sew at Â½â€ seam allowance. Iron. When finished it will look like this:

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle15.jpg)

####Step 8 Now finish the top according to the pattern instructions. (Sew side seams, set in sleeves, hem sleeves, finish neckline with bias tape or facing). ####Step 9 Letâ€™s hem our shirt! Fold the raw hem edge in at Â½â€ and the again at a Â½â€. Topstitch around the folded edge but make sure to start and stop at each ruffle, making sure to fold the ruffle out of the way when needed so that the bottom edge of the ruffle is free when finished.

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/ruffle16.jpg)

All finished! Thanks for following along! Happy spring and happy sewing, friends!

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/styled2.jpg)

![Ruffled Top](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Ruffled%20Top/styled6.jpg)

posts.markdown:
Created by: Sewbon Hello! Erin, from Sewbon, here today with a super quick and easy sewing tutorial to make a DIY Camera Strap. I love taking pictures and have wanted a pretty camera strap for a while now but they can be pricey. Instead of purchasing one, I made this one that I love in less than 15 minutes! Want to make one too? Letâ€™s get started.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-14.jpg)

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-15.jpg)

####Materials * Fabric â€“ I used the Telio Umbria Linen in Grey Stripe * Lace â€“ I used 3 1/4â€ Lace Fringe Abigail Victorian Trim in Grey * Faux leather fabric * 2 Swivel hooks * Leather glue * Clips * General sewing supplies ####Step One: Cut your materials as follows: -Cut the fabric to 36 inches long by 16 inches wide -Cut the lace to 36 inches long -Cut the leather scraps to 2 pieces, each 1 inch by 5 inches ####Step Two: Baste stitch the lace along the 36 inch top, right side of the fabric

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-1.jpg)

####Step Three: Fold the bottom of the fabric to the top long wise, sandwiching the lace between the two edges with right sides of fabric together. Sew the seam with a 3/8 inch seam allowance creating a tube. Turn the fabric tube right side out.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-2.jpg)

####Step Four: Fold one end of the fabric tube together and pass it through the eye of the swivel hook.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-3.jpg)

####Step Five: Fold the bottom of the fabric tube up and stitch the end to the strap 2 inches above the top of the swivel hook. Stitch this seam a few times so itâ€™s extra secure.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-4.jpg)

####Step Six: Using the leather glue, glue the leather strap to the camera strap, covering the stitch line. Using clips clip the leather in place while the glue dries.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-5.jpg)

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-6.jpg)

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-7.jpg)

####Step Seven: Repeat steps 4-6 for the other side of the camera strap.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-8.jpg)

Once the glue dries, remove the clips, attach it to your camera, and snap some photos! Tip: If your camera doesnâ€™t have a large enough hook to clip to, attach a split ring to the camera body that the swivel hooks can clip to.

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-11.jpg)

![Camera Strap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewbon%20Camera%20Strap/Sewbon_Camera_Strap_DIY_Tutorial-13.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Blue Susan Makes Hello sewing friends! Sarah from Blue Susan Makes here. My â€œbabyâ€ just turned 2 and he is busy, busy, busy! Since he can run now and is becoming a little more independent, I donâ€™t need to bring along so many things when we are out and about these days. So, I designed a smaller diaper bag that still has plenty of pockets to help me stay organized.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2035.jpg)

It has a wide base so it stands up easily in the car, and can fit a handful of diapers, toys, snacks, and drinks for a day the park. It has an easy to zip and easy to sew Sport separating zipper as well as handles that are long enough to throw over your shoulder one handed.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2036.jpg)

My favorite thing about this bag are the side pockets. They can easily hold water bottles and more, but I like to throw my keys and phone in them so they are easy to grab. The finished dimensions of this bag are 12â€™â€™ high x 16â€™â€™ wide x 5â€™â€™ deep Want to make one?
