Fold the handle in half, wrong sides together matching the folded edges. Press. Open the folds and insert a strip of Fusible fleece into one side. Refold the folds and press.

Topstitch 1/8 â€˜â€™ away from each folded edge. Cut two 3â€™â€™ pieces from one end of the stitched strip to make the D-ring tabs.

Sew a 7â€™â€™ fold in the center of the handle strip: Find the center. Place a pin 3 1/2â€™â€™ away from the center on each side. Fold the handle strip in half lengthwise matching up the topstitched edges. Sew on top of existing stitches between the outer pins. Backstitch at each end.. Repeat for the second handle and set aside.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%204.jpg)

####Sew the Exterior panels Prepare the D-rings by threading a tab through each ring and basting the tab ends together within the seam allowance. Make 4 altogether.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%205.jpg)

Place a Lower Exterior Panel right side facing up on the table. Position a d-ring 4 inches away from each side along the top edge. Pin in place. Lay an Upper Exterior Panel, right side facing down, on the lower panel sandwiching the tabs between the 2 panels. Pin in place.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%206.jpg)

Sew the panels together with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance. Reinforce the tabs by sewing a second line of stitching over them. Press the seam allowance toward the lower panel. Topstitch about 1/8â€˜â€™ away from the seam on the lower panel. Repeat for the 2nd panel and set aside.

Fuse a piece of Fleece to one half of the wrong side of the pocket. Make sure to use a pressing cloth or fuse the fleece from the fabric side. Itâ€™s no fun to melt fleece onto your iron! It is not necessary to fuse the fleece all the way to the edges. We will be cutting some of it away in the next steps.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%208.jpg)

Fold the pocket in half with right sides together and pin the long sides. The fleece should be facing out.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%209.jpg)

Sew the sides and trim the fleece away from the seam allowance.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2010.jpg)

Turn the pocket right side out, push out the corners, and press.Topstitch two rows of stitching 1/4 â€˜â€™ and 1â€™â€™ away from the folded edge. Backstitch at the beginning and end of each row. Repeat for the 2nd pocket and set both aside.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2011.jpg)

Make 2 pleats in the bottom, unfinished edge of the pocket. Use 4 pins to mark the edge at 2â€™â€™ and 3â€™â€™ away from each side. Pinch a fold at each inner pin and bring it to meet the outer pin to form a 1/2â€˜â€™ pleat on each side. Pin pleats in place and sew a basting stitch about 3â€™â€™ up each pleat. Repeat for the other pocket and set aside.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2012.jpg)

####Make the Small inside pockets and the zipper pocket. Pin the 2 Small Pocket pieces with right sides together. Sew around all 4 sides leaving a 3â€™â€™ opening in one side. Trim off each corner.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2013.jpg)

Turn the pocket right side out through the opening. Push out the corners with a dull point of a pencil and press the seams flat. Topstitch along one long side about 1/8 â€˜â€™ away from the edge backstitching at each end. Find the center of the pocket by folding it in half widthwise and finger pressing a crease. Pin the pocket to the center of one lining piece about 5 inches from the top. Stitch around the sides and bottom of the pocket and sew a divider line down the center.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2014.jpg)

Draw a rectangle on the zipper pocket piece using a pen as follows: Draw a 9â€™â€™ line 2â€™â€™ below the top edge of the zipper pocket piece and in the center. Draw a second 9â€™â€™ line 3/8 â€˜â€™ below the first one. Connect the 2 lines on each side to make a rectangle. These will be your stitch lines.(blue in the photo) Draw another line between the two lines with a little â€œYâ€ on each end.This will be your cut line (red in the photo).

Just take it slow and advance the stitches by using your hand wheel to make sure your needle doesnâ€™t break. Trim any excess zipper tape.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2018.jpg)

####Make the Large inside pockets Place the 2 Large Interior Pocket pieces together and sew 1 long side.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2023.jpg)

Lay the exterior panels face up on the table. Find the center bottom edge of a prepared exterior pocket and match it to the side seam of of the exterior panels. Pin the lower edge in place. Using the corner of a ruler, pin the sides of the pocket to the panel so they are perpendicular to the bottom edge.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2024.jpg)

Topstitch around all three sides 1/8â€™â€™ from the edge. Leave the pleat basting stitches in for now.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2025.jpg)

Fold the panels so that right sides are together again as in step 1. Pin and sew the 2nd side seam. Trim a triangle out of the zipper seam. Press the side seam open. You should now have a big tube. Turn the tube right side out. Slide the exterior end over the end of an ironing board. Pin the 2nd prepared exterior pocket in place just like the first one. I like to slide my ruler underneath the bag as I pin so that I donâ€™t pin it to the ironing board fabric.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2026.jpg)

Carefully turn the tube inside out again. Sew along the bottom edge of the pocket to keep it in place. Position the bottom of the pocket under the sewing machine and topstitch one side of the pocket from the bottom to the top. Backstitch 3-4 times at the top of the pocket. Repeat for the other side of the pocket.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2027.jpg)

####Install the Bottom Panel Find the center of each side of the exterior bottom panel. Find the center of the bottom edge of the Exterior Panels by matching the side seams and marking the fold on each side. With right sides together match the center on the long sides of the bottom panel to the center on the Exterior panels. Pin along each long side. Sew a 1/2â€™â€™ seam all the way through the end of each side.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2028.jpg)

Line up the bottom panel against the Exterior side seam and pin the center in place. If the Exterior panel fabric is a little longer than the bottom panel that is ok. Just make sure the difference is lining up straight. Pinch the corners so they lay flat. Pin and stitch with a 1/2â€™â€™ seam allowance. Repeat for the opposite side.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2029.jpg)

Repeat these steps to install the lining bottom panel, but this time leave a 4-5â€™â€™ opening in the center of one long side.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2030.jpg)

####Finishing touches Turn the bag right side out through the opening in the lining. Fold the raw edges of the opening to the inside and stitch the opening closed.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2031.jpg)

Push the lining to the inside and press along the edge of the zipper so the seam lays flat. Be careful to never put the iron on the zipper teeth, they will melt. Topstitch around the zipper seam about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the edge. Now you can thread the 2 zipper tapes together and zip up the bag. Itâ€™s coming together and looking so good! Unpick the basting stitches from the side pockets.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2033.jpg)

Finally, attach the handles by threading an end through the d-ring, folding it over 1/2â€™â€™ and then 1 1/5â€™â€™. Sew 2 rows of stitching through the folds. Repeat for the rest of the d-rings and 2nd handle.

![Diaper Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Blue%20Susan%20Makes%20Diaper%20Bag/Photo%2034.jpg)

Happy Sewing!

At this point we will take advantage of being able to open this panel and lay it flat to make it easier to sew the pocket on. The next pocket will be a little trickier to install.

Make sure to line up the zipper seams with seams pressed open, as well as the exterior panel seams. Sew along the edge with a 1/2 â€˜â€™ seam. It may be necessary to use a zipper foot to sew next to the zipper ends.

Trim a little triangle out of the seam where the zipper seams come together to reduce bulk and press the side seam open. Before sewing the second side seam install the first Exterior pocket.

Lay the exterior panels face up on the table. Find the center bottom edge of a prepared exterior pocket and match it to the side seam of of the exterior panels. Pin the lower edge in place.

Using the corner of a ruler, pin the sides of the pocket to the panel so they are perpendicular to the bottom edge.

Topstitch around all three sides 1/8â€™â€™ from the edge. Leave the pleat basting stitches in for now.

Fold the panels so that right sides are together again as in step 1. Pin and sew the 2nd side seam. Trim a triangle out of the zipper seam. Press the side seam open. You should now have a big tube.

Turn the tube right side out. Slide the exterior end over the end of an ironing board. Pin the 2nd prepared exterior pocket in place just like the first one. I like to slide my ruler underneath the bag as I pin so that I donâ€™t pin it to the ironing board fabric.

Carefully turn the tube inside out again. Sew along the bottom edge of the pocket to keep it in place. Position the bottom of the pocket under the sewing machine and topstitch one side of the pocket from the bottom to the top. Backstitch 3-4 times at the top of the pocket. Repeat for the other side of the pocket.

Install the Bottom Panel

Find the center of each side of the exterior bottom panel. Find the center of the bottom edge of the Exterior Panels by matching the side seams and marking the fold on each side. With right sides together match the center on the long sides of the bottom panel to the center on the Exterior panels. Pin along each long side. Sew a 1/2â€™â€™ seam all the way through the end of each side.

Line up the bottom panel against the Exterior side seam and pin the center in place. If the Exterior panel fabric is a little longer than the bottom panel that is ok. Just make sure the difference is lining up straight. Pinch the corners so they lay flat. Pin and stitch with a 1/2â€™â€™ seam allowance. Repeat for the opposite side.

Repeat these steps to install the lining bottom panel, but this time leave a 4-5â€™â€™ opening in the center of one long side.

Finishing touches

Turn the bag right side out through the opening in the lining. Fold the raw edges of the opening to the inside and stitch the opening closed.

Push the lining to the inside and press along the edge of the zipper so the seam lays flat. Be careful to never put the iron on the zipper teeth, they will melt. Topstitch around the zipper seam about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the edge. Now you can thread the 2 zipper tapes together and zip up the bag. Itâ€™s coming together and looking so good!

Unpick the basting stitches from the side pockets.

Finally, attach the handles by threading an end through the d-ring, folding it over 1/2â€™â€™ and then 1 1/5â€™â€™. Sew 2 rows of stitching through the folds. Repeat for the rest of the d-rings and 2nd handle.

Happy Sewing!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Shannon McBride Patch & Piece Pillow Makeover! I love combining patterns, textures and shapes to create something unique. I used these several fabrics to play off their patterns to piece in designs, or â€œappliqueâ€ if you will. For the grand finale, I used leftovers plus fabrics from my stash to create an awesome patchwork pillow.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/30.jpg)

####Supplies: * 1 Â½ yard Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Canvas * 1 Â½ yard Kaufman Metallic Gold Linen Blend * 1 yard Waverly Strands Tuxedo * Â½ yard Premier Prints Feather Silhouettes Coral * Â½ yard Art Gallery Canvas Reminder * Â½ yard Faux Suede Black * All purpose thread * Upholstery needle * Fiber Fill * Pillow Forms of your choosing * A few stash fabrics that youâ€™ve been waiting to use! For assembling the pillows, I used the same method for the floral word pillows, the feather pillows and the Aztec pillows. I sewed the two squares together with a Â½ seam allowance, along 3 sides, leaving the bottom side open. I clipped the corners and flipped it inside out, stuffed down the pillow form to allow extra fabric to topstitch the bottom seam closed. Once the seam was closed, I fluffed the pillow and voila! ####Floral Word Pillows: I love this Art Gallery Canvas fabric with typewriter-look lowercase letters. Note- this fabric does not supply a full alphabet, but a Â½ yard gets you enough options to form some desirable words. I cut a Â½â€™â€™ border around the letters I wanted to form the word â€œlove.â€ and the phrase â€œoh, hi.â€ I love the results of the lettering on the Rifle Paper Co. floral linen blend; the white almost looks electric. These finished pillows measure about 20â€ x 20â€. For each pillow, I cut 2 squares of the fabric measuring 21â€ x 21â€ to give a Â½â€ seam allowance.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/1.jpg)

I positioned where I wanted the letters to be, pinned them, and used a concentrated zig zag topstitch to applique on:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/2.jpg)

Following the enclosing method mentioned in the summary, this image shows how Iâ€™ve stuffed the pillow form down and pinned, to allow extra fabric to work with as I topstitch the seam closed:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/3.jpg)

Once the cover was sealed, I fluffed the pillow:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/4.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/5.jpg)

####Feather Pillows: This Premier Prints fabric has coral feathers printed allover, so I wanted to cut them out and form new patterns and designs by piecing them on other fabrics. These finished pillows measure about 16â€ x 16â€, so I cut two 17â€ squares of the Waverly fabric that balance the black and white pattern, so that it would be centered on the pillow. I cut out 18 feathers with a Â¼â€™â€™ white border, and positioned them strategically in the jacquard design of this Waverly fabric. This pillow plays directly off the pattern in the Waverly fabric; the feathers and the design line up just right, so visually, itâ€™s like creating a whole new fabric! I used a concentrated zig zag topstitch along the white border with metallic gold thread.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/6.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/7.jpg)

The feathers also resembled that of flower petals, so I cut out about 20 and positioned them till I had a flower blossom shape I liked based off the exact center of the square. I pinned the outer layer of the feather first, pinned and stitched them with metallic gold thread. I straight stitched within the borders of the feathers, as well as stitched randomly on the feather, creating an abstract grain look. For the center, I just folded over a feather and top stitched. Tip: make sure your machine is well oiled! This particular pillow was a bit tedious, but well worth it.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/8.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/9.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/10.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/11.jpg)

####Aztec Pillow: This pillow is so easy and so on-trend! For each pillow, I cut 17â€ x 17â€ squares of this metallic linen blend fabric, so that the finished size would be 16â€ x 16â€. I cut 10 triangles out of faux suede black fabric, and positioned them on the gold linen square. I experimented with a few different kinds of triangles and different shapes, landing on 2 designs. I pinned the design down and topstitched Â¼â€around all the borders. I even added a stitch design just to give a little something extra. Like the other applique pillows, this faux suede will have some shedding, so just pull and trim the threads as they unravel a little.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/12.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/13.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/14.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/15.jpg)

####Patchwork Pillow: To me, this is the wow-factor pillow. This pillow was inspired by a pillow Anthropologie carried years ago, and I just loved it. To create my own version of it, I played with the leftover fabric I had from the piece pillows as well as some fabric I had in my stash. Depending on the size of the pillow you wanted to make, determines how usable the leftover pieces are. I wanted a rectangular pillow and used fiber fill to make it a custom size of 15â€ x 20â€. ######The fabric I used for this pillow: * Leftover Waverly Strands fabric. I had just enough left off my original 1 yard piece to create a section on the front and used it as the backing. I also cut the selvedges off to create the fringe on the sides. * Leftover Rifle Paper Co. floral fabric * Cut some more feathers out of the Premier Prints fabric * Leftover gold linen blend fabric from the Aztec pillows. * Cotton + Steel Xoxo fabric from my quilting cotton stash. This color way is no longer available, however, there are still more colors available for this style. * Also from my stash, this Charlotte Moss linen fabric I drew this basic design out and started layering the fabrics on each other, designing what I wanted the order and shapes to be. The best part about this pillow design is that it doesnâ€™t have to be perfect! Anything goes. I started by free hand drawing a zig zag in pencil on the back of the XoXo fabric:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/16.jpg)

I followed the same line and cut the butterfly fabric to match:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/17.jpg)

I cut a few more feathers out, but this time cutting all the way to the print to avoid any white borders. I also wanted the points to be included in the seam allowances. I layered and played with the fabrics till I got the look I wanted, and started pinning and sewing!

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/18.jpg)

I cut the black and white fabric to follow the wave pattern, and pinned my layers together. Top stitching with a Â¼â€™â€™ allowance:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/19.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/20.jpg)

For each layer, I trimmed the back as I went to reduce bulk:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/21.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/22.jpg)

I used a variety of topstitches with aqua thread, as shown. I picked a zig zag stitch for the jacquard fabric to secure it a bit more. Like all the other pillows, there will be some fraying and a â€œsheddingâ€ period, but overtime, I want the frayed look to add texture to the pillows:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/23.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/24.jpg)

Once I had patched the front of the pillow together, I used a leftover piece of the black and white fabric for the back, but I used the opposite side. I also cut the selvedge off of the black and white fabric to use as fringe on 2 sides of the pillow:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/25.jpg)

For enclosing this pillow, I wanted to hand stitch it closed. So I left a very small opening along the black and white fabric portion, so that my stitches would be better concealed within the jacquard fabric:

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/26.jpg)

I used a Â½ seam allowance, clipped the corners and flipped it inside out. I carefully stuffed the pillows with fiber fill and hand stitched the opening closed using a slip stitch.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/27.jpg)

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/28.jpg)

Once closed, mold and fluff your pillows to get the fiber fill settled.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/29.jpg)

And done! Seven coordinating pillows that combine unique elements from each fabric. Enjoy!

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Patch%20%26%20Piece%20Pillows/31.jpg)

posts.title: Indigo Spring Quilt Free Pattern
posts.markdown:
Created by: Sarah Marrone @flashbulbsbroken This modern take on the Farmer's Delight quilt pattern is the perfect project to add a burst of color to your day, just in time for Spring! This quilt looks complicated and ornate, but comes together with ease. This is a great way to sharpen your paper piecing skills and conquer any apprehensions you may have with curved piecing. You can create an ombre effect with a mix of solids and prints, or experiment with other fabric combinations if you desire! Finished size is 47"x 47." ####Supplies: * 3/8 yard - binding fabric * 3 yards - backing fabric * 1 1/2 yards - background fabric * 1-2 yards - mix of fabric (solids and/or prints) * Free pattern- click here to download ####Fabrics We Used: * Michael Miller Cotton Couture Broadcloth Royal * Michael Miller Cotton Couture Broadcloth Breeze * Michael Miller Cotton Couture Broadcloth Midnight * Michael Miller Cotton Couture Broadcloth Sailor * Dear Stella Honey Bee Scallop Dot Powder * Dear Stella Honey Bee Butterflies White * Dear Stella Tea Party Steam Texture Navy * Kona Cotton Snow * Kona Cotton PFD Bleach White * Cotton + Steel Basic Sprinkle Anna Blue

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sarah%20Marrone%20Farmers%20Delight%20Quilt/IMG_20170423_140957.jpg)

####Instructions: Print out four copies of the paper pieces and cut them out, a rough 1/4" seam allowance is included (cut near the dashed line). Fabric can be cut into strips- just take the widest point of the paper piece and cut a strip. However, this is optional, and you can work with scrappier pieces as well.. Next, work through all the paper pieces. For each piece, you'll alternate between your background and solid/print fabrics. There are many tutorials online on foundation paper piecing if this is a new technique or you need a refresher. Once your pieces are done, go ahead and sew the following pieces together (do not remove the papers yet): 4a + 4b 3a + 3b 2a + 2b + 2c 1a + 1b + 1c + 1d

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sarah%20Marrone%20Farmers%20Delight%20Quilt/IMG_20170409_114004.jpg)

Trim all your pieces to the dashed line, find something good on TV, and remove the papers. Now onto the curved piecing. Again there are so many tutorials available online, and several different methods. I went with pinning, but there are also tutorials using glue or just using your hands. Find what works best for you and go with it! Practice on a few scraps to get the hang of it (and know that an iron + quilting will work wonders on any problem spots, I definitely had a couple). Sew together 7 + 6 / + 5 / + 4 / + 3 / + 2 / + 1 Repeat the above with all four sections and sew the sections together.

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sarah%20Marrone%20Farmers%20Delight%20Quilt/IMG_20170423_141108.jpg)

Prepare your backing and make your quilt sandwich. I decided to hand quilt this piece with big stitching to add more texture, but it could also be machine quilted. Because of the rounded corners on this quilt, I would recommend using bias binding if you have the time. I wanted a narrow binding, so I went with 2" strips. For bias binding you'll need a 26" square, for regular binding you'll need 5 - 2" x WOF strips. Have fun!

![Patch Piece Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sarah%20Marrone%20Farmers%20Delight%20Quilt/IMG_20170423_140912.jpg)

posts.markdown:
Created by Shannon McBride Rompers are always a wardrobe staple for babies and toddlers, and this closure-free knit romper provides ultimate comfort while showcasing major style. I know itâ€™s ultra-comfortable for little ones and a one-stop-shop for a quick outfit. In this tutorial, Iâ€™ll provide step by step instructions to create your own pattern and construct a baby/toddler romper. While the construction of the romper itself is an advanced sewist project that requires the use of a serger, the custom pattern making process can be applied to any project.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/1%20edit.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/2.jpg)

####Supplies: * Tri-Blend Jersey Knit (I used Grey, Royal and the light heather grey) * Kaufman Laguna Jersey Knit, I used Navy, Pepper or Onyx for ribbing and cuffs. * 4 or 5 thread Serger * Paper for pattern * Clothes for pattern template ####Making the pattern: Dress your child in a T-shirt and pants that fit comfortably. Measure where the T-shirt hem falls in regards to the pants waistband. Measure on the side for best accuracy.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/3.jpg)

Use the T-shirt and pants as a template for a pattern. For pattern paper, I used 3 sheets of printer paper taped together. Turn the pants and shirt inside out. Find the center of the front of the T-shirt and align it with one side of the paper.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/4.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/5.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/6.jpg)

Trace around the shirt. Most knit apparel items have a Â¼â€™â€™ seam allowance for serged seams, which is what I used in this project as well. To account for the arm holes, I used a sewing pin to poke through along the T-shirt arm hole seam. When you remove the shirt, you can simply connect the series of pinpoints to trace the correct armhole curve.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/7.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/8.jpg)

For the neck curve, I did the same because I did not include the neck ribbing. I placed the pants so that the overlap with the shirt would be 3 Â¼â€™â€™, according to my measurement I took earlier when my son was wearing the clothes. Placing the center of the pants along the edge of the paper with the T-shirt tracing, I used the same technique to trace the pants.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/9.jpg)

Once I had it traced, I drew a logical line between the armpit and the let opening.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/10.jpg)

For this romper, I wanted the look of a drop-crotch, so I decreased the inseam by lowering the crotch line about 1â€.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/11.jpg)

For the back pattern piece, I used the front pattern piece to trace as a template. I then extended the length of the shoulder seam, as the T-shirt does. I measured it on the T-shirt and applied it to the pattern. I extended it another Â¼â€™â€™ to add a seam allowance.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/12.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/13.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/14.jpg)

I also lowered the curve for the crotch seam to allow for a slight curve of a baby bottom. This isnâ€™t totally necessary, but it will make the garment lay slightly better along the bottom.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/15.jpg)

This romper has no closures, no snaps to mess with, Velcro, or buttons. So how are you supposed to dress your child in it or do a quick diaper change? The secret here is in a super stretchy neck. The neck has to be wide enough for your babyâ€™s shoulders and hips to go through comfortably, and the fabric has to have enough spandex to bounce back and not loose shape or pop the seam. To get a larger neck opening, I sketched a lower neckline and cut down both the front and the back pattern by about 1 Â¼â€™â€™ each.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/16.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/17.jpg)

The fabric I picked for this romper is this very lightweight tri-blend jersey knit. It would be perfect for the summer so my toddler would be comfortable and cool. Although it has some mechanical stretch, thereâ€™s no spandex in that fabric, but there is spandex in the Kaufman Laguna Jersey Knit I chose for the ribbing and cuffs, which is what will make this garment functional. For the ribbing, I cut three 1 Â½â€™â€™ x 14â€ strips, on grain, of the Kaufman Laguna Jersey Knit. For the cuffs, I traced the cuffs from the template pants, but I wanted a longer cuff, so I added 2â€. This made for a 6 Â½â€ x 5â€ rectangle. Cut 2 of the Laguna Jersey Knit, on grain.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/18.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/19.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/20.jpg)

####Construction: As mentioned, this is for advanced sewists, preferably familiar with sewing knit garments. If you are new to sewing knit garments on a serger, this is a great intro project. Always use a scrap piece of fabric to test the stitch, tension and stretch. I used a 4-thread overlock setting. #####Step 1: Right sides together, serge 1 shoulder seam.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/21.jpg)

#####Step 2: To attach the ribbing to the neck line: Fold one of the 1 Â½â€™â€™ x 15â€™â€™ strips in half, wrong sides together. Romper face up, right sides together, raw edges together, begin serging the neck ribbing on.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/22.jpg)

KEY: as you attach the ribbing, gently stretch the folded strip as you serge. This will make the garment lay better. If you donâ€™t stretch the ribbing as you go, the neckline will gape; if you pull it too much, the neck will be too tight and the fabric will gather. If you have not done this technique before, practice on a spare piece of fabric until you are comfortable.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/23.jpg)

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/24.jpg)

Trim any access ribbing and serge the other shoulder seam, right sides together. TIP: use a regular sewing machine to straight stitch the ribbing of the seam before serging, to avoid any crawling the fabric will do that could cause mismatched seams. #####Step 3: Serge both arm hole ribbings using the same technique as step 2.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/25.jpg)

#####Step 4: Right sides together, serge both side seams. #####Step 5: Serge the inseam. ####Step 6: Pants cuff: for each one, fold it â€œhotdogâ€ style, and serge the side. Flip inside out so that the cuff has a folded edge, right sides are showing, and raw edges are together, ready to be attached to the leg opening of the romper.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/26.jpg)

#####Step 7: Right sides and raw edges together, serge the cuffs to the leg openings.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/27.jpg)

#####Step 8: For finishing, trim your serge threads around each seam, and top stitch the seam with a regular machine to secure the seam on the ribbings.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/28.jpg)

For the back pattern piece, I made a slight convex curve for a better fit on the leg opening. For the leg opening ribbing, I cut two 12â€™â€™ x 2â€ strips of the Laguna jersey knit, and used the same technique as step 2, and finishing technique from step 8.

![Baby Romper](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Baby%20Romper/29.jpg)

Enjoy!

posts.title: Fabric 101: Canvas vs. Duck
posts.markdown:
In the vast world of textiles, youâ€™re likely to be overwhelmed with fiber contents and hundreds of different fabric types. We at fabric.com are passionate about fabric and understand that (even for seasoned sewists) it can be a bit intimidating trying to find the right fabric for your project, let alone differentiating fabrics. Not sure how canvas and duck differ? Letâ€™s find out! To understand which fabric will meet your needs, you first need to really understand what duck and canvas are. Did you know that duck is actually a type of canvas? Both fabrics are plain-weave, are made from cotton and are incredibly versatile. The main difference between duck and canvas lies in thread count. Canvas is known for its coarser weave, while duck boasts a smooth hand thanks to its high thread count. You can see here the difference in weave in canvas (left) vs. duck (right).

![Canvas vs. Duck](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/side_by_side.jpg)

Identifying duck and canvas is fairly easy. We classify our fabrics based on a weight system of ounces per square yard; the higher the ounce weight, the heavier the fabric. Browsing through fabric.com, youâ€™ll notice that canvas comes in heavier weights such as medium/heavyweight to very heavyweight, whereas duck will be more in the medium weight range. When it comes to projects, both plain and duck canvas give you a wide variety of options. You can use plain canvas and duck fabric for everything from durable clothing to accessories. Here are some suggestions for projects which are perfect for duck and plain canvas fabrics, featuring finished projects created by fabric.com customers: #####Baby carriers & stroller covers Baby carriers and stroller covers are a prime example of the balance between strength and softness. Hereâ€™s a great project one of our customers created for her stroller using Premier Prints Llama Love and Premier Prints Strike Sundown.

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/customer%20photo-%20baby%20carrier.jpg)

#####Lunch bags No need to spend money at the store when you can make your own bag using one of our gorgeous patterns. You can personalize it even more with a monogram! #####Homemade canvases Traditional art canvases can be expensive â€“ why not make your own? You can even combine small pieces of canvas with Popsicle sticks to make tiny pieces of art. Simply use hot glue to combine four sticks into a mini frame, let dry, and then wrap a small piece of canvas around the sticks, giving you a miniature canvas that you can use for playing with kids or handing out your own artistic creations. #####Window treatments Curtains and other window treatments can be one of the most expensive home decor projects. With fabric from fabric.com, you can design something unique while also saving money.

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/13697078_10104183724489655_2923431440519113627_n.jpg)

#####Headboards Headboards are an enjoyable project that let you personalize your living space. With canvas fabric, you can create something that is just your style without spending a fortune. #####Tote bags Tote bags are a great choice, especially for duck fabrics. You can make a full-size tote with just a yard of fabric, making them a simple, cost-effective project.

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/tote.JPG)

If youâ€™re creating one of the above projects, feel free to choose whichever fabric type you prefer! We stock everything from plain canvas to beautifully patterned duck, so finding the perfect fabric to create something beautiful should be a piece of cake! Because canvas is a heavier weight fabric, is can be used for projects that will see quite a bit of wear and tear. This includes anything from shoes and duffle bags to sturdy backpacks and aprons. If youâ€™re looking for an even more durable canvas, rhino canvas and sailclothâ€”made with synthetic fibersâ€”are a great option. Our personal favorite, however, is waxed canvas. Itâ€™s made from cotton fibers and treated with paraffin wax to add a cool look and feel as well as built in water repellency. Canvas is great for heavier projects, but cotton duck works well for a lot of projects due to its lighter weight. Not only is it lighter and with a smoother hand, itâ€™s much more pliable and easy to work with than canvas. These properties make it perfect for handbags and totes, draperies, light upholstery and even anorak jackets and blazers. The options are almost endless!

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/dsc_0178-003.jpg)

We are happy to carry a vast selection of high-quality canvas and duck fabrics in a wide variety of colors and styles so that you can create something truly unique. Here are a few of our current favorites: 1)Rifle Paper Co. Les Fleurs Canvas Floral

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/currentfaves1.jpg)

2) Premier Prints Vintage Camper

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/currentfaves2.jpg)

3)Kelly Ripa Home Make It Rain

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/currentfaves3.jpg)

4) Premier Prints Llama Love

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/currentfaves4.jpg)

5) Premier Prints Sioux

![Canvas vs. Duck](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Canvas%20vs.%20Duck/currentfaves6.jpg)

We hope you enjoyed this Fabric 101! If youâ€™re looking for a little inspiration or simply want to expand your fabric knowledge, check back often as weâ€™re always posting tutorials and informational posts. Weâ€™d also love to hear your feedback in the comments below about what youâ€™d like to see next!

posts.title: Five Handy Sewing Accessories
posts.markdown:
Sewing is truly an art, and as the artists say, youâ€™re only as good as your tools. If youâ€™re hoping to create a masterpiece, you need quality tools to help get you there. In the sewing world, this means a fully stocked basket of sewing accessories. Whether youâ€™re a novice sewist or a pro looking to simplify your craft, weâ€™ve got a few tips on the best tools to use. Believe it or not, sewing accessories havenâ€™t always been around; they were a result of seamstressâ€™ trying to simplify their trade. And so with the invention of the sewing machine came other tools to help make sewing less cumbersome. These handy tools were created with sewists in mind, to address well known problems and some you may not even have encountered yet! ####1. Needle Threader Even the most experienced sewists fumble with threading a needle from time to time, which is why there is a multitude of threading tools meant to make this an easy process. Desk needle threaders tend to be the most effective as you simply drop your needle in (any size except tiny quilt petites), rest your thread in the slot and press the button. The Clover Ultimate Needle Threader is our favorite and, quite honestly, a must-have for anyone looking to simplify the needle threading process.

![5 Handy Sewing Accessories](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/5%20Handy%20Sewing%20Accessories/Large_NR-580_needle_threader.jpg)

####2. Frixion Pens These clever pens have a huge following and, if youâ€™ve ever used one, youâ€™ll understand why. They can draw on both fabric and paper patterns and they utilize a gel that erases with heat. Simply draw out what you need and then iron away the evidence! If youâ€™re going to go this route, we suggest the Pilot FriXion Ball Erasable Gel Pens as theyâ€™re easy to use and get the job done.

![5 Handy Sewing Accessories](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/5%20Handy%20Sewing%20Accessories/0375099_gel_pens.jpg)

####3. Pattern Weights Ever try to cut a pattern from a delicate fabric only to realize that the pins snagged the fabric? Us too! Pattern weights are great as they allow you to cut patterns without the pins. We highly recommend these Dritz Pattern Weights if you use patterns often.

![5 Handy Sewing Accessories](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/5%20Handy%20Sewing%20Accessories/Large_NR-2204_pattern_weights.jpg)

####4. Acrylic Ruler Straight and accurate cuts are crucial parts of any project, but they can also be hard to achieve. Acrylic rulers make this easy, especially when used with a rotary cutter and cutting mat. Our personal favorite ruler is the Oâ€™lipfa Ruler with Lip Edge as its size (5â€ x 24â€) makes long cuts possible and it features a unique lip edge that keeps the ruler straight on the edge of the mat.

![5 Handy Sewing Accessories](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/5%20Handy%20Sewing%20Accessories/Large_NR-451_olipfa_ruler.jpg)

####5. Seam ripper Ripping seams can be quite frustrating and time consuming, which is why a good seam ripper made our list of must-haves. Tula Pink's Surgical Seam Ripper is a popular choice amongst sewists as it features a sharp blade instead of the normal tip and is a quick way to rip out stitches. This seam ripper is part of the overall Tula Pink Limited Edition Tools line, which also includes shears, micro-tip scissors, and a number of other tools designed to provide utility and style. The gorgeous coloring on these stainless steel Tula Pink products provides second to none style for your sewing room.

![5 Handy Sewing Accessories](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/5%20Handy%20Sewing%20Accessories/Large_0488106_tula_pink_seam_ripper.jpg)

posts.markdown:
By: Carissa Stevens of Scout Studios There is a huge soft spot in my heart for vintage furniture. They just donâ€™t make furniture like they used to. Vintage pieces have the best lines, they were made so sturdy, and you can always tell a difference in the filling. Thereâ€™s nothing like leaning back onto an old beautiful vintage sofa. You can FEEL the difference. Sure you can find replicas, but they just arenâ€™t the same. Iâ€™m always looking for vintage pieces for different clients. But trust me when I say this. 99.9% will always need a recover. No matter how much cleaning you do. Some stains just wonâ€™t come out. And usually the color doesnâ€™t go with the design plan. So an upholsterer is almost always necessary. Take for example this vintage piece I recently had recovered:

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/DSC_0321-min.jpg)

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/DSC_0310-min.jpg)

Isnâ€™t it stunning? I mean, this green velvet is EVERYTHING. But it didnâ€™t always look this way. Hereâ€™s what it looked like when I found it:

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/before.jpg)

A French Provencial antique sourced from a local shop that had closed? I was in love! It had such great bones. It just really needed a recover. Now it was time to find the perfect fabric. I knew that I was on a budget, and that I needed fabric that would be durable and sturdy enough to put up with my two dogs. Iâ€™m one of those dog moms who doesnâ€™t mind letting the pups on the couch. So durability was so important. (Dogs are people too!)

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/DSC_0298-min.jpg)

So I was the worldâ€™s happiest girl when I came across this gorgeous green velvet from fabric.com. Their site is great because it lists all the projects that the fabric would be suitable for, as well as a price point. (Plus they offer swatches so you can be 100% sure that what you are ordering is exactly what you wanted- and that itâ€™s the durability youâ€™d hoped for!)

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/fabrics.jpg)

Luckily Iâ€™ve had enough pieces redone in the past, and Iâ€™ve made mistakes. A lot of them. So hopefully sharing these tips with you will help you save money (and time) by learning from mine! There are several things I look for when Iâ€™m looking for a good upholsterer. ####1) Do they â€œgetâ€ my vision? Thereâ€™s nothing worse than dropping off a piece for a recover and picking it up and it looking NOTHING like what you expected. Not only has your time been wasted, but so has theirs. (Not to mention the cost of redoing it to get it how you want it.) So bring photos and sketches. Sometimes I even pop in mid job for a â€œdirection checkâ€ to make sure we are on the same page. ####2) Do they know what they are doing? When I was just getting started as a decorator, I didnâ€™t do my research. I hired the first person I could find online who labeled themselves as an upholstery expert. Boy, oh boy, was I wrong. Not only was the job done improperly, but the fabric Iâ€™d purchased was wrong. Even though the â€œexpertâ€ Iâ€™d hired told me it would be fine, it ended up being way too stretchy and after a month or so the shape was completely off. All this to say, hiring online is totally fine. Just research them first. Get references. Is this the first piece they have done like this? How long does a job usually take? How much time can they devote? Or is it something they just do on the side? (Also, totally okay, but always a question I ask up front so that I can manage my own expectations). ####3) Do they deliver? This is an important one for me simply because I donâ€™t always have a crew member available to help with the heavy lifting. Plus, my personal car isnâ€™t big enough, so delivery is always so nice. It saves so much hassle. Sometimes there is a fee, but it usually isnâ€™t much. Totally worth it not having to worry about how youâ€™ll get it home! ####4) Do they have the time? Iâ€™ve worked with upholsterers in the past who said they could â€œfitâ€ my job in. If you have a hard deadline, let them know up front first. If you plan on having friends over for a big reveal, or are having a party or whatever the case may be and need to piece there- make sure they know. ####5) Do they know their fabric? And are they going to be honest about it? In my early days of decorating for a living, I was working with a client on a super tight budget. We purchased fabric from a discount place that was labeled â€œupholsteryâ€ fabric. When I brought the fabric to the upholstery place, they said it would be fine and I believed them. Except it wasnâ€™t fine. The fabric was stretchy, and because it was stretchy, the piece didnâ€™t end up looking like it was supposed to. A good upholsterer, because they get your vision, will say, â€œHey. No. This wonâ€™t work.â€ And to me thatâ€™s invaluable. It will save you time and money in the long run. The piece will last longer, and youâ€™ll be happier. Just like I am with my gorgeous new sofa.

![Choosing an Upholsterer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Choosing%20an%20Upholsterer/DSC_0125-min.jpg)

Iâ€™d love to hear about your adventures in upholstery! Leave us a comment below and tell us any tips we missed. Weâ€™d also love to hear what upholstery projects you are currently working on! Click here to shop all the latest upholstery fabrics on fabric.com!

posts.title: Flamingo Pixel Quilt Free Pattern
posts.markdown:
Created by: Flamingo Toes Blog Skill Level: Beginner Hi fabric.com readers! It's Bev from Flamingo Toes here today with a fun FREE quilt pattern for you! This Fun Flamingo Quilt with free pattern is a great project to show off your flamingo style and it's just in time for Summer!

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20with%20Free%20Pattern.jpg)

It's a big throw quilt made up of pixelated squares so it's super easy to sew! No special angles of complicated piecing here. Just rows of bright summer fabrics that make up this cute tropical flamingo!

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Fabulous%20Flamingo%20Quilt.jpg)

I'm so in love with the aqua colors in that background - it reminds me of beaches and hot summer days. This is a great beginner quilt too! It's made up of simple squares so if you can sew a straight line - you can sew this! So let's dive in! ####Materials (for Finished Quilt Size - 63" x 83") You can select any quilting fabric on fabric.com for this quilt. The colors below are just suggestions! You'll want a pretty light color for your background, then youâ€™ll choose two highlighting fabrics that are a little different. Play with colors by saving swatches to the fabric.com Design Wall - this will let you look at them all in one easy spot! * Main Aqua Print in Background - 3 1/2 yards * Highlight Blue Print in Background - 1/2 yard * Highlight Green in Background - 1/2 yard * Medium Pink for Flamingo Body - 1/2 yard * Dark Pink for Flamingo Wing - 1/4 yard * Light Pink for Flamingo Beak - 1/4 yard * Black for Beak and Legs - 1/4 yard * Flamingo Print for Backing - 5 yards * Black and White Stripe for Binding - 1 yard * Batting Click here to shop for quilting fabrics! ####Pattern Download Click here to download the free Flamingo Quilt Pattern! Or, if you would like to purchase a low cost, ad free PDF version of this pattern that is designed for easy printing, visit my Etsy shop. Thanks! ####Cutting & Sewing This quilt looks complicated but it's really not - it's just a matter of sewing the squares together in blocks, then sewing the blocks together. It takes some time but it's totally worth it! Print out the quilt layout before you get started. This will help you know where the different colors go and how to sew everything together. I also realllllly recommend having a rotary cutter and mat for cutting out your squares. The process will go much quicker and be way more accurate over cutting them out by hand. #####Cut out of your fabrics the following 2 1/2" x 2 1/2" squares * Pale Pink for Beak - 5 squares * Med Pink for Flamingo Body - 108 squares * Dark Pink for Flamingo Wing - 22 squares * Black for beak and legs - 29 squares (cut another small 1" square for eye) * Main Aqua Background - 854 squares * Highlight Blue - 101 squares * Highlight Green - 80 squares Keep workable stacks of your fabrics near your sewing machine so you can pull each color square as needed. ####Assembly Instructions: (all seams are 1/4" seam allowance) Start with the top left block square on the pattern. Chain stitch together the 1st and 2nd little blocks in the top five columns by stitching the blocks right sides together along the right edge.

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Step%201-01.jpg)

Cut the blocks apart. Sew the column 3 blocks to the right side of the column 2 blocks.

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Step%202-01-01.jpg)

Repeat with columns four and five. Now you should have 5 rows of 5 squares each.

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Step%203-01.jpg)

Press the seams to one side on the back but alternate which side you press to for each row. For example, press the top row to the left, the second row to the right, and so on. This will help the seams nest together. Sew row one to row two - right sides together and meeting seams. I found it easiest to pin the first and last seam, the middle two usually met up at that point. I also didn't freak out if they were a little off. There are so many seams in this - and some of them will be off. If you adjust to that going in, you won't worry so much when it happens. :) Continue sewing the rows together until you have a 5 x 5 block.

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Step%204-01.jpg)

Press all the row seams down towards the bottom of the block. Now you've finished Block 1! Repeat these steps for the next block section but press all the row seams up towards the top of the block. Continue on across the top row of the quilt until you have six 5 x 5 blocks. These are the blocks in the top row of the pattern.

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Step%205-01.jpg)

Sew block one to block 3, right sides together and lining up seams. Continue sewing the blocks together until you have one long row. Press the seams you just sewed open. This is Row 1. Set this aside. Refer to the PDF pattern and repeat these steps down each row of the quilt. Because there are so many little squares, I found it easier to assemble each row as I completed the blocks. This keeps each block in the correct row and you can make sure you have the alignment and direction correct. Before you start piecing the rows together, applique on the eye by placing it on the flamingo and zig zag stitching around the four sides. If you have fusible webbing you can hold it in place before stitching with that. Refer to the pattern for placement. Once you have all eight rows finished, begin sewing the rows together. Sew row one to row two, lining up the block seams and pinning. Next, sew row 3 to row 2 and so on down the quilt. Press the long row seams open and give the quilt a final pressing. Quilt and bind as desired. Mine was quilted with an all over loopy pattern by Julie Williams. She did a great job!

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Sweet%20and%20Simple%20Flamingo%20Quilt.jpg)

I used a fun black and white stripe for the binding and this awesome all over flamingo print for the backing. They look so great together!

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Flamingo%20Quilt%20Back.jpg)

Now you can show off your fun new flamingo quilt! It would be a great gift for a flamingo loving friend too!

![Flamingo Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flamingo%20Quilt/Simple%20to%20Sew%20Flamingo%20Quilt.jpg)

posts.title: Choosing the Perfect Knit for Summer Maxi Dresses
posts.markdown:
Created by: Shannon McBride Maxi dresses are so chic and easy, from day to night, they have become a staple wardrobe item for warm weather. Over the past 5 years, Iâ€™ve made a few, bought a few, and worn them frequently. From my experience, here are some tips on how to choose your fabric based on the knit maxi dress you want to create. Let's explore the pros and cons of different fabric types!

Choosing the Perfect Knit for Summer Maxi Dresses from Fabric.com on Vimeo.

![Summer Maxi Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Maxi%20Dresses/Rayon%20Knit%20dress-min.jpg)

####Rayon/Spandex Jersey Knit: #####Pros: * Breathable * Very soft and comfortable on the skin * Drapes well * Well priced #####Cons: * Pills * High maintenance wash care * Clingy * Warps * Fades *Dress made with Rayon Spandex Jersey Knit Rose Cluster Black/Rose Quartz Rayon and Rayon Spandex jersey knits are extremely common fibers for knit maxi dresses. Rayon is a hybrid synthetic/natural fiber derived from wood pulp. It is very soft, silky and has a slight sheen and has excellent drape. The drape of rayon, its breathability, and soft feel against the skin makes this fabric very attractive for maxi dresses. Rayon typically has low abrasion resistance and low color-fastness, so over time it will pill. Because of its wood pulp origin, there is some wrinkling â€“ but not bad. Rayon can be thin and clingy when stretched, so it is best for a flowy maxi dress, not form-fitting dresses. The pilling and color fade will increase dramatically the more the fabric goes through a dryer cycle, therefore it is always best for rayon garments to lay flat/hang to dry. Because of the drape of rayon, it is best to lay flat to dry instead of hang dry, as the weight can warp the shape of the garment while it dries. But thatâ€™s a lot of fabric to lay out to dry! Indeed, it is. If you canâ€™t commit to wet fabric taking up that amount of floor space, you could hang the dress halfway over a pants hanger, so that the weight is evenly distributed. Whether you let the rayon maxi dress lay flat to dry or use the half hang method to dry, throw it in the dryer on a low heat setting for 5 minutes to fluff and take the wrinkles out. Dry cleaning is best, but that can get expensive. The first maxi dress I ever made was rayon. It lasted 2 summers because despite my knowledge of rayon, I dried it in the dryer anyway for convenienceâ€“ and after 2 summers, it was warped, faded, very pilled and unwearable. Rayon maxi dresses are comfortable and drape well against the body, but require a higher maintenance of care if you want to wear the garment season after season. ####Bamboo Rayon/Spandex Jersey Knit: #####Pros: * Durability * Soft hand * Breathable * Slightly easier maintenance than regular rayon * Color fast #####Cons: * Canâ€™t get wet while worn * More expensive Bamboo Rayon Spandex jersey knit is a more durable Rayon fabric â€“ it is more color fast and abrasion resistant than regular rayon. It is a thicker jersey knit too, making it ideal for form fitting maxi dresses as opposed to flowy ones. Bamboo Rayon does have a weakness â€“ water. It is so bizarre to wear a bamboo rayon garment in the rain! The rain drops will make puckers in the fabric from where the water has temporarily weakened the fiber. It goes back to normal after itâ€™s dried. So if you make a dress out of bamboo rayon, do not wear it if you know youâ€™ll be sweating or in the rain. For longevityâ€™s sake, laying a bamboo rayon jersey knit garment flat to dry is best and recommended. However, bamboo rayon can withstand the occasional dryer cycle from time to time.

![Summer Maxi Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Maxi%20Dresses/ITY%20knit%20dress%20full%202-min.jpg)

####Polyester/Spandex ITY Jersey Knit: #####Pros: * Color Fast * Wrinkle resistant * Drapes well * Cut edge does not roll/unravel, so you can leave them unfinished and it still looks great! * Doesnâ€™t pill * Low Maintenance wash care * Retains shape #####Cons: * Not Breathable * Absorbs odor * Clingy *Dress made with Stretch ITY Jersey Knit Black Another extremely common fabric type for maxi dresses is Polyester/Spandex ITY Jersey Knit. ITY stands for Interlocking Twist Yarn and refers to the way the individual polyester/spandex yarns are twisted before being knit up into a jersey fabric. The result is a fabric with a very smooth hand, and a stretch with stability. If you want a flowy maxi dress with bold, brightly colored print or a solid color knit maxi dress with a bit more elegance â€“ this fabric is ideal for that look. This fabric is colorfast, wrinkle resistant and has a wonderful drape. It can have a lustrous or matte appearance. In retail stores, I have seen this fabric widely used for flowy knit maxi dresses. Polyester, a synthetic fiber, has a high absorption rate â€“ which means it will retain its color and prints well. But it will retain other things too, such as smells â€“ so be aware that if you wear a polyester ITY knit maxi dress on a hot summer day, it is very likely that garment will smell pretty sweaty by the end of the day, and youâ€™ll probably sweat more than you would otherwise because the fabric doesnâ€™t breathe. Despite being cool to the touch, this fabric is not very breathable which will make it uncomfortable to wear on very hot days. So if you choose this fabric, I advise you to wear that fabric in a temperature controlled environment. ITY jersey cleans very well, so this garment can be easily washed and dried over and over without losing shape or color. Soft spun polyester jersey knit will pill, however â€“ ITY Jersey Knit will not due to how the fiber is spun and knitted into fabric, making ITY jersey a unique polyester knit, ideal for dresses.

![Summer Maxi Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Maxi%20Dresses/Cotton%20striped%20dress-min.jpg)

####100% Cotton Jersey Knit | Cotton/Spandex Knit: #####Pros: * Breathable * Low Maintenance wash care * Not clingy * Doesnâ€™t pill/very minor pilling over time #####Cons: * Not color fast * Not as nice of a drape * Wrinkles * Shape could warp over time *Dress made with Riley Blake Cotton Jersey Knit 1" Stripes Black 100% Cotton and Cotton/Spandex jersey knits are breathable, soft, durable, and provide a little more structure in maxi dresses. If you want a maxi dress with less drape than rayon to maybe conceal some body-conscious spots, but is ultra-comfortable and breathable like rayon â€“ this is a perfect fabric. Cotton jersey knit blended with some Spandex can provide even more structure and is ideal for form fitting maxi dresses like the one shown. 100% Cotton jersey knits are ideal for oversized or flowy maxi dresses. Over time, putting cotton jersey knit through wash/dry cycles will eventually warp and fade the garment. Granted, this could take years, but we want our creations to last a lifetime! I advise to use the appropriate detergent and let it air dry occasionally.

![Summer Maxi Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Maxi%20Dresses/cotton%20striped%20dress%202-min.jpg)

Jersey Knits also come in a variety of blended fibers. Blends are great because they can combine characteristics within the fabric. The higher the percentage of the fiber, the more that property will dominate. Decide what style maxi dress you want, where youâ€™ll wear it, when youâ€™ll wear it, and how committed you are to proper wash care. And ALWAYS pre-wash your fabrics. Happy sewing!

posts.title: Best Fabrics for Babies
posts.markdown:
We often celebrate new life with presents, cards and, of course, a lot of baby clothes! But what about creating your own baby clothes and accessories? Whether youâ€™re sewing clothes for your own bundle of joy or making them as a gift, handmade items are especially perfect for babies. Before you get started on your next baby project, however, we suggest paying special attention to a babyâ€™s needs, especially when it comes to choosing fabrics. Babies have sensitive skin and are unable to regulate their temperatures, so this should be taken into consideration when looking for fabric for your next baby project. Much like every child is unique, fabrics for babies come in a multitude of options! There are fabrics that can be used for baby clothing, bedding and accessories, many of which you can find on our baby and children's fabric page. ####Cotton Cotton fabric is the most popular choice for childrenâ€™s and baby apparel. Cotton is soft and highly absorbent, and it is gentle against a babyâ€™s skin. Organic fabric, and organic cotton fabric in particular, is the perfect choice for babies, as it is grown without the use of chemicals and fertilizers. Babies and toddlers often have allergies or specific skin conditions which can be aggravated by rough and/or synthetic fabrics. Using organic cotton is a safe way to ensure that children will be comfortable, even if they have skin issues which are triggered by heavy dyes and chemicals. ####Jersey Knit Cotton jersey knit fabric is another strong choice for childrenâ€™s and baby items, given its wearability. Jersey knit is breathable and easy to work with, making it an excellent choice even for sewing novices. It resists pilling and is very stretchable. Remember that the edges of jersey knit fabric can curl after washing; therefore, you can choose to leave the ends unhemmed, giving the fabric a fun curled edge that looks great on sleeves and bottom hems for tops. Jersey knit is also incredibly soft, making it a fantastic fabric for simple, fun apparel. Check out this great tutorial on making jersey knit baby rompers!

![Argyle Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Best%20Fabric%20for%20Babies/knit_2-min.jpg)

![Argyle Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Best%20Fabric%20for%20Babies/BabyLeggingsDIY12-min.jpg)

####Bamboo Rayon Bamboo rayon fabric is the perfect fabric for swaddles, blankets, hats, and garments. It is an ultra soft yet durable rayon fiber derived from bamboo plants. Itâ€™s great for sensitive skin and is thermal-regulating, meaning that it will adjust with a childâ€™s temperature and is therefore less likely to become too hot. This attribute makes bamboo a wonderful choice for layering. ####Minky Minky is a soft polyester knit fabric with a brushed pile that gives it an amazing plush hand. This fabric is great for cozy blankets and soft plush animals and toys. Itâ€™s not as breathable as natural fabrics, so keep that in mind for the climate and purpose of your creation. Fabric.com carries thousands of minky fabrics with short and long piles, embossed designs, trendy prints and a variety of solid colors to create the perfect blanket or plush toy.

![Argyle Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Best%20Fabric%20for%20Babies/minky_1-min.jpg)

####Fleece Fleece is known for its warmth, making it a go-to fabric for outerwear and blankets. Fleece dries quickly and is extremely soft, making fleece materials the perfect fabric for babies. Best of all, fleece is simple to wash and resists stains. When in doubt, choosing a fleece fabric is an effortless way to give the newest baby in your life some comfortable homemade clothing and accessories. ####Gauze Gauze fabric is the perfect baby fabric. Whether you pick single or double gauze, this cotton fabric is light, breathable, and airy. You might find it referred to as muslin in ready-made products for receiving blankets. Single gauze is just one layer of gauze, but Double Gauze is the real star of the show, featuring two layers of gauze that are tacked together at regular intervals. Japanese double gauze is highly prized for its ultra soft hand and opacity. Quality can vary due to dyeing, printing, and maker, so be sure to read carefully when purchasing.

![Argyle Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Best%20Fabric%20for%20Babies/embracedoublegauzemelody-min.jpg)

At fabric.com, we carry a wide selection of fabrics which are designed to fit a babyâ€™s needs. From texture to wearability, we have carefully chosen some of the best fabrics available and grouped them into a simple category page, so that you can find everything you need, all in one place. Happy sewing!

Cotton

Cotton fabric is the most popular choice for childrenâ€™s and baby apparel. Cotton is soft and highly absorbent, and it is gentle against a babyâ€™s skin. Organic fabric, and organic cotton fabric in particular, is the perfect choice for babies, as it is grown without the use of chemicals and fertilizers. Babies and toddlers often have allergies or specific skin conditions which can be aggravated by rough and/or synthetic fabrics. Using organic cotton is a safe way to ensure that children will be comfortable, even if they have skin issues which are triggered by heavy dyes and chemicals.

Jersey Knit

Cotton jersey knit fabric is another strong choice for childrenâ€™s and baby items, given its wearability. Jersey knit is breathable and easy to work with, making it an excellent choice even for sewing novices. It resists pilling and is very stretchable. Remember that the edges of jersey knit fabric can curl after washing; therefore, you can choose to leave the ends unhemmed, giving the fabric a fun curled edge that looks great on sleeves and bottom hems for tops. Jersey knit is also incredibly soft, making it a fantastic fabric for simple, fun apparel. Check out this great tutorial on making jersey knit baby rompers!

Bamboo Rayon

Bamboo rayon fabric is the perfect fabric for swaddles, blankets, hats, and garments. It is an ultra soft yet durable rayon fiber derived from bamboo plants. Itâ€™s great for sensitive skin and is thermal-regulating, meaning that it will adjust with a childâ€™s temperature and is therefore less likely to become too hot. This attribute makes bamboo a wonderful choice for layering.

Minky

Minky is a soft polyester knit fabric with a brushed pile that gives it an amazing plush hand. This fabric is great for cozy blankets and soft plush animals and toys. Itâ€™s not as breathable as natural fabrics, so keep that in mind for the climate and purpose of your creation. Fabric.com carries thousands of minky fabrics with short and long piles, embossed designs, trendy prints and a variety of solid colors to create the perfect blanket or plush toy.

Fleece

Fleece is known for its warmth, making it a go-to fabric for outerwear and blankets. Fleece dries quickly and is extremely soft, making fleece materials the perfect fabric for babies. Best of all, fleece is simple to wash and resists stains. When in doubt, choosing a fleece fabric is an effortless way to give the newest baby in your life some comfortable homemade clothing and accessories.

Gauze

Gauze fabric is the perfect baby fabric. Whether you pick single or double gauze, this cotton fabric is light, breathable, and airy. You might find it referred to as muslin in ready-made products for receiving blankets. Single gauze is just one layer of gauze, but Double Gauze is the real star of the show, featuring two layers of gauze that are tacked together at regular intervals. Japanese double gauze is highly prized for its ultra soft hand and opacity. Quality can vary due to dyeing, printing, and maker, so be sure to read carefully when purchasing.

At fabric.com, we carry a wide selection of fabrics which are designed to fit a babyâ€™s needs. From texture to wearability, we have carefully chosen some of the best fabrics available and grouped them into a simple category page, so that you can find everything you need, all in one place. Sewing Tips: Use a fine sewing machine needle. If your fabric puckers, try lowering your tension. The ideal seam finishing technique to use is a French seam. You can also use sharp pinking shears. Les Fleurs Flamingoes 3) Heather Ross Sleeping Porch Lawn Wildflowers 4) Kaufman London Calling Lawn Border Navy

Itâ€™s usually recommended, even if the fabric is opaque, due to the slippery and lightweight nature of it. Sewing Tips for Challis: As a lightweight fabric, challis also benefits from a sharp and fine sewing machine needle and a French seam, though it can still stand up to serged edges. You should always pre-wash or treat the fabric as you would after it is made into a garment, but for rayon â€“ skip the dryer. It is most commonly found in cotton, but also can be found in silk.
