posts.title: 7 Great Ways to Use Burlap
posts.markdown:
DIY projects allow you to try out new styles and put your creativity on full display. Of course, our favorite way to refresh our homes or decorate for entertaining is with fun fabrics, whether itâ€™s with a newly reupholstered couch or accents such as pillows or table runners. Burlap is a beautiful choice for dÃ©cor accents as it can be transformed easily. This loosely woven fabric is made of jute and has become popular in recent years after being the go-to fabric for rustic weddings. Its texture is perfect for creating rustic touches and the fabric itself is fairly inexpensive, which makes it an affordable option for updating your space. Weâ€™ve created a list of our favorite ways to add this popular fabric into your home: #### 1. Wedding DÃ©cor Rustic weddings are all the rage, and burlap is the best fabric to use to make your magical shabby-chic barn wedding a reality! Use for decorative swags, chair bows, pew bows, and table runners. A long length of burlap can be cut long ways to make 2-3 table runners that are completely no-sew! For a romantic look, layer lace, tulle, or chiffon in pastel hues and add fresh roses and peonies. Finish everything off with twinkle lights for a magical ambiance. Wrap burlap around your bouquets and add to boutonnieres to add burlap to your entire wedding party and youâ€™ll have the shabby-chic wedding of your dreams!

![Burlap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/7%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Burlap/iStock-482061200-min.jpg)

#### 2. Burlap pillowcases This might sound a little strange at first. Burlap on a pillowcase? But these are not pillowcases for your bed. They are purely for decorative use, or even on outdoor furniture. The benefit here is that pillowcases are relatively simple to make, and we carry high-quality pillow forms that can easily be covered. To make sure your pillow form doesnâ€™t show through, use a contrasting or matching closer-woven fabric behind the burlap. To decorate the pillowcase, you simply need some spray paint and a stencil. You can use spray paint over letters to create pillowcases with your initials, or could use a design such as a leaf or a holiday-themed designs. The spray paint will give your home some color, while the design allows you to perfectly personalize the pillowcase.

![Burlap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/7%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Burlap/iStock-668150966-min.jpg)

#### 3. Burlap table runner Table runners are perfect for adding some visual depth to a table. They are easy to make, and you can even add fringe to the ends. Table runners can be used to keep your table looking fun year-round, and can be specialized for different seasons, giving your home a unique look. Try using spray paint or fabric paint and letter stencils to add your name or a holiday greeting to a burlap table runner before your next family gathering.

![Burlap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/7%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Burlap/iStock-629113708-min.jpg)

####4. Burlap vase Burlap vases are among the most popular burlap crafts. You can find a number of ways to use burlap with vases online on craft-making sites. One popular choice is to make a burlap â€œsackâ€ which will cover a mason jar. That way, the sack can be used over and over as you switch mason jars out for cleaning. You can also use hot glue and burlap trim on any jar or vase. Fill them with flowers to make a lovely table centerpiece. You can also use burlap-covered vases as simple rustic wedding table decor.

![Burlap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/7%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Burlap/iStock-599762582-min.jpg)

####5. Burlap Pin Board Making a wall hanging with burlap is another easy project. You can get a blank canvas from an art store and cover it with burlap using glue or staples. The result is a â€œblankâ€ template for creating most any project you would like. You can use it as a pin board for pictures and postcards, or you can use fabric paint to create a design that is unique to you. You could even stretch ribbons across and use clothespins to hang memorabilia. Weâ€™ve even seen contrasting fabric pockets for an all-in-one mail station! ####6. Burlap Embroidery Hoop Art This is one of the more creative options out there: using burlap as a base for hoop art. The holes in burlap make it perfect for sewing-based projects such as this. Simply put burlap into an embroidery hoop, then sew on appliques, such as felt shapes. This is a fun project to do with kids, as they can use yarn and oversized needles for the sewing. Try adding some buttons to your hoop art to give some added depth, and soft materials to add texture.

![Burlap](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/7%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Burlap/iStock-668634808-min.jpg)

####7. Burlap photo frames Burlap looks beautiful when placed behind photos in frames. Itâ€™s easy, just cut your burlap the size of the frame, and put everything back together again. This is a quick project which will give your photographs a rustic look and will bring out the best in your homeâ€™s decor. Want to get started on one of the projects above? Fabric.com is your one-stop shop for burlap, offering a variety of patterns and colors perfect for any of the above projects. Let your creativity run free while you refresh your home with burlap! If you are ready to update your home with fabric, consider the many benefits of burlap. Click here to check out the selection of burlap fabrics available at fabric.com today!

posts.title: Sewing Tips With Knits
posts.markdown:
Created by Shannon McBride Knit fabrics can take many different forms depending on the fiber contents and the specific knit process used to create them. Jersey Knits, Interlock Knits, Ponte de Roma Knits, ITY (Interlocking Twist Yarns), and Rib Knits are all very common knit fabrics used for fashion apparel. Throw in some Lycra Spandex in the already large variety of knit fabrics and that can be very intimidating to sewers! But fear not, here are some tips and 3 solid stitches to sew easily with knit fabric!

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/all_fabrics_square.jpg)

####Walking Foot: A walking foot, also known as an Even Feed foot, will evenly feed the two layers of fabric through the machine at the same time. This prevents the fabric from being stretched out as itâ€™s sewn, which is why it is ideal for very stretchy knit fabrics.

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/walking%20foot-min.jpg)

A walking foot prevents your machine from â€œeatingâ€ your fabric. Very lightweight knits, or very stretchy knits often will get pushed down into the machine when the needle punctures at the beginning of a seam when using a general purpose foot. Knit fabrics that do not have that much stretch are actually better sewn using just a general purpose presser foot, which usually comes standard with the purchase of a sewing machine. The walking foot could actually feed the top layer too much, causing seam puckers. ####Seam allowances: When sewing with a regular sewing machine, I like to sew with a 3/8â€™â€™ seam allowance to ensure seam quality as it feeds through the machine, then trim down the excess. Knits will not unravel, so simply trimming them Â¼â€™â€™ from the seam stitch will reduce bulk.

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/seam%20allowance-min.jpg)

####Serger: A serger is a special sewing machine that seams, trims, and finishes all in one. A 4-thread or 3-thread overlock stitch is very common for knit sewing. Sergers are ideal for knit garment sewing and give professional results. ####Which needle to choose? The right needle can make or break your knit project! If the right one is not chosen, you risk sewing frustration with skipped stitches, or damaged fabric from needle punctures. I advise to have a variety on hand. These color coded needles are my favorite! Ball Point Needles :These are best, as opposed to a sharp needle, stretch needle or universal needle. The tip of the needle is smooth and rounded, so it can glide through the knit fibers, instead of piercing any fibers like a sharp (regular) needle could. Stretch Needles: Stretch needles have a slightly less rounded tip than Ball Point needles do. However they do have a longer scarf, so they can go slightly deeper to catch the bobbin thread. If you are getting skipped stitches on your knit project, try this needle. Universal Needles: Universal needles have the same scarf length as ball point needles and a slightly less rounded tip than Ball Point needles do so that they can pierce woven fabrics also. These will work fine on knits, however, ball point needles are best for knits with Lycra Spandex, or knits with very fine fibers.

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/table2.PNG)

Machine needles perform best when new. After about 8 hours of sewing time, they should be replaced. They could dull or bend, cause skipped stitches, or risk a broken needle puncturing your fabric. ####Machine Settings: What machine settings to use are a big culprit of knit sewing anxiety. With the vast varieties of knits available, thereâ€™s no one perfect setting to configure. The best advice is to test on scrap fabric before sewing your project. This will save so much time not having to undo stitches, save your fabric, and ultimately, save your project! #####Tension: For loftier knits or stable knits, like ponte or scuba knit fabrics, try a lower tension around 2 or 3. Around 4 is usually good for heavyweight knits. The 4-5 Tension range generally yields the best results with light to medium weight knits. If you have to use a tension above 6, your machine probably needs servicing. #####Stitch Length: Longer stitch lengths cause less warp on knit fabrics. Even though straight stitches should not be used for seams, straight stitches set to 4 stitch length can work for topstitching. Shorter stitch lengths (1.5 â€“ 2) should be used with a zig zag stitch to ensure that fabric doesnâ€™t pucker out of the zig zag when the seam is pulled. #####Stitch Width: Applicable to zig zag stitches, 4-5 creates a deeper, wider zig zag, and around 1-2 creates a narrow zig zag stitch. Every machine is different depending on its condition, so again, always test first! #####Stitch Settings: A regular straight stitch will usually not work well for sewing seams with knits, especially Lycra Spandex knits. There are ways to manipulate the fabric as you sew, but it is not ideal and will not yield the best results. It may sew nicely, however, but when put to the test, the seam will easily pop and break once stretched:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/knit%20popped%20seam-min.jpg)

#####Zig Zag stitch: A simple zig zag stitch will allow the seam to stretch without popping:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/zig%20zag%20grey-min.jpg)

Zig zag stitch across the grain with standard presser foot (not recommended, it stretches the fabric):

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/replacement%20pic.jpg)

Zig zag stitch, sewn across the grain with walking foot (recommended for stretchy fabrics): ####Narrow Zig Zag Stitch: A narrow zig zag stitch can be achieved by setting both stitch length and width low, while on a zig zag setting. This stitch can closely mimic the look of a straight stitch, allow the seam to stretch with the fabric, increase sewing speed, and reduce bulk in the seams allowance. This stitch is not recommended for skin-tight garments like leotards or leggings because when the seam is pulled tight, it will have a ladder appearance. A narrow zig zag stitch with a general purpose foot:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/shallow%20zig%20stripe-min.jpg)

As you can see, the seam worked beautifully without the need of a walking foot since this fabric doesnâ€™t have much stretch:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/shallow%20zig%20finish%20stripe%20matches-min.jpg)

Narrow zig zag stitch on stretchy fabric, used a walking foot:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/narrow%20zig%20zag%20stitch.jpg)

####Stretch Straight Stitch: Not all sewing machines have a stretch stitch setting, especially older ones, but most machines made within the last 10 years have a stretch setting. A stretch straight stitch is a series of forward and backward stitches that allow the seam to stretch, but with the appearance of a regular straight stitch. A downside to using this stitch is it is almost impossible to take the seam out if youâ€™ve made a mistake. Seam rippers, scissors and time might get it out, but the quality of the fabric will likely be damaged and warped. Another downside is that it takes longer to sew. Since the stitch itself is made up of several stitches, the speed of which it feeds through the machine is slower. This seam, however, gives great results when properly used! Stretch Straight Stitch, with a general purpose presser foot:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/stretch%20stritch%20stripes-min.jpg)

Stretch Straight Stitch with a walking foot, because this grey rib knit fabric is super stretchy:

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/stretchstraihght.jpg)

This fabric is super stretchy with 75% stretch, and there is only very minimal ruffling from using a walking foot with a stretch straight stitch. The image below is the result AFTER I pulled on it significantly. Success!

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Capture1.PNG)

Without a walking foot (Not recommended, too hard to control stretchy fabric):

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Capture%202.PNG)

####Our Favorite Knit Fabrics 1. Art Gallery Jersey Knit Pop Art Spring Blossom

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Art%20Gallery%20Pop%20Art-min.jpg)

2. Telio Reflection Hatchi Knit Gold

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Telio%20hatchi%20knit-min.jpg)

3. Riley Blake Cotton Jersey Knit Stripes Hot Pink

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Riley%20Blake%20pink%20%20stripes-min.jpg)

4. Kaufman Speckle Jersey Knit Natural

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/kaufman%20confetti-min.jpg)

5. Kaufman Laguna Stretch Jersey Knit Remix Crosses White

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/Kaufman%20crosses-min.jpg)

6. Telio Paola Pique Knit Seafoam

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/pique%20knit-min.jpg)

####Our Pattern Picks for Knits: 1. Sew Over It Heather Dress 2. Ralph Pink Roxy Dress 3. Jamie Christina Mission Maxi Dress 4. Grainline Studio Penny Raglan Tee 5. Cashmere Dartmouth Top 6. Megan Nielsen Axel Skirt 7. True Bias Hudson Jogger Pant (they have a Hudson Jogger pattern for kids, too!) 8. Simplicity 8212 Leggings

![Tips with Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20with%20Knits/IMG_0399_square.jpg)

Happy sewing with knits!

posts.title: Trends We Love: Chevron
posts.markdown:
We are always on the hunt for new and exciting patterns so you can always find something to take your quilt to the next level, but one trend that never seems to go out of style is chevron. This zigzag print can be found everywhere, from pillows to bathing suits and everything in between! Even holiday items are following suit, so itâ€™s no wonder this popular print has stuck around as a top trend.

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/PP%20basket-min.jpg)

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/clutch%20purse-min.JPG)

The word â€œchevronâ€ itself refers to the inverted â€œVâ€ which makes up this pattern. The singular chevron is often referenced as part of military or flag insignia, usually for denoting time of service. It should come as no surprise that the popularity of this simple pattern continues to be high. Like stripes or polka dots, the classics never go out of style!

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/outdoor2-min.jpg)

For quilters, this simple fact makes chevron patterns a wonderful choice for pieces that you create with the intention of passing down through generations. A well-made chevron baby quilt will look just as great in your grandchildâ€™s nursery as it does in your childâ€™s. A chevron quilt is very easy to piece, and can be made with only half square triangles (hstâ€™s) pieced together. The predictable patterning that comes with chevron fabric is designed to look great with complementary pieces in either solid colors or organic patterns such as florals. You can therefore use a chevron quilt in any room of the home and it will always look like it was made to be there. By carefully selecting your color and specific chevron pattern, you can create a beautiful, one-of-a-kind item that youâ€™ll be proud to display.

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/5.5.17%20minky%2C%20embrace%2C%20baby%20crib-min.jpg)

Chevron quilting fabrics have two features that make them perfect for quilting projects: they are fun and simple. The zig-zagging pattern is easy to piece, making it a wise choice even for beginners. And the design lends itself well to any number of color combinations, with each one looking different from the next. The simple style is perfect for everything from baby blankets to quilted comforters. Plus, chevron quilts make great gifts, even when you donâ€™t know much about the recipientâ€™s style. Simply put: everyone loves chevron.

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/minky-min.jpg)

Not only has the chevron trend not gone out of style, it has actually increased in popularity over recent years. Well-known popularity surges include Missoni taking chevron to the high-end clothing market beginning in the 1950s, and then refusing to give up any ground in the fashion world, as Missoni remains popular to this day. The chevron makes for simple coordination with other pieces, and is easy on the eyes. The same pattern that your grandmother used in her quilts now looks great on everything from clothes to walls to furniture. The chevron quilt has always been, and will continue to be, one of the most popular choices for quilters, sewists and DIY fans of all ages. As you consider your next project, take a look at the gorgeous options available on our chevron page. For simple styles, you can choose a single-colored pattern on a white background, such as this grey chevron option. Or, for something a bit brighter, this Riley Blake Rainbow Flannel is a fun choice. You can choose from thin or wide designs, with varying â€œzigs and zagsâ€ to make each of your creations one of a kind. All of our chevron fabrics are 100% cotton or cotton blends, making them breathable and soft - two features that are well-suited for blankets and other frequently-used home items.

![Chevron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Trends%3AChevron/Untitled%20Catalog10188-min.jpg)

Chevron's strength as a quilting and home decorator fabric isnâ€™t going anywhere. If you are looking to buy fabric online, chevron is a great choice as the design is familiar, letting you focus on color and stripe patterns to find the print that is right for you. Choose chevron for your next quilt, and be confident that youâ€™re sure to create something beautiful.

Created by: Sariella Studios Skill Level: Beginner (with basic knowledge of quilt block piecing) Welcome to the final installment of the fabric.com Summer Block Party! We have enjoyed this series so much and hope you have too! If you've missed any of the quilt block designs so far, you can catch up by clicking here. From the Candied Pineapple to the Nautical Stripe, there is something for everyone! Our last block in this series is the Half Square Gingham design by Sariella Studios, featuring fun flamingo fabrics. Nothing says summer like gingham and this easy-to-sew block has endless design possibilities! It is suitable for the beginner quilter with basic knowledge of quilt block piecing. Make a single block into a hotpad or mug rug, make four blocks into a mini quilt, pillow or table runner, or make a full quilt perfect for summer picnics!

![Half Square Gingham Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sariella%20Block/SariellaHSG1-min.jpg)

####Fabric Choices Flamingos are one of our favorite trending prints for summer, and fabric.com has a vast selection of flamingo fabrics for your next project. Here are the fabulous fabrics Sariella Designs selected for the Half Gingham block: Flamingos Floral Multi Mini Flamingos Pink (this one is no longer available but we love Topic Like Its Hot Flamingos as an alternate) Kona Cotton Punch Kona Cotton Snow Or, click here to shop all quilting fabric on fabric.com!

![Half Square Gingham Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sariella%20Block/fabric2.PNG)

####Pattern Download This block is made up of two half square triangle (HST) halves. One half being the pieced gingham squares and the second half being a single fabric triangle. The gingham HST is made up of twenty one squares in three fabric values â€“ light, medium and dark. To achieve a true gingham look, your medium fabric should have the value/color of an even mix between your dark and light fabrics, as if the two were transparent and overlapped. Click here to download the Half Square Gingham block free pattern for step-by-step instructions!

![Candied Pineapple Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sariella%20Block/SariellaHSG3-min.jpg)

The Summer Block Party is a wrap! We can't wait to see how your quilt blocks turn out! Be sure to tag us on Facebook and Instagram to show us all of your summer sewing creations!

posts.title: Fabrics We Love: Chenille
posts.markdown:
After youâ€™ve settled on your next home dÃ©cor project, youâ€™re faced with which fabric will best suit your needs and make the biggest statement. You take into account how soft the fabric is, its durability, color and general fabric characteristics. Given the endless options youâ€™ll likely have, it can be tough to choose which fabric is best. We suggest doing your research (especially when it comes to buying fabrics online), including quality, characteristics and durability. To help, weâ€™ve put together a few reasons as to why this fabric is one of our favorites for home projects. We think youâ€™ll love it, too! Chenille is one of our top product selections, as it is a soft, textured fabric which is perfectly suited for home decor. Chenille uses silken thread sewn onto cotton or wool in tight loops for a lovely 3-D effect. Chenille is commonly made from cotton, but can use synthetic fibers as well, especially for heavier-weight projects. It is a frequent choice for everything from throws to holiday stockings, and its popularity is easy to understand. There are two main type of chenille, one for utility uses that is commonly 100% cotton, perfect for towels, robes, and baby items â€“ and home dÃ©cor chenille that is better suited to upholstery and window treatments. Chenille comes in a number of colors and styles, depending upon your needs and personal tastes. You can narrow down your selections by color, pattern, weight, or even project type on fabric.com, making it easier than ever to find the perfect chenille fabric for your home. Here are three reasons why chenille is a great fabric:

![Chenille](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chenille%20ActBold/IMG_0383.jpg)

####1. Softness Cotton baby chenille is incredibly soft, making it a popular fabric for products which touch your skin, such as blankets, throws, pillows and comforters. This lovely feature also makes chenille well-suited for baby items, such as blankets. Chenilleâ€™s intricate texture is inviting to the touch, making this fabric perfect for gifts - whether for yourself or someone else. If softness is important to you, then Chenille makes a fabulous choice for a variety of fabric projects.

![Chenille](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chenille%20ActBold/baby_blanket.PNG)

Some of our favorite soft chenille fabrics are these Minky Chenille Soft Cuddle by Shannon Fabrics. One important point to remember is that cotton chenille becomes softer as you wash it. So follow the care instructions and youâ€™ll soon have soft burp cloths, towels, and more! ####2. Beauty When you are creating a handmade item using fabric, you want it to be more than just soft. For example, making your project pleasing to the eye can be as important as its feel. Your home decor pieces are almost always going to be seen before they are touched - therefore, beauty is an important attribute for any home decor fabric. Fortunately, chenille is also a perfect choice when you wish to add style to your space. In addition to its softness, chenille is also known for its beauty. One of the reasons why chenille is so attractive is the way that the chenille material can contrast with the background fabric. This contrast can create beautiful patterning, such as in our Monterey Gate Chenille, or combinations of both color and texture contrasts, such as this Fabricut Tsunami Chenille. Many chenille options also feature an incredible luster, making them extremely pleasing to the eye, and a wonderful choice for your next home style upgrade.

![Chenille](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chenille%20ActBold/Large_0514886.jpg)

![Chenille](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chenille%20ActBold/Large_0504975.jpg)

####3. Versatility When you choose a fabric for its softness and beauty, sometimes you are limiting yourself to the types of applications that are suitable for your choice. Chenille, fortunately, does not limit you in this way. It comes in a variety of weights, making it a perfect choice for lighter weight projects or even heavy upholstery projects, due to its incredible versatility. You can use chenille for everything from valances to throw pillows, bedspreads or upholstery projects - depending upon your chosen fabric weight. Our 10 ounce cotton chenille options, for example, are available in a number of colors and are well-suited for soft, fluffy robes and pillows. Or, consider some of our heavier weight options for slipcovers or heavy drapes.

![Chenille](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chenille%20ActBold/Untitled%20Catalog10201.jpg)

Chenilleâ€™s versatility makes it a great go-to for a variety of projects, which is why we suggest keeping it in the back of your mind when selecting fabric for your next project. Itâ€™s super soft and beautiful and great for transforming your home into the space of your dreams!

posts.title: Choosing Fabrics to Suit Your Home's Style
posts.markdown:
Created by: House Homemade Hello! It's Jessica from House Homemade. I'm so thankful to be back on the fabric.com blog! Today I'm talking about picking fabric that works well with your home style. Sewing new curtains or throw pillows for a room can completely change the space or work to drive home the look you're wanting. I know that for some people, choosing fabric from pages and pages of options on a website or rows and rows of choices in a store can be overwhelming. And even if that part isn't overwhelming, you might just need to put a name and a few visuals to help you define the look you're wanting. If any of this is you, hopefully I can help out today and start you down the path of finishing out a space with the perfect pick in fabric. Now, I'm all about the eclectic look. My advice is 'if you like it, use it'. I love mixing and matching fabrics and patterns between styles. I know, though, that some people like to stick with a specific feel for their space. So here we go. Below, you'll read about five different styles that I feel are trending and what fabrics I would use to achieve each look! ####Vintage First up, I'll start with the vintage look. I think these can best be identified as a retro feel with graphic patterns. To me, they feel casual and fun. I think the best way to get an updated vintage look in your home is to use more neutral, modern colors like the ones below.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%201-min.png)

1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 I used the first fabric in our bedroom when I first did a post for fabric.com about pattern mixing. You can find that post here. Again, my taste is totally eclectic. You don't have to stick to one particular style.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%202-min.jpg)

To complete the vintage look, pair any of these fabrics with brass, hairpin legged tables, mid century mod furniture, plants and wood tones.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%203-min.jpg)

fabric: lacefield tulum linen blend basketweave ####Chic The next style board I created is chic and these fabrics make me so happy. They say 'look at me' whether it's because of the prints, the colors, the scale or all three. These are bold and clean and glam.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%204-min.jpg)

1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 If chic is what you're going for, these fabrics can be paired with colorful or neutral walls. Clean, modern lines, bright whites and lots of textures.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%205-min.jpg)

fabric: covington venus basketweave caribbean ####Farmhouse I did my fair share of searching for farmhouse fabrics when I was helping with the decorating of my parents house out in the country. The farmhouse look consists of neutrals in greys, taupe and whites on casual woven or linen looking fabric. Lots of traditional pattern but in very muted, monochromatic colors.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%206-min.png)

1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 I didn't pick this for my design board but in my parents house we used this fabric as curtains on an entire wall in their living room. Since this print was a little more bold, I chose some fabrics like the ones above for pillows and upholstery. You can see more of their house here.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%207-min.JPG)

For the farmhouse look, pair these fabrics with natural or white washed wood tones, burlap, clean lines, white paint and elements from nature like leaves, plants, or.....antlers.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%208-min.jpg)

fabric: premier prints anderson check french grey ####Modern Traditional The next grouping you might like is modern traditional. I think of this as a more updated take on classic prints.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%209-min.png)

1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 Any of these could work for curtains, as upholstery on dining chairs or as throw pillows in a traditional looking home style.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%2010-min.jpg)

fabric: madcap cottage mill reef indigo I picture these fabrics with polished metal finishes, bright white woods and clean, crisp wall colors. ####Boho I saved my favorite for last. Boho is trending right now. To me, it's a mixture of tribal prints, a throwback to the 70's and a natural look. These fabrics are mostly neutral and very imperfect in such a relaxed, laid back way.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%2011-min.png)

1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 You may recognize the 4th fabric as I used it (in orange) to upholster a small wall in our hallway. It's such a cool print. You can see that project here.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%2012-min.JPG)

AND I used the 6th print to recover our porch chairs in a patio makeover I talked about over on my blog, here.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%2013-min.jpg)

While we're talking about outdoor projects. I might have sprinkled some outdoor fabrics into this post. Don't discount them. Most are great for indoor use as well and with kids and/ or pets, why not have something way more durable? A boho style is all about warm wood tones, wicker, plants, and wall hangings. Pair these fabrics with a plush, textured rug, a vintage chair, fringe or tassels and lots of greenery.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/House%20Homemade%20Fabric%20Styles/photo%2014-min.jpg)

fabric: lacefield medina granite basketweave I hope this post provided you with some ideas for recreating or adding extra style to a room in your home. I'd love for you to stop by House Homemade any time and to visit me on Instagram @househomemade. Let me know if I can answer any questions for you. I'd also love for you to comment and tell me which one is your favorite style board.

posts.title: Trends We Love: Faux Animal Fabrics
posts.markdown:
Animal prints always seem to be in fashion, from home dÃ©cor DIYs to apparel projects. Incorporating animal prints into design is a great way to personalize and make a statement. From zebra to giraffe to leopard prints, animal print fabrics add a glam element to any space or any outfit! Vegan animal prints give you the beauty of these types of designs in a more durable and cruelty-free form, which makes them a great, guilt-free choice for your projects. Today weâ€™re taking a look at the wide variety of vegan animal prints available on fabric.com so you can choose which type will suit your project best. ####Faux Leather Faux Leather Fabric, or Vegan Leather, is leather made out of synthetic materials instead of hide. With faux-leather, you might find something you canâ€™t replicate in nature â€“ vivid colors, exotic hide replicas, and more! We recommend using lighter weight apparel leather for fun mini-skirts, apparel accents, and lighter jackets and vests. And heavier weight faux leather for upholstery projects like headboards, ottomans, and more. #####Our favorite faux leather fabrics:

![ActBold Faux Animal Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/ActBold%20Faux%20Animal%20Fabrics/leather_fabrics-min.jpg)

1. Telio Perfection Fused Faux Leather Navy 2. Telio Perfefction Fused Faux Leather Gold 3. Richloom Faux Leather Reptile Saddle

![ActBold Faux Animal Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/ActBold%20Faux%20Animal%20Fabrics/richloomLeather_11-min.jpg)

####Faux Suede: Faux Suede features the soft brushed hand of real suede and it can be used for anything from backing blankets, like the Shannon Cuddle Faux Suede, or making trendy miniskirts and vests with the Telio Whistler Faux Suede, and even home dÃ©cor with this Udder Madness cow print suede that comes in a few fun colors. These Cow Print Poufs we made on the blog a few months back are a crowd favoriteâ€“ find the full tutorial for this project here.

![ActBold Faux Animal Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/ActBold%20Faux%20Animal%20Fabrics/cowhidePouf_3_square-min.jpg)

Another one of our favorite uses for Faux Suedes like Udder Madness are floor coverings- a bit unconventional but the results are stunning! The DIY Mommy created this "Rug for Under $50" tutorial that you can check out here.

Vegan animal prints give you the beauty of these types of designs in a more durable and cruelty-free form, which makes them a great, guilt-free choice for your projects. Today weâ€™re taking a look at the wide variety of vegan animal prints available on fabric.com so you can choose which type will suit your project best.

Faux Leather

Faux Leather Fabric, or Vegan Leather, is leather made out of synthetic materials instead of hide. With faux-leather, you might find something you canâ€™t replicate in nature â€“ vivid colors, exotic hide replicas, and more!

We recommend using lighter weight apparel leather for fun mini-skirts, apparel accents, and lighter jackets and vests. And heavier weight faux leather for upholstery projects like headboards, ottomans, and more.

Our favorite faux leather fabrics:

Our favorite faux suede fabrics

Faux Fur

We carry a huge selection of luxury Minky and luxury faux fur that is just like the real thing! These fabrics are perfect for making luxury throws for the home, backing baby blankets, creating costumes, and even making fun toss pillows.

Our favorite faux fur fabrics

Animal Prints

posts.title: From Pool to Play: Pineapple Cover Up Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Shannon McBride Pineapple prints are everywhere this summer, and what better way to appreciate this trend than a fun cover-up that can be worn even after that aquatic fun in the sun is over!

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Dress%20Poolside%20Action%20Shot-min.jpg)

This simple design made with our favorite Pineapple Rayon Challis can easily translate from a chic cover-up to a casual dress. Check out other pineapple fabrics on fabric.com by clicking here.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Dress%20Cinched%20Waist-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Dress%20with%20Headscarf-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Dress%20with%20Neck%20tie-min.jpg)

Let's start sewing! ####Supplies for this project: * Rayon Challis Pineapple Print (or another fabric of your choice)â€“ 2 Yards * Measuring Tape * Sewing Pins * White General Purpose Thread * Cutting Mat (Optional, but will make your life easier!) * Rotary Cutter(If you havenâ€™t invested in one of these yet, nowâ€™s a good time) #####This tutorial makes a size Small/Medium. Use this guide for other sizes: XS/S â€“ 65â€ x 28â€ S/M â€“ 66â€ x 30â€ M/L â€“ 67â€ x 32â€ L/XL â€“ 69â€ x 35â€

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/supplies.PNG)

This is a fun, easy project that requires a rolled hem and neck binding. It takes about 2 hours to complete. Itâ€™s constructed from just one piece of fabric and a bias strip, plus an optional sash. The finished dress measures approximately 32â€ long. ####Step 1. The goal is a 66â€ x 30â€ rectangle piece of fabric. Fold your 2 yards of Challis fabric hamburger style (across the width), till the cut edge measures about 33-35â€ from the fold. Then fold hotdog style (across the length), so that the selvedged edges are outside and folded about 15â€ over. Cut 15â€ x 33â€. Youâ€™re left with a 4 layered rectangle about so that the neck hole can be easily cut out in step 2.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Fabric%20Rectangle%20Fold%20measurements-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Fold%20Corner-min.jpg)

####Step 2. To create the neck opening, take your 4 layered rectangle, and at the folded corner, measure 1â€ down, and 5â€ wide.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%201%20Inch%20Mark_rotated.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%205%20Inch%20Mark-min.jpg)

Cut a curved line connecting the 2 points.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Cut%20Out-min.jpg)

Take the rectangle piece of fabric and fold it lengthwise so the V can be cut out. Measure 5â€ down and mark. Cut a straight line from the point to the outside of the neck opening to make the V.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/cutout.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/cutout2.jpg)

####Step 3. Roll hem the ~66â€ sides.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Rolled%20Hem%20Sewing-min.jpg)

####Step 4: Attach a 1 Â¼â€™â€™ bias strip binding around the neck.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Bias%20Strip%20Sew-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Binding-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Bias%20Trim%20Top%20Stitching_rotated.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Neck%20Binding%20Done_rotated.jpg)

####Step 5: Pin and stitch the V part of the neck binding.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/step5_1.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/step5_2.jpg)

####Step 6: Fold inside out so that the right sides are together. Fold your rectangle in half hamburger style again so that ends meet. From the shoulders, measure 10â€ down and pin the rest of the way down.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/6_-1.jpg)

Straight stitch the side seams just inside of the rolled hems.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/6_2.jpg)

####Step 7: Roll hem the bottom edges. ####Step 8: Iron press. ####Optional Sash:

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Sash%20collage-min.jpg)

Cut an 8â€ x 32â€ rectangle, right sides together, sew the length of it and one end, leaving the other end open to flip it inside out. Fold 3/8â€ inside and top stitch closed. Approximately 3 Â½â€ x 31 Â½â€ completed size. Press with an iron.

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/sash%201-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Sash%202-min.jpg)

![House Homemade Styles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Pineapple%20Cover%20Up/Sash%203-min.jpg)

That's it! We hope you enjoy this tutorial and are having as much fun with pineapple fabrics lately as we are. Happy Summer sewing!

posts.title: Sewing 101: French Seams
posts.markdown:
Created by: Nikki Johnson It can be difficult to pick the right seam for your fabric and pattern choices â€“ but the French Seam is one of our favorites! French seams create a perfectly enclosed seam on the inside of your garment. Theyâ€™re similar to flat felled seams in their final results, but I prefer French seams for their simplicity. Itâ€™s a little tricky at first, but once youâ€™ve got it down itâ€™s smooth sailing. Use this seam finish when you want a cleaner look on the inside of your clothes. Itâ€™s especially perfect for lightweight fabrics from our recent Fabric 101 post about summer fabrics. It can also be used on button-down shirts for sleeves that you can roll up without raw seams showing. Once you know how to make a French seam, youâ€™ll be using it in everything! Iâ€™ll be demonstrating on this Italian Designer Silk Blend Charmeuse. You can see that the shiny sides are the right sides and the matte sides are the wrong sides.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2707-min.JPG)

The mind-boggling part about French seams is that you begin by sewing the WRONG sides together, which seems counterintuitive. Bear with me â€“ it will work itself out! Sew your WRONG sides together at a scant Â¼â€ seam.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2711-min.JPG)

You can see that the shiny satin side is where we sewed it wrong sides together. Flip your fabric around so that your right sides are now together and the seam you just created is enclosed. Itâ€™s best to press it at this time for an accurate seam in the next step. You can see that the seam is already enclosed, but this isnâ€™t the side that will be facing outward in the final garment. We need to enclose the seam we made in the last step.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2714-min.JPG)

Sew another seam 3/8â€ on this enclosed edge (right sides together)

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2717-min.JPG)

Now your seam is enclosed and you have a beautiful finished seam inside and out! ####Inside:

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2722-min.JPG)

####And Out:

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20French%20Seams/IMG_2726-min.JPG)

If you donâ€™t make sure your seam allowances are perfect, you will get little stray threads on the right side, so keep an eye on that Â¼â€ and 3/8â€ mark! Happy Sewing â€“ the French way! Visit fabric.com to browse our vast selection of apparel fabrics for your next garment.

posts.title: Sewing With Activewear Fabric
posts.markdown:
Created by: Trish McLaughlin of Trish Stitched For the past few years, running has become a saving grace when Iâ€™m feeling overwhelmed and stressed out, and my adventures in running have taken me on many 5kâ€™s, a few half marathons and two full marathons. When I realized my two hobbies of running and sewing could come together, I was so excited! I didnâ€™t know where to start to make my own running gear. I researched all the patterns, drooled over fabrics I thought were appropriate, but felt stuck for over a year before I finally took the plunge. If you are feeling the same way, Iâ€™m here to tell you there is nothing to fear! When I first started sewing active wear, I was nervous. Would I be able to make pieces that would hold up just like my store bought items? But, just like sewing other wardrobe pieces, your handmade items usually last longer than store bought! With the right materials and tools, you can give your gym wear a new look and if anyone asks, â€œyeah, you made it yourself!â€ ####Choosing Fabrics: The number one fear I had about sewing activewear was what fabric to buy. Thankfully fabric.com makes it SO easy to find the right fabric for your project. A quick search of "activewear" will show a bunch of options for making leggings, sports bras, tops, and more! There are a few qualities that make active fabric different from regular knits. The first thing you want to look at is the content of fabric. Most active fabrics will contain polyester, nylon, spandex and/or lycra- contents that will give the material good stretch (and recovery) and should have the ability to wick away moisture. When buying fabric, keep an eye on the amount of stretch the material has (fabric.com has all this info in the description!). Each pattern will call for a different amount of stretch, and having your pattern ready to go will help when purchasing fabric.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0180-min.JPG)

####Fabrics I chose and what to make with them: * Moisture Wicking Diamond Knit Black: Great for leggings, would also be great for an after workout jacket. * Swimwear/Activewear Spandex Knit Stripe Turquoise: Great for Tops, Sports Bras, Leggings and Bike Shorts. * Activewear Spandex Knit Solid Turquoise: Great for leggings, tops and sports bras. * St. Maarten Swimwear Knit Stripes: Good for tops, shorts. * Athletic Mesh Knit: Great for tops. * Power Mesh Nude: Want to add lining and cups to a sports bra? This will help. Almost all of fabric.com'sâ€™s fabrics can be sent in swatch form so if you want to do a few fabric tests for yourself, buy a swatch! ####Sewing your activewear: * Before using your fabric, pre-wash! This will shrink any material and prevent dyed fabrics from bleeding when wearing. * Just like any sewing project, you need to use the proper needle. With active fabrics, a ball point or stretch needle is best.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0157-min.JPG)

Take your time! If youâ€™ve sewn with knits, or even slippery material, you know that all fabrics arenâ€™t always a walk in the park to sew with. For extra strength, sew your straight seam and in the seam allowances, finish with a zig zag stitch or serge and trim the seam. ####Make it professional: You donâ€™t need to sew with a coverstitch machine, serger or even a double needle, you can create beautiful professional pieces with the basics. Many machines have decorative stitches that you can use to create interesting seams. Test a few out on extra material!

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0163-min.JPG)

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0151-min.JPG)

####Store your fabrics: Not ready to sew with the materials you bought? Store them properly! Leave a note with the fabric content so you can remember exactly whatâ€™s in it and can easily pair it with the right pattern.

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0182-min.JPG)

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0184-min.JPG)

####My favorite Patterns: * XYT Top from Fehr Trade * Surf to Summit Top from Fehr Trade * Cora Tights from Jalie * Swim Shorts from Jalie * Simplicity 8339 * Sloan Leggings from Hey June Handmade * Pneuma Tank from Papercut Patterns * Dunbar Top from Sewaholic ####My Workout Outfit: Using Moisture Wicking Diamond Knit Black, Swimwear/Activewear Spandex Knit Stripe Turquoise, and Activewear Spandex Knit Solid Turquoise, I made a pair of Sloan Leggings and Simplicity 8339. I love exercising in this outfit and it was a breeze to create!

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0133-min.JPG)

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0137-min.JPG)

![French Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20With%20Activewear%20Fabric/DSC_0149-min.JPG)

posts.title: No Sew Dining Chair Upholstery Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Today we will show you how to reupholster your dining room chairs to look brand new! This tutorial can also be helpful if your chairs are already well-upholstered but are unappealing or don't coordinate with your space. If you choose the right Upholstery Fabric, upholstering your chairs can transform your dining room from dull, gloomy, and seemingly old to lively, classy, and cozy.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/chair%20before%20and%20after-min.jpg)

Before gathering any supplies, you need to establish a few things. The kind of fabric you use to upholster plays a vital role in the overall look of your dining room. It is therefore important to decipher what your dining room's theme color is and whether you want to match it or contrast it. For instance, if your walls are green, then you ought to avoid using red fabric that will provide a sharp, unappealing contrast. Moreover, when choosing the material's color, take note of your dining room's size. A small room requires bright colors to make it seem spacious and less cluttered. Lastly, the fabric chosen should be determined by how often the chair(s) is utilized. Toddlers in the house call for heavier materials that do not easily wear out or show stains.

####Supplies Needed: * Upholstery Fabric. This might require a screw driver.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/take%20apart%20chair-min.jpg)

Use tools to remove staples/nails to remove the fabric and foam. My chair only had staples, and I was able to get them out by wedging a flat head screw driver and plyers. If nails are present, use this tool to get them out.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/staples%20removed-min.jpg)

####Step 2: Foam cushion and batting Place the seat on the 2â€ foam slab and trace with a marker.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/marker%20on%20foam-min.jpg)

Cut the foam using either an incredibly sharp serrated knife (think Infomercial knife demonstrations) or an insulation knife. We used an incredibly sharp serrated kitchen knife!

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/cut%20foam-min.jpg)

Take the seat + foam and place on the polyester batting. Trace about 5â€ outside the edge and cut.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/cut%20batting-min.jpg)

Use the staple gun to secure the batting underneath, pulling tight as you go. Tip: Itâ€™s best to staple opposite sides until youâ€™re about twelve staples in â€“ that way the tightness will be even.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/staple%20batting-min.jpg)

Trim excess.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/trim%20batting-min.jpg)

####Step 3: Positioning and applying the fabric Position the seat so that the motif print is centered, balanced, and allows for at least 4â€ to secure underneath.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/fabric%20position-min.jpg)

The print for this fabric is still visible on the wrong side, so I can see where to mark and cut to get the portion of the fabric I want for the seat cushion. Staple to secure, trim excess. Tip: pin the fabric to the batting before you start stapling to ensure the positioning of the fabric print.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/pin%20fabric%20to%20batting-min.jpg)

####Step 4: Dust Cover This is optional, but recommended. Trace the seat cushion on the dust cover fabric, cut. Fold Â½ under and staple.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/dust%20cloth-min.jpg)

Reattach to the chair if necessary Voila! Your chairs are just like new!

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Chair%20Upholstery/after%20pic-min2.jpg)

posts.title: Pleated Sleeve Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Hey everyone! Sara Johansen of The Sara Project here. Iâ€™m back with another great sewing tutorial for you. At a recent family reunion, my sister-in-law was wearing a t-shirt with really gorgeous sleeves that were knife pleated from the top to the middle of the sleeve, resulting in a bell/ruffle effect at the bottom of the sleeve. I loved these sleeves so much that I immediately decided I needed to recreate them for myself. Itâ€™s a really interesting design detail that adds a little flair to any basic top, and itâ€™s totally on trend.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/styled4-min.jpg)

This tutorial works great for any woven top (t-shirt) pattern with short sleeves. I used the Key Largo Top by Hey June Patterns for my top, but another great option would be the Scout Tee by Grainline Studio. The original top is from J.Crew and is made out of a knit material, so this could work for a knit t-shirt pattern as well. For this version, I decided to use this really pretty rayon fabric from Fabric.comâ€™s French Designer collection. It was perfect for this top.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/styled3-min.jpg)

Letâ€™s get started! ####Materials: * Water soluble making pen

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo1-min.jpg)

* Fabric required for your pattern plus 1 yard extra for the sleeves * Rectangular ruler * pattern paper / tracing paper * matching thread * Pins ####Creating Your Sleeve Pattern Letâ€™s begin by creating our sleeve pattern. It looks like a lot more work than it really is, I promise! 1) First of all, using the premade sleeve pattern from your shirt, trace another copy on extra tracing paper. Make sure to mark just the bottom corner of your hem to use as a reference to add length in the next step.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo2-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo3-min.jpg)

2) Next we need to add 2â€ in length to the sleeve pattern for a more dramatic looking sleeve from the bottom hemline of the newly traced sleeve.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo4-min.jpg)

3) Draw a line down the center of your sleeve. 4) Now, measuring every Â½â€ from the center line, draw another line. Do this until you have about 15-17 pleats. Mine has 17.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo5-min.jpg)

5) Now on a blank piece of tracing paper, draw a straight horizontal line along the bottom edge of the paper.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo6-min.jpg)

6) Taking your pattern piece with all of the pleats now marked on it, cut along the first line drawn on the right side of the sleeves. Tape it on the right side of the new horizontal line we just drew, lining up the hem of the sleeve to the line. Measure and mark a Â½â€ line next to this piece. (Mine is marked in orange). Now draw another Â½â€ line next to this orange line. 7) Go back to your sleeve pattern and cut the next line off, and tape it next to the two line you just drew. Draw and mark another two Â½â€ marks next to it as we did with the previous sleeves piece.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo7-min.jpg)

8) Continue doing this until all of the sleeves pieces are cut and taped to the tracing paper along the horizontal line.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo8-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo9-min.jpg)

9) Now, using pins, fold all of your knife pleats on the paper pattern, pinning each on into place. Make note of the direction you fold your pleats. It doesnâ€™t matter which direction you choose, but make sure to fold the same way once you are working with your fabric, otherwise your sleeve pleats wonâ€™t make the right sleeve shape. You can tell when you fold your fabric that itâ€™s correct if thereâ€™s no fabric sticking up in the fold, but that it all matches up smoothly.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo10-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo11-min.jpg)

10) Cut out the top curve of your sleeve pattern using scissors, then unpin and unfold. ###Sewing a pleated sleeve Now your pattern is all finished. Letâ€™s sew it up! 1) Cut out all of your shirt pattern pieces. (The Key Largo pattern requires cutting two of the front bodice, I decided to cut my shirt front along the fold of the fabric, and made sure to cut off the front shirt bodice seam allowances before cutting. You can cut it however you like, fold or no fold. 2) Cut out two sleeves. (I had to fold my fabric â€œhamburger styleâ€ to be able to fit the width of my new sleeve pattern along the grainline of my fabric. 3) BEFORE you take the pins out of your sleeve pieces, make a little notch using scissors for EVERY pleat line along the TOP of your sleeve. Donâ€™t worry about doing this to the bottom because our pleats are going to end half down the sleeve.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo12-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo13-min.jpg)

4) Now unpin and remove the pattern piece from your sleeves. 5) Hem both of your sleeves by ironing and folding the bottom edge Â¼â€ and then another Â¼â€, and edgestitch along the fold line to finish.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo14-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo15-min.jpg)

6) Using your water soluble pen, draw a line from top to bottom on the front side of your fabric along the center of your sleeve.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo16-min.JPG)

7) Draw another line on the back side of the fabric HORIZONALLTY measuring 4â€ from the hem. This will be your stopping line for each pleat as you sew them.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo17-min.JPG)

8) Now following the notches we cut along the top of the sleeve, draw your pleats lines using a water soluble pen and a ruler, and make sure each line is Â½â€ apart, moving from the center of the sleeve to the edge. Make sure to really draw your lines where the notches are!

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo18-min.JPG)

9) Once you have marked all your pleat lines, youâ€™re ready to start sewing. Before you start sewing make sure you are folding the pleats in the right direction that you originally folded them, like I mentioned in step 9. Youâ€™ll know youâ€™re folding them correctly if they fit together without any fabric sticking out along the top of the sleeve. Find your direction. 10) Sewing these up is really easy. Get your iron set up and ready to go. You will fold the first pleat on the front side of the sleeve, skipping over one line (a fold line) and matching to the next line. (Covering three lines per pleat). Iron, but be careful not to iron the bottom part of your sleeve so it looks nice and flowy once itâ€™s finished.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo19-min.JPG)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo20-min.JPG)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo21-min.JPG)

11) Now, turn your sleeve over to the back and sew along the fold you just made, stopping at the horizontal line we drew along the back of the sleeve. Make sure to backstitch at beginning and end of your stitching line.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo22-min.JPG)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo23-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo24-min.jpg)

12) Repeat until both of your sleeves are finished!

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo25-min.JPG)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo26-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo27-min.jpg)

13) Sew the shoulder seams right sides together. Finish seam as desired.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo34-min.jpg)

14) Now, along the top of each sleeve, sew one row of basting stitches.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo28-min.jpg)

15) Attach your sleeve to the armhole, following the directions of you pattern, and sew in the sleeves. Finish the seam as desired.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo29-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo30-min.jpg)

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo31-min.jpg)

16) Finish the rest of the shirt as the pattern suggests, these instructions are specifically for the Key Largo Top by Hey June Patterns: a. Sew up the side seams and under arm seam in one go. Finish Seam as desired.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/photo32-min.jpg)

b. Hem the bottom of the shirt, and finish the neckline of the shirt as desired or according to your pattern. For my top, using the Key Largo pattern, I chose to finish the neckline with an exposed binding.

![Pleated Sleeve](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sara%20Project%20Pleated%20Sleeve/styled1-min.jpg)

Thatâ€™s all there is to it! Happy sewing friends!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Hand Slip Stitch
posts.markdown:
The slip stitch, sometimes referred to as a ladder stitch, is an effective easy way to close up seams that require stuffing, or discreet seams that cannot be sewn with a sewing machine. Sewing a slip stitch by hand continues the look of a seam without seeing visible stitches. Use this hand stitch to enclose seams for stuffed toys, pillows, apparel lining, and mitered corners.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/collage-min.JPG)

Depending on the project and fabric, determine if a doubling your thread or single thread is best. For this tutorial, a double thread of contrast color is used. ####Step 1 Knot the thread and insert needle inside the seam allowance along where the seam should continue:

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%201-min.jpg)

####Step 2 Insert needle directly across into the other seam allowance. Push the needle through the underside of the seam allowance and reemerge about 1/8â€ out to continue to the ladder formation joining the 2 fabrics:

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%202-min.jpg)

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%202%20ladder-min.jpg)

####Step 3 Once the seam is joined, pull the thread so that the fabrics are firmly together, the thread is secure and no gathering occurs:

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%203-min.jpg)

####Step 4 Knot the thread off twice:

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%204%20knot-min.jpg)

####Step 5 Insert the needle and thread into the seam and reemerge in an insignificant location. Pull the thread so that you can snip the thread at the base of where it comes out the fabric. The thread end will be lost inside the project.

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%205%20hide%20thread-min.jpg)

![Chair Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Hand%20Slip%20Stitch/Slip%20Stitch%20Step%205%20cut%20thread-min.jpg)

Form the finished result:

posts.html:
The slip stitch, sometimes referred to as a ladder stitch, is an effective easy way to close up seams that require stuffing, or discreet seams that cannot be sewn with a sewing machine. Sewing a slip stitch by hand continues the look of a seam without seeing visible stitches.

Use this hand stitch to enclose seams for stuffed toys, pillows, apparel lining, and mitered corners.

Depending on the project and fabric, determine if a doubling your thread or single thread is best. For this tutorial, a double thread of contrast color is used.

Step 1

Knot the thread and insert needle inside the seam allowance along where the seam should continue:

Step 2

Insert needle directly across into the other seam allowance. Push the needle through the underside of the seam allowance and reemerge about 1/8â€ out to continue to the ladder formation joining the 2 fabrics:

Step 3

Once the seam is joined, pull the thread so that the fabrics are firmly together, the thread is secure and no gathering occurs:

Step 4

Knot the thread off twice:

Step 5

Insert the needle and thread into the seam and reemerge in an insignificant location. Pull the thread so that you can snip the thread at the base of where it comes out the fabric. The thread end will be lost inside the project.

Form the finished result:

Happy Sewing!

posts.title: 5 Tips for Sewing with Double Brushed Poly Knits
posts.markdown:
Created by Tie Dye Diva Sewing Patterns Letâ€™s dispel some fear about working with one of our favorite super soft fabrics, Double Brushed Poly (DBP)! DBP fabric has gained popularity recently as the perfect leggings fabric, but weâ€™re beginning to see it being used for many more types of garments that call for a light to mid-weight knit fabric. Itâ€™s not surprising either! Who wouldnâ€™t want to drape their bodies in this incredibly soft fabric? DBP is a 4-way stretch knit made of 96% polyester/4% spandex. It has also undergone a process where both sides of the fabric are brushed, creating that characteristic suede like feel on both sides, which you can see in the underside of the fabric in the flutter sleeves.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/texture-1-min.jpg)

It has excellent recovery and lovely drape, making DBP an excellent fabric for tops, dresses, skirts, and especially leggings.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/pink-shorties-1-min.jpg)

Today weâ€™re going to share some very simple tips on sewing with DBP. In our examples, weâ€™re using the Opal Knit Flutter Dress and Sterling Shorties patterns, both from Tie Dye Diva, and weâ€™re pairing them with these lovely DBP prints from fabric.com. ####Fabric Choices Double Brushed Jersey Knit Geometric in Fuschia/Purple Double Brushed Poly Spandex Jersey Knit in Ivory Double Brushed Jersey Knit Hearts in Navy/Purple (this fabric is no longer available but you can shop the rest of the collection here!

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/fabric-min.jpg)

####5 Tips for Sewing DBP Here are 5 tips and tricks for sewing with Double Brushed Poly Knits! #####1. Use the Right Needles & Thread First, you will want to make sure you are using the correct needles for your fabric. Use brand new stretch needles for your machine type, whether itâ€™s a sewing machine, serger, or coverstitch. The stretch needles are really the key component in ensuring you donâ€™t get those dreaded skipped stitches people sometimes encounter when sewing DBP. All-purpose polyester thread is best. If you are using a coverstitch machine to finish your hems, quality wooly nylon thread can be used for your looper thread.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/wooly-min.jpg)

#####2. Adjust Your Presser Foot Settings If your machine has the capability of adjusting your presser footâ€™s pressure, try reducing the pressure. This can help your fabric glide through easily while sewing. #####3. Use Correct Stitch Settings If you are using a sewing machine, you will want to use a stretch stitch, lightning bolt stitch, or a narrow zigzag stitch. I used a narrow zigzag for these white shorts with a width of .5 and a length of 3.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/white-shorties-1-min.jpg)

Sergers already provide you with a seam that stretches. On a coverstitch machine, use the same settings as for activewear knits, reducing your looper tension and increasing the stitch length to avoid tunneling. Always test your machine settings on scraps until you get the correct ones for you. #####4. Know When and How to Press Donâ€™t underestimate the importance of pressing your seams with plenty of steam. A damp pressing cloth will protect the fabric and reduce seam impressions.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/press-min.jpg)

#####5. Make it Easier for Yourself with Notions As always, there are a couple of tricks you can try to make sewing with DBP even easier. Wonder Clips can be used to hold fabric seams together in place of pins when youâ€™re sewing. Fusible hem tapes can also help keep your hems looking lovely and crisp, and they make sewing easier too because the fabric isnâ€™t stretching around underneath your presser foot. If youâ€™re hemming an area like a leg opening that needs to stretch when being worn, you can cut strips of fusible interfacing for knit that will allow hems to retain their stretch and still stabilize the fabric enough to make hemming a breeze.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/Opal-1-1-min.jpg)

We hope these tips help you feel ready to tackle DBP. It really isnâ€™t that different from other knits, and possibly even a bit easier because it doesnâ€™t curl at the edges.

![DBP](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Double%20Brushed%20Poly/Opal-Dress-back-1-min.jpg)

We hope you enjoyed learning how to sew with this deliciously soft fabric and will use it to fill your handmade wardrobe!

posts.title: Vintage Chairs Modern Makeover
posts.markdown:
Created by Scout Studios Not long ago, I happened upon two of the most gorgeous mid-century chairs Iâ€™ve ever seen. They were found in a flip that one of my contractors was helping out with. Knowing about my upholstery obsession and my love for giving old things life again, he called me up and asked if I wanted them. (There were sixâ€¦) Ummmm â€œYES.â€

![Vintage Chair Makeover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vintage%20Chairs%20Modern%20Makeover/unnamed-min.jpg)

![Vintage Chair Makeover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vintage%20Chairs%20Modern%20Makeover/before-min.jpg)

The reason I was so over the moon about these chairs is because of the scalloped backs. Channeling and Scallops are on the verge of being all the rage right now when it comes to upholstery. Although tufting is still HUGE, the scalloped backs, the channelingâ€¦ Iâ€™m telling you, itâ€™s about to over take tufting in a big way. Itâ€™s a nod to the beautiful details of years past that is making itâ€™s way around again. As a decorator, I get asked to do fun projects all the time. But itâ€™s one project in particular that I knew these would be perfect for. (After a little love of course. ) This year Iâ€™m participating in the Okalahoma Designer Show House. Itâ€™s my first year participating and I knew that I really wanted to make a splash with my room. The first thing that came to mind were those chairs. With all their spinning channeled amazingness. So first things first were to find out who the chairs were made by. Iâ€™m a little ashamed to admit this, but the first thing I did was rip the fabric off the bottoms. I know. Whyyyyy??? I was looking for markings of any kind. Chairs with original tags or distinctive features are far more desirable than those without. On these particular pieces, I was looking for brass finishing around the bottoms. No luck unfortunately. However, had there been tags or any distinctive marks, I would have made sure that my rock star upholstery gal Krista from All in One Piece Upholstery kept them intact. Then it was on to fabric. (The most important part.) I wanted these chairs to stand out in the show house. I knew that I wanted velvet. Velvet is still in, and it adds texture. Where as many other parts of my space are flat. Velvet with itâ€™s warm, soft, feel is so comforting to sink in to. So after pouring over fabric.comâ€™s incredible selection, I placed an order for samples. Once samples arrived, I carefully matched the green velvets against my wallpaper.

![Vintage Chair Makeover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vintage%20Chairs%20Modern%20Makeover/Screen%20Shot%202017-08-03%20at%201.07.17%20AM-min.png)

Sure enough, this one was dead on. It accented the wallpaper so nicely. And if only you could FEEL how soft it is.

![Vintage Chair Makeover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vintage%20Chairs%20Modern%20Makeover/Large_0367238-min.jpg)

![Vintage Chair Makeover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Vintage%20Chairs%20Modern%20Makeover/after-min.JPG)

As soon as fabric arrived, I hauled the chairs off to be reupholstered. And in less than a week they were in the back of a truck and in the Designer Show House. And luckily, there was enough fabric left over for a custom channeled bench too! Stay tuned for my â€œbench storyâ€ and before and afters of this incredible piece. Canâ€™t wait to share!
