posts.title: Easy DIY Fringed Kimono
posts.markdown:
Today we will show you an easy way to make yourself a kimono to wear year round! Inspired by traditional Japanese culture, Kimono robes have been created in many variations over the years to satisfy a fashionable way to add interest to any outfit! Buying one in a boutique can be costly, but you can easily make one that looks just as chic for as little as $30. Kimonos are great to wear in the heat of summer because they are cool and allow for good airflow. When the weather is cooler, you can wear a patterned kimono over a t-shirt to add interest to your outfit and keep you warm.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20velvet%20sunglasses-min.jpg)

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20velvet%20up%20close-min.jpg)

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20floral%20no%20head-min.jpg)

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20floral%20back-min.jpg)

There are nearly infinite variations on the classic kimono, but for this simple design you will need a piece of fabric measuring 40â€ x 55â€ and 2 yards of accent fringe. ####Supplies Needed * 1 Â½ yard fabric (we used Telio Burnout Velvet and Telio Kimono Satin) * 2 yards of Fringe (we used 4" Black Chainette Fringe for the velvet kimono and Grey Victorian Lace Fringe for the satin kimono) * Thread in a color matching the fabric * Tailor's Chalk or Fabric Pen * Sewing Machine * Pins * Rotary Cutter and Cutting Mat, or Dressmaker Shears * A ruler or measuring tape

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Supplies%20Kimono-min.jpg)

####Other Great Fabrics for Kimonos You can choose nearly any type of fashion fabric for your kimono, but some work better than others. The kimono style works best with fabric with a soft, floppy texture, such as: * Rayon Challis * Voile * Chiffon * Crepe de Chine * Jersey Knits * Cotton Lawn * Border Printed Fashion Fabric * Stretch Velvet Let's start sewing!

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/CB-1889_kimonoPattern%202-min.png)

####Step 1: Cut a piece of fabric: 40â€ x 56â€ for size Small/Medium 43â€ x 56â€ for Medium/Large 46â€ x 56â€ for Large/XLarge *Note: Before beginning to cut, check to see if there is a right and wrong side of the fabric or if there is a one-way design. There is no shoulder seam for this pattern lay-out. However, should your fabric have a one-way orientation, you could cut two 40â€ x 28 Â½â€ rectangles and add a shoulder seam. This pattern can be used with the fabric on grain (weft) or on the warp (vertical). The pattern layout shown is for fabric on the warp, which isnâ€™t traditional, but works wonderfully for this kimono. Fold the material in half, joining the two 40â€ sides together. ####Step 2: From the folded edge, measure 10â€ down on either side of your folded piece of fabric â€“ this is for the sleeves From the outside, measure 10â€ inward for the sleeve length.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20cut%20out-min.jpg)

#####Sew the side seams: * French seams for woven fabrics (clip at armpit corners) * Zig Zag stitch, Stretch stitch or surge Â¼â€ seam allowance for knit fabrics

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Clip%20armpits-min.jpg)

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Armpit%20velvet-min.jpg)

####Step 3: Determine where the middle point of the garment is and draw a line down the center on the top piece of fabric only. Based off that line, draw the 6â€ neck opening and taper down to the bottom center. Cut along the line drawn.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20neck%20cut%20out-min.jpg)

*Tip: Tailors chalk or a water soluble fabric pen is great to use because they are temporary. #####To finish the opening: * Use a 1â€ bias strip binding for woven fabrics * Top stitch a Â¼â€ hem for knit fabrics. You can even leave it unfinished since most knits will not unravel. *Tip: Use a zig zag stitch or a stretch stitch with a walking foot to top stitch the Â¼â€ hem.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20necks-min.jpg)

####Step 4: Hem the sleeve openings and kimono bottom edges. Hemming the edges of knit kimonos is optional if top-stitching fringe trim around the sleeves and bottom. ####Step 5: I couldnâ€™t resist spicing up this simple design with some fringe! For the velvet kimono, I used 2 yards of 4â€ Tassel Fringe. For the satin kimono, I used 2 yards of Victorian lace fringe. I attached them using a zig zag top stitch along the edge of the hemmed edges.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/kimono%20velvet%20fringe%20details-min.jpg)

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20floral%20fringe%20details-min.jpg)

Once you have finished your accessory, voila! You have a kimono. Wear it loose or closed with a brooch. You can wear it on its own or throw it over a shirt with a skirt or jeans. If you make it slightly longer, it makes a great throw-over to wear over a swimsuit.

![Kimono DIY](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kimono/Kimono%20floral%20hand%20pocket-min.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.title: Mommy & Me Tote Bags Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Hi, I'm Kimberly from the sewing blog Sweet Red Poppy and I'm so excited to be sharing this easy DIY with you today. Who's ready for a fun tote bag tutorial?

![Mommy and Me Totes](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20%26%20Me%20Tote/IMG_0912-Edit%20copy-min.jpg)

I don't know about you, but my daughter and I can always use another bag, and with her heading off to preschool this year I decided this was the perfect thing to make! Plus, my daughter loves having unique handmade items that set her apart from the crowd. And let's be honest, I really can't resist seeing her excitement over her handmade items!

![Mommy and Me Totes](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20%26%20Me%20Tote/IMG_1012-Edit-min.jpg)

Isn't this Wonderland fabric created by Rifle Paper Co. for Cotton + Steel dreamy? I've been crushing on it ever since it released, so much so that I decided to make Mommy & Me bags. I'm really loving the Alice and Wonderland theme!

![Mommy and Me Totes](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20%26%20Me%20Tote/IMG_1030-Edit-min.jpg)

Ready to get sewing?!? Here's what you will need for each bag. ####Supplies * 1 yard canvas (we used Wonderland Metallic Navy) * 1 yard quilting cotton (we used Wonderland Metallic Caterpillar Dots Pink) * 1 yard coordinating quilting cotton (we used Wonderland Cheshire Stripe Red) * Matching thread Make sure to prewash your fabrics so you can toss this bag in the washer once it gets dirty. If you're kids are anything like mine, that's inevitable! ####Cutting #####Child Size * Main 13" x 13" (cut 2) * Lining 13" x 13" (cut 2) * Straps 42" x 2.5" (cut 2) * Pocket 9.5" x 4.5" (cut 2) #####Adult Size * Main 17" x 17" (cut 2) * Lining 17" x 17" (cut 2) * Straps 56" x 3" (cut 2) * Pockets 12.5" x 6" (cut 2) 1/2" Seam allowances will be used throughout the tutorial.

![Mommy and Me Totes](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20%26%20Me%20Tote/IMG_0839-3-1024x683-min.jpg)

####Cutting Corners Lay the main fabric and lining on the cutting table and cut a 2" x 2" (1.5" x 1.5" for children's size) square from the bottom corners.

posts.title: Sewing 101: Hand Quilting
posts.markdown:
Hand quilting is a great way to add a special touch to your quilt project that pre-dates the sewing machine! You can use this technique on modern quilts as well as traditional quilts, and it gives a completely different finished look to your project that we love. Check out our video tutorial and step by steps below to learn this great technique! Weâ€™ll also be featuring a full tutorial for this color wheel quilt later this week on the blog, so be sure to check back! ####Hand Quilting Supplies * Hand Quilting Needles * Thread Conditioner * Thimble * Thread

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/supplies-min.PNG)

We used the new Cotton + Steel thread sets in the Rifle Paper Guest Collection ( Menagerie and Beauty Shop ) so we would have all the colors to match our color wheel! It is truly amazing thread made in Italy, and is well suited to hand-quilting.

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/cottonSteelThread_1-min.jpg)

####Making your quilt sandwich We prefer to use cotton batting for quilts that we are hand quilting. You can baste your quilt sandwich any way you like, including spray basting , pin basting , or tacks.

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/sandwich-min.PNG)

Time to hand quilt! ####Threading: Using a piece of thread about the length of your arm, thread your needle and draw it through the thread heaven to condition it. The thread heaven also protects against knots where you donâ€™t want them!

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/threading-min.PNG)

####Make a quilterâ€™s knot: Hold the pointy end of the needle and the long end of the thread next to each other and pointing in the same direction. Tightly wrap the end of the thread five times around your needle. With your thumb and forefinger, draw those wraps down the length of the thread until you reach the end. A perfect knot is formed! The video above shows you how to make a quilter's knot in more detail. ####Bury the Knot: Choose a spot on your quilt a little ways away from where you want to begin your quilting. Insert your needle into the top of the quilt and through the batting, but DO NOT go out the back. Bring the point of your needle out where you want to start quilting. Draw your needle until the knot stops on the entrance point. Lightly tug until the knot goes through the entrance point and buries itself in the batting. Donâ€™t keep tugging, itâ€™s supposed to stay there!

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/buryknot-min.PNG)

####Begin quilting: Fill your needle with stitches by resting the end of the needle on your thimbled finger and rocking your needle from the front of your quilt to the back several times. Draw your needle and thread all the way through, and repeat until you are finished with that line of quilting or you run out of thread.

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/beginquilting1-min.PNG)

####Ending your quilting: For each piece of thread or line or quilting you have to finish it with another knot and bury it again. Make another quilterâ€™s knot at the end and bury it as before.

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/ending_knot-min.PNG)

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/buryknotagain-min.PNG)

Admire your heirloom quality stitching, happy sewing!

![Hand Quilting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hand%20Quilting/hand_quilting_money_shot-min.PNG)

posts.title: Easy Applique Color Wheel Mini Quilt
posts.markdown:
Looking for a mini quilt with the perfect pop of color? Look no further than this easy applique color wheel mini quilt! Today we'll show you how to sew up this project step by step. This delightful mini quilt features a bright rainbow of colors to spruce up your sewing space and serve as a great sewing and quilting reference! We used a rainbow fat quarter bundle and a pie ruler for this easy spin on a classic Dresden plate block. This fun wall hanging will look great in our sewing space next to our Kona Color Chart Quilt Kona Color Chart! This ruler is a great addition to your ruler library â€“ You can make classic Dresden flowers and pies like this one. Let's get started! ####Fabrics & Supplies: * Quilting Cotton Solids in a rainbow of colors â€“ We used this Kona Cotton Elizabeth Hartman rainbow fat quarter bundle but you can use any Kona Cotton solids or quilting cotton prints in saturated hues. You will need 16 pieces to make one color wheel. * Pie Ruler (Dresden ruler) * Thread for piecing and quilting (for piecing we chose this thread and for quilting we used this thread and this thread by Cotton + Steel and Sulky) * Kona Cotton Snow for Background * Any Kona color for backing * Binding fabric (we used Riley Blake 1/4" Stripes Gray) * Hand sewing supplies (needles, thimble, thread wax)

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/Large_0353900.jpg)

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/Large_0491268.jpg)

####Cutting: * (16) rainbow colors with your pie ruler Measure from the 1.5â€ line- accuracy is very important here! * (1) Kona Snow â€œsquareâ€ and one backing â€œsquareâ€ measuring 24â€ square * (3) 2.5â€ strips from your binding fabric ####Assembly: Lay out your colors in ROYGBIV + grey format. You might want to take a picture to reference later if you use your own color combinations! Sew your slices in pairs. An accurate Â¼â€ seam is very important for a non-wonky color wheel!

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2927-min.jpg)

If you keep your lighter color always on top you should avoid sewing them on the wrong side!

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2925-min.jpg)

Sew pairs together to form four groups of four...

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2929-min.jpg)

Then two groups of 8...

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2930-min.jpg)

Then a whole plate!

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2932-min.jpg)

Easy as pie! Press seams open on the back very carefully and with lots of starch to avoid warping your circle.

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2936-min.jpg)

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2933-min.jpg)

Then turn your edges under Â¼â€ in the middle and outsides. Press very well.

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2940-min.jpg)

Center your color wheel on the kona snow fabric and baste with pins or basting spray. Applique to the background fabric with a simple straight stitch or any applique stitch.

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2943-min.jpg)

I used the white piecing thread, but you could use any thread. Grey blends really well for things like this. Baste your quilt in your usual method, and quilt as desired. We hand-quilted with various cotton and steel threads in every-other slice in a radiating pattern. Bind as desired.

![Color Wheel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Color%20Wheel%20Quilt%20Tutorial/IMG_2949-min.jpg)

Check out the hand quilting tutorial below to finish your quilt!

posts.title: Fabric 101: Determining Stretch Direction & Stretch Percentage
posts.markdown:
Directional stretch and stretch percentage are important features when choosing the right fabric for your project. Some patterns will call out specifically the stretch percentage needed for the pattern to fit the best. Stretch fabrics can have mechanical stretch, in that they have a natural stretch based on the way they are made and do not include Lycra Spandex. Fabrics made with Lycra Spandex often have a greater stretch, and better recovery. ####Stretch Direction: 2 Way Stretch refers to fabric having one orientation of stretch. Most fabrics with 2 way stretch will have stretch horizontally, from selvedge to selvedge, with a few exceptions of fabrics designed to stretch only vertically along the selvedges. The term â€œ2 Way Stretchâ€ seems like it should be called â€œ1 Way Stretchâ€ however, the origin of this term is based on stabilizing a portion of fabric, and being able to stretch two ways: to the right and and left. Or if itâ€™s a fabric made to stretch vertically- that 2 way stretch would be referring to its ability to stretch up and down. Seems obvious that if fabric stretches one direction, it would also be able to stretch the opposing direction, but this is the basis for the terminology. 4 Way stretch refers to when the fabric can stretch both vertically and horizontally. Stabilizing a point of the fabric, it will be able to stretch four ways: up, down, right and left. ####How to stretch the fabric:

![Stretch](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Stretch%20Percentage/naturaltug-min.PNG)

To properly determine fabric stretch, you must gently stretch the fabric and observe the recovery, similar to the performance needed as if it were made into a garment, going to be going over your head to put on, or fitting on your body. You wouldnâ€™t want fabric to be stretched beyond its capacity when wearing it, so likewise, yanking on the fabric will not give you the best percentage estimate, and it will likely warp the fabric, compromising its quality. If the fabric becomes warped after stretching it, that is a clear indicator that it was stretched beyond its intention.

![Stretch](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Stretch%20Percentage/warped%20fabric-min.PNG)

####Stretch Percentage: Stretch percentage is estimated by stretching a fabric along a 4â€ - 8â€ ruler scale. Begin with fabric at ease on a 4â€ measurement, and stretch the fabric towards 8â€. The measurement it comfortably reaches will indicate the percentage estimate. For example, this Art Gallery Skopelos Jersey Knit fabric can stretch to 6â€. Since it stretched 2â€ past the 4â€ mark, and 2 is 50% of 4, then this fabric has 50% stretch. *Tip: Fold the fabric and stretch along the fold. Stretching fabric along a cut edge will not give the best estimate. Test the fabric perpendicular and parallel to the selvage to determine proper stretch direction and percentage.

![Stretch](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Stretch%20Percentage/20percent-min.PNG)

![Stretch](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Stretch%20Percentage/50percent-min.PNG)

####Choose Your Fabric! Did you know that fabric.com offers stretch percentage estimates in our fabric descriptions, as well as a navigation option? Weâ€™ve narrowed down stretch characteristics in common groups to make online fabric shopping even easier: Stretch Lycra Spandex Blends 5-10% stretch 10-25% stretch 30-50% stretch 75% stretch and above 4-Way Stretch Happy sewing!

posts.markdown:

posts.title: DIY Drop Cloth Curtains
posts.markdown:
Drop cloth curtains are a great way to spruce up your home dÃ©cor and add elegance to any room. The properties of the materials used in drop cloths are particularly handy for window treatment. When we saw this gorgeous fabric from Lacefield Designs, we knew it would make the perfect drapes for our space! Today we'll teach you how to create these simple curtains yourself. Let's get started!

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/Lacefield%20curtains%20drapery%20clips-min.jpg)

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/Lacefield_Curtain_panels_in_bedroom_color_corrected.jpg)

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/Lacefield%20Curtains%20full%20panels.jpg)

####Materials Needed: * 6 yards of drapery fabric for two 86"x54" curtain panels (we used Lacefield Bindi Large Paisley Slub in Cobalt) * Thread * Tape Measure * Scissors or Rotary Cutter

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/Supplies-min.jpg)

####Step 1 Measure the length that the finished curtain panel will be. This tutorial will provide instructions for two easy hanging applications: a rod pocket or drapery clips. To measure where the bottom of the panel should hit, decide on one of four standard lengths: Sill, Apron, Floor and Puddle.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/cb-1961_curtainLengthDiagram-min.jpg)

#####Sill Length: Curtain length falls right below the window sill. #####Apron Length: Curtain length falls 4â€ below the window sill. #####Floor Length: Curtain length falls about Â¼â€ above the floor. #####Puddle Legnth: Curtain length falls about 6 â€“ 10 inches beyond floor length. ####Step 2 Once measurement of the finished length is determined, add 4â€ on top and bottom. The additional 8â€ will allow for a folded 3â€ hem on both ends. Buy extra yardage than needed for fabrics with motifs or print designs. When cutting the fabric, examine where the motif will be displayed, and cut accordingly so that each curtain panel matches.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/3%20inch%20hem-min.jpg)

####Step 3 Roll hem the sides of the panels. ####Step 4 Press 1â€ inward on the top and bottom. Fold and press another 3â€ and top stitch across. Leave the sides open for the rod pocket. *Tip: Depending on the print orientation of the fabric, you can leave side seams open on both ends, so that thereâ€™s a rod pocket on both ends.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/rod%20pocket-min.jpg)

####Step 5 Press and hang!

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/Lacefield%20curtains%20-%20close%20up-min.jpg)

####Best Fabrics for Drop Cloth Curtains Here are some fabrics we love for drop cloth curtains! #####Printed Cotton Duck Premier Prints makes medium weight cotton and cotton blend fabrics in amazing color patterns, and the cloth is not thick enough to completely block out light. Due to this and its bright colors, it also works well with modern furniture and suits small rooms where it can pull everything together.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/printed_cotton_duck_fabrics.jpg)

Premier Prints Anderson Check Black/White Premier Prints Winston Navy Lacefield Bindi Large Paisley Slub Cobalt Lacefield Monaco Sapphire #####Solid Canvas This fabric is also 100% cotton and the fabric is of medium to heavy weight. As a result, it is perfect for window treatments including draperies, curtains and valances. It is worth noting, however, that its color options may vary due to the distinctive nature of the dyeing process used. Therefore, make sure you buy sufficient quantities to completely finish your project. This fabric is perfect for roller shades and covering floor-to-ceiling windows in large rooms. Its dark shades complement large living rooms perfectly, especially with rustic, dark furniture to balance the antique look.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/canvas_fabrics.jpg)

9.3 oz Canvas Aqua Sky 9.3 oz Canvas Natural Richloom Canvas Optic White 9.3 oz Canvas Gray #####Blackout Drapery Blackout drapery is a bestseller amongst drop cloth curtains, and with good reason. It muffles sound and reduces noises that might be released through the windows. As such, it is perfect for homes, nurseries, workplaces, and schools. This fabric can also insulate rooms according to season, making them cooler during the summer and warmer in winter. It is also perfect for blocking out early morning sunlight rays while still blending in with a roomâ€™s color scheme.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/blackout_drapery_fabrics.jpg)

Fabricut Solar Sheen Blackout Royal Blue Trend 03604 Blackout Hemp Roc Lon Denimtone Blackout Ebony Trend 1526 Blackout Mandarin #####Linen Linen is a timeless fabric choice for drop cloth curtains. A natural fiber derived from the flax plant, linen and linen blend fabrics give a crisp appearrance, and the texture adds a modern elegance to any room.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/linen_fabrics.jpg)

Jaclyn Smith 02616 Linen Dove Gray Formenti 100% Linen Canary Yellow European 100% Linen Cream European 100% Linen Metallic Striped Silver & Grey #####Burlap Burlap drop cloth curtains give a textured and rustic look to any room, pairing perfectly with todayâ€™s modern farmhouse decorating trend. The rough texture of burlap makes this fabric a great choice for curtains that will not be handled often. Faux burlap fabrics are a great choice for frequently used curtains in that they are soft, yet still give the rustic textured appearrance of real burlap.

![Drop Cloth Curtains](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Drop%20Cloth%20Curtains%20DIY/burlap_fabrics.jpg)

Vintage Poly Burlap Eggplant P Kaufmann Metallic Groupie Peppercorn Faux Burlap Burlap Super Natural 60â€ Sultana Burlap Plaid Happy sewing!

posts.title: Fleece Tassel Blanket Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Oversized tassels are one of our favorite home decor trends right now, especially when they provide a pop of color! In this tutorial, weâ€™ll show you how to make your own fleece throw blanket complemented with large colorful tassels created with cotton fabric. Best of all, creating the tassels requires no sewing! ####Supplies: * 2 yards of Shannon Cuddle Fleece (we used Ivory) * 2 yards Anna Maria Horner Loominous Illuminated Graph Cream * 1.5 yards Anna Maria Horner Loominous Headlines Orange * 1.5 yards Anna Maria Horner Loominous Tribe Bubblegum * 1.5 yards Anna Maria Horner Loominous Chemistry Sharp * Rotary cutter and Cutting mat * Walking foot You can select any Cuddle Fleece for the blanket and cotton fabric for the tassels!

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/supplies-min.PNG)

####Making the Tassels: Be sure to watch the video above for details on creating the tassels! Fold your fabric in order to easily cut bias strips. Cut 14-16 bias strips. 1â€ x 18â€ strips (14 -16) 14 is better for thicker fabrics, and 16 for thinner fabrics. #####Then cut: * 1â€ x 30â€ strip (1) * 1â€ x 15â€ strip (1) * 1â€ x 18â€ strip (1) This is to join the tassels and form the head.

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/join_tassels-min.PNG)

Place the 1â€ x 15â€ strip horizontally first, place the 14-16 strips perpendicular, with the 30â€ strip placed last. Tie the 15â€ strip, joining all the other strips. Tie the 30â€ strip roughly 11â€ times in the center and knot once, this is to provide structure bulk for the head of the tassel. Take the original 1â€ x 15â€ strip, tie around, and double knot to form the top of the tassel head and to serve as the tassel attachment. Use an additional 1â€ x 18â€ strip to join the tassels and knot twice. Fluff, and trim.

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/finished_tassel-min.PNG)

1 Â½ yard of 45â€ fabric makes approximately 4 tassels using the technique shown. Make as many or as few as you want. The blanket shown has 10 tassels total of three coordinating fabrics. ####Cut the accent fabric: Cut 7â€ bias strips and join them together to equal two 7â€ x 65â€ strips. Press one side Â½â€ inward. ####Attaching the Tassels: On each cut edge of the fleece fabric, pin your tassels evenly along the edges and corners. With right sides together, pin the accent fabric to the fleece, with the tassels sandwiched in the middle.

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/pin-min.PNG)

Using a walking foot, sew a shallow zig zag stitch and a 3/8â€ seam allowance. When stitching over the tassels, back stitch to re-inforce the tassels.

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/zig_zag_stitch.PNG)

Trim the excess tassel fabric within the seam allowance. Flip the accent fabric outward, so that wrong sides are together. Pin and top stitch using a shallow zig zag with a walking foot. Fold the excess fabric on the sides inward in order to top stitch them as well.

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/top_stitch-min.PNG)

Voila! A cozy tassel blanket to spruce up your decor. Happy sewing!

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/finished_blanket_1-min.PNG)

![Tassel Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fleece%20Tassel%20Blanket/tassel_blanket_couch-min.PNG)

posts.title: NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Football season is right around the corner, so it's time to start creating projects that show your team spirit! Today we'll show you how to make a reversible bandana and fleece blanket for your pet so they can sport your favorite team's colors! One of our resident fabric.com pups, Buddy, is sporting Dallas Cowboys spirit, but you can browse all of your favorite team's fabric in our Team Shop by clicking here.

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_7332-min.JPG)

###Reversible Bandana Project These bandanas are reversible, so you can even showcase two different teams if you'd like! Best of all, the bandana slips right onto your pet's collar. We decided to use two coordinating broadcloth fabrics featuring the same team for our bandana. ####Supplies Needed: * 2 team fabrics (we used this one and this one) * Coordinating thread (we used Aurifil Grey) * Cutting supplies * Rotary cutter * Ruler * Cutting Mat ####Instructions We are using the measurements from Buddyâ€™s collar and neck. Use your own petâ€™s measurements in the parentheses for a custom sized bandana. Measure your petâ€™s collar â€“ the width of it at the widest part. Remember to allow for buckles and other hardware if they add to the width. We are using 1â€ for Buddyâ€™s â€“ add a Â½â€ for allowance. Buddyâ€™s collar and neck measure 19â€ around â€“ you want the longest part of the bandana (the hypotenuse of the triangle) to be shorter than this measurement. Use a Â¼â€ seam allowance throughout. Cut two squares â€œon pointâ€, like so. We cut 12.5â€ squares.

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2982-min.JPG)

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2984-min.JPG)

Cut them in half for two triangles with the patterns facing the way the bandana will lie.

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2985-min.JPG)

At the corners, cut in your width measurement +1/2â€, for us â€“ thatâ€™s (1.5â€)

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2986-min.JPG)

Your bandana triangles will look like this

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2987-min.JPG)

Sew your bandana triangles together along the flat side with right sides together. Press seam open or to the darker fabric. Take the remaining flat sides and turn under Â¼â€ and then another Â¼â€. Edgestitch down, remembering the backstitch at the beginning and ends for durability.

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2989-min.JPG)

Fold right sides together. Beginning at the flat opening, sew around the open sides, pivoting at the point for a sharp corner. Remember to leave the openings unstitched!

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2991-min.JPG)

clip the point of the bandana like so...

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2992-min.JPG)

Turn right side out through either opening. Topstitch along top edge, and (1.5â€) down to create a channel across the bandana for the collar. You can also topstitch along the sides for a professional finish.

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_2998-min.JPG)

Feed the collar through the channel with your favorite side facing out. Now you are ready to cheer on your team!

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_3002-min.JPG)

![NFL Pet Bandana & Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/NFL%20Pet%20Bandana%20and%20Blanket/IMG_7285-min.JPG)

Trim the cut edges to match, and then trim the fleece width to match the minky width. Pin around the edges.

Football season is right around the corner, so it's time to start creating projects that show your team spirit!

Today we'll show you how to make a reversible bandana and fleece blanket for your pet so they can sport your favorite team's colors! One of our resident fabric.com pups, Buddy, is sporting Dallas Cowboys spirit, but you can browse all of your favorite team's fabric in our Team Shop by clicking here.

Reversible Bandana Project

These bandanas are reversible, so you can even showcase two different teams if you'd like! Best of all, the bandana slips right onto your pet's collar. We decided to use two coordinating broadcloth fabrics featuring the same team for our bandana.

Supplies Needed:

  • 2 team fabrics (we used this one and this one)
  • Coordinating thread (we used Aurifil Grey)
  • Cutting supplies
  • Rotary cutter
  • Ruler
  • Cutting Mat

Instructions

We are using the measurements from Buddyâ€™s collar and neck. Use your own petâ€™s measurements in the parentheses for a custom sized bandana.

Measure your petâ€™s collar â€“ the width of it at the widest part. Remember to allow for buckles and other hardware if they add to the width. We are using 1â€ for Buddyâ€™s â€“ add a Â½â€ for allowance.

Buddyâ€™s collar and neck measure 19â€ around â€“ you want the longest part of the bandana (the hypotenuse of the triangle) to be shorter than this measurement.

Use a Â¼â€ seam allowance throughout.

Cut two squares â€œon pointâ€, like so. We cut 12.5â€ squares.

Cut them in half for two triangles with the patterns facing the way the bandana will lie.

At the corners, cut in your width measurement +1/2â€, for us â€“ thatâ€™s (1.5â€)

Your bandana triangles will look like this

Sew your bandana triangles together along the flat side with right sides together. Press seam open or to the darker fabric.

Take the remaining flat sides and turn under Â¼â€ and then another Â¼â€. Edgestitch down, remembering the backstitch at the beginning and ends for durability.

Fold right sides together. Beginning at the flat opening, sew around the open sides, pivoting at the point for a sharp corner. Remember to leave the openings unstitched!

clip the point of the bandana like so...

Turn right side out through either opening. Topstitch along top edge, and (1.5â€) down to create a channel across the bandana for the collar. You can also topstitch along the sides for a professional finish.

Feed the collar through the channel with your favorite side facing out. Now you are ready to cheer on your team!

Team Fleece & Minky Blanket

Now let's make an easy and super cozy fleece and Minky blanket for those chilly autumn games!

Supplies Needed:

  • 1.5 yards team fleece fabric (we used this one)
  • 1.5 yards Minky Cuddle Fleece (we used this one)
  • Coordinating thread (we used Aurifil Grey)
  • Ball point needles
  • Walking foot

You can sew this with a regular foot and needles, but it will be much easier with a walking foot and ball point needle since Minky is a tad stretchy and is prone to shift.

Instructions

Lay your Minky out on top of your fleece, right sides together. Trim the cut edges to match, and then trim the fleece width to match the minky width. Pin around the edges.

With a walking foot, ball point needle, and zig zag stitch, sew around the edges of the blanket at around 1â€ seam allowance, backstitching when you begin and end. Just make sure to keep an even seam allowance all the way around. Pivot at the corners with your needle down.

When you have about a foot left of space from where you started, end your stitching. Backstitch to anchor.

Trim your corners like so...

Turn your blanket right side out. Fold under unsewn portion and pin.

Close with a hand slip stitch. If you aren't familiar with how to do this versatile stitch technique, check out our tutorial here.

Finish turning out your corners for a perfect point.

Topstitch 1â€ in if desired.

Cuddle up under your cozy blanket!

posts.title: Brand Spotlight: Cotton + Steel
posts.markdown:
The world of fabric is an exciting, inspiring and creative one that thrives on innovative designers who create beautifully crafted works of art that use fabrics as their canvas. A few such designers practice their art at one of our favorite fabric companies out there, Cotton + Steel! Founded by a fabric designer, all of Cotton + Steelâ€™s unique prints have high quality design elements, beautiful patterns a touch of whimsy that have captured the eyes and hearts of sewists across the world.

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/rifle_1-min.jpg)

Cotton + Steel is a funky, collaborative and fun extension of RJR Fabrics dreamt up and brought to life by Melody Miller. After crafting a business email to the CEO of RJR Fabrics, Melody was invited to give a presentation on this new and eclectic brand she hoped to start. An important tenet was collaboration, which is why Melody wanted to bring on five talented designers to make the famous designs we know and love. And thus, Cotton + Steel was born.

The Cotton+Steel Story from Cotton + Steel on Vimeo.

Cotton + Steel wouldnâ€™t be the brand it is today without its incredibly imaginative team of designers who collaborate to curate unique collections and designs that we canâ€™t get enough of! The team is made up of Melody Miller, Rashida Coleman-Hale, Alexia Marcelle Abegg, Sarah Watts and Kimberly Kight.

![Cotton + Steel](http://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/CS.designers-min.jpg)

A South Carolina native, Melody moved to New York City to study industrial design at the Pratt Institute, which is where she honed her incredible design skills. Her whimsical designs and vibrant color palettes embody this creative designerâ€™s style perfectly. Rashida is a born maker who found her passion in the fashion industry while studying at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. After a brief hiatus, she rekindled her love of design and started a sewing blog to chronicle her creative adventures. This author and designerâ€™s creations are inspired by her time in Japan, which is reflected in her simplistic and modern designs. Alexia grew up in a creative household with her painter father and fashion designer mother, so itâ€™s no surprise she ended up a creative herself. She tried her hand in photography, acting, fashion design and a plethora of other arts before settling into the sewing world. Sheâ€™s now known for her hand painted, watercolor designs and funky aesthetic.

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/DSC_0283-min.jpg)

Sarahâ€™s nomadic childhood gave her all the inspiration she needed to create the unique designs you see today while her time at Ringling College of Art and Design allowed her to become a talented illustrator. Youâ€™ll see her skills put to use in her detailed, hand drawn designs. After being laid off, Kimberly began sewing and became interested in fabric, which lead to her creating a sewing blog. An avid vintage fabric collector, Kimberly is passionate about recreating and reimagining these prints to share with new generations, which comes through in her designs. Despite having five different designers with different backgrounds and styles, Cotton + Steel is able to seamlessly bring them together in their world famous collections. We are obsessed with their collaborations with Rifle Paper Company, from Les Fleur to the latest Menagerie Collection.

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/menagerie32-min.jpg)

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/1_080717_MenagerieGallery_Intro_1200x800-min.jpg)

Some of our other favorites include Lagoon, which features colorful and bold designs by Rashida Coleman-Hale, and Bluebird from a collaboration of C+S designers is still one of our absolute favorites!

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/ssbluebird3-min.jpg)

We also adore their new line of thread by Sulky! that is available in packs or individually! These seamlessly coordinate with each of the Cotton + Steel collections, and is a 50 wt. thread featuring exquisite long staple egyptian cotton.

![Cotton + Steel](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cotton%20Steel%20Brand%20Feature/CSsulky1-min.jpg)

Want to be the first to know about our new Cotton + Steel collections? Check our new arrivals frequently to find new, eclectic and fun creations from our favorite collaborative brand! The best part is that Cotton + Steel has canvas, rayon challis, lawn and quilting cotton fabrics , so you can incorporate this trend-setting brand into any project.

posts.title: Fabric 101: Drape
posts.markdown:
Drape is one of the most important factors to consider when constructing a garment. Do you want a dress to hug every curve, or skim them? Do you want a skirt to fall in graceful folds to the floor, or to make a crisp box-pleat? Drape could be the missing link in making a dress that matches the pattern envelope perfectly! Check the product descriptions for each fabric to see which ones fall under this classification â€“ we will be sure to tell you what fabric has fluid drape, moderate drape, or full-bodied drape. ####Fluid Drape: Think a slinky wrap dress, or that Summer maxi skirt that makes you feel like a goddess. Fabric with fluid drape does what it sounds like â€“ it is so silky soft that it almost moves like a liquid. Fabrics with fluid drape usually try their best to show every flaw if your pattern is figure-hugging. For a look that skims your curves, these fabrics hold a gather amazingly well. Fabrics that fall under this classification include Rayon Challis, ITY Stretch Jersey Knit, Rayon Jersey Knit and Satin Charmeuse.

![Fabric 101 Drape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Drape/fluid_drape-min.jpg)

####Moderate Drape: Moderate drape just might be the most versatile type of drape, suitable for a variety of projects. Think of your favorite t-shirt or A-line skirt. Most jersey knits made with cotton or polyester fall into this category. These fabrics donâ€™t fall straight down, but they donâ€™t fall away from the body very much either. They can hold a pleat or a gather pretty well; they are neither crisp, nor flowy. Moderate drape fabrics can be used for almost anything depending on the substrate. Cotton jersey knit is perfect for maxi dresses, maxi skirts, and any knit dress-even pajamas and t-shirts. Most polyester or poly blend jerseys are perfect for t-shirts, but for dresses and skirts some require a lining or a fuller or gathered pattern depending on the sheerness. Wool or polyester suitings will using have amazing drape for the weight of the fabric â€“ a true sign of quality!

![Fabric 101 Drape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Drape/moderate_drape-min.jpg)

####Full bodied drape For classic looks with fun style elements, fabrics with full bodied drape are the perfect addition to your wardrobe. These fabrics hold themselves away from the body. It will hold dramatic pleats that will be a little softer than ones made in a more crisp fabric, but might have trouble with gathers. Ideal for special occasion and Fall & Winter fashions. You might find full bodied drape (also described as heavy drape) in fabrics like Scuba Knit and Pique Knit, which are perfect for circle skirts, unstructured blazers, knit jackets, and dresses, and special occasion fabrics like Duchess Satin and Dupioni Silk.

![Fabric 101 Drape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%3A%20Drape/full_bodied_drape-min.jpg)

posts.title: DIY Fabric Basket
posts.markdown:
Created by: Laura of Trash to Couture Hello everyone! Laura here from Trash to Couture and I'm excited to share this DIY home decor project with you! My family and I just moved into a new home in Atlanta from Boulder, Colorado and it has inspired me to sew more home decor projects then my usual fashion designs. I wanted to bring some of the western boho style of Colorado into our traditional southern home. Iâ€™ve been on the hunt for fabric that represents this style: geometric prints, vibrant colors, and indigo shades. Justina Blakeney's new line of fabrics seemed to check off all boxes. I actually had a hard time cutting into the fabric as it was so beautiful! The fabrics are great stand alone pieces you can use for rugs, wall tapestrys, headboards and even as a throw blanket over the couch.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/SM-Justina-Blakeney_Fabrics-5.jpg)

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/justinaBlakeney_red_7.jpg)

I had some time to think about what types of decor I wanted to DIY, and will be sharing a few of these projects exclusively with fabric.com! First, I wanted to make a fabric basket which is great for storage of all kinds: books, sewing supplies, fabric, blankets, etc. Both are great projects to customize fit and style.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/basket%20final%203-min.jpg)

The Justina Blakeney fabric is heavyweight and perfect for projects like these! Follow the tutorial below and sew your own! ####Supplies: * 1 yard Justina Blakeney Fabric * 1 yard Pellon fusible fleece * 1 yard interior fabric * General sewing supplies ####Cutting: * 2 exterior pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 interior pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 fusible interfacing pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 straps: 4" x 8" ####Instructions: Cut out your pattern pieces.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%201-min.jpg)

Iron your fusible interfacing on the liner according to the product instructions. I usually do this on the exterior fabric but the heavy weight fabric I'm using makes it hard to bind the adhesive side so the liner works for this.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step2.jpg)

Take both your interior pieces and place right sides together. Sew both sides and bottom but leave a 4" opening at the bottom. For the exterior so both sides and bottom. Make sure to leave a top opening for both.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%203-min.jpg)

Mark and cut a 4" square on each corner of the interior and exterior and cut each of them out.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%204-min.jpg)

They will appear like this...

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%205-min.jpg)

Fold the bottom seam up to meet the side seam of all 4 corners including the exterior and liner.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%206-min.jpg)

Pin into place and sew along the edge.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%207-min.JPG)

As you sew finger press the seams toward the same side.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%208-min.jpg)

They both should look like this...

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%209-min.jpg)

Flip the exterior piece right side out.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2010-min.jpg)

Create your straps. I folded my strips in half, sewed right sides together using a 1/4" seam allowance. Then I used a loop turner to flip the right side out. You can press so the seam lies in the middle of the back.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2011-min.jpg)

Place your straps so the right sides are together against the exterior body. Position them so there is a 1" gap from the side seam. Then baste stitch them along the top edge to hold them in place. This is optional but I LOVED the fringe selvage of the fabric so I folded it over 1/4" and top stitch it down. I did have to posting the straps over the folded trim. Again, totally optional but if you want to add this detail this is how I did it. You'll see it's like this in the final as well.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2013-min.jpg)

Place the exterior right side out into the liner so the right sides are together. Line them up and and pin so the side seams are matching. Sew all the way around make sure to sew the straps in as well. I'd do a 1/2" seam allowance if you didn't do the fringe edge. If you did the fringe border sew a 1/4" seam allowance.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2014-min.jpg)

Now use that opening you left at the bottom of the liner to flip everything out through this.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2015-min.JPG)

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2016-min.JPG)

Sew the liner opening closed.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2017.jpg)

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2018.JPG)

It will look like this. You will now want to sew down the top edge and create a bit more stability in the straps and overall structure. To do this just top stitch along the top edge exterior. Start at one of the side seams and make sure the straps are upright when sewing.

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2019.jpg)

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/step%2020.JPG)

![DIY Fabric Basket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Fabric%20Basket/DSC_1949-min.jpg)

Now go make 10 in all different sizes and prints! You can change the width and length just by altering the above measurements.

I actually had a hard time cutting into the fabric as it was so beautiful! The fabrics are great stand alone pieces you can use for rugs, wall tapestrys, headboards and even as a throw blanket over the couch.

I had some time to think about what types of decor I wanted to DIY, and will be sharing a few of these projects exclusively with fabric.com! First, I wanted to make a fabric basket which is great for storage of all kinds: books, sewing supplies, fabric, blankets, etc. Both are great projects to customize fit and style.

The Justina Blakeney fabric is heavyweight and perfect for projects like these!

Follow the tutorial below and sew your own!

Supplies:

  • 1 yard Justina Blakeney Fabric
  • 1 yard Pellon fusible fleece
  • 1 yard interior fabric
  • General sewing supplies

Cutting:

  • 2 exterior pieces: 18" x 18.5"
  • 2 interior pieces: 18" x 18.5"
  • 2 fusible interfacing pieces: 18" x 18.5"
  • 2 straps: 4" x 8"

Instructions:

Cut out your pattern pieces.

Iron your fusible interfacing on the liner according to the product instructions. I usually do this on the exterior fabric but the heavy weight fabric I'm using makes it hard to bind the adhesive side so the liner works for this.

Take both your interior pieces and place right sides together. Sew both sides and bottom but leave a 4" opening at the bottom. For the exterior so both sides and bottom. Make sure to leave a top opening for both.

Mark and cut a 4" square on each corner of the interior and exterior and cut each of them out.

They will appear like this...

Fold the bottom seam up to meet the side seam of all 4 corners including the exterior and liner.

Pin into place and sew along the edge.

As you sew finger press the seams toward the same side.

They both should look like this...

Flip the exterior piece right side out.

Create your straps. I folded my strips in half, sewed right sides together using a 1/4" seam allowance. Then I used a loop turner to flip the right side out. You can press so the seam lies in the middle of the back.

Place your straps so the right sides are together against the exterior body. Position them so there is a 1" gap from the side seam. Then baste stitch them along the top edge to hold them in place.

This is optional but I LOVED the fringe selvage of the fabric so I folded it over 1/4" and top stitch it down. I did have to posting the straps over the folded trim. Again, totally optional but if you want to add this detail this is how I did it. You'll see it's like this in the final as well.

Place the exterior right side out into the liner so the right sides are together. Line them up and and pin so the side seams are matching. Sew all the way around make sure to sew the straps in as well. I'd do a 1/2" seam allowance if you didn't do the fringe edge. If you did the fringe border sew a 1/4" seam allowance.

Now use that opening you left at the bottom of the liner to flip everything out through this.

Sew the liner opening closed.

It will look like this. You will now want to sew down the top edge and create a bit more stability in the straps and overall structure. To do this just top stitch along the top edge exterior. Start at one of the side seams and make sure the straps are upright when sewing.

Now go make 10 in all different sizes and prints! You can change the width and length just by altering the above measurements.

posts.title: Sewing 101: Attaching Knit Bands
posts.markdown:
Nothing complements a handmade knit garment more than clean, functional arm and neck finishings. It can seem intimidating, but attaching knit bands is easier than you think! Weâ€™ll show you 3 simple band application techniques using a serger and a regular sewing machine along with 3 optional top stitch techniques for beautiful, professional results. For all the techniques below, I used 1 Â¼â€ wide crosswise grain strips of coordinating cotton lycra jersey knit fabric, with black thread in order to visually show the stitching better. The strips are all folded in half, wrong sides together.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/3%20techniques%20side%20by%20side-min.jpg)

To apply, I used a zig zag stitch with a sewing machine, or a 4-thread overlock stitch with a serger. Always practice on a scrap first.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/serge%20and%20zig%20zag-min.jpg)

####1. Measured Knit Band: This technique takes the longest, but yields the greatest reward! You can opt to use this standard formula (opening measurement X .09) to determine the length of the band, or you can simply take the knit band strip, and physically measure it against the opening it will be sewn onto. I prefer the latter, since every fabric stretches differently, and I can visually determine the performance of the fabric. Gently tug the strip along the opening, add room for seam allowance, and cut. When joining the knit band, angle the seam so that the band will lay flat against the body when worn. Pin the folded band along the opening, and sew.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/measured%20knit%20band-min.jpg)

####2. Seamed Knit Band: This technique is very popular because thereâ€™s no measuring involved, and itâ€™s preferred when binding edges that are too small to do a measured knit band easily, like kidâ€™s clothes. Attach the folded strip by gently stretching the band as you attach it to the garment. If you stretch too much, it will create puckers in the garment, fit poorly, and it could bend your needle from pulling the fabric too hard as itâ€™s being sewn. Gently stretching the band is very beneficial for a proper fit on the garment. If the band isnâ€™t applied this way, gaping arm holes and neck holes are a risk. Once the band is applied, simply trim the excess to match the angles of the side seam or shoulder seam, and sew closed. Bartack the seam allowance to finish so it lays flat.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/seamedd%20knit%20band-min.jpg)

#### 3. Overlap Knit Band: This technique gives the finish of a measured knit band, without the measuring. This one requires a bit more sewing experience, because the band has to be manipulated as itâ€™s being sewn. Before applying the band to the opening, clip a graduated angle on one end. Pin the band to the opening, to where the full length of the folded band lands on the seam of the garment. Serge or zig zag while gently stretching the band. When you reach the point of the start of the angled knit band, begin tapering off the band to overlap another angle. If youâ€™re using a serger, the serger will trim the excess to create the angle. When using a sewing machine, pull the knit band off, so that the zig zag stitch stays in line, then trim the excess fabric.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/overlapping%20knit%20band-min.jpg)

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/knit_bands_moneyshot_2-min.PNG)

####Top Stitching (Optional): Top stitching for these knit band techniques is optional. The decision to topstitch is based on how the fabric will perform, how the garment will be cared for, and sewing skill level. Top stitching does require a high level of control in order to get that perfect line. It can be easier than you think, especially with a little practice. For this stretchy cotton knit fabric, I used a 14/90 stretch needle (stretch needles are best for avoiding skipped stitches on stretchy fabric), and a basic straight stitch. No stretch-stitch required, since the stability comes from stitching 4 or more layers of fabric. Practice a few of these options:

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/Top%20stitch%20options-min.jpg)

####Top Stitch Knit Band: Simply top stitch to secure the seam allowance. This will allow the neck and arm openings to lay flat consistently.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/top%20stitch-min.jpg)

####Clean Finish and Seam-Covered Binding: My personal favorite. Depending on whether the knit band is sewn to the right side of the fabric or the wrong side of the fabric, determines what part of the band will show. If sewn to the right side, no band will show. If applied to the wrong side, the band will show. Either way, the seam allowance for applying the band initially is totally concealed. To do this, wrap the knit band around the seam allowance, and edge stitch to secure.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/clean%20finish-min.jpg)

#### Narrow Seam Covered Band: Similar to the clean finish band, this one plays off the natural fold of the knit band, making it a little easier to top stitch. Fold the knit band inward about Â¼â€ and topstitch. A small portion of the seam allowance may be visible from the inside only.

![Attaching Knit Bands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Attaching%20Knit%20Bands/narrow%20knit-min.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.title: Greatest Granny Square Quilt Free Pattern
posts.markdown:
Created by: Emily of Quilty Love Skill Level: Beginner Today Iâ€™m excited to share this easy beginner friendly quilt pattern with you all. Granny square quilts are a favorite of mine so I supersized this block to create The Greatest Granny Square!

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9580-min.jpg)

The Greatest Granny Square quilt is constructed with squares making it super easy for even the first time quilt maker. Starting out with simple squares is always a good idea for the beginner quilter. ####To start you will need the following fabric and supplies: * (3) 1 yard cuts of quilting cotton (I used Art Gallery Little Town Winterberry Mist, Art Gallery Little Town Twinkle Stars and Art Gallery Little Town Seasons Carols). * 1 Â¼ yards neutral background quilting cotton (I used Art Gallery Pure Elements in Solid Snow) * 5/8 yards of binding fabric or use the leftover fabrics to make a scrappy binding * 3 Â¼ yards backing fabric (I used Art Gallery Les Petits Checks in Midnight) * Quilter's Dream Batting * Thread, rotary cutter, cutting mat and a ruler

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-7576-min.jpg)

####Pattern Download Follow along below or download a PDF copy HERE. ####Cutting Instructions Choose your A, B, and C fabrics from your 1 yard cuts. Fabric A is the largest ring in your quilt, B the middle and C the inside. See the diagram below. From the white background fabric cut x5 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x24 8.5in squares. From Fabric A, cut x3 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x13 8.5in squares. From Fabric B, cut x2 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x8 8.5in squares. From Fabric C, cut x4 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x4 8.5in squares. Set aside remaining strips for borders. Cut the binding fabric into x7 2.5in x WOF strips.

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/Fig1%20copy.jpg)

####Assemble the quilt top Arrange your cut fabric squares into the granny square block as shown in the diagram. Sew together in rows using a 1/4in seam allowance. Press each row in the opposite direction (see arrows) for nesting your seams. To make the top and bottom borders, sew together the remaining C strips. Cut into x2 8.5in x 56.5in pieces. Add borders to top and bottom and sew together rows to make quilt top.

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9257-2-min.jpg)

Prepare your backing fabric by folding in half width wise and cutting at fold. Sew together the two pieces using a 1/2 in seam allowance. Press seam. Baste your quilt by placing the backing right side down, adding your batting and placing your quilt top right side up. Pin or spray baste in place. Quilt by outlining each seam on both sides using a walking foot. Bind your quilt.

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9261-min.jpg)

From your binding fabric, cut x7 2.5in x WOF strips. Sew them together end to end. Fold your binding wrong sides together length wise and press. Attach the binding to the quilt. The Greatest Granny Square quilt top can be completed in an afternoon. Itâ€™s large scale allows it to go together quickly. I canâ€™t wait to see what fabrics you choose for your quilt! Be sure to share your quilts using #thegreatestgrannysquare!

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9605-2-min.jpg)

Once you have tackled this large scale granny square, head on over to my blog for a free tutorial on a scrappy granny square quilt.

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9605-2-min.jpg)

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9673-min.jpg)

![Greatest Granny Square](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Greatest%20Granny%20Square%20Quilt/quiltylove-9671-min.jpg)

From Fabric B, cut x2 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x8 8.5in squares.

From Fabric C, cut x4 8.5in x WOF strips. Sub-cut into x4 8.5in squares. Set aside remaining strips for borders.

Cut the binding fabric into x7 2.5in x WOF strips.

Assemble the quilt top

Arrange your cut fabric squares into the granny square block as shown in the diagram. Sew together in rows using a 1/4in seam allowance. Press each row in the opposite direction (see arrows) for nesting your seams.

To make the top and bottom borders, sew together the remaining C strips. Cut into x2 8.5in x 56.5in pieces.

Add borders to top and bottom and sew together rows to make quilt top.

Prepare your backing fabric by folding in half width wise and cutting at fold. Sew together the two pieces using a 1/2 in seam allowance. Press seam.

Baste your quilt by placing the backing right side down, adding your batting and placing your quilt top right side up. Pin or spray baste in place.

Quilt by outlining each seam on both sides using a walking foot.

Bind your quilt.

From your binding fabric, cut x7 2.5in x WOF strips. Sew them together end to end. Fold your binding wrong sides together length wise and press. Attach the binding to the quilt.

The Greatest Granny Square quilt top can be completed in an afternoon. Itâ€™s large scale allows it to go together quickly. I canâ€™t wait to see what fabrics you choose for your quilt! Be sure to share your quilts using #thegreatestgrannysquare!

Once you have tackled this large scale granny square, head on over to my blog for a free tutorial on a scrappy granny square quilt.

posts.title: Wingback Chair Slipcover Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Hello again! It's me, Jessica from House Homemade. I'm so thankful to be back here on fabric.com to tell you all about a slipcover I made recently.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/1.0-min.jpg)

By "I" I mean myself and a super sweet and amazing friend, Melissa, that shares my love for jumping in, winging it and correcting along the way. I tell you that because before you say you can't do this project, I say, try it. Really, we were pleasantly surprised by how simple it was to make and we think it's worth a shot.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/1.2-min.jpg)

We recovered this wing back chair that my family affectionately refers to as 'Papa's Chair'. It was my great grandfathers, then my parents and my mom passed it down to us. At least as far back as I can remember I've seen it with a pink plaid upholstery job, a burgundy slip cover and then about 7 years ago, I worked with a friend's sweet grandmother to upholster it in this brown scroll fabric.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/2.0-min.jpg)

Upholstery is hard. I have so much respect for people who do it well and totally understand why the pricing is what it is. It's hard work. It was done well thanks to my friend but I was so relieved to try a slipcover this time. ####Supplies Needed The fabric I picked for my slipcover is Premier Prints Zoey Cove. Cove is the color name and it's a taupey grey. There is also 'clay' which looks to be more grey. Cove is warmer.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/2.1-min.jpg)

I looked at fabric.com's yardage chart estimator and checked a few others and ended up ordering 9 yards. Note: I didn't use all 9 but I got nervous and rounded up! #####You'll Need: * ~9 Yards of home decor fabric * Scissors * Pins * Sewing machine * Thread * Pencil * Seam ripper

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/3-min.jpg)

####Instructions: First I washed and dried the fabric. I'm so bad about skipping this step when I'm doing small projects. It was especially important this time because all this work would go to waste if it shrunk up the first time I washed it...

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/4-min.jpg)

We draped the fabric (right side down) over the chair making sure it almost touched the floor in the back, touched the seat of the chair and went almost to the floor in the front too. I trimmed the width I needed and then trimmed the length.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/5.1-min.jpg)

Next we took a scrap of what I cut off from the width and draped it from the seat of the chair over the wing and down to the floor. The angles get confusing on the wing but you just want to make sure the fabric's print is sitting straight, not on a diagonal.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/5.0-min.jpg)

When we had the fabric where we wanted them on the wings, I pinned the fabric closed around it and trimmed off the extra material.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/7.0-min.jpg)

Next to that, I pinned where the wing fabric met the section in the inside corner of the chair.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/7.1-min.jpg)

Let me stop right here and tell you. pins, pins, pins. They're your best friend for this. Make sure you have a bunch on hand.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/8.1-min.jpg)

Then we draped fabric over the arms in the same way. From the floor, over the arm, down to the seat.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/8.2-min.jpg)

We chose to cut separate pieces for the front of the chair arms.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/9-min.jpg)

I began with a rectangular scrap. I used pins and joined it with the arm piece starting from the bottom of the chair up and around the curve of the arm, and back to the bottom.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/10-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/11.1-min.jpg)

From here, each section was complete.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/12-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/5.3-min.jpg)

Completely pinned. We carefully pulled it off of the chair and I began to sew the lines that I was positive about. Its a huge slip cover full of weird angles so as soon as it came off of its form, it was hard to recognize what went where.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/13-min.jpg)

When I got to an angle that seemed tricky or didn't make sense, I just stopped sewing and went to another section. I realize this proves that I had no idea what I was doing. A pro would probably never do this. But it also proves that you can do it. Just with lots of guess and check. After the first round of sewing, we put the cover back on, re-pinned some spots that I needed clarification a little more help with.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/5.2-min.jpg)

For the inside corners, where we couldn't fit any pins, we used a colored pencil to mark a line to make it easier to sew.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/14-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/14.1-min.jpg)

Then more sewing. At this point, I had gotten most of the pieces sewn in the right spot and we were able to flip it right side out and see a preview of our handiwork.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/15-min.jpg)

Cue high fives and pats on the back! Clearly we weren't lacking self esteem that day. We did have to make a few more adjustments but really the hardest part about all of that is pulling the slipcover on and off. Cushion time. Melissa cut out two squares about 2" wider than the dimensions of the cushion.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/17-min.jpg)

Then cut a long and skinny piece that was the height of the cushion (+ 2" for seam allowance) and the length of the perimeter of the cushion with an extra 6 inches to create an envelope enclosure.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/18-min.jpg)

We matched a cushion corner with the trim corner, pinned and sewed almost all the way around. Lined up the bottom cushion piece and did the same thing.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/13-min.jpg)

We decided to make it an envelope enclosure because zippers are scary. ; ) We hemmed the top and bottom ends, folded them in, one on top of the other, and sewed them to the side edge.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/30-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/31-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/32-min.jpg)

LAST THING! I promise. For the super unfancy skirt, I cut rectangles 7" tall and then 2 at the width of the chair and 2 at the depth of the chair.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/34.jpg)

I hemmed the sides and bottom of each peice.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/35.jpg)

Then pinned them to the bottom of the slip cover (right sides together) making sure the skirt grazed the ground evenly on all sides.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/36.jpg)

I pulled the cover off, sewed one long line, one last time then that was it!

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/37.jpg)

This project took us a little less than a school day and the addition of the skirt over the weekend. I am so happy with how it turned out!

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/20-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/21-min.jpg)

I chose to have the dot pattern going horizontal on the back of the chair, seat of the chair, the tops of the arms and the front view of the wings. This lends to the pattern looking different on the sides. I was completely fine with this. In fact, I like that its uniform but there is a bit more interest in certain areas. It would be the easiest to sew with fabric that has no direction but I CANNOT, NOT DO PATTERN. Solid is so hard for me.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/22-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/23-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/24-min.jpg)

The chair is so much lighter and brighter now. I love the modern fabric and the neutral design.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/25-min.jpg)

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/26-min.jpg)

I honestly can't believe we did it ourselves. Not because it's perfect because it's not. It's obviously not. But it looks great to me. It gives me the updated look I wanted and the job is DONE!

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/21-min.jpg)

I hope this has inspired you to give a slipcover a go. You really CAN do this. Get a friend that's willing to help and make a fun day of it. It was a great day and I'm so thankful.

![Wingback Chair Slipcover](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wingback%20Chair%20Slipcover/27-min.jpg)

Happy sewing!

This fun coffin block is the perfect addition to your spooky Halloween dÃ©cor. Create an entire quiltâ€™s worth of blocks, or just one for a charming pillow!
