posts.title: The TÃ‰LIO Collection: Enchanting Emerald
posts.markdown:
Created by: Emily Hallman Designs Hi fabric.com blog! I am so excited to be here today to bring you a fabulous project that I just finished up featuring TÃ‰LIO fabrics.

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald1-min.jpg)

This project is all about color! I can't think of a single color I don't like to sew with or wear. I definitely have favorites that I wear a lot, but it's hard to think of a color that I make a concerted effort to avoid, or that I just don't care for. I've spent a great deal of time looking for the right color fabric over the years too. Navy must be rich and dark, not vintage or faded looking, yellow should be bright without being gaudy or cheap looking, and reds should be true red - not too orange, not too blue. Emerald is a color I love, especially for fall, and it's a color I think I wear well. (After a summer in lots of white, I'm reminded thanks to all the pictures I take that white is actually not a great color on me. So, moving forward: less white, more bold colors. Hold me to it.) I found this fabric on fabric.com, and the moment I saw it I not only squealed with delight at having finally found the perfect shade of emerald! It's 100% Viscose Rayon, 56" wide, and it's machine washable.

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Large_0266988.jpg)

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald18-min.jpg)

Rayon (also called viscose) is made from wood pulp, a naturally occurring, cellulose-based raw material. I like it because its characteristics are similar to that of linen and cotton, and it is beyond comfortable to wear in the Texas heat. I love the drape of viscose batiste or challis, and it's easy to work with and launder. It also retains color well, which is why you can find such rich colors in a rayon fabrication. It doesn't pill unless the fabric is made from short, low-twist yarns (I've never had a rayon that even remotely pilled), and it doesn't build up static electricity. Rayon does, however, wrinkle so loose fitting garments are best (full skirts and dresses, flowy tops, and scarves). Bemberg rayon is also a fantastic option for linings. I choose it over polyester or acetate every time.

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald20-min.jpg)

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald21-min.jpg)

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald22-min.jpg)

This particular rayon is a batiste, so it's especially lightweight and drapes exceptionally well. It's opaque enough to forgo a lining, which is great. Use a little extra care when you cut it out, because it can be a tad slippery (no edges hanging off your cutting table!), and I would also pin your pieces together in one or two additional areas just to ensure it doesn't move around as you sew it. I used a size 70 universal needle, all purpose thread, and I serged all the raw edges. French seams would also be lovely. I let the dress rest on the dress form overnight to let the bias fall, then I leveled it and hemmed it.

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald17-min.jpg)

I used an out-of-print pattern, Butterick 5878, and I replaced the tiered skirt with a full circle skirt for the most movement.

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald5-min.jpg)

For those of us in warmer climates where seasons take their sweet time arriving (or don't change at all), color is a great way to dress for the season without layering or piling on coats or things that don't make sense for the weather. So, this emerald viscose makes for one seriously pretty dress, and I can ease my way into fall without looking ridiculous. Considering how much I love this color, I'm surprised that this dress is the first garment in this color I have in my closet. I think I'm looking at a fall season jam packed with emerald green!

![Telio Brand Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Telio%20Collection%3A%20Enchanting%20Emerald/Emerald14-min.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.markdown: Created by: The Late Sew Hello lovely fabric.com friends! My name is Vienna and I have a little blog called The Late Sew (I only sew late at night, because motherhood), and Iâ€™m so excited to be here today talking about this amazing new digitally printed rayon challis. Fabric.com has several brand new beautiful prints to choose from and Iâ€™m here to show you what I sewed up with mine! I chose the Garden Grove Digitally Printed Rayon Challis, which is a gorgeous medium-scale floral print in dreamy blues, purples and greens. When I opened my fabric after it came in the mail, I was like, â€œWhaaaaat?!â€ and let me tell you why. First of all, the print is even prettier in person; the colors are lovely and the design has an almost watercolored, painterly quality that I really love. But the main reason for the â€œWhaaaaat?!â€ was the texture of the fabric. It wasâ€¦crispy? Crunchy? Anyway, whatever it was, it didnâ€™t feel like any rayon challis Iâ€™ve ever used before. Much heavier and not drapey at all. I was a bit skeptical at first, but this turned out to be part of the magic of this fabric. As stated on fabric.com in the description of this fabric, itâ€™s really important to pre-wash your digitally printed rayon. In order to print the beautiful designs on the fabric, it has to be specially treated. This is why it feels all crispy crunchy. I threw mine in the washer, washed on cold, and I dried mine on medium for about 20 minutes. NOTE: Itâ€™s recommended on fabric.com that you lay flat to dry. I decided to dry mine in the drier a wee bit to prevent future accidental shrinkages (ask me how I know about this), but lots of sewing people have lots of opinions about this. Do what your heart tells you. But I wouldnâ€™t recommend drying it on high heat. Anyway, once I took it out of the drier, it was like magic. Suuuper soft, totally lovely, drapey, perfect rayon challis. I even twirled it around all dramatic like and heard that lovely swoosh sound that rayon has and it was music to my ears. You know what Iâ€™m talking about, all you fellow rayon lovers out there. It was time to cut into this bad boy, and I had the perfect pattern in mind. A few weeks ago, I made a Tea House Dress, pattern by Sew House 7. Itâ€™s this lovely vintage-style dress that is SOOOOO comfortable and pretty and wearable and just everything a dress ought to be. You can check out the first one I made over at The Late Sew. I wore my first one three times in one week, so I knew I needed another, and the Garden Grove Rayon Challis seemed like the perfect fabric for this pattern. I cut my pattern pieces and got to sewing. This rayon sews up like most rayon Iâ€™m familiar with. Itâ€™s light weight, and can be shifty, so be extra careful when cutting and sewing. Cut carefully and use pattern weights (or, you know, random heavy objects you have lying around). If you are lazy with the pins like I am, maybe up your pin game a little? If youâ€™ve ever sewn with rayon before, youâ€™ll be just fine. If you havenâ€™t, donâ€™t be afraid! The heavenliness that is wearing rayon challis is worth the extra effort. So soft! My new Tea House Dress in the Garden Grove print is SO good you guys. Itâ€™s drapey and flowy and pretty AND I can just throw it on and look like I tried to look nice, when actually, I didnâ€™t have to try that hard. It ties at the waist so itâ€™s flattering, but itâ€™s loose and comfy so you donâ€™t have to worry about how many donuts you may or may not have eaten recently. And the pockets, darlings. All dresses should have pockets, donâ€™t you agree? So here I am modeling my Garden Grove Tea Dress in my garden. Actually itâ€™s just my backyard. I donâ€™t really garden, because Iâ€™m too busy sewing, but letâ€™s pretend I have a pretty garden in which I can traipse about, swooshing my rayon dress around like a tea party princess. Get your digitally printed rayon challis from fabric.com, WASH it to see the magic unfold, and sew up some swooshy goodness for yourself. Then tell me all about it, because I love new sewing friends and chatting about sewing adventures. Thanks for letting me hang out with you all on the fabulous fabric.com blog. Happy sewing, loves!

Rather than making a single block at a time, you will be building all the blocks required simultaneously. When finished, various sized squares and rectangles will create 12" (finished size) blocks.

![Fall Block Party Mod Tartan](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Block%20Party%3A%20Mod%20Tartan/Floor%20pillow_6-min.jpg)

####Fabric Requirements We chose a fall palette of Kona Cotton solids for our block, and these fabric requirements are for a 72"x72" finished product!

![Fall Block Party Mod Tartan](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Block%20Party%3A%20Mod%20Tartan/swatch-min.jpg)

* 1.25 yds. Kona Cotton Eggshell * 0.75 yds Kona Cotton Curry * 1.25 yds. Kona Cotton Jade Green * 1.25 yds. Kona Cotton Sienna * 0.125 yds. posts.title: Sewing 101: Tips for Sewing With Minky
posts.markdown:
Created by: Dot Dot Baby Hi, Iâ€™m Jes from dotdotbaby.com a handmade baby gift shop.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/BlanketsNoConetti-min.jpg)

There is nothing sweeter than bringing your new babe home from the hospital to wrap them up in a soft and cozy blanket! And, there is nothing softer than Minky! Shannon Fabrics offers the highest quality Minky material, with endless options like dimple dot, faux fur, patterned, embossed, etc. You can create the cutest gifts for a mom-to-be or yourself!

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/GoTos-min.jpg)

Minky is a material similar to knit, as it tends to stretch while sewing. If you have never tried sewing with Minky, or past attempts have left you stumped, these tips and tricks will have you mastering projects like a pro. First, Iâ€™ll share with you some of the most helpful tips I have learned and then we will create the perfect shower gift together. ####Prewash Your Cotton Minky does not shrink, so if you are pairing it with cotton (like in this tutorial), make sure to pre-wash the cotton first. ####Heat and Washing Minky is heat sensitive and embossed patterns can be ruined if it comes in contact with an iron. You shouldnâ€™t need to iron your minky at all, but since we are pairing it with a cotton we will iron that before we put them together. Keep in mind your heat settings when your drying the finished blanket. Tumble on low heat, or if possible - hang to dry. Avoid using fabric softeners, as they can leave a greasy film and clump the fibers. ####Leave Excess Minky Around All Edges If your Minky has wavy selvage (especially on the Dimple Dot), donâ€™t try to sew over the top- cut those off! Since Minky has the tendency to stretch slightly, I have found if you leave yourself extra Minky around all your edges youâ€™ll have a little extra in case you have any pulling. Just 1/2 - 1 inch is all you need. We will trim the excess off later.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/Selvage-min.jpg)

####Vacuum Your Edges Vacuum the edges of your Minky right after cutting, especially the faux fur. It becomes airborne and messy really easy, so vacuuming the edges with the wand makes quick clean-up. It also prevents the fibers from getting stuck in your machine. If youâ€™re sewing near outdoors, you could also take it outside and shake it out or use a lint roller. ####Minky on the Bottom When you are getting ready to pin, always have your cotton on top. You will have less stretching, and since you cut your Minky larger than your cotton youâ€™ll be able to see where youâ€™re sewing.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/pinnedblanketpanel-min.jpg)

####Pin Like Crazy Use lots of pins! Seems excessive, but spacing them every 1-2â€ keeps everything in place and prevents some of the stretching. ####Stat Sewing on the Length Side of the Minky Begin sewing on the length side of your Minky (the side you cut the selvage off). Minky tends to be less stretchy lengthwise and more widthwise. If youâ€™ve forgotten, slightly pull your edges and you will feel the difference. ####Wide Seam Allowance For this project, I recommend using 1/2â€ seam allowance. Donâ€™t forget your locking stitches. ####Control Your Fabric I am constantly working my left hand, under the Minky and then over the cotton, wherever I feel like the Minky is moving or needs help staying in place. My right hand is holding the project in place from pin to pin as I sew.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/controlfabric-min.jpg)

####Sewing Minky to Minky & Walking Foot There is only one way to do this! Invest in a walking, or even feed foot. With all my Minky experience, I thought I would be able to sew a double sided minky blanket. It was a nightmare, and did not turn out. The first time sewing with a walking foot, was magical. No stretching. At all. Your bottom feed dogs are guiding the bottom Minky anyway, but with a walking foot, the top Minky is also being fed through the presser foot, feeding both materials at the same rate. If you plan on sewing a lot of Minky projects, you will thank yourself for this purchase. I now sew all of my minky projects with this foot. ####Use a Stretch Needle and Longer Stitch Length Replace your standard sewing machine needle with a New stretch sewing machine needle- ideally use a size 90/14. Sew using at lease a 3mm stitch length. As Minky is a knit, this will help provide a professional sewing results. ####Clean Your Machine Regular cleaning of your machine is a good idea anyway, but when you are sewing with Minky you will find more fuzz than usual. Open your bobbin compartment and brush or vacuum out any buildup. ####DIY Baby Shower Gift with Minky Now that you have all the tips and tricks needed to start your next project with Minky, let's create a baby blanket and burp cloth set that will be perfect as a shower gift! I made a version for a boy and girl to give you inspiration for both.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/ConfettiPic-min.jpg)

####Materials Needed: * 1 yard Shannon CuddleÂ® Minky (for the boy blanket I used Shannon Minky Luxe CuddleÂ® Mountain Fox Pewter and for the girl blanket I used Shannon Minky Luxe CuddleÂ® Hide Ice Pink. I used Shannon Minky CuddleÂ® Dimple Ivory for the burp cloths, but you could make them from the 1 yard Minky you purchase for your blanket * 1 yard quilting cotton (For the boy blanket I used Dear Stella Adventure Awaits Animals White and for the girl blanket I used Art Gallery Letters Xoxoxo. I also love Art Gallery, Cotton + Steel, Moda, Michael Miller, Dear Stella * Mat and rotary cutter - or scissors and ruler * Pins * Sewing thread * Coordinating topstitching thread

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/Materials-min.jpg)

####Cutting Your Materials For the blanket: Cut ONLY the cotton section 32â€ wide x 36â€ long For the burp cloths: Cut your remaining material in 1/2 leaving you with (2) 10â€ x 18â€ long panels

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/Materials-min.jpg)

If you own a serger, serge edges of blanket now. Lay your cotton blanket panel on your minky right sides together making sure your Minky hangs out around all edges. In case you have any stretching, leaving yourself a little extra Minky is always better than cutting too short. Cut the Minky about 1â€ away from the edge of your cotton. Vacuum those edges too. You can do the same with your burp cloth panels now. Pin in place. Place pins about 1-2â€ apart. Now, youâ€™re ready to sew! ####Start Sewing On the length side of you project and with about 1/2â€ seam allowance add your first locking stitch. No need to rush, sew slow and steady all the way around. Leave about a 6â€ opening for your blanket, and about 4â€ for your burp cloths. ####Trim edges Trim off any excess minky and notch your corners so they arenâ€™t bulky when you turn your projects inside out. Make sure to pull your corners out so they look nice and sharp.

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/Notches-min.jpg)

####Topstitch Choose a coordinating thread and topstitch your blanket and burp cloths. How amazing do these look?

![Tips for Sewing With Minky](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20with%20Minky/Finished-min.jpg)

Now you can choose a lovely ribbon to finish your gift!

posts.title: Tie Front Flannel Shirt Dress Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Weâ€™re not sure thereâ€™s a more well-known look than the quintessential red and black flannel shirt. From 90s grunge fans who rocked the look as part of an overall edgy, rocker vibe to the outdoorsy crowd who preferred the casual, easy-to-wear style (and ability to keep them warm) flannel was a fashion staple that seemed posed to be around for the long haul. But as the years went on and trends changed flannel fabric took a back seat to other more prominent fashions. But, as most of us know, what goes around comes around and this staple of the 90s fashion scene is making a comeback in a big way! Gone are the days of sticking with the simple flannel shirt. Instead, new designs from flannel pants to skirts and dresses are becoming just as popular as the humble flannel shirt, making it the perfect fabric for those who love DIYing their own personal fashions. ####Why Wear Flannel Fabric? If youâ€™re either too young to have appreciated flannel in the 90s, or simply never jumped on the flannel bandwagon, weâ€™re here to let you know youâ€™ve been missing out! Flannel fabric goes through a special mechanical process that raises the fibers of the cloth, making it soft and warm to wear. Itâ€™s durable enough to withstand even vigorous activity (like a hike on a chilly fall day) and is typically associated with a relaxed fit that allows for unrestricted movement and flatters pretty much any body type. Plus, itâ€™s an easy to sew fabric thatâ€™s stable, versatile and relatively inexpensive. #####Here are some of our favorites this season:

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/flannel_shirt_fabrics.jpg)

Kaufman Mammoth Flannel Buffalo Check Medium White Kaufman Mammoth Flannel Plaid Blue Kaufman Mammoth Flannel Plaid Adventure Yarn Dyed Flannel Check Red Black ####The Flannel Shirt: Always in Style Like we mentioned before, flannel shirts have been popular for decades. With long sleeves and buttons up the front theyâ€™re perfect for throwing on to keep warm without needing a heavy coat. Or you can pair them with a variety of outfits. Dress them up with jeans and high heeled boots for a night out or dress it down with leggings and sneakers for some lounging time at home. If youâ€™re going to start with a shirt you canâ€™t go wrong with classic red flannel like this popular fabric. It works well for men and women (and would make a great homemade gift!). But modern flannel isnâ€™t limited to the tradition designs of the grunge era. Choose a fun and unexpected print to take your flannel shirt in a whole new direction that combines the traditional fabric with modern design elements for a perfectly funky look. Check out this great shirt pattern from Grainline Studio. ####DIY Tie Front Flannel Shirt Dress Inspired from a 2017 designer dress, the R13 tie-waist flannel dress retails for a few hundred dollars, but you can create this look for under $40 with a basic menâ€™s shirt pattern and some flannel fabric.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20dress%20close%20up-min.jpg)

####Supplies: * Yarn Dyed Red/Black Check Flannel Fabric â€“ 2.5 yards (45" wide flannel-4 yds) * McCallâ€™s Menâ€™s Shirt Pattern M6044 * Shirt Buttons * Pattern Paper or Tissue Paper This look requires a loose-fit, so we chose a Menâ€™s shirt pattern in order to obtain that look with minimal pattern alterations. In the designer dress, thereâ€™s traditional elements in the collar and sleeve cuffs, and no back yoke, so this pattern satisfied those needs.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20dress%20side%20view-min.jpg)

####Altering the Pattern: Use tissue paper or pattern paper to lengthen the shirt pattern where itâ€™s marked. I extended it 8â€ for a knee length dress. I marked where the tie-waist sleeves would be attached.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/8%20inch%20lengthen%20pattern-min.jpg)

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Pattern%20Sleeve%20attach%20points-min.jpg)

The sleeves will become the waist tie- so I extended the sleeve shoulders to create a straight line so they could easily be incorporated into the side seams.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Sleeve%20patterns-min.jpg)

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20sleeve%20pieces-min.jpg)

For the cap sleeve look, I added paper to extend the shoulders, and marked where the sleeve opening would be. I measured my bust and altered the pattern for a proper fit. I also compared the design to the pattern and reduced the underarms to obtain a straight, loose fit.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/pattern%20cap%20sleeves-min.jpg)

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Pattern%20side%20by%20side-min.jpg)

Once my pattern alterations were complete, I followed the pattern as directed, but I did skip the interfacing for a more casual look.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20dress%20laid%20out-min.jpg)

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20dress%20laid%20out%20with%20waist%20tie%20showing-min.jpg)

With flannel your options are pretty much limitless. This versatile and timeless fabric is perfect for nearly any type of sewing project. So whether youâ€™re looking to tackle an intricate dress pattern or want to start simple with a pair of pants youâ€™ll end up with an end project you can be proud of. Plus, you can easily find hundreds of flannel options at fabric.com. So go check them out, find your favorites, and create some on trend flannel fashions.

![Tie Front Flannel Dress](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tie%20Front%20Flannel%20Shirt%20Dress/Flannel%20dress%20option%202-min.jpg)

If youâ€™re going to start with a shirt you canâ€™t go wrong with classic red flannel like this popular fabric. It works well for men and women (and would make a great homemade gift!). But modern flannel isnâ€™t limited to the tradition designs of the grunge era. Choose a fun and unexpected print to take your flannel shirt in a whole new direction that combines the traditional fabric with modern design elements for a perfectly funky look.

Check out this great shirt pattern from Grainline Studio.

DIY Tie Front Flannel Shirt Dress

Inspired from a 2017 designer dress, the R13 tie-waist flannel dress retails for a few hundred dollars, but you can create this look for under $40 with a basic menâ€™s shirt pattern and some flannel fabric.

Supplies:

  • Yarn Dyed Red/Black Check Flannel Fabric â€“ 2.5 yards (45" wide flannel-4 yds)
  • McCallâ€™s Menâ€™s Shirt Pattern M6044
  • Shirt Buttons
  • Pattern Paper or Tissue Paper

This look requires a loose-fit, so we chose a Menâ€™s shirt pattern in order to obtain that look with minimal pattern alterations. In the designer dress, thereâ€™s traditional elements in the collar and sleeve cuffs, and no back yoke, so this pattern satisfied those needs.

Altering the Pattern:

Use tissue paper or pattern paper to lengthen the shirt pattern where itâ€™s marked. I extended it 8â€ for a knee length dress. I marked where the tie-waist sleeves would be attached.

The sleeves will become the waist tie- so I extended the sleeve shoulders to create a straight line so they could easily be incorporated into the side seams.

For the cap sleeve look, I added paper to extend the shoulders, and marked where the sleeve opening would be. I measured my bust and altered the pattern for a proper fit. I also compared the design to the pattern and reduced the underarms to obtain a straight, loose fit.

Once my pattern alterations were complete, I followed the pattern as directed, but I did skip the interfacing for a more casual look.

With flannel your options are pretty much limitless. This versatile and timeless fabric is perfect for nearly any type of sewing project. So whether youâ€™re looking to tackle an intricate dress pattern or want to start simple with a pair of pants youâ€™ll end up with an end project you can be proud of. Plus, you can easily find hundreds of flannel options at fabric.com. So go check them out, find your favorites, and create some on trend flannel fashions.

posts.title: Trick or Tweet Bird Costume
posts.markdown:
Created by: Little Lizard King Hi everyone, Iâ€™m Jane, and I am a designer for Little Lizard King. I was so thrilled to be given the opportunity to blog for fabric.com for Halloween! My youngest son has been begging me for a bird costume and I had been brainstorming ideas. My first thought was that it would get way more wear if I could think of a way to make it something he could put on all by himself. At the age of 4, independence is a huge factor in how often something gets played with or worn in our house. The Little Lizard King Yogger pattern was the perfect choice for the pants and I used the Ravenna raglan pattern for the top. Once I settled on my patterns, I was excited to get started!

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/DSC_19472046-min.jpg)

####Fabric Choices For this bird costume you'll need knit fabrics in a variety of bold, bright colors. I used the following knits for my costume, and the colors were amazing: * 3 yds. Kaufman Laguna Stretch Jersey Knit Royal (this is the main fabric) * 1/2 yds. Kaufman Laguna Stretch Jersey Knit Orange (bird legs) * 1/4 yd. Kaufman Dana Jersey Knit Fern Clover * 1/4 yd. Kaufman Catalina Interlock Knit Red * 1/4 yd. Kaufman Dana Jersey Knit 4.8oz Yellow * 1/4 yd. Telio Stretch Bamboo Rayon Jersey Knit Sky Blue ####Costume Patterns Two of Little Lizard Kings popular patterns, the Yogger and Ravenna patterns, pair perfectly to create this costume! * Little Lizard King Yogger pattern * Little Lizard King Ravenna pattern

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/DSC_19562046-min.jpg)

####Preparing the Pants/Yoggers The pants were extremely easy! I simply followed the step by step instructions provided in the Little Lizard King Yogger pattern. I chose the full length pants option and simply created the look of bird legs by manipulating the color placement. To create the look of skinny bird legs, I used the orange colored knit for the bottom most fitted part of the yoggers. I used the royal blue colored knit for the top, bubble part of the yoggers, to mimic the wider thigh of a bird leg. The yoga style waistband made the pants super easy for my son to slide on and off without assistance. ####Pattern Adjustments Because the Ravenna Raglan top was designed for girls, I sized up 2 sizes for my son so it would have a looser fit. I also omitted the waistband and wristbands and just extended the pattern pieces 3 to 4 inches longer so they could be hemmed normally. ####Preparing the Wings This is the part of the tutorial where I kind of winged itâ€¦â€¦pun intended. But I will walk you through the construction step by step. First, I laid out my front shirt piece and one sleeve. I placed the sleeve at an angle because I wanted to cut the wing in way that would allow him to raise his arms without the shirt pulling up. I measured the length of the sleeve and the length of the shirt from the armpit down. I then cut my wing flaps (as mirror images) 1.5 inches shorter than both of those measurements and rounded it down. This is also where I said that I winged it. The angle of the wing flap and sleeve do not have to be identical and there is no exact way to round the wing flaps.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/Tutorial%20Pic%201-min.JPG)

You are now ready to add the feathers. My feathers were about 4 inches long by 3 inches wide, but this is personal preference. I stacked up a few of my knits and cut several at a time. When I added the feathers to the wings I started at the very bottom and worked my way up. Once I had a row in place, I would sew across the entire row to attach them all at once. Use a matching bobbin thread color so the thread is not noticeable on the back side of the wing.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%202-min.JPG)

Continue adding rows of feathers.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%203-min.JPG)

When you reach the upper part of the wing, start angling the feathers slightly. By the top row, the straight raw edge of each feather should be flush with the raw edge of the wing.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%204-min.jpg)

You will now enclose the top raw edge of the wing in binding. Cut a strip of knit 1.5â€ by a measurement that is half inch longer than the top wing width. Flip the wing, wrong side up. Place the strip of knit across the back of the wing, lining up the top raw edge of the wing with the long raw edge of the knit binding. Sew to attach.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%205-min.jpg)

Flip the wing right side up and trim the seam allowance.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%206-min.jpg)

Flip the bias up. Tuck the short raw end in towards the wing. Fold the top raw edge of the bias to the seam and then fold it down again to enclose the top raw edge of the wing. Sew to attach.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%207-min.JPG)

Your finished wing will look like this. Give the feathers a good steam press and baste them down the straight side of each wing (if desired).

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%208-min.jpg)

####Finishing the Top Cut an oval for the center of the shirt. For easier application, back the oval with wonder under and then apply it and topstitch it to the shirt front.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%209-min.JPG)

Sew the raglan shirt front, shirt back and sleeves together as directed in the pattern. They will now make a continuous loop. Place a wing on the shirt front, right sides together. The top wing binding should begin directly under the underarm seam. The straight raw edge of the wing will be lined up with the straight raw edge of the shirt. Baste in place. Repeat with other wing.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%2010-min.JPG)

Fold the back of the shirt over onto the front of the shirt. Line up the sleeve, underarm seam and side raw edges. Sew to attach using a stretch stitch. Repeat on other side.

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/tutorial%20pic%2011-min.jpg)

Turn the shirt right side out. Following the directions in the pattern add the neck band to finish the neckline. Hem the sleeves and bottom of the shirt 1/2". The only step left is to tack the wing bias to the sleeve seam of the shirt so it looks like one piece. I tacked the wing about every 1.5 to 2 inches with a quick hand stitch. ####The Hat The bird hat is something I quickly drafted for my son. I extended the center piece of the bonnet to a little peak to create the look of a bird. I also sewed three pairs of feathers, right sides together, with interfacing sandwiched in between. The interfacing helped them stand up nicely. I basted the bottom of the feathers together to make them easier to work with and to keep them positioned the way I wanted them. I then cut a small slit in the top of the hat and inserted the feathers. To secure them I sewed across the opening and the base of the feathers from the underside of the hat!

![Bird Costume](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bird%20Costume/DSC_19162046-min.jpg)

That's it- you're done! I hope your little trick or tweeter has a great Halloween and loves their costume. This costume idea could easily be modified to be a bat or a butterfly!

posts.title: DIY Hooded Bat Cape
posts.markdown:
Created by: Blue Susan Makes Hello sewing friends! This is Sarah from Blue Susan Makes. We have a little hooded bat cape that I made years ago that has lived through the toddler life of 3 little boys. Now that our 4th boy is hitting the dress-up stage I thought it would be fun to remake this cape and teach you how to make one too. With Halloween right around the corner you can sew it up to add to a set of Batman pajamas and your costume is ready to go! For this project youâ€™ll need a sturdy black knit that wonâ€™t fray and has a little body to it. A knit with 4 way stretch is ideal but not necessary. I chose to use this Polyester Spandex Matte Lame Jersey. It has a sheen to it on one side that makes it look a little like a soft vinyl but itâ€™s stretchy and has great drape. I love it!

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%2025.jpg)

This pattern is sized to fit about 3-4T. The cape length is about 38â€™â€™ from the nape of the neck to the pointed bottom. In this tutorial you will be making 2 hoods. One will be the outer hood and one will be used as the lining. Iâ€™ll show you how to put the hoods together and sew them to the single layer cape. We will hem the sides of the cape and stitch on a Velcro closure. The bottom of the cape will remain unhemmed. Letâ€™s get started!

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%2024.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 1 yard black knit fabric (we used Polyester Spandex Matte Lame Jersey) * 1 square 5/8'' black, sew in, hook and loop tape, velcro * â€œStretchâ€ sewing machine needle * Printed copy of the Hooded Bat Cape Pattern ####Cutting and Pattern Prep Tips * Print pattern pages and tape them together into a grid as instructed on the PDF file. To assemble the grid, cut one short side and one long side off of each page to make it easier to tape together. Cut out pattern pieces. * Fold your fabric in half to quickly cut out the pieces 2 at a time. Lay all your pieces out on the fabric before you begin cutting. * Use pattern weights to hold the patterns in place while cutting. Table knives from your kitchen work great in a pinch. * Pay attention to the stretch lines on the fabric and place those lines parallel to the direction the fabric stretches the most * Use washable chalk (test on a fabric scrap) or washi tape to mark the placement of the bat ears on one Right Hood Side Panel and one Left Hood Side Panel. These panels will be used for the Outer Hood. * The perfectionist in me didnâ€™t want to attempt cutting out the points on the cape with the paper floating around so I used a white chalk marker to draw around them before cutting. Just cut off the white as you cut since these points will not be hemmed.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%2023.jpg)

####Cutting Instructions: * Cut 4 pieces from the Hood Side Panel pattern (2 Right Side Hoods, 2 Left Side Hoods) * Cut 2 pieces from the Hood Center Panel pattern * Cut 1 piece on the fold from the Cape pattern * Cut 4 pieces from the Bat Ear pattern ####Sewing Instructions *All seams are sewn with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance unless otherwise specified. ####Make the Outer Hood and Hood Lining Using the Outer Hood Side Panels (marked for the ears) begin to construct the Outer Hood. With right sides together pin a Right Hood Side Panel to a Hood Center Panel. Sew the 2 panels together with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance.The matte finish on this fabric showed every pin mark so I decided to keep all the pins within the seam allowance. I pointed the pins in the direction of my sew starting point so that they were easy to remove as I sewed.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%201-min.jpg)

With right sides together, pin a Left Side Panel to the other side of the Center Panel. Sew them together and press seams open with a warm iron. Set this Outer Hood aside.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%202-min.jpg)

Repeat the first two steps to make the Hood Lining using the remaining 2 Side Panels and Center Panel. Press all seams open.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%203-min.jpg)

Press the bottom edge of the Hood Lining toward the inside 1/2â€˜â€™. This will be topstitched along the pressed fold later to enclose the neck seam.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%204-min.jpg)

With right sides together, match up the front seams of the Hood Lining and the Outer Hood and pin them together around the face opening.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%205-min.jpg)

Sew around the face opening. Make sure to unfold the bottom edge of the Hood Lining. Start sewing at that crease and stop sewing at the crease on the opposite side. Backstitch at the beginning and end.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%206-min.jpg)

Trim off the top front corner on each end, close to the stitches and clip into the seam allowance of the curves as shown.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%207-min.jpg)

Turn the Hood right side out and push out the front corners with a dull pencil tip. Press the seam around the face so it lays flat.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%208-min.jpg)

####Hem the sides of the cape Fold the straight sides of the cape towards the inside 3/8â€˜â€™ and press.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%209-min.jpg)

Stitch along the hem about 1/4â€˜â€™ from the folded edge. It works best to start at the neck of the cape and sew toward the point. It may be tricky to sew along the narrow point but you can make it easier by using a pin to help hold the tip as you feed it through the machine.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2010-min.jpg)

####Attach the Hood to the Cape With right sides together, lay the Outer Hood onto the neck of the Cape. Lift the Hood Lining out of the way and pin the Outer Hood to the neck of the Cape. Make sure to line up the side hem of the cape with the front corner of the Hood.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/Photo%2011-min.jpg)

Sew the Outer Hood to Cape backstitching at the beginning and end of the seam. Press the seam allowance toward the Hood.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2012-min.jpg)

At the front corner where the hood meets the cape trim down the Outer Hood seam allowance to about 1/8 â€˜â€™ to reduce bulk.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2013-min.jpg)

Slightly trim the remaining seam allowance at the corner to allow it to tuck into the front corner of the hood easily. Refold the Hood Lining along the crease to enclose all the raw edges.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2014-min.jpg)

Pin the pressed fold of the Hood Lining so it lines up with the Outer Hood stitch line.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2015-min.jpg)

Topstitch along the Hood Lining about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the folded edge.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2016%20-min.jpg)

Sew a small square of hook and loop tape to the corner points of the Hood. Sew the soft (loop) side to the inside of one corner and the scratchy (hook) side to the outside of the opposite corner.

![Hooded Bat Cape](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hooded%20Bat%20Cape/photo%2017-min.jpg)

####Make and Attach the Ears Place 2 Bat Ear pieces with right sides together. Created by: Blue Susan Makes

Hello sewing friends! This is Sarah from Blue Susan Makes. We have a little hooded bat cape that I made years ago that has lived through the toddler life of 3 little boys. Now that our 4th boy is hitting the dress-up stage I thought it would be fun to remake this cape and teach you how to make one too. With Halloween right around the corner you can sew it up to add to a set of Batman pajamas and your costume is ready to go!

For this project youâ€™ll need a sturdy black knit that wonâ€™t fray and has a little body to it. A knit with 4 way stretch is ideal but not necessary. I chose to use this Polyester Spandex Matte Lame Jersey. It has a sheen to it on one side that makes it look a little like a soft vinyl but itâ€™s stretchy and has great drape. I love it!

This pattern is sized to fit about 3-4T. The cape length is about 38â€™â€™ from the nape of the neck to the pointed bottom. In this tutorial you will be making 2 hoods. One will be the outer hood and one will be used as the lining. Iâ€™ll show you how to put the hoods together and sew them to the single layer cape. We will hem the sides of the cape and stitch on a Velcro closure. The bottom of the cape will remain unhemmed. Letâ€™s get started!

Supplies Needed

  • 1 yard black knit fabric (we used Polyester Spandex Matte Lame Jersey)
  • 1 square 5/8'' black, sew in, hook and loop tape, velcro
  • â€œStretchâ€ sewing machine needle
  • Printed copy of the Hooded Bat Cape Pattern

Cutting and Pattern Prep Tips

  • Print pattern pages and tape them together into a grid as instructed on the PDF file. To assemble the grid, cut one short side and one long side off of each page to make it easier to tape together. Cut out pattern pieces.
  • Fold your fabric in half to quickly cut out the pieces 2 at a time. Lay all your pieces out on the fabric before you begin cutting.
  • Use pattern weights to hold the patterns in place while cutting. Table knives from your kitchen work great in a pinch.
  • Pay attention to the stretch lines on the fabric and place those lines parallel to the direction the fabric stretches the most
  • Use washable chalk (test on a fabric scrap) or washi tape to mark the placement of the bat ears on one Right Hood Side Panel and one Left Hood Side Panel. These panels will be used for the Outer Hood.
  • The perfectionist in me didnâ€™t want to attempt cutting out the points on the cape with the paper floating around so I used a white chalk marker to draw around them before cutting. Just cut off the white as you cut since these points will not be hemmed.

Cutting Instructions:

  • Cut 4 pieces from the Hood Side Panel pattern (2 Right Side Hoods, 2 Left Side Hoods)
  • Cut 2 pieces from the Hood Center Panel pattern
  • Cut 1 piece on the fold from the Cape pattern
  • Cut 4 pieces from the Bat Ear pattern

Sewing Instructions

*All seams are sewn with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance unless otherwise specified.

Make the Outer Hood and Hood Lining

Using the Outer Hood Side Panels (marked for the ears) begin to construct the Outer Hood. With right sides together pin a Right Hood Side Panel to a Hood Center Panel. Sew the 2 panels together with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance.The matte finish on this fabric showed every pin mark so I decided to keep all the pins within the seam allowance. I pointed the pins in the direction of my sew starting point so that they were easy to remove as I sewed.

With right sides together, pin a Left Side Panel to the other side of the Center Panel. Sew them together and press seams open with a warm iron. Set this Outer Hood aside.

Repeat the first two steps to make the Hood Lining using the remaining 2 Side Panels and Center Panel. Press all seams open.

Press the bottom edge of the Hood Lining toward the inside 1/2â€˜â€™. This will be topstitched along the pressed fold later to enclose the neck seam.

With right sides together, match up the front seams of the Hood Lining and the Outer Hood and pin them together around the face opening.

Sew around the face opening. Make sure to unfold the bottom edge of the Hood Lining. Start sewing at that crease and stop sewing at the crease on the opposite side. Backstitch at the beginning and end.

Trim off the top front corner on each end, close to the stitches and clip into the seam allowance of the curves as shown.

Turn the Hood right side out and push out the front corners with a dull pencil tip. Press the seam around the face so it lays flat.

Hem the sides of the cape

Fold the straight sides of the cape towards the inside 3/8â€˜â€™ and press.

Stitch along the hem about 1/4â€˜â€™ from the folded edge. It works best to start at the neck of the cape and sew toward the point. It may be tricky to sew along the narrow point but you can make it easier by using a pin to help hold the tip as you feed it through the machine.

Attach the Hood to the Cape

With right sides together, lay the Outer Hood onto the neck of the Cape. Lift the Hood Lining out of the way and pin the Outer Hood to the neck of the Cape. Make sure to line up the side hem of the cape with the front corner of the Hood.

Sew the Outer Hood to Cape backstitching at the beginning and end of the seam. Press the seam allowance toward the Hood.

At the front corner where the hood meets the cape trim down the Outer Hood seam allowance to about 1/8 â€˜â€™ to reduce bulk.

Slightly trim the remaining seam allowance at the corner to allow it to tuck into the front corner of the hood easily. Refold the Hood Lining along the crease to enclose all the raw edges.

Pin the pressed fold of the Hood Lining so it lines up with the Outer Hood stitch line.

Topstitch along the Hood Lining about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the folded edge.

Sew a small square of hook and loop tape to the corner points of the Hood. Sew the soft (loop) side to the inside of one corner and the scratchy (hook) side to the outside of the opposite corner.

Make and Attach the Ears

Place 2 Bat Ear pieces with right sides together. Starting in the middle of the base (smallest side) of the triangle, sew around all three sides leaving a 1 1/2 â€˜â€™ gap for turning. Trim off the corner points as shown, and turn the Bat Ear right side out. Use a dull pencil to push out the corners.

Tuck the seam allowance into the opening and press the ear flat. Repeat to sew the 2nd Bat Ear.

Align the base of one ear to the Bat Ear placement line marked on the Outer Hood. Make sure the Hood lining is lined up properly with the Outer Hood and pin in place.

Stitch about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the base of the ear and sew a second row of stitches about 1/4â€™â€™ above the first line.

You are finished! Give it to your little one and let him go!

Hope you liked this tutorial! Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Mommy & Me Circle Skirts
posts.markdown:
Created by: Sweet Red Poppy Hi, I'm Kim from Sweet Red Poppy and I'm excited to share one of my favorite tutorials with you today! Circle Skirts are super easy to make and oh SO comfortable! My little girls and I love wearing them and the best part is they transition from season to season perfectly! Throw on a pair of boots and a button up in the winter, or a v-neck tee and sandals in the summer, to get all-year wear out of this closet staple!

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2483.jpg)

Once you start making these skirts you won't want to stop! ####Supplies Needed * 1-2 yards of knit fabric (use the skirt calculator below to determine the exact amount)- we used Art Gallery Swifting Flora Boho, Aqua Di Rose Boho, Observer OverShot Gold * 1 yard of 1" Elastic * Sewing Machine or Serger * Coordinating thread * Iron I used Art Gallery knits for this tutorial. They are some of my favorite knits to work with because they have great recovery, thanks to their blend of cotton and spandex. I find that the cotton spandex blend creates a more stable knit fabric which makes it much more beginner-friendly than most knits!

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2383-min.jpg)

Before choosing a fabric, decide what type of a circle skirt you want. The type of fabric makes all the difference in the way the skirt drapes. If you want a really full skirt with plenty of body, try a scuba knit like these. If you want a skirt with less volume that's more drapey, try out a lighter weight rayon knit like these. ####Let's Get Started! First, head over to By Hand London to use their circle skirt calculator . This tool is a huge help and saves you from having to do all the math yourself! Insert your waist measurement into the calculator. You'll need to choose the full circle skirt and your desired length. When determining the length keep in mind the width of the fabric you will be using. Have the calculator do the math and make a note of your waist radius. Lay your knit fabric out on a large table and fold the fabric in half so the selvage edges are aligned.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2224-min.jpg)

Using a ruler and a washable marking pen, trace out your waistline circle using the radius measurement that coordinates with your waist measurement. I like to slowly drag the ruler along the fabric while I use my other hand to keep the end of the ruler lined up with the edge of the fabric. Once the waist is marked, it's time to move on to the hem.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2225-min.jpg)

First, you'll need to determine how long you want your skirt to be. The skirt will sit at the smallest part of your waist, so measure from there and add a half inch for the hem. Add the skirt measurement to the radius measurement and mark the next cutting line. I typically use a string or a skinny measuring tape for this step. Cut the hem of the skirt and repeat this process to create the back of the skirt.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2228-min.jpg)

Cut out the waistband length (waist measurement) x height 3"

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2253-min.jpg)

Lay the skirt front and back on top of each other with right sides together.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2245-min.jpg)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2248-min.jpg)

Place pins along the side seams. Sew with a half inch seam allowance. Don't forget to take your pins out as you sew! You can also use a regular sewing machine for this project, I just prefer to use a serger with knits.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2252-min.jpg)

With right sides together sew the short end of the waistband together. Flip it right side out and fold in half so that the wrong sides are on the inside. This will create the casing for the elastic.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2254-min.jpg)

Flip the skirt right side out and divide the waist into 4 equal sections. Mark the middle front and back with a pin. This will help you to accurately line up the waistband and skirt together.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2262-min.jpg)

Section the waistband into 4 equal sections and mark with pins. Line up the skirt pins and the waistband pins, stretching the waistband so it's on the outside of the skirt. Sew around the waistband leaving a 2 inch opening to thread the elastic through.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2263-min.jpg)

Cut the elastic the same length as the waist measurement. Attach a safety pin to the end of the elastic and thread it through the casing. Pull both ends of the elastic out and overlay them on top of each other by 1 inch. WIth a zigzag stitch, sew them together. Pull the elastic back into the casing (try on the skirt to make sure it fits) and stitch the opening closed.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2272-min.jpg)

####Now it's time to work on the hem! Set your sewing machine to the longest stitch length and baste along the perimeter of the skirt hem.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2274-min.jpg)

Gently pull on the top thread and ease the fabric so it begins to fold on top of itself. The basting stitch allows the excess fabric to be eased in, which creates a beautifully even hem with no puckers.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2275-min.jpg)

Fold the hem up one-half inch and pin in place.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2283-min.jpg)

Sew 3/8th's of an inch from the bottom of the hem all the way around the skirt.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2281-min.jpg)

Press the hem and the waistband with a hot iron and plenty of steam.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mommy%20and%20Me%20Circle%20Skirts/IMG_2496.jpg)

If you enjoyed this tutorial, check out my Mommy & Me Tote Bags tutorial!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Tips for Sewing Faux Fur
posts.markdown:
Working on a Halloween costume, sewing stylish seasonal apparel or a creating home decor accents? Sewing with faux fur is easier than you think! Today we are bringing you simple tips and tricks for working with fur that will help you achieve professional results without turning your sewing space into a furry mess. There are more than 350 faux fur fabrics available on fabric.com in a wide array of colors and textures. Some of our favorite faux furs to sew with are from Shannon Fabrics! We got to work with their Luxury Shag and Siberian Fox furs for this post, and the quality and softness just can't be beat.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/IMG_5220-min.JPG)

####Finding the Nap: Nap is the direction of the fur, just like a real animal. When the nap is found, itâ€™s helpful to mark an arrow on the back of the fur fabric to eliminate directional confusion when cutting out a pattern. Marking faux fur fabric is easy- since the backing is an extra thick knit, you can trace your pattern with a marker and it will not show through. ####Cutting Faux Fur: When cutting faux fur, make small snips on the backing knit fabric only and avoid cutting the fur pile. You donâ€™t want to cut the fur pile during cutting, it will result in uneven fur pile visible around the seams. You can also use a box cutter with a fresh, sharp blade to cut the fur backing. The razor blade cutting method is faster, but it can also distort the edges of the fabric.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%201%20-%20small%20snips-min.png)

Expert Tip: Use strips of packing tape along the cut fur edges to pick up any loose piles. ####Sewing Fur With No Seam Allowance: With right sides together, tuck the fur pile in. Using Wonder Clips instead of pins â€“ itâ€™s better because the thickness of the fur will distort the fabric when pinned.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%202%20-%20tuck%20and%20wonder%20clips-min.png)

Expert Tip: Use a walking foot. Use a wide zig zag stitch along the edge. Sew slowly and use a lot of control on the fur as you sew. When opened, the seam is secure, minimal and almost invisible on the face of the fur fabric. This seam technique is great for most fur-to-fur projects, and will require pattern modifications to reduce the suggested seam allowance.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%203%20-%20zig%20zag%20stitch-min.png)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%204%20-%20no%20seam%20bulk-min.png)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%205%20-%20grey%20fur%20overhead-min.jpg)

####Sewing Fur With a Seam Allowance: If you need to sew fur with a seam allowance, use a walking foot and a straight stitch with at least a Â½â€ seam allowance. Finger-brush the nap of the fur straight down in the seam allowance. Donâ€™t tuck the fur pile, or else youâ€™ll end up with short fur piles poking through the seam, try to direct the fur pile as naturally as possible. Once sewn, brush out any caught fur piles within the seam. Youâ€™ll need to trim the fur pile within the seam allowance.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%206%20-%20sewing%20seam%20allowance-min.png)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%207%20-%20bulky%20seam%20allowance-min.png)

Trimming the seam allowance: Trim the fur pile as close to the backing as possible. Expert Tip: Use a packing tape strip to cover the seam allowance. The tape strip will catch the cut fur piles and greatly reduce the mess. If youâ€™re an avid sewer of faux fur, you may want to invest in grooming clippers to trim fur more efficiently.

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%208%20-%20trimming%20seam%20allowance-min.png)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%209%20-%20trimmed%20seam-min.png)

![Mommy and Me Circle Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Faux%20Fur/pic%2010%20-%20maroon%20overhead-min.jpg)

Try out these tips and techniques on your next faux fur project! Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Fall Block Party: Double Windmill
posts.markdown:
Created by: Happiness in the Making Skill Level: Beginner Welcome back to the fabric.com Fall Block Party! Next up is a beginner friendly block called the Double Windmill created by Haley Anderson of Happiness in the Making. This mesmerizing block would make a beautiful full-sized quilt for fall! If you are just now tuning into this great block series, be sure to check out the other designs here! posts.title: Sewing 101: Using Tricot Fusible Interfacing
posts.markdown:
Created by: Chalk & Notch Patterns I'm Gabriela from Chalk & Notch patterns, and Iâ€™ll be talking a little about my love for Tricot Fusible Interfacing. I personally recommend it in all of my pdf patterns, for both woven and knit designs. I thought I would explain a little about why I use it for most apparel projects, and show you a maxi dress I just made using Tricot and Cotton + Steel Menagerie Rayon Lawn!

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/Fringe%20Maxi3-min.jpg)

* Dress fabric: Cotton + Steel Menagerie Rayon Lawn in Monstera Midnight * Dress pattern: Fringe Dress modified to a maxi length. In case you are not familiar with Tricot Fusible Interfacing, it is a fusible interfacing that has 2-way or 4-way stretch and is traditionally used to stabilize knit fabrics. Fusible means that it will bond to fabric when heated with an iron. The great thing is that it works for woven apparel fabrics as well as knit fabrics.

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/Tricot-min.jpg)

Left: FusiKnit Tricot Fusible Right: Heatâ€™n Bond Q2432 Tricot Fusible There are so many different types of interfacing, and it can be confusing to decide which works best for your project. As a garment sewer, I use Tricot Fusible Interfacing for waistbands, collars, facings and plackets; I also use it as reinforcement for zippers, buttonholes and pockets. I work in both knit and woven fabrics, and Iâ€™ve found that Tricot Fusible Interfacing works for most of my needs. Plus, I like the convenience of keeping one type of fusible on hand. I started this practice because when I worked in the apparel industry at a custom dress shop, Tricot was all we used. In that shop, we never worked with knit fabrics, but we did work in leather, lace, denim, silk, rayon and lots of other apparel fabrics. For as long as I can remember, Iâ€™ve always used Tricot on woven fabric, and it wasnâ€™t until recently that I realized that it wasnâ€™t a common practice.

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/Fringe%20Maxi6-min.jpg)

You might be concerned that while Tricot has stretch, your woven fabric does not. Not to worry; since the interfacing is heat bonded to the fabric, it will only stretch as much as your fabric stretches, and most woven fabric has a bit of crosswise stretch or give in the weave. If you are sewing with knit, then Tricot is your best option for sure. When cutting, remember that Tricot has a grain, make sure to match the grain of the fusible with the grain of your fabric.

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/Fringe%20Maxi12-min.jpg)

When you use Tricot Fusible Interfacing, you can maintain the original drape of the fabric while adding stability and structure when needed. For this sample, I used the FusiKnit Tricot Fusible for the facings on my Fringe Dress. This collar shape in View B of the Fringe dress requires a nice, crisp corner, and the Tricot is able to do that without being too stiff. It also works for View A, which has a curved neckline, by stabilizing the center front button closure. To illustrate how fabric fused with Tricot can still maintain most of the fabric drape, I cut 8" squares of this Cotton + Steel Menagerie Rayon Lawn in Monstera Midnight and tested a few fusible options, all from fabric.com. The sample on the left is the fabric without any fusible. The two center samples are Tricot options, and the far right sample uses a lightweight pellon fusible. You can see that the Tricot options look very similar to the fabric without any fusible. The Pellon option removes the natural drape of the fabric, and although it would still work for the Fringe pattern and most woven apparel projects, itâ€™s just not my preference.

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/4drapeswatches-min.jpg)

1) Cotton + Steel Rayon Lawn - without fusible 2) FusiKnit Tricot Fusible 3) Heatâ€™n Bond Q2432 Tricot Fusible 4) Pellon 906F Sheer Fusible Interfacing After testing these two Tricot fusible options from Fabric.com, I would say both are very similar. If I had to pick, I prefer the FusiKnit Tricot Fusible with a little more 2-way stretch than the Heatâ€™n Bond Q2432 Tricot Fusible, but both are comparable and I would recommend both.

![Tricot](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Tricot/Fringe%20Maxi14-min.jpg)

I hope this gives you the confidence to try Tricot Fusible Interfacing on your next apparel project when you would like to maintain the fabric drape and feel while adding stability. If you do, Iâ€™d love to know what you think! You can get in touch with me on Instagram or Facebook. Happy sewing!

posts.title: Brand Spotlight: Cloud 9 Organic Fabrics
posts.markdown:
Gorgeous new matte laminate prints from Cloud 9 Organic Fabrics are here! We thought this was a perfect opportunity to tell you more about this sustainable brand and provide lots of inspiration for these new waterproof prints. ####About Cloud 9 Organic Fabrics Cloud 9 Fabrics is a proud leading source for organic cotton fabric for the home sewing enthusiast. They use only 100% certified organic cotton in the manufacturing of their base cloths, and eco-responsible low impact dyes for printing and dyeing. Cloud 9 works closely with mills that are committed to ethical and responsible conduct, including a devotion to sustained social compliance and an accountability to the environment. Cloud 9 works with artists who inspire them, so that they can inspire us with their fabrics! They place s a strong emphasis on the distinction of artists, designers and partners, and offer a wide variety of substrates that appeal to quilters and garment sewists alike. Now let's take a look at the latest line of sustainable fabrics from Cloud 9!

posts.title: Fall Fabric Picnic
posts.markdown:
Created by: PMQ for Two Hi, my name is Ariel and I'm the voice behind PMQ for Two. I create bright, bold, colourful, and eclectic home decor and DIYs. I never met a pattern I didn't like, and some even call me a colour wizard. While fall still has a few more weeks to go before it starts getting a little nippy, I am enjoying every minute of it by indulging in a picnic or tailgate. The only difference between a summer and fall picnic is the amount of fabrics involved, and this one called for lots of textures and colors from fabric.com! ####Fabric Choices for Fall Picnic For this picnic I chose fabrics and materials in complimentary shades and patterns. Stripes, florals, and lots of fun reds are exactly what the occasion called for! I used: * Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co Wonderland Rose for the napkins * Cloud 9 Organic Yarn Died Shirting Plaid for the food wrap and basket liner * Cotton + Steel Noel Snow Leopard for the tablecloth * Sunbrella Outdoor Mason Stripe Forest Green for the outdoor pillows

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-2-min.jpg)

Although there's a large blanket for guests to sit on (because the ground was kind of wet and definitely cold) I always add an extra surface between the ground and food. I made a simple double-sided tablecloth using the Cotton + Steel Noel Snow Leopard, and the Sunbrella Outdoor Mason Stripe Forest Green outdoor fabric. This one can be used on its own at a picnic table, or even on the ground (because it's double sided). I essentially made a large pillow case, but didn't fill it. See below for pillow-case tutorial!

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-17-min.jpg)

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-10-min.jpg)

For napkins I went with Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co Wonderland Rose. I love this little print for table linens, and actually used these napkins in my fall tablescape here. The details and flourishes of the florals are a nice compliment to the stripes and structure of the plaids.

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Napkin-sewing.gif)

I cut the napkins to measure based on existing napkins that I like (18â€ x 18â€), gave them a 1/2" seam, and sewed them with a tight stitch. No need for fuss with these since they'll be used for the day to day instead of fancy occasions. Iâ€™ve illustrated the steps above.

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-6-min.jpg)

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-39-min.jpg)

While sitting on the ground is fun as a kid, I find it less comfortable as an adult. When I picnic you'll often find me totting some large ground pillows or chairs, and for this event I chose to make some pillows using outdoor fabric. I wanted them to be UV resistant and moisture proof, and that's exactly what I got with Sunbrella Outdoor Mason Stripe in Forest Green. I chose the green stripe because it picks up on the stripes in the plaid, as well as in nature. It's another bold pattern that I can use going forward in other events.

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/pillowase-sewing.gif)

I sewed the pillows like your normally do (inside-out) and then stuffed them before sewing the last seam closed by hand. I used old pillows for inserts to save on costs, considering these will be outdoor only.

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-7-min.jpg)

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-16-min.jpg)

Ok so you've probably noticed the green check wrapped loaf. That's a delicious pumpkin loaf that I've been making for a few years now. It's essentially pumpkin spice muffins, but done in a loaf pan instead of muffin cups. I highly recommend with some cream cheese icing. For transport I didn't want bulky Tupperwares, or have to deal with them at the end of the picnic. Instead I wrapped my loaf in wax paper, Cloud 9 Organic Yarn Died Shirting Plaid, and twine. It was perfect for transport within my picnic basket, and the fabric kept the wax paper from ripping or being punctured. I highly recommend when transporting baked goods going forward.

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-12-min.jpg)

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-15-min.jpg)

And finally, because we were outside, I brought along some extra fabric to serve as a makeshift shawl, as well as another picnic blanket in case more people joined-us. You never know what will happen when you're hanging out in a park on a lovely afternoon!

![Fall Picnic](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Fabric%20Picnic/Fall%20Outdoor%20Picnic%20PMQ%20fortwo-40-min.jpg)

Happy fall sewing, everyone!

And finally, because we were outside, I brought along some extra fabric to serve as a makeshift shawl, as well as another picnic blanket in case more people joined-us. You never know what will happen when you're hanging out in a park on a lovely afternoon!

Happy fall sewing, everyone!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Tips for Sewing with Lace
posts.markdown:
Lace is a year-round fashion favorite fabric. Delicate and feminine, lace or lace accents add sophistication to any garment! Sewing with lace can be a bit intimidating, so today we are sharing some of our favorite lace fabrics to work with and sewing tips and tricks from our resident fabric.com experts. ####Our Favorite Lace Fabrics This Season Telio has some of our favorite lace fabrics right now, and you can browse their entire selection of lace here.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/lace_fabrics.jpg)

Pictured above: Ornamental Lace in Navy Telio Amelia Stretch Lace in Black Telio Kala Lace in Black/Gold Telio Veronica Lace in Dusty Rose Lace has a net or mesh background, so it doesnâ€™t ravel, making it easy to sew. To illustrate a few preferred seam and hem demonstrations, we used Telio Mara Lace Black. ####Skip the backstitching when starting and stopping seams Backstitching risks your fabric being shoved into the needle plate. Make sure thereâ€™s enough thread at the start and end of the seam to hand-knot. When starting the seam, gently tug the machine threads to guide the lace fabric through to avoid machine eating as well. ####Plain Seam A straight stitch set to 2.5mm length and a 3/8â€ seam allowance.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/plain%20stitch-min.jpg)

####Double Stitch Seam A second straight stitch close to the seam stitch to stabilize the seam allowance.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/double%20stitch%20seam-min.jpg)

####Lapped Seam Continuing after creating a plain seam, grade the seam allowance (cut one seam allowance fabric down), finger press the graded seam, and top stitch the seam. This secures the seam allowance and makes the seam lay nice and flat.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/lapped%20seam%201%20grade-min.jpg)

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/lapped%20seam%203%20underside-min.jpg)

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/lapped%20seam%202%20top%20stitch-min.jpg)

####Overlock Seam If you have a serger, you are in luck, a 4-thread overlock seam will beautifully join and finish most lace fabrics seams.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/overlock%20seam-min.jpg)

####Selfâ€“Hem Border Pattern pieces for apparel doesnâ€™t always follow straight lines, thereâ€™s curves meant to compliment the body. A-line skirts, a popular style for lace fabric, have curved hemlines, as does ruffle sleeves. Many laces have scalloped borders along one or both selvedges. Hereâ€™s a tip for incorporating those beautifully scalloped selvedges into your sewing.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/Lace%20hemline%20finished_hanging-min.jpg)

Step 1: Cut the border of the lace where thereâ€™s a noticeable threshold, and thereâ€™s a bit of thickness in the lace motif, so it can be topstitched easily.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/border%20cut-min.jpg)

Step 2: Pin the border to the lace so that the scallops cover the hemline.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/curved%20lace%20piece-min.jpg)

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/Border%20pinned-min.jpg)

Step 3: Use a Zig Zag to topstitch along the border edge, securing it to the fabric piece.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/zig%20zag%20stitch%20up%20close-min.jpg)

Step 4: Turn over, and trim any excess fabric to create a continual sheer effect, accentuating the beauty of the selvedge and the lace.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/trim%20%20lace-min-rotate.jpg)

Step 5: Press with a presscloth and a low iron setting to smooth out any warping during sewing.

![Lace](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Tips%20for%20Lace/finished%20hemline-min.jpg)

Using the fabricâ€™s own scalloped selvedges gives a professional look and adds beauty to any hemline. Happy Sewing!
