posts.title: DIY Dog Bed Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Looking for a stylish and practical place for your furry friend to rest their head? This quick and easy tutorial gives you all the tools you need to sew two pet bed sizes- small and large! You can use any fabric for your pet bed, but we recommend a durable fabric like outdoor fabric, canvas, duck or super durable Crypton fabric. Crypton fabric has performance technology built into every fiber! Spills bead up and are easily wiped away, and odor resistance helps keep fabric fresh. Perfect for pups that arenâ€™t good at keeping themselves clean! We are proud to announce that fabric.com now carries 6 exclusive pet designs from Crypton, which we used to create this bed for a resident fabric.com pup, Romeo.

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/pet_bed_fabrics-min.jpg)

Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed * 1 yard 54â€ wide Crypton fabric for small bed (we used the Dog Bones print in Denim from our Exclusive pet designs collection) * 2 yards 54â€ wide Crypton fabric for large bed * Pet Bed Insert * Invisible Zipper â€“ 20â€ * Invisible Zipper Foot * Heavy duty/upholstery thread

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/supplies-min.PNG)

*NOTE: The dimensions for the large bed will be in parentheses next to the small bed dimensions throughout. Use a Â½â€ seam allowance unless noted otherwise. ####Cutting Cut two rectangles out of your pet bed fabric 21â€ x 31â€ (28â€ x 37â€)

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/cutting-min.PNG)

####Insert Zipper Insert your favorite zipper with your favorite method if you want it to be removable. If not, skip this step. We used an invisible zipper and zipper foot to create our invisible zipper. Remember to iron your zipper teeth out so you can get your needle as close to them as possible while sewing. Place your zipper tape, teeth side in and sew with your invisible zipper foot 3â€ (4.5â€) from each edge, careful not to twist and locking your stitches when you start and stop! Test your zipper to make sure it closes and opens. Trim excess and sew over the zipper on the ends to make sure you donâ€™t lose that zipper head. Open the zipper part way.

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/sew_zipper-min.PNG)

####Sew Sew around the rest of your rectangle, right sides together. You now have basically a pillowcase. What we do next will turn it into a dog bed.

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/sew%20seam%20allowance-min.PNG)

####Box Corners Once you know how to sew boxed corners, you will be able to sew cushions, bags, and more with ease! Itâ€™s a little tricky at first, but watch the video to check it out! You basically take the seam and manipulate it/fold it so that the corner is now facing a different way from the rest of the fabric. Use both hands to pinch and pull apart the corner. The fabric will begin to make a corner with the seam lines running down the middle of the front and back instead of on either side. Make sure those seams on the front and back line up!

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/box%20corners-min.PNG)

Mark a line across your new corner 3.5â€ (6â€) down and 5â€ (9â€) across. Sew along that longer line (5/9â€).

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/sew%20boxed%20corners-min.PNG)

Trim the corner on the other side of the line to about Â½â€.

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/cut%20corner-min.PNG)

Turn your pet bed right side out â€“ this is where it was important to open your zipper â€“ and stuff with your pet bed insert. Add your furry friend, and youâ€™re all set!

![DIY Dog Bed](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Dog%20Bed/diy_dog_bed_hero_image-min.PNG)

posts.title: Fall Block Party: Gather
posts.markdown:
Created by: Elise and Emelie Skill Level: Confident Beginner Finished block size: 12" square Hey there fall lovers! Itâ€™s been a really mild (meaning hot) fall this year here in Southern California where I am. The trees are still green being that they are palm trees, but Iâ€™ve seen a few trees with their leaves changing colors and itâ€™s beautiful! The fall block party colors were so inspiring that even after I had decided on which Liberty Fabrics print to focus on, I couldnâ€™t help but create a block with some of the amazing Kona Cotton solids as well. So, I will share a few color ways with you for inspiration!

![Fall Block Party Time Lapse](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Block%20Party%20Gather/IMG_2546-min.jpg)

You might not be a fan of applique, but fear not! These Gather blocks can be sewn onto the background fabric by machine too. I used clear monofilament on this block so that the colors of the individual pentagons would still stand out and the color of the stitching would be minimal. ####Fabric Choices I used the following Kona Cotton Solids for the first version of this block I created: * Kona Cotton Avocado * Kona Cotton Bonsai * Kona Cotton Olive * Kona Cotton Curry * Kona Cotton Amber * Kona Cotton Cedar * Kona Cotton Sienna * Kona Cotton Paprika * Kona Cotton Crimson * Kona Cotton Garnet * Kona Cotton Eggshell

![Fall Block Party Time Lapse](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Block%20Party%20Gather/IMG_1963-min.JPG)

####Pattern Download Click HERE to download the Gather quilt block pattern for the full instructions. *Note: This pattern is for an experienced beginner and assumes you know how to whip stitch and applique. The possibilities for this pattern are endless! I even made a placemat by just making the background piece a little wider on the sides and quilted it with big stitches using Perle cotton size 8 in Ecru for a subtle effect! One of my practice blocks also become a mug rug that I did some improv quilting on (matchstick quilting lines mixed with lines spaced 1/2" apart). I love how both turned out!

posts.title: All Purpose Apron Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Whether youâ€™re a beginner or experienced sewer, aprons are great sewing projects. The right apron can make a great gift, or meet your own daily need for functional fashion around the house. Weâ€™ve had many aprons over the years and this apron is by far our favorite!

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/worn%20apron%20kitchen-min.jpg)

We love an apron that you can wipe your hands on. We also wanted a durable fabric that can absorb and clean well. Finally, we wanted pockets for holding essentials full body coverage to protect my clothes, and most importantly, it needs to be able to be washedâ€¦ a lot. Added bonus: the fabric is super cute! Option A from this McCalls Apron Pattern has all the function we need: The full skirt, the tie, the pockets, and a full bib front with a no-fuss adjustable button closure. We skipped the frill trim.

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/Apron%20pattern-min.jpg)

To take this apron to the next level, we made an optional hand towel attachments out of terry cloth towel fabric. In the kitchen, weâ€™re constantly reaching for a hand towel to clean something or wipe ourhands. Attaching it to the apron keeps my towel right at the waist, and gives you the option to take it off, replace it, or wash it!

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/apron%20hanging%20closeup-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed: * 2 yards Cotton + Steel Macrame Canvas Leaves Linen * 1 yard Terry Cloth Black * (3) Black Â¾â€ buttons * McCalls Apron Pattern

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/supplies-min.jpg)

####Step 1 Pre-wash all fabrics. We put them through a warm wash cycle and a regular dryer cycle to allow for any shrinkage. Cotton + Steel Macrame Canvas Leaves Linen is a perfect choice. Itâ€™s medium weight and has a fantastic print. The density of the print and color variations will help hide future set-in stains. The small amount of linen gives the fabric a slight abrasion, perfect for tackling messes. The canvas is durable so if it gets hit with food or drink, itâ€™s not soaking through to your clothes.

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/Cotton%20Steel%20Fabric-min.jpg)

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/Terry%20Cloth%20Fabric-min.jpg)

####Step 2 Make Option A as directed in the pattern. Fun, easy project, it can be completed in about 2-3 hours. ####Step 3 Once the apron is made, add one Â¾â€ button to the side waistband of the apron.

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/apron%20waist%20button-min.jpg)

####Step 4 Make up to four hand-towels with binding and button holes.

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/towel%20dimensions-min.jpg)

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/towel%20buttonhole%20closeup-min.jpg)

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/apron%20waist%20button%20towel-min.jpg)

To do this, simply cut four 22.5â€ x 17.5â€ rectangles from 1 yard of Terry Cloth. Bind the edges with the left-over apron fabric with 2.5â€ strips. Sew a button hole in the upper center of the towel, about 2â€ from the edge. Attach one 3/â€™4â€ button on the waistband of the apron. The towels can now be interchangeable and washed separately.

![Apron](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Apron%20Tutorial/worn%20apron%20apple%20cutting-min.jpg)

Happy Sewingâ€¦and Cooking!

posts.title: Throw Pillows 4 Ways
posts.markdown:
Throw pillows are an easy way to add a pop of color and fun into your home dÃ©cor. Theyâ€™re great for mixing and matching to brighten up a space, and you can use all your favorite patterns. Today we'll share four different methods for constructing toss pillows and the pros and cons of each so you can decide which method suits you best! ####Supplies Needed: * Fabrics for Pillows (3/4 yard will make at least 2 pillows with mismatched fronts and backs). We used Genevieve Gorder Flock Velvet, Justina Blakeney Euc Jacquard Stella, Justina Blakeney Hypnotic and Laura Kiran Finnish Stripe with coordinating navy and black solid fabric for the pillow backs. * 20â€ Pillow Form * For the invisible zipper pillow: Invisible zipper Invisible zipper foot * For the inset seam zipper pillow: 22â€ zipper Zipper foot * Coordinating Thread (polyester)

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/supplies.PNG)

Use a Â½â€ seam allowance throughout. I serged the edges to all my pieces to prevent fraying. MC: Main color CC: Coordinating Color ####Envelope Closure Method: #####Cut: MC: (1) 21â€x21â€ CC: (2) 15â€ x 21â€

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_cut-min.PNG)

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_cut2-min.PNG)

This is a great method for beginners, as it doesnâ€™t require a zipper at all. Itâ€™s also a good choice if you plan on changing out your pillow covers often (great for holiday pillow covers!) The premise is that you have two back pieces that are hemmed that overlap to completely encase your pillow form. Itâ€™s super easy and fast to whip these up. #####Steps: Hem the two back pieces on one long side by folding over twice at Â½â€ and sewing

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_hem-min.PNG)

Place your main fabric right side up, and place your back pieces right side down and overlapping. The long and unhemmed edges will be on the top and bottom of your main fabric piece. It doesnâ€™t matter which way you place it if your main fabric is non-directional.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_place_back_pieces-min.PNG)

Sew all the way around at Â½â€, locking your stitches when you start and stop. No need to leave a space to turn, your envelope closure is all you need!

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_sew-min.PNG)

Trim your corners and turn, fill with your pillow form.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/envelope_finished-min.PNG)

####Invisible Zipper Method: This is probably the easiest method, but it does have one special requirement â€“ an invisible zipper foot. You can purchase generic ones on Amazon for most machines, but the more expensive machines usually require you to buy a particular brand in order to fit. Itâ€™s a worthwhile investment, and by far the easiest way to add a zipper to garments and pillows!

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/invisible_zipper.PNG)

It requires only two pieces, and no visible stitching on the right side of the pillow. This is great for fabrics that are hard to top stitch or look best without top-stitching, like lighter weight faux leather, velvet, or if you donâ€™t like cutting out very many pieces. #####Cut: MC: (1) 21â€ x 21â€ CC: (1) 21â€ x 21â€

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/invisible_cut-min.PNG)

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/invisible_cut_2-min.PNG)

Iron your invisible zipper with the top of your iron flattening out the zipper teeth. This will make it easier to get close to the zipper teeth when sewing. Place your invisible zipper on the right side and bottom of one pillow piece, with the teeth on the seam allowance (1/2â€), the right side of the zipper tape facing the right side of the fabric.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/invisible_place_zipper-min.PNG)

Sew this with your invisible zipper foot, your needle getting as close to the zipper teeth as possible without sewing over the teeth. Itâ€™s okay if your zipper is twisted once, as long as you untwist it before you sew around the edges. It helps to have the two pieces butting up next to each other that youâ€™re sewing the zipper tape to. Close the zipper to make sure everything zips up all right, but leave it half open before sewing the pieces together or you wonâ€™t be able to turn. ![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/invisible_finished.PNG)

####Lapped Zipper Method: A lapped zipper creates a lovely professional pillow with a fully hidden zipper. It does require some extra pieces and a bit more steps while sewing but the finished product is so worth it.

#####Cut: MC: (1) 21â€ x 21â€ CC: (2) 21â€ x 11.5â€

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_cut.PNG)

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_cut_2.PNG)

On one back piece (right side up), place zipper right side down on one long side and sew along the edge with your zipper foot. Flip out and press. You can also top stitch on the backing fabric for a professional finish, but that is optional.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_sew_zipper_foot.PNG)

On the other back piece, fold over 1â€ and you can either just press, edgestitch, or hem based on your preference. Go slowly and make sure youâ€™re keeping everything lined up.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_sew_together.PNG)

Test your zipper, leave it open halfway before sewing the pillow together Sew all the way around your pillow with a Â½â€ seam. Trim the corner and excess zipper tape.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_sew_seam.PNG)

Turn using your open zipper.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/lapped_finished_pillow.PNG)

####Inset seam zipper This zipper method is great for upholstery projects and it does not require an invisible zipper foot or zipper. You can use a standard zipper and zipper foot for this method, but it is a little nerve-wracking. We will sew the zipper on a closed seam and open it up using a seam ripper to expose the zipper. You will be able to see your bottom thread on the finished pillow. This is perfect for fabrics that wonâ€™t be damaged using a seam ripper too close to a seam. You can use this for almost anything!

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_zipper_close-min.PNG)

#####Cut: MC: (1) 21â€ x 21â€ CC: (1) 21â€ x 21â€

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_cut-min.PNG)

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_cut_2-min.PNG)

Right sides together, sew the bottom seam. You can use a longer stitch length to make it easier to rip out later (3.5mm), or if youâ€™re feeling confident, you can use a standard stitch length. Press this seam open and leave wrong side facing up to insert the zipper. Lay your zipper on the back of your pressed open seam, zipper teeth right on top of the seam.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_lay_zipper-min.PNG)

Sew over the zipper tape on the wrong side with your zipper foot to get as close to the teeth as possible. Lock your stitches when beginning and ending. Unzip your zipper a little/enough so that the zipper head will be expose when you rip it out. Turn your pieces over to the right side. Insert the tip of your seam ripper into the stitches. You should be able to feel the zipper teeth with the seam ripper.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_remove_stitches-min.PNG)

Carefully rip out your line of stitches all the way down, exposing your zipper! Leave about 1â€ â€“ 2â€ on either end unripped. Optional: stitch a perpendicular line on each end for extra durability. Make sure your zipper head is exposed as well. You may have to feed it in between the zipper tape and the enclosed seam. Unzip your zipper half way. Right sides together, sew all the way around at Â½â€, matching your seams from your zipper.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_half_inch_seam-min.PNG)

Trim zipper tape and corners. Turn and stuff.

![Toss Pillows](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Toss%20Pillows%204%20Ways/inset_finished-min.PNG)

Happy pillow making!

Created by: Sarah Thomas of SARIDITTY Skill Level: Experienced Beginner Finished block size: 12" square Happy fall, yâ€™all! October is by far my most favorite month of the year with crisp and cool air, leggings and sweaters and tall socks, cinnamon everything, and all the leaves changing colors!

![Forest Floor Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fall%20Block%20Party%20Forest%20Floor/finished%20block-min.jpg)

I opted to create a true translation of autumn with my block, Forest Floor. It captures the essence of the ground cover going dormant while fallen leaves are scattered all about. And even though itâ€™s not necessarily my â€œgo toâ€ type of pattern that I often gravitate toward, I pretty much love it to pieces! ####Fabric Choices: * Cotton + Steel From Porto With Love Metallic Sardinha in Neutral * Tula Pink True Colors Making Waves in Olive * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Tangerine * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Eucalyptus * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Sunshine * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Jade * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Bordeaux * Kaffe Fassett Collective Shot Cotton Clementine

posts.title: Kites & Clouds Nursery Mobile
posts.markdown:
A baby mobile is a perfect accent for any nursery. Keeping in mind a mobile is soothing entertainment for little ones, weâ€™ve created this Kite and Cloud mobile: an array of colors and shapes to capture the attention of new eyes as they drift off to sleep. Making one can seem daunting, but weâ€™ve taken out the guesswork. This is a fun, easy project, sure to add to the excitement of Babyâ€™s arrival. ####Supplies: 1/2 yard each of assorted cotton fabrics . We used: * Art Gallery Millie Fleur Line Drawings Yellowed * Art Gallery Garden Dreamer Diamond Fragments Gold * Art Gallery Garden Dreamer Twinklestar Berry * Art Gallery Garden Dreamer Bumblebeez * Art Gallery Garden Dreamer Climbing Posies Pale * Riley Blake 1/8â€ Stripes Gray * Plush Felt White You'll also need: * 14â€ Embroidery Hoop * Pellon Perfect Loft Stuffing * Wire Cording Black * Twine 8 ply or Bakerâ€™s Twine * 12â€ Bamboo Skewers * Hot Glue Gun * Wire Cutters (for skewers) * Embroidery Needles ####Templates: We created free printable templates for each kite and cloud design for you! Click the links below to download each. 4-part Kite Angled Kite Flare Stripe Kite Front Flare Stripe Kite Back Box Kite + Small Diamond Kite Vertical Half Kite Horizontal Half Kite Cloud 1 Cloud 2 ####Instructions Make kites and clouds, using the above templates. Use Â¼â€ seam allowance on the kites and an edged zig zag stitch on the clouds. Once the kites are flipped and pressed, no need to sew the opening closed. Once the clouds are flipped and stuffed, hand stitch closed the flip-openings on the clouds.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Frame%200_17-min.png)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Frame%201_45-min.png)

####Box Kite: Join the box kite fabric piece using with French seams. Use wire cutters to cut 4 skewers to equal 6 Â½â€ and mark 1â€ inward on each end. Cut 4 skewers equaling 3 Â¼â€, mark the center (1 5/8â€). Hot glue the 3 Â¼â€ skewers to the 6 Â½â€ skewers as shown, using the 1â€ marks as joints. On one structure, glue the inner pieces just above the 1â€ mark, on the other, glue just below the 1â€ mark. Staggering the joints will allow the structure to be even height once completed. Continue as picture shows, generously hot gluing all joints, waiting at least 1-5 minutes per joint.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Box%20Kite%20Collage-min.jpg)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Skewer%20glue%20joint-min.jpg)

Leave the box kite skewer structure to set overnight. Then simply pull the box kite fabric pieces over each end. Tie wire cord to the inside of the skewer structure, and decorate with fabric strips.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Naked%20Box%20Kite-min.jpg)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Fabric%20pulled%20over%20box%20kite-min.jpg)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Box%20Kite%20done-min.jpg)

For assembling the mobile, intersect two 6â€™ pieces of twine and knot at four evenly spaced points on the embroidery hoop.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Frame%202_34-min.png)

####Attaching the Mobile Center Attach the big cloud to the box kite. Insert needle through the bottom of the cloud, secure and knot, leave 10 Â½â€ of twine, then double knot around the inner structure of the box kite. Attach large cloud to small cloud till a 7 Â½â€ length of twine is achieved.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Center%20cloud%20attaching-min.jpg)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Center%20mobile%20piece-min.jpg)

Take 4â€™ of twine and insert it through the top of the cloud with an embroidery needle. Once poked through the bottom, loop in the twine intersection thatâ€™s attached to the hoop. Insert the needle back up into the cloud, and knot to secure. Bury the thread to hide any loose ends. The mobile should now be adjustable from the cloud. Once hung, the weight of the mobile will secure the setting. Kite and Cloud attachments: Follow this diagram for how long each kite or cloud should hang down. Attach twine at the skewer intersections. Bury the thread to hide the loose ends.

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Frame%203_31-min.png)

![Kites Clouds Mobile](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Kites%20and%20Clouds%20Nursery%20Mobile/Bury%20Thread%20Kites.jpg)

  • Wire Cutters (for skewers)
  • Embroidery Needles

Templates:

We created free printable templates for each kite and cloud design for you! Click the links below to download each.

4-part Kite
Angled Kite
Flare Stripe Kite Front
Flare Stripe Kite Back
Box Kite + Small Diamond Kite
Vertical Half Kite
Horizontal Half Kite
Cloud 1
Cloud 2

Instructions

Make kites and clouds, using the above templates. Use Â¼â€ seam allowance on the kites and an edged zig zag stitch on the clouds. Once the kites are flipped and pressed, no need to sew the opening closed. Once the clouds are flipped and stuffed, hand stitch closed the flip-openings on the clouds.

Box Kite:

Join the box kite fabric piece using with French seams.

Use wire cutters to cut 4 skewers to equal 6 Â½â€ and mark 1â€ inward on each end. Cut 4 skewers equaling 3 Â¼â€, mark the center (1 5/8â€).

Hot glue the 3 Â¼â€ skewers to the 6 Â½â€ skewers as shown, using the 1â€ marks as joints. On one structure, glue the inner pieces just above the 1â€ mark, on the other, glue just below the 1â€ mark. Staggering the joints will allow the structure to be even height once completed. Continue as picture shows, generously hot gluing all joints, waiting at least 1-5 minutes per joint.

Leave the box kite skewer structure to set overnight. Then simply pull the box kite fabric pieces over each end. Tie wire cord to the inside of the skewer structure, and decorate with fabric strips.

For assembling the mobile, intersect two 6â€™ pieces of twine and knot at four evenly spaced points on the embroidery hoop.

Attach the big cloud to the box kite. Insert needle through the bottom of the cloud, secure and knot, leave 10 Â½â€ of twine, then double knot around the inner structure of the box kite. Attach large cloud to small cloud till a 7 Â½â€ length of twine is achieved.

Take 4â€™ of twine and insert it through the top of the cloud with an embroidery needle. Once poked through the bottom, loop in the twine intersection thatâ€™s attached to the hoop.

Insert the needle back up into the cloud, and knot to secure. Bury the thread to hide any loose ends. The mobile should now be adjustable from the cloud. Once hung, the weight of the mobile will secure the setting.

Kite and Cloud attachments: Follow this diagram for how long each kite or cloud should hang down. Attach twine at the skewer intersections. Bury the thread to hide the loose ends.

posts.title: Tips for Sewing Athletic Wear
posts.markdown:
Created by: Trash to Couture. When I saw fabric.comâ€™s new athletic knits, they inspired me as a designer and runner to create my own athletic wear. You would think at first that this was a match made in heaven, but to be honest, for years I was intimidated to try such projects. As an athlete that consistently trains, the last thing on my mind is fiddling with what Iâ€™m wearing. It MUST be comfortable, supportive, and functional first and foremost. Bonus points are given for style and design.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/DSC_0433-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/DSC_0447-min.jpg)

Fabric.comâ€™s athletic knits, are so fun and colorful that I just had to add them to my running wardrobe. Below, I am going to share with you some tips and tricks that Iâ€™ve learned along the way to successfully sew your own fitness apparel.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/supplies-min.jpg)

####The keys to well-made fitness clothing: ####The Fabric Thanks to fabric.com, they offer athletic knits, made for performance wear with bonus points for cool prints and colors.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/DSC_0457-min.jpg)

* Fabrics should have a 25% four-way stretch for comfort and ease. * Quality fabrics should offer great recovery when stretched and compressed to last through repeated washings and wearings, as well as having full coverage. * Fabrics should also offer thermal insulation depending on what climate you train in: staying cool in warm temperatures and warm in cold temperatures. Spandex, for example, is a popular material used as a base layer to soak up sweat. * Athletic knits are mostly made with synthetic fibers like spandex, nylon, and polyester, though, we are seeing more made with natural fibers like bamboo as well. ####My other go-to supplies: * Coatâ€™s Surelock thread * Dritz 1â€ non-roll elastic * Stretch or Ball Point Needle * Twin Needle

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/construction%20photos-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/construction1-min.JPG)

####The Pattern Because fit, function, and support are the most important aspects of athletic apparel, make sure you find a pattern that is made for this and your size. * Be prepared to make a sample and edit according to your body measurements. I know for me in making these leggings, I had to take them in a few times to get them to fit. * Be sure to take notes along the way and edit the pattern accordingly. For example, if you had to increase the seam allowance or add length to the hem by 1â€, mark this on the pattern for next time. * Consider creating a pattern from your favorite fitness garments. This is done by laying the garment flat on a sheet of pattern paper and tracing it. This is especially easy for leggings that have just a front and back pattern. For a legging that has several sections (like mine), it could be a bit trickier, so try a pattern like this one here

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/serger%203%20thread-min.jpg)

####The Construction Letâ€™s dive into some of the sewing techniques used to make athletic apparel and show you how to do some of these yourself. If you notice on your athletic apparel, most of it is made with an overlock stitch. This usually done by a serger or coverstitch machine using most often the flatlock stitch. This is great for fitness wear because it offers strength and stretch with the least abrasion possible against the skin. This is done with a serger using 3 â€“needle threads. You can also use this technique for hemming the edges as well. The serger I have is a Brother 1034DX that works great for all my knit projects from fitness to ready wear.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/flatlock%20stitch%20side%201%20-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/flatlock%20stitch%20side%202-min.jpg)

#####Flatlock Stitch When you sew a flatlock stitch, you will alter the settings of the serger and usually use three threads and the left needle. This stitch attaches the pieces together so they lay flat as if they were one whole piece of fabric. The top side creates rows of parallel lines like a ladder, and the bottom side is the typical overlock look. You can decide which one you prefer to be your outer seam by altering how you serge them together. I use both, and you can see in the below photo how I used them together. If you look at most professional athletic wear, they usually are done with a flatlock seam.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/flatlock%20stitches-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/Flatlockstitch%20combine%20on%20garment-min.jpg)

#####Zigzag Stitch If you donâ€™t have a serger, the zigzag stitch on your sewing machine will do the job. This is used on seams that need stretch so the threads wonâ€™t break when stretched. It can also be used along the hems as well.

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/twin%20needle%20a-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/twin%20needle%20b-min.jpg)

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/twin%20needle%20hem-min.jpg)

#####Twin Needle For the hem, I like to serge the raw edges for a clean finish, and then use a twin needle to top stitch the hem allowance into place. This is how most clothing (fitness to ready to wear) is finished. A twin needle is used as a decorative stitch that produces parallel lines along the top and zigzag threads on the bottom to allow the threads to stretch when pulled (like pushing your legs through the pant sleeve or pulling a shirt over your head). For my leggings, I wanted a pop of pattern and a solid navy/blue. I went with Supplex Athletic Knit in navy and this butterfly flutter athletic knit . I also wanted a matching top. This t-shirt with the open back was a pattern I made myself as well as the white tank with the mesh racer back. For the racer back top, I used Telio Mod Stretch Mesh White and Telio Stretch Bamboo Rayon Jersey Knit White. Either way, donâ€™t let the intimidation of making athletic wear deter you from going for it. You might find your own custom look is the key to looking great while doing a workout....and it might even make you work harder, too. Happy sewing!

![Sewing Athletic Wear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20with%20Athletic%20Fabrics/DSC_0369-min.jpg)

posts.markdown:
Created by: House Homemade Hello! Iâ€™m Jessica from House Homemade and Iâ€™m so happy to be invited by fabric.com to tell you about this super simple, big impact Christmas craft I made.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%201-min.jpg)

These ornaments made from awesome fabric I picked from fabric.com and small embroidery hoops. They can be displayed in your tree. They can be strung as a garland. They can be hung from your windows. Anything! But the best part? The fabric choice isnâ€™t permanent so you can change your Christmas dÃ©cor style, color or theme Every. Single. Year. Yay for versatility! Psst. Here are the hoop ornaments I made last year.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%20last%20year-min.JPG)

Itâ€™s a little early but since Christmas is my absolute favorite time of year, Iâ€™ve had my decorating wheels turning for a bit and think this is where Iâ€™m headed with my dÃ©cor this year.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%202-min.jpg)

I thrifted this beautiful blanket a couple months ago thinking 1. Itâ€™s the happiest blanket of all timesâ€¦I must add it to my collection. And 2. It would make an awesome, fun, whimsical Christmas tree skirt. Did you know you donâ€™t even have to use an actual tree skirt as a tree skirt? It never occurred to me until last year. With this great blanket in mind, I thought about the staples we have at Christmas and then the colors I used year-round in our home. Our red gingham stockings are a must. Green is a big deal around here and a fair amount of pink. With these things in mind, I chose a few Cotton + Steel fabrics that I love. (I love all of their fabrics. Theyâ€™re so fun and pretty.)

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%203-min.jpg)

Fabric 1: Wonderland Rose Garden Crimson (this fabric is currently unavailable but you can view the entire collection here ![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/fabric%201-min.jpg)

Fabric 2: Printshop Moons Pink This one pulls in the pink that is sprinkled throughout our house and the lighter backdrop will help them to stand out when theyâ€™re on display in our tree.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/fabric%202-min.jpg)

Fabric 3: Add it Up Lollipop Tip: Pay attention to the scale of the fabrics by looking at the ruler below each one. This last one is very small scale but pulls in greenâ€”my favoriteâ€”and still has the lighter background to stand out in the tree.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/fabric%203-min.jpg)

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%204-min.jpg)

I chose the 4â€ embroidery hoops but depending on the size of your tree, you might be able to get away with using larger ones.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/step%201-min.jpg)

You unscrew the tops of the embroidery hoops. Theyâ€™re made up of two rings with the outside ring being tightened to hold the inside ring in. Put the fabric, right side down, on top of the outside of the hoop.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/step%202-min.jpg)

Adjust the fabric over the outside hoop making sure itâ€™s not wrinkled (or crooked if itâ€™s a directional fabric). Also, make sure you position it as close to the edge as you can so that you donâ€™t have much waste.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/step%203-min.jpg)

Push the inside hoop over the fabric and into the outside hoop. Continue to adjust the fabric to keep in straight, pulled tight and close to the edge.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/step%204-min.jpg)

Tighten the screw on the outside hoop again.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/step%205-min.jpg)

Using fabric scissors cut the extra fabric away from the back part of the hoop. Cut as close to the edge as possible. If you tightened it enough, the fabric wonâ€™t slip and the finished product will look nicer without scraps hanging off the back.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%205-min.jpg)

Donâ€™t they look so pretty? I love how they turned out and how nice they all look together.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%206-min.jpg)

Like I said, from here they could be strung together as a garland. They would be so cute one attached to each stocking as a stocking tag with an initial or a name printed on top of the fabric. Theyâ€™d be nice hanging from a window as ornaments for the neighbors to view. Ours will end up in our tree as ornaments. You could tie them up by strings, but I like placing them in between branches to sit on the boughs.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/Photo%207-min.jpg)

I created this post in October and in efforts to not annoy my sweet husband or confuse my sweet kids, I put the hoops in a cedar tree outside instead of dragging out Christmas tree out so early.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/photo%208-min.jpg)

I hope you love this project. Itâ€™s one of my favorites. Itâ€™s so versatile. Simple. Casual. Crafty. Perfect for the kind of Christmas tree I love. For more quick and easy DIYâ€™s make sure you come over and visit my blog, House Homemade. Big thanks to Fabric.com for having me. Happy Holidays, yâ€™all! Photo 1

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Embroidery%20Hoop%20Holiday%20Ornaments/Photo%20Oct%2030%2C%2012%2054%2024%20PM-min.jpg)

posts.title: Sewing 101: Pattern Drafting
posts.markdown:
If youâ€™re like most of us, you probably have quite a few garments in your wardrobe that you love the fit or style, and wish you could recreate more. Weâ€™re going to show you an easy way to draft a pattern from an existing garment using a brand new fabric. ####Supplies Needed * Fabric for new garment (we used Telio Topaz Hatchi Knit Fuchsia ) * Existing garment * Tracing paper * Cutting Mat * Pins * Sewing supplies ####Instructions Lay your garment on tracing paper over a cutting mat. You can also use pattern material with printed gridlines. Either method will help you draw the dimensions evenly. Smooth out any wrinkles and try to correct any fabric warping. Mark any corners with a pencil outside of the seam allowance.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/0_15%20Mark%20Corners-min.png)

Use a measuring tape to measure bust, waist and hips or any other important measurement based on the garment being traced. Divide that by 2, and use a pin to poke through the fabric onto the tracing paper for each measurement taken to form half of the front sweater piece. The same line will be the edge for the back pattern piece.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/0_42%20Measure%20and%20Poke-min.png)

Take your pin and poke through the seam allowance to create a dot-to dot outline of the garment. Use this technique on any seam that the tracing paper isnâ€™t immediately visible to trace directly.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/Pin%20hole%20close%20up-min.jpg)

Remove your garment and continue drawing the pattern. Connect the pinhole dots, and trace the outlines accounting for a seam allowance and hem.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/1_05%20Hem%20and%20seam%20allowance-min.png)

Continue to do this for the back piece, and the sleeve piece.

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/0_51%20Pin%20poke%20in%20action-min.png)

![Embroidery Hoop Ornaments]( https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Pattern%20Drafting/2_06%20Pattern%20Pieces%20done-min.JPG)

Measure and apply any finishings needed such as cuffs or neck binding. We used the measured knit band method from this knits tutorial.

If youâ€™re like most of us, you probably have quite a few garments in your wardrobe that you love the fit or style, and wish you could recreate more. Weâ€™re going to show you an easy way to draft a pattern from an existing garment using a brand new fabric.

Supplies Needed

  • Fabric for new garment (we used Telio Topaz Hatchi Knit Fuchsia )
  • Existing garment
  • Tracing paper
  • Cutting Mat
  • Pins
  • Sewing supplies

Instructions

Lay your garment on tracing paper over a cutting mat. You can also use pattern material with printed gridlines. Either method will help you draw the dimensions evenly. Smooth out any wrinkles and try to correct any fabric warping. Mark any corners with a pencil outside of the seam allowance.

Use a measuring tape to measure bust, waist and hips or any other important measurement based on the garment being traced. Divide that by 2, and use a pin to poke through the fabric onto the tracing paper for each measurement taken to form half of the front sweater piece. The same line will be the edge for the back pattern piece.

Take your pin and poke through the seam allowance to create a dot-to dot outline of the garment. Use this technique on any seam that the tracing paper isnâ€™t immediately visible to trace directly.

Remove your garment and continue drawing the pattern. Connect the pinhole dots, and trace the outlines accounting for a seam allowance and hem.

Continue to do this for the back piece, and the sleeve piece.

Measure and apply any finishings needed such as cuffs or neck binding. We used the measured knit band method from this knits tutorial.

Tip: The garment will more than likely have some manipulation due to assembly and being worn in high-function areas, such as shoulders. Find the grain of the fabric and manipulate the fabric to follow the grain as needed to acquire appropriate pattern dimensions.

Tip: If the fabric youâ€™re using doesnâ€™t match the characteristics of the garment being copied, account for that by adding or subtracting dimensions to account for stretch percentage. The Telio Topaz Hatchi Knit Fuchsia fabric we used to copy the green sweater has 75% stretch, and the green sweater has a little more than that, so we added Â¼â€ to the seam allowances to account for the different stretches.

Tip: Make notes on each pattern piece like naming it, how many to cut, seam allowance used, fabric recommendations and date created.

posts.title: DIY Holiday Village
posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Hi fabric.com readers! It's Bev from Flamingo Toes here with you today and I'm so excited to bring you with this fun and whimsical DIY Holiday Village! I just love projects where I can do a little fussy cutting and this Christmas village made with Tasha Noel's fabric line for Riley Blake, Pixie Noel, was so fun to sew up! ####Supplies Needed:
  • Pixie Noel Fabrics - 1/2 - 1 yard of each - depending on how much you want to use for the background and roofs of the houses:
    • Snow Aqua
    • Stripe Red
    • Floral Red
    • Main Green
    • Floral White
    • Floral Aqua
    • Hats and Socks Red
    • Hats and Socks Green
  • Pom Pom Trim
  • Riley Blake White and White Daisy
  • Heat'n Bond Fusible Webbing
  • Heavyweight Fusible Interfacing
  • Fiberfil
  • Small piece of cardboard for base of each house
  • Aurifil Black 50wt Thread
I made a whole group of little houses for my village - all decorated with cute florals, trims and even little striped stockings! All the details on the houses are pieces of fabric cut out for the designs so it's super easy to decorate and customize them. I just love all these little whimsical details. ####Pattern Download Download the DIY Holiday Village pattern here:

Fabric Houses, Doors and Windows Patterns

The patterns have a variety of house and roof shapes - feel free to mix and match those up so your houses all look a bit different. Choose doors and windows that have shapes that work with the images you are fussy cutting from the fabrics. It's fun to plan it all out! I'll walk you through one of the houses but they're all constructed with the same steps. Â For all the houses, measure up 1" from the bottom and then start your details like doors and windows. For the little clothes line I drew a line with a disappearing marking pen for the line guide. Cut out socks and hats from the fabric and iron these to the fusible webbing. Trim around the shapes and remove the paper backing. Iron the socks, hats, and door and window to the front of the house. Stitch around everything with the black Aurifil thread two or three times. I like to use a free motion foot and just do a sketched stitch look. Sew the roof pieces to the front and back of the house pieces. If you want, add in trim to the top of the house before or after your roof is sewn on. If you are adding a chimney to your roof, cut a piece of heavyweight interfacing and fuse this to one side of the chimney pieces. Sew the pieces together on three sides, leaving the bottom edge open. Turn right side out and press. If you're adding a chimney to a curved or triangle roof, your chimney will need to be perpendicular to the roof edge. So the roof will actually be pointing sideways inside the front and back of the roof pieces as you sew them together. This will allow it to stand up straight when turned right side out. If you're adding a chimney to a straight roof, just sew it in pointing downwards. Place the front and back of the house right sides together and sew around the pieces with a 1/4" seam allowance. Leave an opening in the side of the house for turning right side out. Clip all the curves and pointed edges. Bring the bottom edge of the house up to match the side edge at the corner to form a point in the bottom corner. Sew a seam across this point 1" from the pointed end. This will make a box pleat in the bottom of the house and allow the house to stand up straight. Repeat for the other corner of the house. Trim the corner edge off just outside of the seam. Turn the house right side out and press. Cut a piece of cardboard the size of the box pleat section on the base of the house. Most of mine were 1 1/2" x 3" but you'll want to double-check yours. Slide the cardboard into the base of the house, then stuff the house with fiberfill. Hand sew the opening closed. Repeat for all the other houses you'd like to make! Wouldn't these be so cute lined up along a mantel or shelf?!

posts.title: Classic Cut & Sew Stockings
posts.markdown:
Looking for a quick and easy way to create handmade stockings this holiday season? These cut and sew stockings are the perfect project to add to your list!

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/IMG_7434-min.JPG)

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/IMG_7419-min.JPG)

####Easy Sew Stocking Templates These easy sew stocking templates can be found exclusively on fabric.com in 7 different designs, including reindeer, poinsettias, holiday birds and more. They are very lightweight jacquard panels, and feature gorgeous metallic accents! Each of the stockings measures approximately 27" x 18.8", making them a great size for filling up with holiday goodies!

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/0544883-min.jpg)

We chose to mix and match the traditional jingle bells, a festive tree and a fun dog and cat design for our mantle. We paired them with a soft cotton velvet for the lining. #####To create 1 stocking, you'll need: * 1 stocking panel of your choice * Â½ yd. of fabric for lining (we used Acetex Cotton Velvet Forest but you can use any quilting cotton, velvet, velveteen, or satin) * General sewing supplies * Tool for turning One of the best things about this fabric is the quality and detail! They have such a lovely hand and almost feel hand stitched.

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/IMG_7467-min.JPG)

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/IMG_7484-min.JPG)

####Instructions In case this is your first time creating stockings, or you are new to sewing, we wanted to include step-by-step instructions for this festive project. These custom woven panels feature seam allowance on each stocking. Keep along these lines and match them for your lining for a perfect finished product! *Tip for sewing with jacquards: Since this is a custom woven jacquard with many different colors, the edges are prone to fraying when cut. Sew together as soon as possible after cutting and donâ€™t handle the edges too much. ####Step 1 Cut out your two pieces from the jacquard stocking panel. Use these as a pattern to cut two corresponding pieces out of your lining fabric. If youâ€™re a beginner, we recommend using quilting cotton for lining. It will be easiest to work with. Satin and velvet will shift when being sewn. Cotton velvet or velveteen is also a good option, but it will make for a bulkier lining. We used this cotton velvet. Also cut a small piece of your lining that is 1.5â€x6â€ for a hanging loop.

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/1-min.jpg)

####Step 2 Sew one matching main piece and one lining piece together along the top edge. Repeat for the other corresponding main and lining pieces. ####Step 3 Create a loop for turning by sewing the long sides together on the 1.5â€x6â€ piece and turning. If you have a turning or stuffing fork, that works great. You can also use a pencil or knitting needle!

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/2-min.jpg)

####Step 4 Place the folded loop piece on the right side of one main stocking piece. Pin or baste in place.

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/3-min.jpg)

####Step 5 Pin main stocking pieces right sides together, leaving an opening in the lining for turning. Backstitch over the place where the loop is, making sure that your loop stays stacked on top of itself.

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/4-min.jpg)

####Step 6 Turn stocking right side out through the hole left in the lining. Close the hole in the lining now with a hand slip stich or by machine. Nest the lining into the stocking now.

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/5-min.jpg)

####Step 7 You can topstitch the top of the stocking so the lining stays neatly, or you can skip this step. You now have an heirloom stocking with a loop for hanging by the fire with care!

![Cut and Sew Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cut%20%26%20Sew%20Stockings/IMG_7442-min.JPG)

Happy holiday sewing!

First things first, you need to decide on a pattern! I also like to spend time looking for inspiration online by searching â€˜Fall 2017 Coat Trendsâ€™ (for example) to get some ideas of what is current in fashion. I also really love using an online resource called The Foldline to search different types of patterns. Go with a design youâ€™re drawn to, but that is also practical for your lifestyle. Sewing a coat is a big investment of both your money and time, and you want to make sure youâ€™re making something you will really love. Down below Iâ€™ve included 6 of my current favorite coat patterns to give you a few ideas.

This is Elise from www.eliseandemelie.com and today Iâ€™m sharing a no sew project with you all! Fabric garlands are such a fun way to personalize a wall or decorate for the holidays, so letâ€™s get started! Itâ€™s a perfect project to do together with kids too as there is no sewing or hot glue guns involved once the prep work of cutting the fabric strips are done.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0009-min.jpg)

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0010-min.jpg)

#####Optional Supplies: * Scissors * inking shears * Mini clothes pins * Pellon Lite EZ-Steam II ####Instructions Alright, letâ€™s cut our fabric strips! I experimented with different widths and ended up with a mix of fabric strips ranging in width from 1.75â€ to 2.5â€ wide. I started with thinner strips but in the end I wanted to be able to see as much of the prints on each fabric as possible so I cut them wider. When the prints have cute faces you donâ€™t want to chop them up! So, depending on the print you choose to work with, test a few strips in different widths and see what you like. Line up your ruler with the edge of your fabric. Here you see it lined up at the 2.5â€ mark.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0011-min.jpg)

And cut.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0012-min.jpg)

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0015-min.jpg)

Take another strip of fabric and repeat steps 1-4 and keep on going until youâ€™ve added strips to fit your desired fabric garland width. Once youâ€™ve added enough strips, tie loops on each end of the string to hang it up.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0016-min.jpg)

Tadaaaaa! Super easy and fun!

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0017-min.jpg)

This garland makes for a festive backdrop to a table spread for the holidays too. Itâ€™s easy to add a little fun to a wall and with a cute christmas tree, even better! Itâ€™s really easy to customize the width too. If itâ€™s not wide enough, add more strips. If itâ€™s too wide, take off a few strips. So by now youâ€™re probably wondering about the need for the optional tools mentioned in the beginning. Well, did you notice how cut those llamas are? I mean, come on, leg warmers, pompoms and sweaters! So cute! I just had to make a bunting with the llamas!

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0019-min.jpg)

Also no sewing required here either!

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0020-min.jpg)

You can make a bunting, decorate the christmas tree with them, or even just use them individually to decorate the table and walls! Here are the steps to making the llama bunting:

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0021-min.jpg)

Place your print fabric facing down. Then take a sheet of the Pellon Lite EZ-Steam II and trace around the shape you want to cut out.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0022-min.jpg)

Cut the Pellon and remove one side of the paper backing.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0023-min.jpg)

Stick it onto the back of the fabric and cut it out. You can reposition the Pellon so donâ€™t worry if you donâ€™t place it right the first time. It wonâ€™t be permanent until you iron it.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0024-min.jpg)

If you have pinking shears, you can use them to cut out the shapes too. Clip your shapes onto string with mini clothes pins and youâ€™ve got yourself a super fun bunting! Thatâ€™s all from me this time and I hope you have fun making your own fabric garland and bunting.

![No Sew Fabric Garland](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Garland/2017-11-15_0018-min.jpg)

Happy holiday sewing!

Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Christmas stockings are the perfect finishing touch to holiday dÃ©cor. They can be made as a treasured heirloom, gifted for a new family member, or made yearly to follow trends and keep a fresh look to your seasonal atmosphere. This year, weâ€™ve mixed plaid flannel and faux fur fabric to modernize a classic tradition: a stocking with a faux fur cuff and adorable pom accents! I donâ€™t know if weâ€™re more excited about the goodies Santa will stuff them with, or the stockings themselves. Letâ€™s get started! ####Supplies: * 1 yd. stocking fabric (we used Kaufman Mammoth Flannel Buffalo Plaid Red) * 1/2 yd faux fur fabric (we used Shannon Luxury Faux Fur Candy Shag Gray) * 1 yd. lining fabric (we used Kona Cotton Poppy Red) * Satin Ribbon

####Pattern Download Click here to download our free stocking pattern, complete with the stocking, lining, fur cuff and fur poms templates!

####Step 2 Ccut out your fabric, right sides together. Cut and sew faux fur fabric using tips from this video. ####Step 3 Sew both liner and face fabric with 3/8â€ seam allowance. On the stocking piece, grade, clip and notch the seam allowance, flip and press. For the liner piece, leave an opening at the bottom in order to eventually flip the stocking rightside out. Trim the seam allowance down to Â¼â€ so that it fits well within the face fabric. Tip: press the opening Â¼â€ upward, it will make topstitching easier in step 5.

![Stockings](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Flannel%20and%20Fur%20Stocking/Pressed%20opening-min.jpg)

####Step 4 Layer the face fabric and cuff as shown in the video. Line the seam up on the outer seam of the stocking.

posts.title: 3 Ways to Wrap Gifts in Fabric
posts.markdown:
Welcome to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Today we're showing you 3 quick and easy ways to wrap gifts in fabric that require no sewing! Use holiday fabric for festive gift wrapping, or utilize these techniques year-round with versatile prints or solids for any occasion. The fabric used for wrapping makes a great gift for sewists, too, and is a super fun alternative to paper! It's a gift that keeps on giving. ####Supplies Needed: * Fabric of your choice Our fabric favorites for holiday: Cotton + Steel Noel My Favorite Sweater Natural Cotton + Steel Noel Metallic Gold Stripe Red Riley Blake Cozy Christmas Snowmen Our fabric favorites for year-round gifts: Art Gallery Boardwalk Delight Sprinkles Cotton + Steel Sprinkle Peaches Kona Cotton Emerald * Ribbon * Pins * Scissors

![Fabric Wrapping](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wrapping/Fabric%20Gift%20Wraping_-8-min.jpg)

####Technique 1: Tie in a Knot First up is the tied knot wrapping technique- a square box or gift works best for this method. First, cut a square of fabric 4 times the size of the box you are wrapping. Position the box in the center of the underside of the fabric (see video). Next, fold the corner of the fabric over so that it touches the other length of the box. Fold the opposite corner over the box, folding under any extra bits of fabric. Using the two opposite corners, tie a knot above the box. We tied a double not to make it extra secure!

![Fabric Wrapping](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wrapping/tiedknotbox.PNG)

![Fabric Wrapping](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wrapping/Untitled%20Catalog17732-min.jpg)

####Technique 2: The Standard Box Next is the standard box method. For this technique you will wrap a present much like you would with regular wrapping paper. Measure and cut a piece of fabric to cover the box much like you would with paper gift wrap. Start wrapping the gift like you normally would, but instead of using tape, using pins to hold the fabric in place. When it gets time to add the ribbon, pull it extra tight so that when you pull out the pins the fabric stays where it is. Once the ribbon and bow are tight, pull the pins from the box. Make sure you get 'em all!

![Fabric Wrapping](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wrapping/Fabric%20Gift%20Wraping_-min.jpg)

####Technique 3: Hard to Wrap Gifts This final technique is great for hard to wrap items, like cylindrical shaped gourmet foods! First cut a piece of fabric that is about 2" wider than the height of the box, that is also the circumference of the box (or depending on the fabric you choose, you might want to double the fabric up!). Place your gift in the top center of the fabric and roll. Tie off each end with ribbon and you are done!

![Fabric Wrapping](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Wrapping/Untitled%20Catalog17734.jpg)

We hope you enjoy these quick and easy ways to wrap your gifts in fabric this holiday season and beyond!

posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Today we are adding some festive flair to your home for the Holidays with this seasonal snowglobe quilt block! Fill your snowglobe with fun fussy cuts to create quilts, pillows and more. ####Supplies Needed: * 1 cotton print fabric for Snowglobe (MC)- we used the Snow Fuzzies print from the Cotton + Steel Noel Collection * 1 cotton print fabric for base (CC)- we used Candy Canes print from the Cotton + Steel Noel Collection * 1 solid fabric for background (BC)- we used Kona Cotton Snow * Quilting supplies

![Snowglobe Quilt Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Snowglobe%20Quit%20Block/supplies.png)

####Cutting Be sure to watch the video above for detailed cutting instructions! MC: (1) 10.5â€ x 10.5â€ CC: (1) 10.5â€ x 2.5â€ BC: (6) 2.5â€ x 2.5â€ ####Instructions: We will be preparing the snowglobe block by using the same method as for Half Square Triangles (HSTâ€™s). To prepare for this method, mark a line on all of your 2.5â€ squares from one corner to the other to sew over. Sew the squares. On the main square for your snowglobe, place four 2.5â€ squares on all corners, making sure your lines match up. Sew over the lines you drew in the previous step so that when finished, the shape of the snowglobe will be the same, but with white corners. Trim on the outside of the squares. Press open. On the base piece, do the same by placing 2 squares on each end and sew as before and trim. Press open. Sew these two pieces together to form a snowglobe block. Press seams open. Now you have a versatile quilt block perfect for any holiday quilt.

posts.title: Giftable Winter Blankets
posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Holiday gifts are that much more special when they are handmade, and you can't go wrong with a versatile blanket to curl up in all winter long! There are plenty of people on your list who would love this warm and cozy quilt. This easy striped quilt can be sewn up in an afternoon and is the perfect holiday gift for teachers, spouses, neighbors, parents or a special friend. Emily from Quilty Love will show us how!

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6116-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 1 1/2 yards Robert Kaufman Yarn Dyed Essex Linen (we used Shale) * 3 1/2 yards Robert Kaufman Mammoth Flannel (we used Americana) * 1 1/4 yards Kona Cotton White * 1/2 yard Kona Cotton Curry * Quilters Dream Batting * Thread * Rotary cutter * Cutting mat * Quilt ruler

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6058-min.jpg)

The Essex Linen in this easy striped quilt provides modern texture and warmth. The cozy flannel backing is festive and warm. Choose your favorite linen color and flannel print and make up a few of these quilts as handmade holiday gifts!

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6045-min.jpg)

####Instructions This easy quilt top goes together in strips. First you'll need to cut the fabric for the quilt top. #####Cutting the Essex Linen: First, cut seven 7.5in x WOF strips from the Essex linen. Trim five of these strips to 42in. From the remaining two strips, cut five 7.5in x 10in strips. Join together a 42in strip with a 10in strip using a 1/4in seam allowance and a smaller stitch length. Repeat for all five strips.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6060-min.jpg)

#####Cutting the White Fabric: Next, cut five 7.5in x WOF strips from the Kona Cotton white. Trim four of these strips to 42in. From the remaining strip cut four 7.5in x 10in pieces. Join together a 42in strip with a 10in strip using a 1/4in seam allowance. Repeat for all four strips. ####Assemble the quilt top Sew the strips together lengthwise using a 1/4in seam allowance. Start with a linen strip then a white strip, then a linen stripâ€¦etc.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6061-min.jpg)

Pin liberally during this step. While sewing straight strips together is simple, they will warp if you are not careful. Another trick to prevent warping is to sew each strip on in the opposite direction as the one before it. By flipping the quilt top in each direction the stripes will be straighter. ####Tips for working with linen Use a smaller stitch length when working with linen. Linen has a looser weave so the smaller stitch length will help it hold up better. Linen also has a tendency to stretch a bit so handle it carefully and consider using starch. Find more tips and tricks for successfully sewing with linen in this article.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_striped_quilt_tutorial--min.jpg)

There you have it! Your super simple striped quilt top is done. ####Prepare the backing fabric You are now ready to prepare the backing flannel fabric for your quilt. Cut the flannel backing in half on the short side.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_striped_quilt_tutorial-15-min.jpg)

Trim the selvedge off the two sides you will join together. Sew the two pieces back together on the long sides using a 1/2in seam allowance. Press this seam.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_striped_quilt_tutorial-14-min.jpg)

####Baste the quilt Next baste your quilt by placing the backing flannel piece right side down, adding the batting and placing the quilt top right side up. Pin or spray baste in place. ####Quilting Quilt by outlining each seam using a walking foot. Add accent lines as desired. I added 2 more lines outside of each seam spaced 1/2in apart. I also added 3 1/2in spaced lines right down the center of each strip. ####Bind the quilt From your binding fabric, cut six 2.5in x WOF strips. Sew them together end to end. Fold your binding wrong sides together lengthwise and press. Attach the binding to the quilt. Follow this easy binding tutorial here.

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6063-min.jpg)

Sew up a few of these striped flannel quilts to have on hand this holiday season. You will want to keep one for yourself after you see how cozy these quilts are!

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6094-min.jpg)

![Winter Blankets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Giftable%20Winter%20Blanket/quiltylove_EmilyDennis-6118-min.jpg)

posts.title: No Sew Rosette Wreath
posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Today we are making a no sew wreath with beautiful rosettes that can be used for holiday decorating or given as a festive gift! You can also create this wreath in a variety of colors and utilize them year round. First things first: There is no right or wrong way to do this! Just pin the fabric by twisting, wrapping, folding, and tying 4â€ bias strips of Dupioni Silk, covering a Styrofoam wreath. In this tutorial, we used a 12â€ wreath form. Follow the video for rosette techniques and have fun making this your own creation! ####Supplies: * 1 yd. Dupioni Silk (we chose this Red) * 12â€ Styrofoam Wreath Form * 3/8â€ Double -sided Satin Ribbon * 100 count Long Pearlized Pins

![Spa Robe](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Rosette%20Wreath/0380646.jpg)

####Step 1 Measure how long you want the wreath to hang, cut ribbon, tie ends together, loop knot onto the wreath and pin to secure around the wreath form. ####Step 2 Tie the 4â€ bias strips around the wreath. Secure them by tying, knotting or pinning. Leave the tails varying lengths for forming rosettes later. The longer the tail, the bigger the bloom! ####Step 3 Form the rosettes by loosely twisting, wrapping, and knotting. Secure with pearlhead pins discretely within the folds of the petals, and visibly in the center for a dimensional floral look. Use the remaining ends as leaves, or cut to shape as needed. Tip: Start your rosette in the center for the remaining tail to either form a leaf or go into another neighboring rosette. Start the rosette on the outside and finish the end in the middle to conceal any remaining tail.

![Spa Robe](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Rosette%20Wreath/Close%20up%20rosette-min.jpg)

####Step 4 We recommend to spray this wreath with a generous coating of heavy starch. It will protect the wreath from outdoor elements, as well as gently freeze your rosette and leaf formations.

![Spa Robe](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Rosette%20Wreath/IMG_7496-min.JPG)

Use different colors of dupioni silk throughout the year for a festive look all year round! We love this wreath in Dupioni Silk Iridescent Blue Ice.

![Spa Robe](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/No%20Sew%20Rosette%20Wreath/Blue%20Wreath%20blue%20door-min-rotated.jpg)

Happy Crafting! And Happy Holidays!

posts.title: Luxe CuddleÂ® Infinity Scarf
posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. This scarf is a quick project to keep you warm all winter, or makes a lovely handmade gift! The Minky Luxe CuddleÂ® Collection from Shannon Fabrics has a wonderful variety of textures, colors, and longer pile lengths that are perfect for this infinity scarf. ####Supplies: * 2 yds. Minky Luxe CuddleÂ® * General sewing supplies ####Step 1 Cut Minky fabric into a 59â€ x 24.5â€ rectangle.

![Infinity Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Infinity%20Scarf/minky%20measurements-min.JPG)

The 59â€ measurement is along the selvedge to complement the vertical nap of the minky texture. This cutting suggestion requires 2 yards of minky and will yield 2 scarfs (one to keep, one to give!). It is possible to cut this rectangle with the 24.5â€ on the selvedge and the 59â€ across the width, which would require only 1 yard of minky. Keep the orientation of fabric in mind when determining how many yards to purchase. ####Step 2 Fold right sides together, and sew the 59â€ side seams with a Â½â€ seam allowance. Once the side seam is complete, flip inside out. *Tip: Use a walking foot in your sewing machine.

![Infinity Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Infinity%20Scarf/side%20seam%20tube-min.JPG)

####Step 3 Join one side of the ends to the opposite end, but before you do, twist it! Twisting it before joining the ends allows the scarf to have a more flattering fit around the neck when worn!

![Infinity Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Infinity%20Scarf/twist%20sequence-min.JPG)

####Step 4 Use pins or wonder clips to join one side of the tube opening to the other, right sides together. Sew Â½â€ seam along the tube opening until you should have about a 6â€ opening. The scarf should be almost completely right side out at this point, and you can hand stitch the opening closed. Itâ€™s best to join the tube this way so that the scarf infinity tube can freely move, creating a better fit.

![Infinity Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Infinity%20Scarf/pin%20scarf-min.JPG)

To wear, double it around your neck to create a soft and cozy cowl around your neck, pairing perfectly with any coat or jacket.

![Infinity Scarf](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIY%20Infinity%20Scarf/shannon%20wearing%20it-min.JPG)

This same tutorial can be used with many apparel fabrics. We love Minky Luxe CuddleÂ® for winter, but this scarf would also be great in lawn, voile, chiffon, jersey knit and crepe for transitioning into warmer weather! Happy Sewing! And Happy Gifting!
