posts.title: Fabric Gift Baskets
posts.markdown:
Welcome back to our 12 Days of Project series! To view all 12 of our holiday projects, from DIY decor to giftable projects, click here. Today weâ€™re sharing a tutorial to line a simple basket with fabric, using just a glue gun! This fabric requires no sewing, and is perfect for when youâ€™re in a crunch for time but still want to create a really special gift. You might have a basket lying around at home that could use a little make over as well! So, check to see if you have one at home hiding in a closet or tucked away in the garage. If no basket is to be found at home there are a lot of places you can buy them used for a few dollars. Letâ€™s get started!

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0018.jpg)

####Supplies needed * Fabric of your choice for basket lining (we used an assortment of Riley Blake Pixie Noel fabrics) * Batting (we used Warm & Natural batting, but polyester batting is good too) * Measuring tape * Pencil * Fabric scissors * Paper scissors * Glue gun and extra glue sticks * Cardboard or paper * Optional: pinking shears and ribbon Here is the basket before adding the liner. We used a set of baskets in two different sizes. You can use any shape or size, and itâ€™s super easy to customize the fabric liner!

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0001.jpg)

####Instructions Measure the basket circumference. Multiply the circumference by 1.5. That is the length of fabric you will need to line the side of the basket because we will be ruching the fabric as weâ€™re gluing it on. If you want more ruching, double the circumference and cut the fabric to that length (i.e. 20â€ circumference x1.5= 30â€ long strip of fabric).

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0009.jpg)

Next, measure the height of the basket inside. Add 3â€ to the basket height (i.e. 4â€ high basket side + 3â€= 7â€).

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0006.jpg)

Cut the fabric strip according to the width and height totals figured out in steps 1 and 2. Trace the basket bottom onto the cardboard. It doesn't have to be an exact trace, just make sure to get general shape of the basket.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0010.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0013.jpg)

Cut it out. Since we traced the outside of the basket, the cardboard will not fit inside the basket bottom. Trim the cardboard down little by little to fit inside the basket.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0014.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0015.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0016.jpg)

Take two layers of batting and cut to fit the cardboard for the basket bottom.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0020.jpg)

Take your glue gun and glue on the batting to the cardboard.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0021.jpg)

Cut one layer of batting strip to fit the basket circumference. Glue the inside of the basket, about an inch below the edge.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0027.jpg)

Attach the batting strip and go around the whole basket.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0028.jpg)

Just work on a few inches at a time since the glue hardens fast and you need to attach the batting while the glue is still hot.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0029.jpg)

Now that the batting is glued on to the inside of the basket side, itâ€™s time for the fabric strip to be glued on! Start by applying some glue above the batting and attach the fabric strip.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0030.jpg)

Once the strip is on, you will do the ruching by squishing it over the the side. Glue, attach and do the ruching as you go around the whole basket. If you find that you need to use more than one strip of fabric, just overlap the fabric pieces where they meet and continue to work your way around.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0031.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0032.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0033.jpg)

Now take your basket bottom that you glued the batting onto and place it on top of a piece of fabric . Place the fabric wrong side up, and the basket bottom with the batting side down.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0023.jpg)

Cut the fabric and leave enough to glue onto the cardboard bottom.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0024.jpg)

Apply glue to the edge of the cardboard and attach the fabric.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0026.jpg)

Flip the bottom piece right side up and place it inside the basket.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0034.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0035.jpg)

Now that your basket is done, fill it up with goodies! We made a gift basket full of embroidery supplies for an aspiring embroiderer. Embroidery hoops, floss, and pattern tracing materials.

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0038.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0040.jpg)

Here are both of the baskets, and now we have just have to fill the smaller one to gift!

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0043.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0044.jpg)

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0048.jpg)

The jar covers are super easy to make as well, just trace a circle using a jar or small plate and cut out with pinking shears. Then tie them up with a ribbon!

![Fabric Gift Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Bakset/2017-10-31_0053.jpg)

Happy holiday sewing!

![Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20with%20Sequins/step%209%20inside%20clutch-min.JPG)

![Sequins](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20with%20Sequins/clutch%20square-min.jpg)

posts.markdown:
Created by: Emily Hallman Designs For those of us who delight in making our own clothes, this time of year is nothing short of magnificent. Thereâ€™s no better season for everything glitzy and special â€“ we basically have a free pass to wear all the shimmer and shine we want! And whatâ€™s the holiday season without a little sparkle? Not complete, if you ask me. Iâ€™ve always liked making a few sequin garments in December, and I like to encourage other sewists to do the same. Thereâ€™s no need to be intimidated by projects like this â€“ with a few tips in mind youâ€™ll be asking yourself why you didnâ€™t start the sparkle party sooner.

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric7-min.jpg)

####Fabric Choices The garments in todayâ€™s post were both made with Glitz Sequin and Mesh fabric in navy and gold. Itâ€™s a very easy sequin fabric to work with, and itâ€™s available in a lot of different colors. (That red is especially gorgeous!) Looking for sewing tips for working with sequins? Click here to view our blog post and video! Whether you are new to working with sequin fabric, or have been sewing for years, these helpful tips and tricks are a great reference!. ####Pattern Choices For these NYE looks, I chose simple patterns with no darts or zippers or buttons and only a few seams. Itâ€™s a good idea to avoid over-complicated designs when working with sequin fabric, and everything you would normally anticipate when you undertake a sewing project (seam finishes, hems, facings, closures, etc.) is even more important to plan fabrics like this. For unlined garments like these two, bias tape around the seams and hems is a great alternative to serging, which is a huge no-no for sequin material. For the top, I attached bias tape to each edge (neckline, arms, and hem) and then turned the seam under and hand stitched it down. This fabric isnâ€™t at all scratchy on the wrong side, so you can absolutely choose patterns that have no lining. By the same token, garments that are lined would be great options too. For the top I used McCall's 6566, and for the skirt I used McCallâ€™s 5430 (lengthened).

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric16-min.jpg)

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric15-min.jpg)

I used the same technique for the skirt and, just like the top, it makes for clean edges with no loose sequins or unfinished seams. For additional stability for the ties and waistband, I placed the sequin fabric on top of an underlining that had been interfaced. And in place of a button and buttonhole like the pattern suggests, I used snaps.

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric9-min.jpg)

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric13-min.jpg)

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric14-min.jpg)

The biggest thing to remember when you work with sequin fabric is that it is the star of the show. Any design with too many bells and whistles will only make things crowded and distracting. Instead, go with a pattern that is more simple to let the fabric really shine. Itâ€™s also important to be patient and take it a little slower with these kinds of fabrics. And I always wear safety glasses when I cut out my garment. Cut sequins go rogue all the time, and you want to protect those peepers!

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric17-min.jpg)

![DIYs for NYE](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DIYs%20for%20NYE/Fabric11-min.jpg)

Thereâ€™s still plenty of time to whip up something pretty in time for New Yearâ€™s Eve and, gosh, if you arenâ€™t wearing sparkle on New Yearâ€™s Eve are you really doing it right? Happy sewing!

posts.title: Lounging or Lunging: Athleisure DIYs
posts.markdown:
Created by: Love You Sew The trend reports are out for 2018 and yes, Athleisure style is staying! Whether you have some New Year's resolutions to fulfill, or just enjoy some comfy clothes, the newest athletic knits from Pine Crest Fabrics will be perfect for your project from lounging to lunging!

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4082-min.jpg)

I'm working on my goal to get some regular exercise into my routine, because sewing isn't the most aerobic activity out there- ha! To stay motivated, I know I need some fun new gear, and knew that a fun pair of leggings and long-sleeved tunic could get me through this cold season. ####Fabric Choices The following fabrics were pulled to keep me (hopefully) on task! First is the Pine Crest Fabrics Strata Athletic Knit White/Grey/Black. This is a perfect neutral with the trademark space-dyed athleisure print you see out in the market. This print is great at hiding up sweat marks you might see in just a solid but remains a perfect staple. The fabric feels so smooth and luxurious with an amazing 30% four-way stretch!

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4103-min.jpg)

Then I went for a more wild print for my leggings! Pine Crest Fabrics Jungle Leaves on Olympus Athletic Double Knit Green is a gorgeous on-trend print to add some fun to the mundane tasks of working out! Although this is a large scale print being used on a skin-tight garment, the different colors and shades really make the eye move around, creating a very flattering effect. These large leaves are printed on a double-knit 10% four-way stretch and feels so fabulous. This fabric has great compression but still feels so smooth and not sticky against my skin.

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4141-min.jpg)

####Tips for sewing athletic wear Working with athletic wear doesn't have to be scary with some of these tips! * As with any knits, make sure to use new ball point jersey knit stretch needles. * Try wooly (aka bulky, fluffy) nylon in the bobbin or in the lower looper of a serger. This reduces the friction of seams against your skin, as well as having some additional stretch in your stitching.

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4098-min.jpg)

* Relieve the pressure on your presser foot (if it's an option on your machine.) This will allow the fabric to move more evenly and not be stretched out in the process. * Use a scrap piece of "leader" fabric to help with guide your thicker seams through your machine (this helps prevent your machine from "eating" up your precious project).

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4097-min.jpg)

* If you have the option, use a triple zig-zag stitch on your domestic (much more strength and stretch than your basic zig-zag.) * Use a wash-away or tear-away stabilizer to help the fabric move through your machine. (Although, I will use tissue paper in a pinch.)

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4093-min.jpg)

* Stabilize shoulder seams and any other high stress-points with knit interfacing or clear elastic.

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4100-min.jpg)

* Leave at least a few inches on every thread tail as you move through your project.

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4095-min.jpg)

* Most importantly, test every. single. seam. with all your strength. Test out your stitches on scraps and see if any pop. Adjust as needed. After every seam sewn, pull horizontally and vertically. Your bobbin or looper threads may shift and that's okay...you just added more easement into your stitches and that's why you have those thread tails! * Backstitch at the beginning and end of each seam AFTER the stress tests. If you are serging, either use a large-eye needle to pull the tail back into the stitching or loop it into an adjoining seam. Home-sewn athletic wear is very possible and I hope these tips help you through your next project. For additional fabric.com athletic wear posts, check out this post on Sewing with Activewear Fabric and these tips for Sewing Athletic Wear! ####Make my Outfit

![Athleisure](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Athleisure%20Jan%202018/IMG_4124-min.jpg)

#####Tunic Denver Tunic by Blank Slate Patterns with cowl neck and thumb-hole hacks. With the colder temperatures, a tunic is great to layer over a tee or tank. The high cowl neck protects against the cold and folds down when you need to release some heat. The thumb holes keep your sleeves in place while keeping those hands warm. The longer length helps hide what you need and those pockets are perfect for everything. #####Leggings Taylor Contoured Waist Leggings by Laela Jayne Patterns These are a great beginner pattern for basic leggings with a nice thick contoured waistband for a curvy figure. Good luck with your own 2018 goals and I hope you include making some Athletic Wear in them!

posts.title: Hanging Pocket Organizer How-To
posts.markdown:
Created by: Elise Baek (Elise & Emelie) Hi there, Elise here! I have a super fun wall pocket tutorial for you today, because I donâ€™t know about you, but with the New Year I always feel the need to move stuff around and re-organize things around the house. Thatâ€™s when a wall pocket organizer such as this one will come in handy for all those little bits and pieces youâ€™ve got laying around. I have a sewing space that always needs a bit of organizing and I knew this would be the solution to my organizing needs.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0002.jpg)

####Materials needed *Finished size: Approximately 21â€ wide x 36â€ tall I chose an assortment of prints from the Cotton + Steel Sienna Collection for my organizer, but the possibilities are endless with fabric.com's selection! #####Main panel: * 3/4 yard fabric for main panel front * 3/4 yard fabric for main panel back * 21â€ x 36â€ piece of ByAnnieâ€™s Soft and Stable #####Pocket panels: * 1/2 yard of each of the four Cotton + Steel Sienna prints featured in the project * 1 3/4 yards Pellon SF 101 #####Binding: * (5) strips 2.5â€ x WOF *Notes: Use a 1/2â€ seam allowance throughout unless otherwise noted. Width of fabric (WOF) is assumed to be 42â€.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0028.jpg)

####Tools needed * Ruler * Rotary cutter * Hera marker * Binding clips * Pins * Disappearing fabric marker/pen * Glue basting spray ( I used 505 Spray and Fix by Odif ) * Walking foot for your sewing machine Finally, you'll need a set of curtain clips for hanging! ####Step 1 Cut out your fabric and Pellon SF 101 pieces according to the chart below. #####Main panel front and back: * 22â€ wide x 37â€ tall ( youâ€™re cutting these pieces slightly bigger than the soft and stable because when you quilt you lose some of the width and height of the fabric ) #####Main panel soft and stable: * 21â€ wide x 36â€ tall #####Top row pockets: * (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer * (1) 33â€ wide x 7â€ tall piece of Pellon SF 101 #####Second row pockets: * (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer * (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101 * (1) 33â€ wide x 7â€ tall piece of lining #####Third row pockets: * (1) 11â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of fabric for the center pocket * (2) 10â€ wide x 8â€ tall pieces of fabric for the left and right side pockets * (1) 11â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of Pellon SF 101 * (2) 10â€ wide x 8â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101 * (1) 29â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of lining #####Fourth row pockets: * (2) 14â€ wide x 9â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer * (2) 14â€ wide x 9â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101 * (1) 27â€ wide x 9â€ tall piece of lining ####Step 2 Place your main panel back facing down, Soft and stable on top, and your main panel front facing up. Glue baste the three layers together.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0029.jpg)

Once the glue is set, quilt the three layers together by sewing straight lines one inch apart or as desired.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0030.jpg)

####Step 3 Take your pocket pieces and corresponding Pellon SF 101 pieces and fuse together with a hot iron by placing the pocket fabric face down and placing the Pellon with the glue side down. Iron.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0031.jpg)

####Step 4 Take the pocket pieces for each row and sew them together with a 1/2â€ seam allowance. You will end up with four long strips. Make sure to press the seams open.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0032.jpg)

####Step 5 Now itâ€™s time to mark the folding lines on your pocket panels! Take your hera marker and make crease marks 3/4â€ away from the seam on both sides on the front side of the fabric.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0033.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0034.jpg)

Mark 1â€ in from each end on the front side of the fabric.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0035.jpg)

Flip the pocket panel over so that the back side of the pockets are facing up, and mark the following lines. Make crease marks 1.5â€ away from the seam on both sides.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0036.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0037.jpg)

Mark 1.75â€ in from each end on the back side of the fabric.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0038.jpg)

####Step 6 Following the crease lines made in the above step, go ahead the and fold the fabric and use binding clips to keep them in place. Finger press or use an iron to press to make sharp fold lines.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0039.jpg)

####Step 7 Now that your fabric has the fold lines set, itâ€™s time to sew on the lining. Use a 1/2â€ seam allowance and sew along the top of the pocket panel. Press the lining over and edge stitch on the lining.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0040.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0041.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0041.jpg)

Press the lining back and sew 1/2â€ in from the top edge. At this point its good to give the folds a good press again.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0044.jpg)

Repeat steps 5-7 for the remaining 3 pocket panel strips. ####Step 8 Once all the pocket panels have been sewn together, take the bottom row panel and line up the sides and bottom with the main panel. Baste stitch the two sides.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0049.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0050.jpg)

####Step 9 Make the folds in the pocket panel and find the space in between two pockets. Pin in place.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0051.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0052.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0053.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0054.jpg)

Sew up from the bottom edge, to the top and around down to the bottom edge 1/8â€ from the center seam.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0055.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0056.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0057.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0058.jpg)

Once the pocket sides have been sewn into place, fold the pockets in place and baste stitch the bottom edge.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0059.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0060.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0061.jpg)

Repeat steps 8-9 for the remaining three pocket panels. Place the pocket panels 1.25â€ apart.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0045.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0048.jpg)

####Step 10 Take your binding strips and sew them together.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0062.jpg)

And press in half.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0063.jpg)

####Step 11 Take the folded binding strip and line up the raw edges with the raw edge of the pocket panel. Sew in place with a 1/4â€ seam allowance. Do this on the top three pocket panels.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0064.jpg)

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0065.jpg)

Next, fold the binding strip down to the sewn line.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0065.jpg)

Fold the binding strip down one more time.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0067.jpg)

And sew in place.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0068.jpg)

####Step 12 Take the folded binding strip and sew it to the back side of the main pocket panel, raw edges together. Sew it to one corner, and finish with a 45 degree angle.

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0069.jpg)

Fold the binding strip up,

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0070.jpg)

and down again,

![Hanging Organizer](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Hanging%20Organizer/2018-01-09_0071.jpg)

and stitch in place,

Created by: Elise Baek (Elise & Emelie)

Hi there, Elise here! I have a super fun wall pocket tutorial for you today, because I donâ€™t know about you, but with the New Year I always feel the need to move stuff around and re-organize things around the house. Thatâ€™s when a wall pocket organizer such as this one will come in handy for all those little bits and pieces youâ€™ve got laying around. I have a sewing space that always needs a bit of organizing and I knew this would be the solution to my organizing needs.

Materials needed

*Finished size: Approximately 21â€ wide x 36â€ tall

I chose an assortment of prints from the Cotton + Steel Sienna Collection for my organizer, but the possibilities are endless with fabric.com's selection!

Main panel:
  • 3/4 yard fabric for main panel front
  • 3/4 yard fabric for main panel back
  • 21â€ x 36â€ piece of ByAnnieâ€™s Soft and Stable
Pocket panels:
  • 1/2 yard of each of the four Cotton + Steel Sienna prints featured in the project
  • 1 3/4 yards Pellon SF 101
Binding:
  • (5) strips 2.5â€ x WOF

*Notes: Use a 1/2â€ seam allowance throughout unless otherwise noted. Width of fabric (WOF) is assumed to be 42â€.

Tools needed

  • Ruler
  • Rotary cutter
  • Hera marker
  • Binding clips
  • Pins
  • Disappearing fabric marker/pen
  • Glue basting spray ( I used 505 Spray and Fix by Odif )
  • Walking foot for your sewing machine

Finally, you'll need a set of curtain clips for hanging!

Step 1

Cut out your fabric and Pellon SF 101 pieces according to the chart below.

Main panel front and back:
  • 22â€ wide x 37â€ tall ( youâ€™re cutting these pieces slightly bigger than the soft and stable because when you quilt you lose some of the width and height of the fabric )
Main panel soft and stable:
  • 21â€ wide x 36â€ tall
Top row pockets:
  • (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer
  • (1) 33â€ wide x 7â€ tall piece of Pellon SF 101
Second row pockets:
  • (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer
  • (4) 9â€ wide x 7â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101
  • (1) 33â€ wide x 7â€ tall piece of lining
Third row pockets:
  • (1) 11â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of fabric for the center pocket
  • (2) 10â€ wide x 8â€ tall pieces of fabric for the left and right side pockets
  • (1) 11â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of Pellon SF 101
  • (2) 10â€ wide x 8â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101
  • (1) 29â€ wide x 8â€ tall piece of lining
Fourth row pockets:
  • (2) 14â€ wide x 9â€ tall pieces of each fabric as seen on the wall pocket organizer
  • (2) 14â€ wide x 9â€ tall pieces of Pellon SF 101
  • (1) 27â€ wide x 9â€ tall piece of lining

Step 2

Place your main panel back facing down, Soft and stable on top, and your main panel front facing up. Glue baste the three layers together.

Once the glue is set, quilt the three layers together by sewing straight lines one inch apart or as desired.

Step 3

Take your pocket pieces and corresponding Pellon SF 101 pieces and fuse together with a hot iron by placing the pocket fabric face down and placing the Pellon with the glue side down. Iron.

Step 4

Take the pocket pieces for each row and sew them together with a 1/2â€ seam allowance. You will end up with four long strips. Make sure to press the seams open.

Step 5

Now itâ€™s time to mark the folding lines on your pocket panels! Take your hera marker and make crease marks 3/4â€ away from the seam on both sides on the front side of the fabric.

Mark 1â€ in from each end on the front side of the fabric.

Flip the pocket panel over so that the back side of the pockets are facing up, and mark the following lines.
Make crease marks 1.5â€ away from the seam on both sides.

Mark 1.75â€ in from each end on the back side of the fabric.

Step 6

Following the crease lines made in the above step, go ahead the and fold the fabric and use binding clips to keep them in place. Finger press or use an iron to press to make sharp fold lines.

Step 7

Now that your fabric has the fold lines set, itâ€™s time to sew on the lining. Use a 1/2â€ seam allowance and sew along the top of the pocket panel. Press the lining over and edge stitch on the lining.

Press the lining back and sew 1/2â€ in from the top edge. At this point its good to give the folds a good press again.

Repeat steps 5-7 for the remaining 3 pocket panel strips.

Step 8

Once all the pocket panels have been sewn together, take the bottom row panel and line up the sides and bottom with the main panel. Baste stitch the two sides.

Step 9

Make the folds in the pocket panel and find the space in between two pockets. Pin in place.

Sew up from the bottom edge, to the top and around down to the bottom edge 1/8â€ from the center seam.

Once the pocket sides have been sewn into place, fold the pockets in place and baste stitch the bottom edge.

Repeat steps 8-9 for the remaining three pocket panels. Place the pocket panels 1.25â€ apart.

Step 10

Take your binding strips and sew them together.

And press in half.

Step 11

Take the folded binding strip and line up the raw edges with the raw edge of the pocket panel. Sew in place with a 1/4â€ seam allowance.
Do this on the top three pocket panels.

Next, fold the binding strip down to the sewn line.

Fold the binding strip down one more time.

And sew in place.

Step 12

Take the folded binding strip and sew it to the back side of the main pocket panel, raw edges together. Sew it to one corner, and finish with a 45 degree angle.

Fold the binding strip up,

and down again,

and stitch in place,

This will leave you with a little wing of fabric in the corners that will fold over to the right side.

Once you come to the point where the two ends of the binding strip meet, over lap the ends the width of the binding strip. ( in this case 2.5â€)

Cut off the excess and sew the two ends together at a 45 degree angle.

Continue to sew on the binding strip. Then flip the pocket organizer over facing up.
Sew the binding strip down 1/8â€ from the edge and once you get to a corner, stop and fold over the next side as shown in the photos below.

Step 13

Take your curtain clips and clip the onto the top. I placed mine fit my over the door hanger hooks as you can see here.

And filled it up with some things I had laying around,

There you have it, a super easy and fun wall pocket organizer you can fit a lot of stuff into!

Happy organizing!

posts.markdown:
Welcome to our new Designer Spotlight series on the fabric.com blog! Each month we'll give you a behind the scenes peek into the inspiration behind some of our favorite designer's latest fabric collections, their personal style and even some little known fun facts. We're kicking things off with a bang with a fun Q&A from Justina Blakeney! ####About Justina Blakeney Justina Blakeney is a designer, artist, author of The New York Times best-selling book The New Bohemians and the founder of JungalowÂ®, a blog and brand about decorating wild! With a passion for color, pattern and plants, Justina and JungalowÂ® have quickly become the go-to sources for bohemian design inspiration. As one of the leading design personalities on the web, Justina has over two million followers online and has been named a top designer to follow on Instagram by Harperâ€™s Bazaar, New York magazine and Lonny magazine.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/Headshot%20-%20JB-min.jpg)

Justina's eponymous lifestyle brand, Justina Blakeney Homeâ„¢, includes a wide range of lifestyle and home products including furniture, fabric, case goods, rugs, pillows, wallpaper, bedding and stationery. Justina lives in Los Angeles with her husband Jason, young daughter Ida, kitty Luda and 52 houseplants. ####Q&A In this exclusive Q&A, we had a chance to ask Justina about the inspiration for her latest fabric collection, her personal style, what's coming up next and more! ####When did you realize you had a passion for art and design? Ever since I was a child I was very art and design oriented. I loved to paint, sew and collage. After studying art in college I moved to Italy and began to think about design as a way to make a living using my creative talents. I opened a small boutique for vintage and new-designer clothing and I found that after a few years, I was most excited about the finding vintage objects and furniture for the shop. It was then that I realized my passion for decor and began working on home decor projects. I originally began blogging as a way to do something creative everyday. I loved blogging right away as it was a natural way to combine so many of the things that I love including writing, photography, graphic design, crafting, styling, collaging, curating and decorating. Now, my blog is truly an extension of myself. I blog about all the things that I love--my family, my jungalow, my closet, my obsession will plants and global textiles, wild patterns, thrifted finds and bohemian dwellings.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/Fabric%20Show-min.jpg)

####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/cb-2417_0115_justinaBlakeney_answer1-min-nonumber.png)

####You teamed up with Valdese Weavers to create your line of textiles. What about Valdese made them the perfect partner for this project? Pretty much everything! Valdese weavers weaves the fabric here in the U.S. at their mill in North Carolina so I get to visit the mill and watch the process of my yarns being dyed and my fabrics being woven. I get to work closely with their (AMAZING!) design team and add textures to my patterns that give them so much movement and life. It is a dream collaboration for me because of their wonderful team and extremely sophisticated capabilities. ####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/cb-2417_0115_justinaBlakeney_answer2-min-nonumber.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/IMG_3837-2-%20small-min.jpg)

####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/cb-2417_0115_justinaBlakeney_answer2-min-nonumber.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/IMG_3837-2-%20small-min.jpg)

####If you had to choose one favorite fabric from your entire collection, what would it be, and why? Oh that's so, so hard. I think right now Rainforest is probably my favorite. Seeing that watercolor pattern come alive as a jaquard textile was SO much fun.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/IMG_8869-min.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in home dÃ©cor? Um, PLANTS! Although I don't think of it as a trend--more as a staple. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? For years now, my favorite thing about my job as both a designer and blogger is helping others ignite their own creativity. Seeing people use my fabrics in such creative, fun and beautiful ways really feeds my soul. ####What DIY projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/cb-2417_0115_justinaBlakeney_answer3-min-nonumber.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/Fabric%20Show%202-min.jpg)

####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? I look at designers like Kelly Wearstler and Jonathan Adler, and aspire to build something similar for myself -- a brand that provides both services and beautiful, well made products to the masses. My hope is to help people bring more color, pattern, plants and creativity into their lives and make their lives better (even in my small way) in the process. I also look towards brands like Tom's Shoes and Warby Parker, who have amazing 'social good' components to their businesses and I aspire to that paradigm as well. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? Lots more color, pattern and plants! We've just launched our first kid's collection with Pottery Barn Kids and I'm very focused on growing our online boutique (maybe there's a brick and mortar in our future too? Who knows?)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Justina%20Blakeney%20Designer%20Spotlight/fabric-lifestyle-justina-blakeney-2-min.jpg)

####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? I love to hang out with my daughter, Ida (and my husband too!). Ida started kindergarten this year and we have a lot of fun doing arts and crafts, traveling, cooking and going on bike rides together. ####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. I speak five languages! Click here to shop Justina's full fabric collection on fabric.com!

Ready to get organized in style? These DIY fabric baskets are a quick and easy way to tidy up those tricky rooms in the house where there always seems to be disarray. We targeted a few problem rooms for this project: The laundry room, sewing room and the playroom/kids room. Let's get started!

![Fabric Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Baskets%20v2/DSC_0407-min.jpg)

![Fabric Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Baskets%20v2/IMG_1106-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed We chose a variety of fabrics from Premier Prints for this project. They have really fun designs at a great price point for a project like this where you'll want to create multiples! * 1 yard Premier Prints fabric * 1 yard Pellon fusible fleece * 1 yard of interior fabric (we used Premier Prints 10 oz. Cotton Duck White) * General sewing supplies ####Fabric Choices For our laundry/sewing room baskets, we went with an indigo and white color palette. Shibori fabrics are one of our favorite trends in home decor right now: * Premier Prints Fearless Slub Canvas Regal Navy * STOF France LeQuilt Shibori Dark Blue * Premier Prints Tribal Vintage Indigo

![Fabric Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Baskets%20v2/DSC_1212-min.jpg)

For the kid's room baskets (to store all those pesky toys) we went with fabrics that were a little more whimsy and fun, but still neutral: * Premier Prints Desert Valley Sundown Grey * Premier Prints Mountain High Awendela * Premier Prints Arrow Cool Grey How fun is that mountain print? ![Fabric Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Baskets%20v2/DSC_1214-min.jpg)

####Cutting: * 2 exterior pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 interior pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 fusible interfacing pieces: 18" x 18.5" * 2 straps: 4" x 8" ####Instructions This tutorial is one of our favorites, and once you get the hang of it you can create lots of fabric baskets in a snap! To view the full tutorial by Laura from Trash to Couture with step-by-step instructions, click here.

![Fabric Baskets](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20Baskets%20v2/DSC_1243-min.jpg)

Happy organizing!

Created by: House Homemade Hello and Happy New Year!! Iâ€™m so thankful to be back this year as a guest blogger on fabric.com. If we havenâ€™t â€˜metâ€™ yet, Iâ€™m Jessica. The New Year is all about blank slates and new ventures. People makes goals, make changes, and set out to live a better life every January. After the Christmas dÃ©cor gets put away, I like to organize. I like to thin down on the things we have and get rid of things that donâ€™t get utilized. Something that became a focus to me last year was giving a purpose to every square inch of our home. Itâ€™s important that your house works for you. You should love to spend time in it. We had unused corners and spaces we didnâ€™t fully appreciate because they didnâ€™t really do anything. To fix this, we rethought the use of some of our rooms. My husband and I built a small desk to fill up an empty corner in our living room, this past fall I sold everything in the entryway and built a coat rack to give more function to the space, and last spring we created built ins in the playroom for maximum storage and coziness. So, I created a few mood boards for DIY reading nooks to inspire you in the New Year with what I think are the perfect fabrics to complement each! ####The Modern Boho Book Nook First is a book nook with eclectic style. Now donâ€™t let the term â€œnookâ€ deter you. You can create purpose for any corner of your home. It doesnâ€™t have to be a space secluded from others. Itâ€™s about giving a function to an area of your house. A nook for reading, coffee drinking, Pinterest browsing, or all the above really just needs a few things: good lighting, cozy seating, throw pillows, a rug, maybe some art and (of course) books!

Using beautiful fabrics in curtains, for throw pillows and as the pendant would give it so much texture and warmth. For this farmhouse-inspired nook, I included my DIY embroidery hoop pendant light. posts.title: Envelope Pocket Quilt Block
posts.markdown:
Fall in love with this charming quilt block â€“ an envelope you can fill with valentines, sweet treats and special keepsakes. This project is perfect for seasonal dÃ©cor, full quilts and wall hangings. You can even change up your fabric choices for office or sewing room decor! Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed: * 2 coordinating fat quarters of Valentine's themed fabric for the envelope and background (we used Art Gallery Paperie Happily Ever After and Kona Cotton Silver ). * Coordinating Quilting Thread (we used Aurifil 50wt Aluminium) * Frixion Marking Pen * Rotary Cutter * Cutting Mat * Square Ruler * Long ruler

![Envelope Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Envelope%20Quilt%20Block/supplies-min.PNG)

####Cutting: Main Color (MC) (1) 12.5â€ x 12.5â€ Contrasting Color (CC) (2) 3.5â€ x 6.5â€ (envelope bottom) (3) 3.5â€ x 7.5â€ (envelope top)

![Envelope Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Envelope%20Quilt%20Block/bg_cutting-min.PNG)

![Envelope Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Envelope%20Quilt%20Block/envelope_cutting-min.PNG)

####Instructions Be sure to watch the video above for step by step instructions for creating this quilt block! #####Envelope Top: With the two 3.5â€ x 7.5â€ pieces placed on top of each other, make your triangle by maarking the middle of the top of this rectangle, Â¼â€ from top. Using a ruler and marking pen, mark a line from the bottom right corner to that mark, repeat for the bottom left corner. Using these lines as a guide, and using a Â¼â€ seam allowance on the long edge, sew your triangle all the way around, leaving a gap on the long edge for turning. Trim around your shape, clipping the corners for sharp points. Topstitch using a longer stitch length about 1/8 inch from the edge. This will also close the space you left to turn your triangle. Your envelope top is complete! #####Envelope bottom: With the two 3.5â€ x 6.5â€ pieces placed on top of each other, sew all the way around, leaving a space to turn on one long edge. Turn your rectangle inside out after trimming the corner for sharp points. Topstitch as before, using a longer stitch length, this will close your opening that you left for turning. #####Envelope Placement: This depends on personal preference, but to make your finished block, Place the envelope bottom on your background square, centered but a little bit down from middle. This was about 3.5â€ from each side for us, and 4.5â€ from the top and bottom. It doesnâ€™t have to be perfect! Sew your envelope on the background fabric, leaving the top open, and locking at the beginning and end. Place your triangle over the envelope bottom, about Â½â€ â€“ Â¾â€ above it. Sew this down onto the background fabric, locking your stitches at the beginning and end, careful not to cover the pocket.

![Envelope Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Envelope%20Quilt%20Block/finished_open-min.PNG)

There you have it â€“ an adorable envelope block perfect for your Valentine.

![Envelope Block](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Envelope%20Quilt%20Block/CB-2462_blog_pocketQuilt_img.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Elastic Waistbands
posts.markdown:
Sewing elastic waistbands can be as easy as wearing them! Follow these 3 techniques to learn the basics. *Tip: Use a universal ballpoint machine needle for sewing through elastic. ####1) Self-waistband

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/self%20waistband%20done-min.JPG)

#####For this example, we used a serger and these supplies:

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/skus_1.jpg)

* Stretch Jersey Knit Solid Bright Coral * Knit Elastic 1/2"X 3 yd-White Whether youâ€™re sewing with a serger or a standard sewing machine, an elastic waistband can be easily sewn on using the existing fabric in your project for professional results. When using a standard sewing machine, use a zig zag stitch for best results. The 2 key points to make this waistband method successful is making sure the fabric waist portion of your project allows for the width of the elastic in order to do so, and an effective top stitch. Once the elastic is applied, simply fold it under and top stitch. When top stitching, choose a zig zag stitch on a standard machine, or a coverstitch or chainstitch on a serger. Stretching the waistband as you topstitch allows for the topstitch to be able to complement the stretch performance.

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/self%20elastic%20sewn%20on-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/self%20top%20stitch-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/self%20underside-min.JPG)

####2) Separate Waistband, Sewn-in: #####For this example, we used a standard sewing machine, and the following supplies:

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/skus_2.jpg)

* Kaufman Burly Beavers Flannel Collage Iron * Yarn Dyed Flannel Check Red Black * Heavy Stretch Waistband Elastic 1-1/2"X1-1/4yd-White The elastic is sewn onto the seam allowance of the main fabric and separate waistband fabric. It is then fully enclosed with the remaining waist fabric being folded over, and then secured with a stitch in the ditch.

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/beaver%20pin%20elastic-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/beaver%20stitching%20elastic-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/beaver%20waistband%20layer-min.JPG)

â€œStitch in the ditchâ€ refers to sewing a top stitch in the crevice between 2 fabrics. This technique is effective for creating a seamless transition between fabrics, while securing fabric on the underside.

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/beaver%20stitch%20in%20the%20ditch-min.JPG)

####3) Elastic Casing Waistband Making a casing is an easy way to accomplish an elastic waistband. It doesnâ€™t require any stretching while sewing, or sewing through the elastic itself (other than joining the elastic).

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20done-min.JPG)

Making a casing can be done with the self-fabric, or by attaching a separate piece of fabric for the waistband. Using the self-waistband method, you would simply fold the fabric under, the width of the elastic + seam allowance. Top stitch to secure, leaving an opening to thread the elastic thru. Once the elastic is joined, top stitch to close. #####For this example, we used a serger and these supplies:

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/skus_3.jpg)

* Art Gallery Wonderful Things Jersey Knit Aquarelle Study Tint * Stretch Jersey Knit Solid Bright Coral * 1'' White Flat No-Roll Elastic The key to making a casing, is exact measurements. If the waistband casing is too small, the elastic will not lay properly. If the casing is too big, it risks too much movement for the elastic.

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20elastic%20formula-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20waist%20pinned-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20leave%20opening-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20guide%20thru-min.JPG)

A good way to counteract any unwanted movement from the waistband, is to use no-roll elastic, also known as woven elastic. Itâ€™s more stable than knitted or braided elastic. It does require the butted method to join, since it is too dense to overlap and sew nicely.

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20butted%20elastic-min.JPG)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/casing%20sew%20opening-min.JPG)

(picture waistbands done)

![Elastic Waistbands](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Elastic%20Waistbands/waistbands%20done-min.JPG)

Happy Sewing!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Sarah Marrone Finished Size: 50"x62" Itâ€™s that time of year when candy dishes are filled with conversation hearts- the perfect candies to show that special someone how youâ€™re feeling and also the perfect inspiration for a fun Valentineâ€™s Day quilt. This Be Mine quilt is a fun throw size quilt to make, and using Cotton + Steelâ€™s Ombre Pigment fabric is a great way to create an ombre effect with the hearts. This is also the time to break out or build up your stash of black and white quilting cotton. You can also use solid fabric for the background, but the scrappiness of the black and white fabric is a lot of fun.

![Be Mine Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Be%20Mine%20Quilt/cb-2508_bemine_full-min.jpg)

![Be Mine Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Be%20Mine%20Quilt/IMG_20180129_112634_social-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 4 yds. of black and white quilting cotton for hearts and text * 2 yds. of quilting cotton for background, including sashing and borders (we used Cotton + Steelâ€™s Ombre Pigment Peony) We chose these black and white fabrics: Riley Blake Swiss & Dots Black Mini Pearl Bracelets Licorice Pixie Square Dot White Susybee Gwyn the Penguin Dot * Â½ yd. of quilting cotton for binding * 3 Â½ yds.of quilting cotton for backing * Batting ####Pattern Download Click here to download the Be Mine Quilt free pattern!

![Be Mine Quilt](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Be%20Mine%20Quilt/cb-2508_bemine_closeup-min.jpg)

All instructions are included in the pattern, and you may have noticed that there is a Y-seam in the Heart pattern. Itâ€™s not my favorite, but I promise it is worth it! By having the Y-seam, the Heart is one piece of fabric, meaning there is tons of fussy cutting potential, itâ€™s perfect for showcasing large scale patterns and in this example you get a seamless ombre! This pattern can be adjusted as needed. More Heart blocks can be added to create a larger quilt, or widen the border. If time is tight, create a table runner by placing a Heart block before and after the â€˜Be Mineâ€™, and you have an adorable Valentineâ€™s Day decoration. Happy sewing!

Sewing a button is as fundamental as it gets when it comes to sewing. Whether youâ€™re sewing buttons on a new creation, or repairing a popped button on a beloved garment, sewing a button is a vital hand sewing skill that everyone should know! ####Supplies Needed:

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/supply%20shot-min.JPG)

* fabricThread â€“ mercerized cotton or general purpose thread is best. Double up for efficient button stitches! * Needle â€“ Sharps hand needles, size 9 average works well. In addition to your basic needle and thread, thereâ€™s a few optional, yet very helpful, tools: * Beeswax â€“ a thread strengthener and detangler. Sewing a button is best with doubled thread, and beeswax helps detangle the 2 threads. It also adds strength to the thread, something needed to keep the button on. * Thimble â€“ a thimble is â€œhandyâ€ for sewing by hand, it helps protect your finger, and helps push the needle through. * Needle Threader â€“ threading a needle can be a challenge in itself, having a needle threader can expedite the process. * Disappearing Ink fabric marking pen â€“ marking where the button goes is paramount, this ink will disappear with time, heat or water. * Toothpick â€“ a toothpick serves as spacer between the button and the fabric when making a thread shank. You could also use a machine needle, just watch out for the point! Now let's talk about 3 basic techniques for sewing buttons by hand for effective, professional results! The above video will walk you through each one of these techniques in detail. Be sure to save this video for when you get in a pinch! ####4-Hole Button Creating a thread shank is highly recommended for 4-hole buttons. Shirt buttons are predominantly 4-hole buttons and when examining a professionally made shirt, a 4-hole button with a shank is standard. The thread shank allows for the thickness of the joining fabric, so when buttoned, both fabrics will lay flat. The thread shank also joins 4 sets of button thread stitches on the underside of the button, cinching them together so that they fit properly within the buttonhole.

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/4hole%20side%20by%20side-min.JPG)

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/thread%20shank-min.JPG)

For the 2-hole and 4-hole button examples, we used Kaufman Chambray 4.5 Oz Washed Light Indigo and Dress it up Buttons. ####2-Hole Button Simply stitching in and out joining the button to the fabric will create a stable button, flush with the fabric. Itâ€™s best used when the joining fabric isnâ€™t very thick, the button wonâ€™t be heavily used, or for decorative buttons. Sewing a 2-hole button doesnâ€™t necessarily require a thread shank.

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/2hole-min.JPG)

####Shank Button Sewing a shank button is as easy as stitching in and out. The key here is the direction of the shank, making sure itâ€™s the same orientation as the button hole for a proper fit. Shank buttons are common with coats and jackets. Depending on the thickness of the fabric, a shank button might require an additional thread shank, so the joining fabric doesnâ€™t pucker.

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/shank-min.JPG)

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/shank%20done-min.JPG)

For this example, we used Riley Blake Wool Melton in Orange and 3/4" Faux Leather Shank buttons.

![Sewing a Button](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Sewing%20a%20Button/CB-2496_blog_button_img-min.jpg)

Happy sewing buttons!

posts.title: Children's Spring Apparel DIYs
posts.markdown:
Created by: Sweet Red Poppy Hi, It's Kimberly from Sweet Red Poppy. I'm so excited to be sharing some Spring sewing inspiration with you today! I fell in love with this Michael Miller Sommer fabric collection the minute it released and I'm thrilled with how these outfits turned out.

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_5954.jpg)

SOMMER, the Scandinavian word for Summer, is a collection of designs inspired by fabric designer Sarah Jane's Scandinavian heritage. In this sweet collection of fabric, you'll find bicycles, blooming tulips, adorable bunnies, swans, and children flying kites. It's the perfect collection of fabric to welcome the warmer months of Spring.

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6020.jpg)

####Fabric Choices Here's a list of the fabric's I used for my children's Spring outfits this year: Painted Gingham Bloom Painted Gingham Blueberry Garden Blueberry Garden Bloom

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6544-2.jpg)

You can view the entire fabric collection here or browse fabric.com's entire selection of Spring themed fabric here. I chose to sew the dresses for my girls with a combination of the gingham and garden bloom prints. The hand painted gingham is brimming with character and practically begs to be sewn into a dress!

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6018.jpg)

My girls fell in love with the Garden Bloom print which features tulips, bunnies and birds. I combined a dark and a light print to really give each dress a pop of color. ####Patterns I used the Olive Ann Penelope Dress Pattern for my girl's dresses. This sweet little pattern features a scooped back, a beautiful bow, ruffled neckline and a shaped skirt. It even comes with a matching doll pattern!

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6059.jpg)

The only changes I made to the pattern was to omit the pockets ( I felt like it would take away from the print) and to lessen the seam allowance of the bias tape making it a bit smaller. I sewed a size 2 with a shortened skirt and a size 3 with a size 4 skirt. Isn't that scooped back just the sweetest?

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6032.jpg)

For my son, I used McCall's Tie, Vest, Shirt & Shorts Pattern The tie is incredibly easy to sew and has a Velcro closure for safety.

![Spring Dresses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dresses/IMG_6029.jpg)

I hope you enjoyed this Spring sewing inspiration. Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Sewing 101: 4 Half Square Triangle (HST) Methods
posts.markdown:
The HST, or Half Square Triangle, is an essential building block used in many traditional quilt designs. We love to make a bunch and have fun arranging them in our favorite designs! This Sewing 101 is perfect for both traditional and modern quilters â€“ and instructions are given for 5â€ finished squares. Of course we couldn't resist using the Kona Cotton Color of the Year, Tiger Lily for this video tutorial. We cannot get enough of this color! ####Supplies Needed: * 2 quilting fabrics of your choice. Traditionally you would choose one printed fabric or a solid color, and one white or neutral fabric. We used Kona Cotton Tiger Lily 2018 Color of the Year paired with Kona Cotton Snow * Rotary Cutter * Acrylic Rulers (6.5" square size and a longer ruler for marking) * Marking Pen * Cutting Mat * Thread

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/supplies.PNG)

####Method 1: Traditional Method/2 HSTâ€™s This method is perfect if youâ€™re working with scraps and donâ€™t have large pieces to try the methods that make more. Each square makes two HSTâ€™s.

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/2_at_a_time.PNG)

#####Cutting Cut (1) 6â€ square from each fabric. #####Sewing Mark a diagonal line with your marking pen on one fabric square (it can even be a permanent pen or pencil, this line wonâ€™t show on your finished blocks. With your two squares placed on top of each other, sew a scant Â¼â€ on each side, remember to backstitch! Cut in between these two sewn lines. Press towards the darker fabric. Trim if needed. ####Method 2: Four at a Time HSTâ€™s This method is great because you donâ€™t have to draw any lines at all, which is perfect for a Â¼ yard piece of fabric! Youâ€™ll be able to get 16 5â€ square out of an 8.5â€ strip cut into 4 8.5â€ squares.

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/4_at_a_time.PNG)

####Cutting Cut (1) 8.5â€ square from each fabric. #####Sewing Placing one square on the other, sew along the edges at Â¼â€, pivoting at the corners. Cut in an X formation, corner to corner. Press towards the darker fabric â€“ now you have 4 HSTâ€™s! ####Method 3: 8 at a Time HSTâ€™s This method is great for yardage, and itâ€™s super easy to cut if you have a 12.5â€ square ruler.

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/8_at_a_time.PNG)

#####Cutting Cut (1) 12.5â€ square out of 2 fabrics. #####Sewing Place one fabric on top of the other. Mark diagonal lines in an X formation. Sew at a scant Â¼â€ on either side of your marked lines. Make sure your fabric stays in place and doesnâ€™t bunch when you sew over existing lines. Cut your fabric in a cross formation, even in the middle on all sides. Then, cut between seams. Press your triangles towards the darker fabric. Trim if necessary. Now you have 8 HSTâ€™s. ####Method 4: Strip HSTâ€™s This method is great if you have an eighth of a yard, a quarter of a yard, or even jelly rolls for itty bitty HSTâ€™s. This one is tricky and takes some very precise cutting.

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/strip_method.PNG)

#####Cutting Cut (1) 4.5â€ strip of each fabric by however long you want. If you want a lot, cut by WOF (Width of Fabric). #####Sewing Sew your two strips along the long edges at Â¼â€ seam allowance. Using your square ruler, place your ruler as demonstrated in the video. The tip of the square should just touch the top seam. Cut on each side. For the next HST, you will flip your ruler so the point is in the opposite direction, but will only have to cut one side. Keep cutting until you run out of strip to cut from.

![HSTs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20HSTs/CB-2471_blog_hst_img2.jpg)

Happy HST making!

posts.title: Designer Spotlight: Lori Holt
posts.markdown:
Get to know Riley Blake Designs designer and lover of all things quilting, Lori Holt, in today's Designer Spotlight! You'll find out about her farm girl roots, how she started designing, details on her latest fabric collections and what's coming up next!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/cb-2500_loriHolt_projects.jpg)

####About Lori Iâ€™m a small town farm girl who spent her childhood playing in the sunshine on tractors and climbing trees. I grew up happily immersed in all things domestic. Iâ€™m the middle child of a large family and live closely surrounded by grandparents, uncles, aunts and cousins. My mom says that I was practically born with a needle in my hand. My earliest memories are of sitting underneath the quilting frames and threading needles for my grandma and great aunts until I eventually grew old enough to make stitches of my own. As a girl, I spent many happy hours designing and sewing clothes for my dolls, crocheting and doing embroidery. My deep love of all needle art comes from the early influence of my mother and grandmothers, who were my first teachers. Now I teach others to create and I find joy in using my creativity to make beautiful things. I am drawn to stacks of colorful fabrics, pretty papers, aprons, buttons, embroidery, old dishes, gingham and polka dots, sprinkles and glitter and all things vintage. I am married to my best friend and childhood sweetheart and together we have 3 creative, intelligent children, and a new baby granddaughter. Life is good! I sew, draw, create, decorate and re-decorate on a daily basis. I think of myself as the luckiest girl in the world, because I get to do what I love everyday. I feel blessed to have my own company called, â€œBee in my Bonnet,â€ which I began in 1994. My wish is that my designs in both patterns and fabric, will inspire others to create and will also instill the desire to pass down the valuable lessons of days gone by taught to us by our mothers and grandmothers. ####Q&A #####When did you realize you had a passion for design? I knew I had a passion for design when I was a girl. My mom taught my 3 older sisters and I how to sew, and as we were following patterns I often found myself changing them up. My mom and my grandma were free with their fabrics and suppliesâ€¦allowing me to create whatever my heart desired. #####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/cb-2500_loriHolt_answer1.png)

#####Your newest collection, Bake Sale 2, is now available on fabric.com! What was the inspiration behind this collection?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/cb-2500_loriHolt_answer2.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/IMG_4986.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/IMG_6047.jpg)

Click here to shop Bake Sale 2! #####You partnered with Riley Blake to launch your line of fabrics. What made them the perfect partner for you? I love working with Riley Blake Designs! I feel that they are the perfect partner for me because they understand the vision that I have for each of my fabric collections. They support me every step the way. #####What are your current favorite trends in sewing / quilting?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/cb-2500_loriHolt_answer3.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/FullSizeRender.jpg)

#####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric or seeing customers creating with your fabric? I especially love working with my happy prints and colors. When I hear others describe my fabric and designs in the same way, I feel so grateful to be a part of their creative world!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/IMG_6046.jpg)

#####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? I am currently rekindling my love affair with crochet and cross stitch. I am having fun mixing both with fabric and quilting to create fun new projects. #####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? Iâ€™m currently working on my next bookâ€¦along with brand new notions...and of course a new fabric collection!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lori%20Holt/IMG_5111.jpg)

#####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? During my free time I love to relax and enjoy the simple things with my family and friends. Gardening and camping are two of my favorites. #####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. One thing people may not know about me is that I am a true blue music lover and was a singer in a band for 3 years! Want to see all of Lori Holt's amazing fabrics and notions? Click here to shop!

Trim the edges of the quilt sandwich so they are all even.

posts.title: Sewing 101: Seam Basics Part 1 (Woven Fabrics)
posts.markdown:
Seam construction can make or break a sewing project. We want to make sure your creations last a lifetime, so weâ€™re kicking off a 2-part Sewing 101 all about seams. First we will go over basic seams for woven fabrics, and in the second installment we will cover all things knits! ####Plain Seam The most basic of all seams, a plain seam is simply a straight stitch joining multiple pieces of fabric. Your fabric and project will determine the needle, stitch length, and tension setting on the sewing machine. For this example, we used Red Cotton Twill fabric.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/plain%20seam.JPG)

You can use Universal (Regular Point) needles for woven fabrics. Their sharp point penetrates the fabric as it sews. Hereâ€™s a quick needle guide for size: #####Needle Guide Very Lightweight or Sheer Wovens: 70/09 Lightweight Wovens: 80/11 Medium Weight Wovens: 90/14 Heavyweight Wovens: 100/16 Very Heavyweight Wovens: 100/18 Upon creating a plain seam, most likely a seam finish is required. A seam finish secures the seam allowance fabric so that it doesnâ€™t fray or unravel. Tip: You could choose to finish the edges before sewing the fabrics together, or after the seam is created. For beginner apparel sewing, we recommend finishing the edges prior to sewing a plain seam. For removable pillow covers, finishing the edges prior to sewing is easier because many home dÃ©cor fabrics are easily frayed. Mostly, seam finishing in home dÃ©cor sewing is not required at all since the fabric edge will never be disturbed or seen, such as upholstery sewing. #####Zig Zag Seam Finish The Zig Zag seam finish can be done on a standard machine. Zig zag stitch each seam allowance piece (or both joined together) and trim any excess fabric. Tip: When trimming, avoid cutting the zig zag stitching.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/Zig%20zag%20finish.JPG)

#####Overedge Zig Zag Seam Finish This method cannot be used on very lightweight fabric, because it requires the right points of the zig zag stitch to go outside of the fabric. This is a very effective finishing method if a serger cannot be used.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/Overegde%20zig%20zag%20finish.JPG)

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/Overedge%20in%20action.JPG)

#####Overedge Stitch on a Serger This stitch can be done with or without the straight stitch (or chain stitch) depending on what kind of serger it is. A 5-thread serger can sew a plain seam, trim any excess, and finish the seam edge all in one step. These machines can be quite an investment, but it can save lots of time and give professional results from home.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/Serger%20overedge%20finish.JPG)

#####Stitch and Pink Seam Finish A classic seam finish, simply straight stitch each seam allowance piece, then trim the excess with pinking shears or a pinking rotary blade. A pinked edge will not unravel, but may fray slightly over time.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/Stitch%20and%20Pink%20edge%20finish.JPG)

Time saving tip: depending on the project, you could skip the additional straight stitch step, and just trim the excess seam allowance fabric with pinking shears. ####Flat Felled Seam The flat felled seam is an ultra-secure, flat, and somewhat decorative seam most commonly used in jeans and pants construction. A combination of 2 visible stitches, this seam is fully enclosed. For this example, we used Cotton Yarn Dye Chambray Denim Blue Fabric.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/flat%20felled%20seam.JPG)

#####Step 1 Sew wrong sides together 5/8â€ seam allowance.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/flat%20fell%20step%201.JPG)

#####Step 2 Trim one side to 1/8â€.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/flat%20fell%20step%202.JPG)

#####Step 3 Fold remaining 5/8â€ side under and over the trimmed 1/8â€ side, and top stitch.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/flat%20fell%20step%203.JPG)

####French Seam French seams are ideal for delicate, sheer, or very lightweight fabric such as chiffon or crepe. A combination of 2 stitches, this seam is fully enclosed. For this example, we used Telio Misora Crepe Fabric in Seafoam.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/French%20seam.JPG)

#####Step 1 Sew wrong sides together 3/8â€.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/french%20step%201.JPG)

#####Step 2 Trim seam allowance to 1/8â€.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/french%20step%202.JPG)

#####Step 3 Turn fabric right sides together making the seam along the fold, press if needed, and sew Â¼â€ seam allowance.

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/french%20step%203.JPG)

Happy sewing!

![Seam Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt.%201%20Wovens/CB-2497_blog_seam1_img3.jpg)

We will see you next time for part 2 of seam basics on knit fabrics.
