posts.title: Bedroom Refresh: Fabric Wrapped Side Table
posts.markdown:
Created by: Lindsey Crafter Hey everyone! Lindsey Crafter here, Iâ€™m excited to jump on with fabric.com to share a fun DIY project along with a few other ways you can refresh your bedroom this Spring. I love using fabric for more than just sewing projects - so Iâ€™m going to show you how to wrap a generic side table with fabric to create a luxe upholstered bedside table! Style your bed with a few new shams and throw pillows and your space can feel fun and refreshed in just an afternoon!

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8542_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/table_before-min.jpg)

Now letâ€™s get started! ####Supplies Needed Hereâ€™s what youâ€™ll need for this project:

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/things_you_need-min.jpg)

* 2 Yards printed fabric (adjust to suit your size of side table)- we used Premier Prints Twill Devada Canal * Spray Adhesive * Straight Edge or Ruler * Staple Gun with Staples * Fabric Scissors * Iron and Ironing Board * Square White Side Table ####Instructions I chose Premier Prints Twill Devada Canal- a medium weight printed fabric with an trendy print. Be sure the fabric you choose isnâ€™t too transparent or has a pile or nap. Iron your fabric to press out any creases or wrinkles before cutting out pieces for your project.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8443_fabric_weight-min.jpg)

Spray adhesive is ideal for this project because it ensures even coverage over the whole surface of the table without bleeding through in certain spots like regular glues. Be sure youâ€™re working in a well ventilated area and protect your work surfaces and clothing from overspray. Test a small swatch of fabric for color fastness and bleeding. I actually switched adhesives mid-project because my first choice seeped through the fabric and was staining the test swatch yellow!

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8449_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8454Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Donâ€™t worry about assembling your table! Weâ€™ll be wrapping the legs individually first. Be sure to cut out fabric for each leg in the same direction so that they all match! Cut out a rectangle with fabric scissors to cover all four sides of the leg. Allow for at least a Â½â€ folded overlap at the seam and a Â½â€ folded edge at the top and bottom of the leg.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8457Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Press a Â½â€ fold along the vertical length of the fabric with an iron before applying the fabric to the table leg. After spraying the leg with glue, apply the folded edge about a Â¼â€ from the corner edge. Press down while the glue sets. Take care to keep the folded edge flush with the top and bottom ends of the table leg. Apply glue to each side and wrap the table leg with the remaining fabric.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8461Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8463Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Fold and press the remaining overlap to create a sharp crease and apply adhesive to the underside of the flap. Press down firmly to adhere it to the leg. Set aside so the glue has a chance to set and wrap the remaining legs using the same steps.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8469_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8471_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Measure and cut out a square of fabric to cover the bottom of the table and add an extra Â½â€ on each side to create an overhang. Apply Glue to the unfinished bottom of the side table and smooth down the fabric maintaining the Â½â€ overhang on all sides. After gluing down all four sides of the overhang, snip each corner and overlap the extra fabric to create a sharp corner before gluing down. When covering the top of the table this overlap will ensure there wonâ€™t be a seam where the table finish is exposed.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8472_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8478_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

The final piece of fabric you cut will be the largest and will cover the top of the table. It should be long enough on two opposite ends to and fold in Â½â€ along the bottom edge of the table, and 4-5â€ inches extra length on the two remaining opposite ends so that creased corner tabs can be created and stapled underneath the table. Apply glue to the entire surface of the table and smooth down the fabric so that there are no wrinkles.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8476_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Flip the table back upside down and fold up the shorter ends folding in the extra fabric to create a seam at the bottom edge of the table. Press with an iron to create a sharp edge. Secure the fabric with adhesive and repeat on the remaining side.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8487_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8488_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Fold the remaining excess fabric just like if you were wrapping a present. Grab a corner and pull it inward along the top edge, creating a right triangle. Use a quick spray of adhesive to keep it in place. Repeat with the other side. Spray the wrong side of the fabric with glue and pull the tab tightly over the table edge and press onto the underside of the side table. Keep the tab tightly in place with staples along the folded edge.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8495_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8496Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Place staples at the top and bottom of each leg to reinforce the fold at the seam before re-assembling the table and styling in your bedroom!

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8541_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

This is a great way to update your room on a budget. I even picked out a few more fresh fabrics to make some fresh throw pillows. I used two different linens to make two-toned shams with flanges so I can switch up my look whenever I want! Natural fringe trim quickly elevates a lightweight cotton print that makes a snazzy statement pillow.

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8558-min.jpg)

#####Here's what I used to create the pillows: Michael Miller Indian Summer Ginger Blossom Linen Blend Sunrise Seafoam Rayon Linen Blend Blue Fringe Trim 20"x20" Pillow Form 12"x20" Pillow Form

![Bedroom Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bedroom%20Refresh%20Fabric%20Wrapped%20Side%20Table/IMG_8565_Lindsey_Crafter-min.jpg)

Ready for a refresh? Shop fabric.com's collection of cotton prints and solid linens to get started!

When covering the top of the table this overlap will ensure there wonâ€™t be a seam where the table finish is exposed.

The final piece of fabric you cut will be the largest and will cover the top of the table. It should be long enough on two opposite ends to and fold in Â½â€ along the bottom edge of the table, and 4-5â€ inches extra length on the two remaining opposite ends so that creased corner tabs can be created and stapled underneath the table. Apply glue to the entire surface of the table and smooth down the fabric so that there are no wrinkles.

Flip the table back upside down and fold up the shorter ends folding in the extra fabric to create a seam at the bottom edge of the table. Press with an iron to create a sharp edge. Secure the fabric with adhesive and repeat on the remaining side.

Fold the remaining excess fabric just like if you were wrapping a present. Grab a corner and pull it inward along the top edge, creating a right triangle. Use a quick spray of adhesive to keep it in place. Repeat with the other side. Spray the wrong side of the fabric with glue and pull the tab tightly over the table edge and press onto the underside of the side table. Keep the tab tightly in place with staples along the folded edge.

Place staples at the top and bottom of each leg to reinforce the fold at the seam before re-assembling the table and styling in your bedroom!

This is a great way to update your room on a budget. I even picked out a few more fresh fabrics to make some fresh throw pillows. I used two different linens to make two-toned shams with flanges so I can switch up my look whenever I want! Natural fringe trim quickly elevates a lightweight cotton print that makes a snazzy statement pillow.

posts.title: Sewing 101: Seam Basics Part 2 (Knit Fabrics)
posts.markdown:
Welcome to part 2 of our Seam Basics series! If you missed part 1 of the series on woven fabrics, you can check it out here. Today weâ€™ll be covering all things Knit seams. Knit fabrics can be intimidating â€“ but fear not â€“ this sewing 101 will give you the tools and confidence you need to succeed! ####First, you need the right tools #####Walking Foot A walking foot attachment for a regular sewing machine eliminates any distortion the knit fabrics may experience while being sewn. It makes for a much cleaner seam, better seam performance, and an enjoyable experience! #####Universal Ball Point Needles Universal ball point needles are generic machine needles that can be used on most knits. Stretch or Jersey Knit needles may also be appropriate depending on what kind of knit fabric youâ€™re working with. Stretch needles have a longer scarf (better for knits with more than 5% Lycra Spandex). Jersey knit needles have an even more round point than Universal ball points do. For more information on machines and needles, check out this blog post.

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/CB-2498_blog_seam2_img2.jpg)

####What you need to know about knits Knit Fabrics are made up of interlocking loops of fine yarns. The rounded point of a machine needle glides through the fibers rather than penetrating them, preserving fabric quality. Knits can have mechanical stretch and/or Lycra Spandex generated stretch. Mechanical stretch refers to the natural give that the interlocking loops experience when being pulled. The looser the loops have been knitted, the stretchier the fabric will be. Lycra Spandex stretch refers to the incorporation of 1-20% Lycra Spandex fiber that has been added to the primary fiber contents. This gives any fabric stretch, and makes knits extra stretchy since they already have mechanical stretch by nature. For more information on stretch, check out this blog post and watch this video. ####Stitch options #####Zig Zag Stitch This is a very basic stitch that joins knit fabric, and accounts for lengthwise (vertical) stretch. Simply trimming any excess fabric from the seam allowance will reduce bulk. This stitch is not ideal for tight, form fitting knit garments â€“ because the fabric can pucker through the zig zags when heavily stretched on the crosswise (horizontal) grain.

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/zig%20zag.JPG)

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/trim%20zig%20zag.JPG)

#####Shallow Zig Zag Stitch Also called â€œnarrow zig zagâ€ - this stitch resembles a straight stitch, while still accounting for some stretch. The fabric will not pucker through the seam stitch. This seam is great for knits that will not be stretched vertically, since it can be slightly limiting to lengthwise stretch. For the zig zag stitch examples, we used Kaufman Laguna Jersey Knit in Pink.

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/shallow%20zig%20zag.JPG)

#####Stretch Stitch This straight stitch is made possible by switching your machines settings to â€œstretchâ€. It has the appearance and function of a straight stitch, but each stitch is actually made up of 3 lightning bolt style stitches. This accounts for stretch vertically and horizontally, making it a great stitch for knits. Two downsides to this stitch is that it takes a bit of extra time to sew, and it is almost impossible to remove if the seam without damaging the fabric, should the seam need to be undone for any reason. For this example, we used Riley Blake Jersey Knit in Hot Pink.

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/machine%20stretch%20setting.JPG)

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/stretch%20stitch.JPG)

#####4-Thread Overedge Stitch This seam is the most common for professionally made knit garments. This seam can be done on a 4 or 5-thread serger. Sergers have an adjustable â€œdifferential feedâ€ function that beautifully sew knits or any other fabrics that have a tendency to distort under pressure. For this example, we used Fabric Merchants Stretch Cotton Jersey Knit in Bright Coral.

![Seam Basics Pt 2 Knits](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%20Seam%20Basics%20Pt%202%20Knits/serger.JPG)

Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Sewing with African Wax Fabric
posts.markdown:
Created by: @marcyharriell from Oonabaloona Hey there fabric lovers! Marcy of oonaballoona here, ready to enable your new African Wax Print obsession. Because once you startâ€¦ you wonâ€™t stop! This fabric has long been a favorite of mine, largely due to its colorful nature and wonderful patterns. It has an interesting history, originating in Holland, intended as a knockoff of Indonesian Batik print. The Indonesian market didnâ€™t respond to the brighter, graphic designs of wax print, but it found a delighted reception in Africa. Therefore, you might hear it called Dutch Wax Print, African Wax Print, or Ankara.

![African Wax Print](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/African%20Wax%20Dress/0555917.jpg)

Wax print is 48â€ wide, but, you get a whopping six yards in every cut. SIX. YARDS. So the possibilities in a single cut are fairly endless! Iâ€™ve actually made two garments from this single cutâ€” one is a maxi skirt awaiting a waistband, and the other is this little yellow wrap dress of sunshine, a modified @McCalls 7246. And I still have decent sized remnants left!

![African Wax Print](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/African%20Wax%20Dress/0538175.jpg)

Here are my tips for working with African Wax Print fabric, in no particular order: ####Choose a simple pattern Choose a simple pattern for your first foray, something that wonâ€™t break up the print too much. As you get deeper into this obsession, itâ€™s loads of fun to choose patterns with lots of pieces, to incorporate all the scraps youâ€™ll accumulate (like I said, six yards in a cut)! For example, Iâ€™ve used scraps from another garment to face my hem. ####Embrace the print Even with careful planning, youâ€™re likely to get a circle, bird, or what-have you highlighting a place you didn't intend. Consider this when placing your pattern, but when working with a repeating print like this, itâ€™s bound to highlight an area anyway!

![African Wax Print](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/African%20Wax%20Dress/P1040368-min.jpg)

####Remove your stickers with care Authentic wax print comes with a sticky label. Place your pressing cloth over the label, and use a hot iron to melt the glue. Then, you can easily pull the label off. ####Use both sides Another great thing about wax print is the wrong sideâ€” as you can see in the photo detailing the faced hem, the colors are almost as vibrant on the wrong side as the right side. If youâ€™re working with a print that involves symbols, as many wax prints do, you can flip over to the reverse to get a mirror image. ####To wash, or not to wash? Itâ€™s your call! Wax print comes, as the title suggests, with wax embedded in the fabric. This gives it a crisp, stiff drape, great for structural styles that need shape. If you want to take advantage of the wax, itâ€™ll need to be a â€œdry clean onlyâ€ garment. If youâ€™d like a softer cotton, simply give it a pre-wash, and itâ€™ll soften right up (I like to wash on cold and dry on low heat, as thatâ€™s how I treat most of my handmade items). ####Go against the grain The skirt of this dress was cut on the crossgrain. Iâ€™ve made many wax garments cut on the crossgrainâ€” just be sure youâ€™re thinking about the stress you might put on the garment. You wouldnâ€™t want to make a pencil skirt on the crossgrain, thatâ€™d be too much stress for the crossgrain! Here, the bodice of the dress, which takes more stress than the loose, wide skirt, is cut on the lengthwise grain. Lastly, HAVE FUN. Though really, when playing with these candy colors, what other choice do you have?

![African Wax Print](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/African%20Wax%20Dress/P1040355-min.jpg)

Happy sewing!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Erin Sobon (Sewbon.com) Spring is in the air and that means wedding season is right around the corner! If you are a bride and want to add a handmade, personalized touch to the big day, weâ€™ve rounded up some fabulous DIY bridal inspiration for you from patterns to step by steps. Find the perfect fabrics to get started on your wedding DIY projects in our bridal shop, from tabletop decor to all things apparel!

![Wedding DIYs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wedding%20DIYs/RobeAndVeil-21-min.jpg)

####Getting Ready Robe Pattern: Kwik Sew K2325 This Kwik Sew pattern is a workhorse because it comes with three different designs. I sewed up the robe. The robe is a wrap with dropped shoulders and has a neckline band, pockets in the side seam, and a tie belt. It would be perfect for a bride and her bridesmaids to wear while getting ready to look stylish for all those bridal pictures. You could pick any lightweight woven fabric that has a soft drape for this robe. We went with this White Slipper Satin (the prize point is amazing!), or if you want something even more luxurious we recommend silk charmeuse.

![Wedding DIYs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wedding%20DIYs/RobeAndVeil-1-min.jpg)

![Wedding DIYs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wedding%20DIYs/RobeAndVeil-5.jpg)

Not into the white wedding aesthetic? Maybe you want to create handmade getting ready robes for your bridesmaids too? We love these fabrics for a more colorful look: * Liberty Fabrics Belgravia Silk Charmeuse * Mi Amor Dutchess Satin in Blush Pink * Kaufman Classic Seersucker Stripe in Light Blue and White * Silky Satin Charmeuse in Light Pink * Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co Les Fleurs Rayon Challis Birch Floral

![Wedding DIYs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wedding%20DIYs/RobeAndVeil_Fabric-4-min.jpg)

####Veil (with Step by Step tutorial!) While there are veil sewing patterns out there like this McCallâ€™s M4126, did you know itâ€™s also very easy to make your own, DIY veil? All you need is some pretty tulle or lace and a hair comb. Want to try this project? Hereâ€™s a simple tutorial to make this veil:

![Wedding DIYs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Wedding%20DIYs/RobeAndVeil-20.jpg)

posts.title: Sewing 101: Chiffon
posts.markdown:
Chiffon is one of the most beautiful fabrics to use in your apparel projects, but can also be one of the more challenging fabrics to work with. Its delicate nature can be intimidating to sewists, but fear not! With some patience, the right tools and few simple tricks, sewing chiffon is easier than you think! Fabric.com has a wide selection of chiffon fabrics, from poly chiffons in a variety of fun colors to luxurious silk chiffons. ####For these tips, we used the following supplies: * Chiffon Solid Coral Fabric * Pattern Weights * Machine Needle, size 70/09 * Walking Foot * Cutting mat * Rotary Cutter with a Fresh Blade * Sharp Pins * Fine Weight Thread * Heavy Starch ####Preparing the Fabric Laying and cutting the chiffon properly is step 1 for success. This step takes patience, but will make construction much easier, and the final product will be higher quality. Snip a piece of fabric so that you can locate a warp (vertical) and weft (horizontal) thread. Pull those threads out of the fabric, and you will have created your own guide to the grain of the fabric. Laying it on a gridded cutting mat will allow you to line up the absent warp and weft thread lines with the grid.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/warp%20thread-min.JPG)

*Tip: When removing the warp thread, do it closely to the selvage so the absent thread isnâ€™t visible in your fabric pieces. When removing the weft thread, be mindful of how the pattern will be placed on the fabric, so that the fabric pieces will not have a missing weft thread. Use pattern weights instead of pins. This prevents fabric shifting from all the work you just did laying out the fabric properly. Instead of scissors to cut out chiffon, use a fresh, sharp rotary blade on a cutting mat to cut the chiffon. This cutting method prevents the fabric shifting. You just spent all that time getting the fabric warp and weft lined up with a pattern, no need to discard that by handling it with scissors.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/rotary%20cutter-min.JPG)

Now that your fabric pieces are beautifully cut, use fine sharp pins to pin pieces together. When sewing, use a walking foot and a sharp machine needle, size 70/09 or less. Fine weight, or bobbin thread is recommended. Avoid backstitching, and hand tie thread tails. ####Seams French seams are ideal for chiffon. Check out this video for French seams. A 4-thread overedge stitch on a serger will work as well, just adjust the differential feed on your serger so that the stitches are closer together, since chiffon is easily unraveled.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/french%20seam-min.JPG)

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/chiffon%20serger-min.JPG)

####Hemming A rolled hem, or narrow hem on a serger is ideal for chiffon. A great trick for a rolled hem with chiffon, is to stitch the first role with a Â½â€ fold under, trim the excess to 1/8â€, turn again and topstitch.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/narrow%20hems-min.JPG)

####Binding For neck and arm openings, a bias strip binding is best. It is easily achieved with a trick: heavy starch. If the chiffon is machine washable, give the chiffon bias strip and unfinished edges a spray of heavy starch, and iron to set. The chiffon turns into a crisp, organdy-like fabric that is easy to work with.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/bias%20strip-min.JPG)

####Pressing The heat from an iron has a magical way of de-warping fabric and seams from sewing.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/press-min.JPG)

####Stabilizing This leads us to emphasize our favorite chiffon sewing tip: heavy starch! The only downside is that itâ€™s not recommended for silk chiffons. Once the fabric pieces are cut, starching 2â€ of the fabric edges make sewing chiffon easier than ever. Simply machine wash and dry your finished project to remove the starch, and it will be soft, flowy and sewn beautifully.

![Sewing 101 Chiffon](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Chiffon/cb-2583_chiffon-min.jpg)

Happy sewing with chiffon!

posts.title: Cactus Throw Pillow Free Pattern
posts.markdown:
Add some bohemian flair to your home with this adorable cactus pillow free pattern download, made with fun fabric by Justina Blakeney! This pillow is perfect for stylish seating areas, trendy bedrooms and more. Let's get started! ####Materials: * 1 yd. of fabric (we used Justina Blakeney Nomadic Jacquard but you could use any woven or quilting cotton to create this pillow) * Polyester Stuffing * All Purpose Thread * Sewing Machine * Hand Sewing Needle ####Free Pattern Download Once you've picked out the perfect fabric, click here to download the free Cactus Pillow Pattern before you start sewing! ####Instructions With your fabric right sides together, cut out two mirror image pieces at once from the cactus template. You can do this with a rotary cutter and mat, or just sewing scissors. With right sides together, sew at a Â½â€ seam all the way around. Leave a space for turning at the bottom and pivot at the corners.

![Cactus Pillow](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cactus%20Pillow%20Free%20Pattern/IMG_3359.JPG)

Next, clip the corners and notch the curves. Clipping and notching ensures that your cactus maintains its shape without puckers and lumps. Clipped corners:

![Cactus Pillow](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cactus%20Pillow%20Free%20Pattern/IMG_3363.JPG)

Notched curves:

![Cactus Pillow](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cactus%20Pillow%20Free%20Pattern/IMG_3364.JPG)

Since the cactus has a lot of curves, you will be notching almost all of it. Only the sections where the â€œarmsâ€ meet the body need to be clipped. Make sure not to cut through any of your stitching. Turn your cactus right side out. You can use a knitting needle, turning tool, or pencil for this. To make sure your curves are rounded, run the tip of your tool around all the seams (gently, but firmly) to get the right shape.

![Cactus Pillow](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cactus%20Pillow%20Free%20Pattern/IMG_3372.JPG)

Stuff firmly with fiber-fill. Hand sew opening closed with a ladder stitch.

![Cactus Pillow](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Cactus%20Pillow%20Free%20Pattern/cb-2592_cactusPillow.jpg)

Enjoy your new boho creation!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Flying Geese 3 Ways
posts.markdown:
Flying geese are an essential quilt block you'll want in your sewing repertoire, and today we're showing you 3 quick and easy methods for sewing flying geese blocks! Did you know that this technique dates back to the 1800s? It can be used in many larger blocks like the Dutchmanâ€™s Puzzle and any blocks featuring stars. Or, use them as is to create fun patterns that are graphic and modern! All of the instructions in this post will produce 2x4â€ finished blocks, but check out the handy charts below for other common finished sizes. Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed * 2 contrasting quilting fabrics (we used Kona Cotton Snow to contrast with Chartreuse, Bright Pink and Navy) * Rotary Cutter * Acrylic Rulers (6.5" square size and a longer ruler for marking) * Marking Pen * Cutting Mat * Thread ####Method 1: Traditional Method This method is great for scrappy quilters! This method makes one flying geese block, but you will have 3 main segments left over for additional blocks. If youâ€™d like to make four, just add 3 additional 2 7/8â€ squares of your "sky" fabric and cut them in half. This method is great for chain piecing if you cut all your triangles in advance. You do have to be careful when handling your cut fabrics, as youâ€™re working with bias edges that may warp. #####Cut: * (1) 5 Â¼â€ square, cut diagonally into 4 (quarter square) triangles * (1) 2 7/8 â€œ square, cut diagonally into 2 (half square) triangles

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose1.PNG)

Bias edges together, place one small triangle on the right bias edge of the large triangle, sew at Â¼â€.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose2.PNG)

Press this before sewing your next triangle on.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose3.PNG)

Place the second white triangle on the left bias edge of the main triangle, sew at Â¼â€ seam. Press.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose4.PNG)

Now you have a 1 flying geese block! You can always trim this for more accurate results.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/cb-2580_flyingGeeseChart_traditional.jpg)

####Method 2: Stitch and flip Method The Stitch and Flip Method seems to be the most common, but it does produce some waste. But, you can use the extra triangle scraps to make small HSTâ€™s for another project! This method is also great for chain-piecing, and using full squares adds extra stability while piecing. #####Cut: * (1) 2.5â€ x 4.5â€ of main fabric * (2) 2.5â€ squares of contrast fabric Mark your small white squares diagonally with a marking pen, pencil or chalk. If your fabric is not solid (has a wrong and right side), make sure you have half of your squares with the diagonal line pointing one way and half pointing the other, like the lines of the flying geese block.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose5.PNG)

Place your right contrasting square on the right side of the rectangular piece, making sure your diagonal mark is going left to right and top to bottom. Sew just along the outside of this line to allow for pressing.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose6.PNG)

Trim the excess (to the right of the line) and press.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose7.PNG)

Repeat this for the left side of the block, making sure your diagonal line is going top to bottom, left to right. Trim for better accuracy.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose8.PNG)

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/cb-2580_flyingGeeseChart_flip.jpg)

####Method 3: Four at a time This method is great for when you need a lot of geese, and the method itself can be mind-boggling, but itâ€™s actually quite easy. Accuracy is extremely important for this method to turn out correctly. #####Cut: * (1) 5 Â¼â€ square of the main color * (4) 2 7/8â€ squares of contrasting color Mark your small squares diagonally.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose9.PNG)

Place two of your small squares on the large square, one in the top left and one in the bottom right, overlapping slightly, with the markings making a diagonal line.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose10.PNG)

Sew a scant Â¼â€ seam on either side of this line.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose11.PNG)

Cut between the lines and press.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose12.PNG)

With each of these cat-eared segments, place a small square.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose13.PNG)

Sew a scant Â¼â€ seam on either side of this line.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/goose14.PNG)

Voila â€“ you have two flying geese! Repeat to the other segment for a total of 4. This is a fun method that is best used for non-directional prints.

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/cb-2580_flyingGeeseChart_4up.jpg)

We couldn't resist sewing up a quilt with flying geese using Liberty Fabrics Lawn, and we love the end result!

![Flying Geese](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Flying%20Geese/cb-2580_flyingGeese_Quilt.jpg)

Happy sewing!

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/pleats1.jpg)

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/pleats2.jpg)

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/pleats3.jpg)

*Fabric shown: P/Kaufmann Imperial Velvet Drapery Peach #####Grommets Get the grommet look without the hammer and hassle! You can now find this hardware in a handy click-together format you can install without any additional tools. Love these antique gold grommets on fabric.com!

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/grommet%20sketch.PNG)

Simply measure and mark hole placement with chalk along the panelâ€™s top edge, distributed equally depending on the amount of grommets in your kit, cut out the center, and press the grommets into place! Now you can easily slide curtain panels onto a curtain rod for easy installation!

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/grommet1.jpg)

*Fabric shown: Cotton + Steel Rifle Paper Co. Menagerie Canvas Monstera Here's a quick guide to DIY draperies that will help you choose the perfect fabric and look for your space!

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/cb-2649_diyDrapes_infographic.jpg)

####Sewing Basic Panels and Linings Sewing window treatments is a great home improvement project for those just getting comfortable on a sewing machine because essentially youâ€™re only sewing straight lines! No piece work or pattern making required. Once youâ€™ve determined the desired dimensions of your finished curtains, add 1â€ seam allowance to the bottom and sides of the panel and add an additional 3â€+ inches to the top of your curtain panel to accommodate the width of your curtain rod (if using rod & pocket method). Turn-under the raw edges Â½â€ and turn over again to create a Â½â€ fold. Press the edge and pin in place before sewing around the outside of the panel. Fold the top edge down 3â€ and test that your curtain rod can still pass through the channel before top stitching down the fold. This pocket will allow a rod to pass through to easily install in a window.

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/sewing1.PNG)

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/sewing2.PNG)

![Guide to DIY Draperies](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Guide%20to%20DIY%20Draperies/sewing3.PNG)

In addition to filtering light, linings can also aide in lowering room temperature, adding body to lightweight fabrics and enhance privacy. posts.title: Designer Spotlight: Lacefield Designs
posts.markdown:
Today's designer spotlight features Beth Lacefield, the founder of Lacefield Designs, an artisan design house and manufacturer and one of our favorite home decor brands. Lacefield Designs' artful designs are the perfect combination of trendy and timeless. We are also thrilled to celebrate the launch of Lacefield's latest collection, Global Market, which is now available exclusively on fabric.com!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Lifestyle%20Image%20from%20Global%20Market%20Collection%20for%20Blog-min.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Image%20of%20Beth%20for%20Blog%20Option%20Two-min.jpg)

####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for design?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/cb-2619_lacefieldAnswer1.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Behind%20The%20Scenes%20Image%20of%20Beth%20for%20Blog-min.jpg)

####Describe your aesthetic in 4 words

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/cb-2619_lacefieldAnswer2.png)

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Lacefield%20Designs%20Lifestyle%20Image.jpg)

####You decided to launch your own lifestyle brand in 1996. What made you decide to start your own business? I wanted the freedom to earn a living but still be a Mom, so I evolved my thinking. I was creating private label product and I decided I could start my own brand and build a business around it. ####Many of your designs are inspired by your travels. What is the most inspirational place youâ€™ve visited? Morocco, without a doubt. It is a magical blend of cultures. But, I draw inspiration daily from my surroundings it doesnâ€™t matter where I am. ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric or product that youâ€™ve designed, what would it be and why? It would have to be our Document fabric. It is so personal for meâ€¦it is full of names, place and dates (the birthdays of my children for example) that are meaningful. I created it from old documents I bought at a flea market in Paris.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/0277672.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in sewing / home dÃ©cor? Watching how people reinvent the classics, and I love layering old with new in every room. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? To me, creative expression is most interesting when people think outside the boxâ€¦.meaning, they create something unique.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Lacefield%20Designs%20Lifestyle%20Image%20%281%29.jpg)

####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? Itâ€™s a long list. One thing I am working on is designing and printing fabric for caftans for the summer! ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? It varies, but right now, I am following Kelly Wearstler, Robert & Christina, Park & Oak, designsponge, and Ashley Stark Kenner..to name a few. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? New collection launches, more strategic partnerships, and I am working on a new brandâ€¦â€¦stay tuned!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/Lifestyle%20Image%20from%20Global%20Market%20for%20Blog-min.jpeg)

####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? I love to spend time with friends and family. My husband and I have been married 30 years, we have lots of fun together. Of course, I love to travel and paint. ####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. I wanted to be a pediatrician growing up. However, during science lab one day, I had an â€œah haâ€ momentâ€¦suddenly getting a 0 to avoid the fetal pig dissection seemed like a great decision! A kind teacher encouraged me to think differently about my career path. That is the short story of how I ended up studying interior design!

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Lacefield%20Designs/cb-2619_0323_lacefield_projects-min.jpg)

####Shop the Exclusive Collection Click here to shop the full Global Market home decor fabric collection exclusively on fabric.com!

posts.title: How to Sew Lace AppliquÃ©s
posts.markdown:
Lace appliquÃ© can add interest to any project â€“ from fashion to home dÃ©cor. Many beautiful lace fabrics feature delicate motifs that can be cut out and sewn to other fabrics. Embroidered fashion is a huge trend right now, and this look can easily be achieved by appliquÃ©ing a motif from any of these beautiful embroidered lace fabrics. Weâ€™re going to show you 2 ways to sew lace applique â€“ by hand and by machine. Both give great results. Watch the video below for the full tutorial! ####Lace AppliquÃ© by Hand For this example, we used Telio Marlow Denim Shirting Fabric in Green and Telio Effie Embroidered Mesh Lace Fabric.

![Lace Appliques](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Lace%20Appliques/effie%20and%20green%20fabric-min.JPG)

Use a sharp hand needle and matching thread to sew a blanket stitch to sew the applique to the base fabric. The benefits of doing this by hand is that you can easily hide the thread stitches within the embroidery lace design already there, making the embroidered lace look as if it were an embroidery design on the fabric of the project.

![Lace Appliques](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Lace%20Appliques/up%20close%20by%20hand-min.jpg)

Another benefit is having control of the tension and position of the applique as you sew. Eliminating puckers, or machine sewing damaging the embroidery design. This process take patience and time, but the results are beautiful!

![Lace Appliques](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Lace%20Appliques/green%20applique%20done-min.JPG)

####Lace AppliquÃ© by Machine For this example, we used Kaufman Dana Jersey Knit Fabric in Orchid, and Telio Amelia Lace Fabric in Black.

![Lace Appliques](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Lace%20Appliques/dana%20and%20amelia-min.JPG)

Adjust your machine tension setting a little lower than normal and use whatever machine needle is recommended for the base fabric being used. Once the applique in pinned in place, use a zig zag stitch, leaving Â¼â€â€™ around the edge. When pivoting corners and angles, lift the presser foot with the needle in the down position, turn the project, and lower the presser foot to keep sewing. After the applique is sewn in place, you can cut away the base fabric underneath for a sheer effect if desired. This is a classic look and adds lots of interest to any project.

![Lace Appliques](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Lace%20Appliques/up%20close%20black%20lace-min.jpg)

When cutting away the underside, leave about Â¼â€ around the edges for stability. When cutting away woven fabric, use Fray Check on rough edges of base fabric to prevent unraveling. Fabric.com has a great selection of lace fabrics, as well as finished appliques. Check them out for your next project! *Laundering recommendations: If the base fabric is machine washable, wash the completed lace applique project inside-out, on a cold delicate/hand wash cycle, and lay flat to dry. Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Spring Dress Refresh: 3 Silhouettes to Sew This Season
posts.markdown:
Created by: Cristy Stuhldreher of Love You Sew Spring is finally here! With the change in weather, our lives seem to always be prompted to do some "spring cleaning." We can put all the bulky coats and thick, heavy layers away to bring back the light jackets, airy tops and flowy dresses. It's a great time to evaluate what still fits, what works with your current life needs, and what is still in style (or not.) We all tend to have a few holes in our wardrobes from season to season, especially as new trends emerge from the Spring/Summer 2018 runways. Today we'll be highlighting some of our favorite silhouettes, substrates, color trends and pattern trends for the season that you can easily incorporate into your next DIY fashion garment!

![Spring Dress Refresh](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Spring%20Dress%20Refresh/IMG_4633-min.jpg)

Denim + Pineapples + Midi Length

posts.title: Sewing 101: How to Sew Gathers
posts.markdown:
Sewing gathers is a great way to fit lots of fabric onto a project: ideal for full dresses, skirts, and ruffles. In this tutorial we will walk you thorugh 3 variations of creating gathers- check out the video below to get started! ####Fabric Choices For these examples, we used these fabrics with this pattern: * Liberty London Classic Tana Lawn Mitsi Valeria Pink Fabric * Liberty London Tana Lawn Favourite Flowers Coral/Multi Fabric * Riley Blake Wool Blend Melton Fuchsia Fabric * McCallâ€™s Infantsâ€™ Lined Dresses Pattern M6105

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/supplies-min.JPG)

####Pull Method The pull method is very common and can be executed efficiently with a few simple tricks: Your fabric will glide along the threads much easier if you set the tension to 0 and stitch length to 4mm or more.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/machine%20settings-min.JPG)

With the fabric facing up - sew 2 parallel rows from the edge of the fabric. Do not backstitch to lock stitches when starting OR stopping. After the two parallel rows have been sewn, separate the bobbin thread from the top thread. Tie off the top threads so they stay in place, and clip the top thread tails.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/face%20up-min.JPG)

Measure each fabric piece into equal fourths and pin the pieces together. Start on one end, holding both bobbin thread tails and slide the fabric towards the center. Repeat for the other side until the fabric is gathered to match the length of the joining fabric.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/gather%20each%20side-min.JPG)

Sliding the fabric along the bobbin thread is much easier than the top threads and will make for a cleaner seam finish. Set your machine settings back to normal and sew the seam allowance just past the gather rows. Adjust the ruffles as you go to keep them straight, and finish the seam when done. Another way you can do the pull method is to sew the seam allowance in between the 2 parallel rows. The gathered fabric results are absolutely beautiful and itâ€™s easier to sew to the joining fabric. An extra step is involved though â€“ you must remove the lower gather stitch row afterwards since itâ€™s outside the seam.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/sew%20in%20middle-min.JPG)

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/remove%20thread-min.JPG)

####Cord Method Medium to heavyweight fabrics can be too thick for the parallel row pull method. Instead, try the cord method for creating gathers. Sew a wide zig zag stitch instead â€“ with yarn or cord in the middle to pull.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/cord%20method-min.JPG)

You can get the cord there 1 of 2 ways â€“ sew the zig zag stitch with the cord in the middle as you sew, or thread the cord through with a craft needle afterward. Continue as you would otherwise, pinning the fabric piece together, and then pulling the cord to gather the fabric until the lengths match. Remove the cord afterward, clip gathers to reduce bulk within the seam allowance, and finish the seam. If you sew a lot of projects with gathered fabric, investing in a ruffle foot or gathering foot might be a good idea. They give much more uniformity to the gathers and can be a big time saver.

![Gathers](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Gathers/cb-2587_gathers-min.jpg)

Happy gathering!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Elastic Waist Seams
posts.markdown:
Elastic Seams are perfect to use for dresses and rompers. In this Sewing 101 video tutorial you'll learn how to add seam-enclosed and exposed elastic waist seams to your garments! ####Supplies we used for this tutorial: * Kaufman Dana Jersey Knit Yellow * Kaufman Dana Jersey Knit Salmon * 1/4â€ Knit Elastic

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/supplies.JPG)

####Seam-Enclosed Elastic Waist Seams The seam-enclosed variation is very common and offers a lot of comfort!

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/enclosed%20done.JPG)

Start by joining the bodice and skirt piece with a 5/8â€ seam allowance. Attach a strip of elastic on the underside the seam by using a zig zag stitch. A little tip we like to use is cutting the elastic with an additional 2â€, so that it stretch consistent all the way around the waistband, and no pre-joining elastic is required.

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/finish%20sew%20elastic.JPG)

Next lay the seam allowance down, toward the skirt. Top stitch 3/8â€ around to enclose the elastic and secure the seam allowance. Sewing the waistband down on the skirt piece instead of the bodice piece gives much less risk for popping the topstitch, since the bodice is usually more form fitting than the skirt piece.

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/in%20machine.JPG)

####Exposed Elastic Waist Seams Exposed elastic waist seams are very common as well, and give a cleaner look. It requires less steps, but a tad more precision.

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/exposed%20done.JPG)

Start by combining the bodice and skirt piece with a Â¼â€ seam allowance. Attach the Â¼â€ elastic strip with a zig zag stitch. When you sew the zig zag stitch- position it so that one point of the zig zag overedges the elastic, and the other point penetrates the elastic and meets the seam at the same time.

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/zig%20zag%20seam.JPG)

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/seam%20edge.JPG)

Having that little edge of fabric left on the seam allowance adds as a buffer between the elastic band edge and your skin, for a more comfortable fit. Otherwise an exposed elastic seam can be a little itchy.

![Elastic Waist Seams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Elastic%20Waist%20Seams/cb-2586_elasticWaist2.jpg)

Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Spring Diamonds Quilt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Flamingo Toes Hi fabric.com readers! It's Bev from Flamingo Toes here today with another fun Quilt pattern today. This new Spring Diamonds quilt is quick and easy to sew and it's perfect for showing off your favorite spring fabrics! For this quilt I used the gorgeous Sweet Prairie line by Sedef Imer Of Down Grapevine Lane for Riley Blake Designs. It's full of gorgeous florals and prints - I chose the red, pink and yellow prints. They are perfect for Spring! Let's get sewing!

Spring Diamonds Quilt Tutorial

Finished Quilt size: 71" x 71" Materials:
  • Sweet Prairie Main White - 3 1/2 yards
  • Sweet Prairie Floral Red - 1 yard
  • Sweet Prairie Night Sky Yellow - 1 yard
  • Sweet Prairie Main Coral - 1 1/2 yards
  • Sweet Prairie Gingham Pink - 1 yard
  • Sweet Prairie Leaves Pink - 5 yards
  • Batting
  • Aurifil White Thread - 50 wt
Cut out of your fabrics:
  • 32 Sweet Prairie Main White squares - 8 1/2"
  • 64 Sweet Prairie Main White squares - 5 1/8"
  • 32 Sweet Prairie Floral Red squares - 5 1/8"
  • 16 Sweet Prairie Night Sky Yellow Squares - 5 1/8"
  • 16 Sweet Prairie Main Coral Squares - 5 1/8"
  • Sweet Prairie Floral Red - 8 strips - 1 1/2" x 42"
  • Sweet Prairie Main Coral - 8 strips - 3 1/2" x 42"
If you'd like, you can also purchase a low-cost PDF version of this pattern here. It includes everything in the tutorial below, along with a blank quilt printable of the design so you can plan colors and prints.Â  You'll be making 32 half-square triangles from the floral red and main white and 16 each of the yellow and the coral with the main white. To make a half square triangle, place a 5 1/8" square of main white with a 5 1/8" square of floral red, right sides together. Draw a diagonal line from one corner to the opposite corner with a marking pen on the wrong side of the fabric. Sew a straight seam 1/4" on either side of the marked line. Cut on the marked line with your rotary cutter to separate the two triangles. Open up the squares and press the seams to one side. Trim the square to 4 1/2". Repeat for all of the Red Floral, Yellow, and Main coral 5 1/8" squares. You will have 64 Red and White squares, 32 Coral and White squares and 32 Yellow and White squares. Begin sewing your pieced blocks together. Start by sewing a red/white square to a coral/white square. Sew a yellow/white square to a red/white square. You'll now have 2 sets of two block rows. Press the center seams opposite directions. Place the two rows right sides together and sew together, matching the center seams. Press the seam to one side. Use the photo below for half square triangle alignment and directions. Your four squares should form a diamond of prints in the center with the main white floral on the outside of all of the triangles. Repeat this step to sew a total of 32 diamond blocks. The finished size of the blocks should be 8 1/2". Begin to sew your rows together. For all of your diamonds, the red/pink side should be at the top of the block. Alternate a diamond block with an 8 1/2" main white floral block. Row 1 should start with a diamond block. Row 2 should start with an unpieced block, then alternate the pieced and regular blocks. Continue for 6 more rows. You should have 4 rows that start with a diamond block and four that start with a plain block. Press the seams to one side, alternating the direction with each row. Sew your rows together to form the center of the quilt. Press the row seams towards the bottom of the quilt. Sew two of the red floral 1 1/2" strips together to form a 1 1/2" x 84" strip. Repeat with the remaining strips to sew 3 more long strips. Press the seams to one side. Sew one of each of the strips to the top and bottom of the quilt. Trim off the ends to line up with the center of the quilt. Sew the remaining two 1 1/2" strips to the left and right sides of the quilt. Repeat for the larger coral border, sewing the strips together to form four long pieces, then sew the top and bottom border pieces, trimming, then the left and right border pieces. This finishes your quilt top! Prepare your backing fabric (I used the Leaves Pink fabric as the backing) and quilt and bind as desired. Mine was quilted by Julie's Longarm Service. I chose a pretty floral quilting design - I thought it looked great with the floral prints! Once your quilt is quilted, bind it with the Gingham Pink print. I cut my binding straight (not on the bias) because I wanted the gingham to be at a diagonal. My strips were 2 1/2" and I did double fold binding, sewn to the front and hand-stitched to the back. Feel free to bind it however you choose! Now you can show off your sweet new quilt for Spring!

Continue for 6 more rows. You should have 4 rows that start with a diamond block and four that start with a plain block. Press the seams to one side, alternating the direction with each row.

Sew your rows together to form the center of the quilt.

Press the row seams towards the bottom of the quilt.

Sew two of the red floral 1 1/2" strips together to form a 1 1/2" x 84" strip. Repeat with the remaining strips to sew 3 more long strips. Press the seams to one side.

Sew one of each of the strips to the top and bottom of the quilt. Trim off the ends to line up with the center of the quilt. Sew the remaining two 1 1/2" strips to the left and right sides of the quilt.

Repeat for the larger coral border, sewing the strips together to form four long pieces, then sew the top and bottom border pieces, trimming, then the left and right border pieces.

This finishes your quilt top! Prepare your backing fabric (I used the Leaves Pink fabric as the backing) and quilt and bind as desired. Mine was quilted by Julie's Longarm Service. I chose a pretty floral quilting design - I thought it looked great with the floral prints!

Once your quilt is quilted, bind it with the Gingham Pink print. I cut my binding straight (not on the bias) because I wanted the gingham to be at a diagonal. My strips were 2 1/2" and I did double fold binding, sewn to the front and hand-stitched to the back. Feel free to bind it however you choose!

Now you can show off your sweet new quilt for Spring!

posts.title: Designer Spotlight: Sarah Jane
posts.markdown:
Today's designer spotlight is all about Sarah Jane! Her charming designs for Michael Miller Fabrics are some of our favorites for creating quilts, apparel and so much more. Let's get to know Sarah Jane!

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/hello%20about%20pic.jpg)

####About Sarah Jane Sarah Jane is a textile designer and childrenâ€™s book illustrator, but most importantly, mother to 4 ambitious and creative children. From her love of childhood, her designs evoke the essence of childhood with simple, whimsical and almost nostalgic illustrations. With her motive of cultivating the wonder of childhood, Sarah Jane has built a business offering her embroidery designs, artwork, wallpaper and paper toys online as well as collaborations with Ralph Lauren, Paris Ritz, Land of Nod, among others. She has designed fabric for Michael Miller Fabrics for 7 years. Most recently, she and her husband have joined creative forces to become an author/illustrator team, creating the new childrenâ€™s book series and character, LOLA DUTCH, which released in January of this year. Lola Dutch is a character who embodies curious and creative childhood and will be a multiple book series with book 2 and 3 coming soon! Sarah Jane and her husband live in the mountains of Utah with their 4 children.

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/150323_SarahJaneStudios_406.jpg)

####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for design? As early as I can remember! I remember being 2-3 years old and being stunned by the color of the ocean in Hawaii where my mother is from. I can still see it in my mind! From then, I donâ€™t remember a time where my hands werenâ€™t holding a pencil, crayon, or creative utensil of some kind.

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/150323_SarahJaneStudios_565.jpg)

####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. Simple, charming, classic. ####You partnered with Michael Miller to launch your line of fabrics. What made them the perfect partner for you? They approached me, but I would have approached them first if I had the chance. I canâ€™t imagine working with a better partner. They completely trust my design approach, they truly value creativity and exploration. And because they have a relatively small team for how big their market is, they are like a family: approachable, willing to explore new ideas, open to changing with the market, and the best partâ€¦they are a lot of fun! I have felt so supported in my design journey, and they have been 200% supportive, which as a designer is so paramount! Michael Miller is like a family to me. They have always been on top of market shifts, and in my opinion create some of the top quality product in the industry. Quality has always been their #1 and as an artist and designer, Iâ€™ve really truly appreciated that. But bottom line, they are just so much fun to work with, and so easy as a client. Iâ€™m truly grateful! ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric or product that youâ€™ve designed, what would it be and why? *Please select something sold on fabric.com How could I choose one! If I had to choose one, Iâ€™d choose either â€œMagic Paradeâ€ because itâ€™s so versatile, and depicts each one of my kids. Also, â€œPlockadeâ€, which is Swedish for â€˜gatheredâ€™ because it reminds me of my Grandmother of Scandinavian decent and her incredible love of being outside and gathering flowers.

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/Magic_v1.jpg)

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/Magic_v2.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in sewing / quilting? I love the low volume quilting trend as well as the trend towards simple classic clothing. Iâ€™m thrilled to see more clothing designs that arenâ€™t about the complicated layers of clothing, but about the fabric quality, function and design. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? I absolutely love watching others be creative with my creative offering. To see sewers use my fabric as an inspiration to inspire their own creative projects is incredible! Little girl dresses and bedroom dÃ©cor are probably the #1 creation used with my fabric, and so I absolutely love seeing mothers and grandmothers sew for their children and decorate their rooms with my designs! I love witnessing that creative process between mother and child, grandparent and -grandchild. Itâ€™s so incredibly fulfilling. Iâ€™m very involved on Instagram and Facebook, and when people share their projects and their personal stories behind them, itâ€™s incredible. Iâ€™ve heard stories that have brought me to tears, and it makes what I do so worth it. ####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? I am currently making (well, someone else is making them, because Iâ€™m not the best seamstress) some lovely vintage dresses as well as some new quilts for my kids. Iâ€™m working on my next collection, and Iâ€™m redoing my kids rooms with the new designs! They are pretty lucky that they get new bedding and clothing every season it seems! ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? I mostly look to my favorite designers from the past for inspiration. I absolutely adore the French Textile Designer Paule Marrot, illustrators Virginia Lee Burton, Ludwig Bemelmens and Gyo Fujikawa. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? 2018 has been so full already! Iâ€™ve just finished illustrating the second book in the Lola Dutch Series, and Iâ€™m finishing up the 3rd. Iâ€™m releasing a new Fabric Line, Peter Pan, this summer with Michael Miller Fabrics and will be launching another fabric line soon after that! 2018 already feels like itâ€™s over with how much we are producing this year, but itâ€™s all so much fun.

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/150323_SarahJaneStudios_480.jpg)

####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? Just being with Kenneth, my husband, and the kids. It doesnâ€™t matter where we are, we just absolutely love spending time together. ####Tell us one thing people might not know about you: Iâ€™m horrible at science (flunked physical science in collegeâ€¦twice), but I got an A in Honors Chemistry in high school because my final research paper was on the chemical reaction between paint and the fresco process during the Renaissance, a topic which I am pretty sure the teacher was clueless about, but the only thing that excited me about chemistry...which was a stretchâ€¦but it got me an A and it taught me the most invaluable lesson: if your curious about it, and truly love it, you will go far.

![Sarah Jane](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%3A%20Sarah%20Jane/CB-2676_blog_sarahJane_projects.jpg)

posts.title: Summer Scarves 3 Ways
posts.markdown:
Hi, it's Kimberly from Sweet Red Poppy and I'm excited to share three quick and easy scarf sewing tutorials with you today! Each scarf takes less than an hour to sew and they make perfect gifts! I'll be sewing up a few for my mom for Mother's Day (and a couple for myself too!).

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9568-2-min.jpg)

####Pom Pom Scarf

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9504-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 2 yards of Cotton + Steel Rayon Challis (we used Rifle Paper Co. Menagerie Rayon Jardin De Paris in Mint) * 4 Yards of Pom Pom Trim (we chose this pink color) * Coordinating Thread * Sewing Machine ####Instructions Cut a rectangle 72" long x 15" wide. If you would like to use 1 yard instead of two yards of fabric you can piece the rectangle together using two shorter rectangles.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9477-2-min.jpg)

Fold the rectangle in half and cut the fabric so the ends of the scarf taper to a 2-3 inch point.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9478-2-min.jpg)

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9479-min.jpg)

Pin the pom-pom trim along the perimeter of the fabric so that the pom-poms are facing inwards.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9482-2-min.jpg)

Using a zigzag stitch, sew the trim all the way around the scarf. The zig-zag stitch should just barely catch the edge of the fabric. This will prevent the fabric from unraveling. Overlap the ends of the pom-pom trim and secure with a zigzag stitch.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9486-2-min.jpg)

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9491-min.jpg)

Flip the pom-pom trim towards the wrong side of the fabric so that just a bit of the trim peeks out from behind the fabric. Pin in place along the entire scarf. With a straight stitch, sew 1/4 away from the edge of the fabric around the entire scarf taking care to backstitch at the beginning and end.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9496-min.jpg)

When looking at the scarf from the back, the edge of the trim should cover the edge of the fabric completely to keep it from unraveling.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9506-min.jpg)

####Tassel Scarf

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9539-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 2 yards Telio Viscose Rayon Challis (we chose this coral color) * Sewing Machine * Coordinating Thread * 1 yard of Tassel Trim (we used this multicolored one). ####Instructions Cut a rectangle 60â€ x 17â€

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9509-min.jpg)

Sew a basting stitch along both long edges of the fabric 3/8" from the edge. The basting stitch will serve as a guide as you iron the fabric.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9511-min.jpg)

Fold the fabric along the basting stitch and press with a hot iron, then fold again to conceal the raw edge. Repeat this process on the opposite side.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9515-min.jpg)

With a 1/4â€ seam allowance sew a straight line along the folded edge of both sides of the scarf.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9524-min.jpg)

Gently remove the basting stitch from both sides.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9526-min.jpg)

Place the scarf with the right side facing upwards on a table. Pin the tasseled trim to the fabric so that the tassels are facing upwards instead of dangling down beneath the fabric. Pin the trim in place and sew a zig-zag stitch along the edge of the trim catching the edge of the fabric.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9531-min.jpg)

Fold the trim towards the wrong side of the fabric and in it in place. Sew along the edge of the fabric with a 1/4â€ seam allowance.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9533-2-min.jpg)

Press all seams with a hot iron and you're done! ####Infinity Scarf

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9558-min.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 2 yards Telio Viscose Rayon Challis (we chose this emerald color) * Sewing Machine * Coordinating Thread * 2 Â½ yards of Pom Pom Trim (we chose this fun multi colored one) ####Instructions Cut two rectangles 15â€ x 42â€

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9544-min.jpg)

Place the fabric together with wrong sides together. Sew the two pieces together with a 1/4 inch seam. Iron the seam to one side and fold the fabric together with right sides together and sew with a 3/8" seam. This will create a french seam that encloses the raw edge.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9550-min.jpg)

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9552-min.jpg)

Repeat this process on the other side to create a circular piece of fabric.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9548-min.jpg)

Sew a basting stitch along both long edges of the fabric 3/8ths inch from the edge. The basting stitch will serve as a guide as you iron the fabric. Fold the fabric along the basting stitch and press with a hot iron, then fold again to conceal the raw edge. Repeat this process on the opposite side.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9553-min.jpg)

With a 1/4â€ seam allowance sew a straight line along the folded edge of one side of the scarf. Pin the trim to the other side of the scarf that has not bee sewn yet. Pin it in place along the edge of the fabric and sew it in place using a zig zag stitch and a zipper foot.

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/IMG_9555-min.jpg)

![Summer Scarves](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Summer%20Scarves%203%20Ways/CB-2688_Blog_scarves_socialNOTXT.jpg)

Happy sewing!

Fold the fabric along the basting stitch and press with a hot iron, then fold again to conceal the raw edge. Repeat this process on the opposite side.

With a 1/4â€ seam allowance sew a straight line along the folded edge of both sides of the scarf.

Gently remove the basting stitch from both sides.

Place the scarf with the right side facing upwards on a table. Pin the tasseled trim to the fabric so that the tassels are facing upwards instead of dangling down beneath the fabric.

Pin the trim in place and sew a zig-zag stitch along the edge of the trim catching the edge of the fabric.

Fold the trim towards the wrong side of the fabric and in it in place. Sew along the edge of the fabric with a 1/4â€ seam allowance.

Press all seams with a hot iron and you're done!

Infinity Scarf

  • 2 yards Telio Viscose Rayon Challis (we chose this emerald color)
  • Sewing Machine
  • Coordinating Thread
  • 2 Â½ yards of Pom Pom Trim (we chose this fun multi colored one)

Instructions

Cut two rectangles 15â€ x 42â€

Place the fabric together with wrong sides together. Sew the two pieces together with a 1/4 inch seam. Iron the seam to one side and fold the fabric together with right sides together and sew with a 3/8" seam.

This will create a french seam that encloses the raw edge.

Repeat this process on the other side to create a circular piece of fabric.

Sew a basting stitch along both long edges of the fabric 3/8ths inch from the edge.
The basting stitch will serve as a guide as you iron the fabric.

Fold the fabric along the basting stitch and press with a hot iron, then fold again to conceal the raw edge. Repeat this process on the opposite side.

With a 1/4â€ seam allowance sew a straight line along the folded edge of one side of the scarf.

Pin the trim to the other side of the scarf that has not bee sewn yet. Pin it in place along the edge of the fabric and sew it in place using a zig zag stitch and a zipper foot.

Happy sewing!

Pin down your binding on top of the gauze with a Â½â€ fold under all the way around.

![Self Binding Baby Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Self%20Binding%20Baby%20Blanket/215.PNG)

Topstitch the binding in place about Â¼â€ from the inside edge. You can also use a blanket or zig zag stitch for this. A walking foot is essential for even binding.

![Self Binding Baby Blanket](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Self%20Binding%20Baby%20Blanket/blanket1.jpg)

posts.title: Fitted Crib Sheet Tutorial
posts.markdown:
A fitted crib sheet is a fun and easy way to personalize any nursery! Today we'll show you how to create a crib sheet in a few simple steps. Quilting cotton fabric is perfect for fitted crib sheets! There are endless prints to choose from, it is 100% cotton and the manufacturerâ€™s width of 44â€ makes for quick and easy cutting. Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed * 2 yards of 44â€ wide cotton fabric for a standard crib mattress (52.5â€ x 27.5â€ x 5.5â€). We used Art Gallery Littlest Floral Frolic Apricot Fabric. Art Gallery cotton fabrics are especially great for sheeting, since they have a higher thread count. * 74â€ piece of Â¼â€ knit elastic. ####Step 1 Cut fabric so that the length measures 69 5/8â€. Quilting cotton fabric should already be 44â€ wide, so no cutting required for the width! Do not cut off the selvedges. ####Step 2 Fold each corner and sew 9â€ in from each angle to create corner seams. Finishing the seams is imperative since this will get washed many times.

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/measure%209-min.JPG)

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/sew%209-min.JPG)

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/cut%209-min.JPG)

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/done%209-min.JPG)

####Step 3 On a strip of Â¼â€ elastic: mark measurements for 8 Â½â€, 29â€, 45â€ and 65 Â½â€ â€“ these will be the points attached to each corner for even spacing. After youâ€™ve made the markings, join the elastic ends together with a 1â€ overlap to create an elastic circle.

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/elastic%20mark-min.JPG)

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/elastic%20overlap-min.JPG)

####Step 4 Pin the elastic to each point and any other additional points needed to secure. Roll hem the fabric with the elastic inside and topstitch with a wide zig zag stitch.

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/topstitch-min.JPG)

![Crib Sheet](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Crib%20Sheet/cribSheet_2.jpg)

Happy Sewing!
