posts.title: Easy Modern Triangles Quilt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Skill level: Confident Beginner Created by: Kristi McDonough/Schnitzel & Boo Triangle quilts might look challenging, but theyâ€™re actually quite simple especially if you are working with equilateral triangles! This quilt is super fast and easy to make, but looks difficult because of the strips in each triangle. When we saw the Amalfi Collection by Rifle Paper Co. for Cotton + Steel we couldn't wait to create this quilt with it! The line features fun summer prints, from girls lounging in the sun to whimsical waves.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/cb-2733_modernTriangle1.jpg)

Let's get started! ####Supplies * (5) high volume 1 yard cuts of Amalfi fabric (or any quiltling cotton ) * (5) low volume 1 yard cuts of Amalfi fabric (or any quiltling cotton ) * Aurifil 50wt thread * Equilateral triangle ruler (must have an 8.5â€ option like this one) * Straight ruler * Rotary cutter

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8800_edit.jpg)

####Instructions *Note: Seam allowance is 1/4â€, unless noted differently Cut each fabric into 4.5â€x WOF strips (width of fabric). Separate into High Value (HV) and Low Value (LV) piles.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8812_edit.jpg)

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8814_edit.jpg)

Sew two HV strips together down the length of the fabric; press seams open. Repeat for all remaining HV fabrics and again for all LV fabrics. Try to mix the fabrics so no two fabrics are matched together.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8858_edit.jpg)

Using the equilateral triangle ruler, align the top point and bottom edge, or 8.5â€ line on the ruler, with the strip; cut. Flip the ruler around, align the diagonal edge of the ruler with the 60* cut edge of the strip; cut. Continue this way until you have cut all the triangles you can from this strip. Repeat for all remaining strips. You will notice that this will result in a triangle with a smaller triangle in the corner.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8852_edit.jpg)

Using the photo below as a layout guide, place the triangles on your design wall, table or floor, alternating between HV and LV. Place the small corner triangle in the upper left for the LV pieces, and to the bottom right for the HV pieces. You will start to see a secondary half hexagon pattern emerge. Repeat until you have 21 triangles in the row.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/cb-2733_modernTriangle4.jpg)

For the second row, place the small triangle of the LV piece in the bottom right position and the HV in the upper left. Keep arranging the rows as described above until you have ten rows of triangles. Use the finished quilt photo at the top of this post for reference as you go! Once you have all the triangles arranged to your liking, you are ready to sew. Place the triangles right sides together and stitch. You will have 1/4â€ of the edges sticking out on top and bottom, but once you have two sewn together, the pressed seam allowance will create a "seam guide" to lay the new triangle upon.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8917_edit.jpg)

Repeat until all triangles in the row have been stitched, making sure to press the seam allowance open before sewing on a new triangle. Sew and label each row as you complete them. This will make it less confusing when you go to sew the quilt top together.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8918_edit.jpg)

Sew all the rows together, pressing seam allowances open. Using the rotary cutter and straight ruler, trim the zig zag edges from the sides of the quilt.

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/IMG_8929_edit.jpg)

Your new quilt is now ready to be quilted and bound! That was easy, right? The hardest part of this quilt is getting the perfect layout, but even that part isnâ€™t so bad when youâ€™re working with such pretty fabrics!

![Modern Triangles](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Triangles%20Quilt/cb-2733_modernTriangleB1.jpg)

Happy sewing, everyone!

posts.title: Picking the Perfect Outdoor Fabric
posts.markdown:
Picking the right outdoor fabric for your project can be a daunting process, but today we are going to make it quick and easy! We'll tell you everything you need to know about selecting the right outdoor textile for your desired durability, price and design aesthetic. ####Select Fabrics Labeled for Outdoor Use Start by selecting fabrics labeled for outdoor use. These fabrics have been specially treated for resistance to water, stains, UV and other outside elements. Fabric.com has a wide variety of outdoor fabrics to choose from, but today we will talk about some of the most common outdoor fabrics, their benefits and what projects they are best suited for. #####Some of the most common fabric groups to look for in outdoor use are: * Polyester * Solution-dyed Acrylic or Solution-dyed Olefin * PVC (Polyvinyl Chloride) Mesh * Marine Vinyl ####Consider Desired Durability and Price When selecting fabric for your outdoor project, one important item to consider is how durable youâ€™d like your project to be. If a wider selection of prints and styles, along with a lower price, is most important to you, then look for products labeled for outdoor use which are Polyester-based Outdoor fabrics such as: Richloom Indoor/Outdoor Remi Palm Tommy Bahama Indoor/Outdoor Island Hopping Emerald Richloom Solarium Outdoor Fresca Fiesta These fabrics are typically medium weight, easy to sew with, and come in a wide variety of prints and styles. Many are UV treated for an average of only 500 light hours before fading occurs, so they should be brought indoors when not in use. They can be easily cleaned with warm water and mild soapy solution. These fabrics are perfect for adding a personal touch to an outdoor space with pillows or light upholstery.

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/Poly%20fabrics-min.PNG)

If youâ€™re looking for something more durable that you wonâ€™t have to worry about bringing indoors during those long summer days, look for products labeled for outdoor use which are either Solution-dyed Acrylic or Solution-dyed Olefin fabrics. These fabrics will provide more durability over polyester-based fabrics and can withstand the long hours of direct summer sunlight. Some of our favorites are: Sunbrella Blend Mist Basketweave Sunbrella Outdoor Dupione Papaya Sunbrella Outdoor Canvas Stripe Seville Seaside

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/Acrylic%20olefin%20fabrics-min.PNG)

These fabrics range from medium to very heavyweight canvas or jacquard-style fabrics made for durability. Although very limited in prints, these fabrics get their color from solution dyed fibers before they are spun into fabric, drastically reducing any fading from UV rays. This fiber is often used for outdoor awnings, umbrellas and covers. These fabrics have a higher abrasion resistance (stated in double-rubs) as well, making them perfect for outdoor upholstery, cushions and pillows. Although these fabrics are made to resist the outdoor elements, they should still be brought under cover when not in use to help prolong the life of your project. The price points are usually higher than Polyester fabrics, but for good reason.

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/AdobeStock_100414669-min.jpeg)

One common approach is to mix both of these fabric types together. Utilize acrylic fabrics for your solids which will last much longer, and add Polyester fabrics to add that personal touch to your outdoor space.

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/iStock-104230539-min.jpg)

####Heavy Duty Outdoor Projects Now letâ€™s talk about more heavy duty outdoor fabrics. If you are working on a project such as poolside or patio chairs, look for fabrics labeled as PVC Mesh. PVC Mesh fabric is commonly used in sling-style outdoor furniture - pool chairs and patio chairs that have a plastic-like basket weave appearance. Water can pass through them, they dry quickly, and most are fade resistant. Because PVC mesh doesnâ€™t stretch, they donâ€™t require any cushioning underneath for support- it can be simply attached to a metal or wood furniture frame. Some of our favorites are: Phifertex Patio Novelty Blue Phifertex Plus Dupioni Poolside Outdoor Abbey Shea 9 oz. 911 Mesh Green

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/pvc%20mesh%20fabrics-min.PNG)

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/iStock-182837707-min.jpg)

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/AdobeStock_138722522-min.jpeg)

For heavy duty upholstery, such as boat or automotive upholstery, marine vinyl is an excellent choice. The most durable of the outdoor fabrics we are covering today, marine vinyl has been treated for water, stain and UV resistance and has a high abrasion resistance as well.

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/Marine%20vinyl%20fabrics-min.PNG)

![Outdoor Fabric](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20the%20Perfect%20Outdoor%20Fabric/AdobeStock_107078610-min.jpeg)

Marine vinyl typically has a leather-look and can be used for boat or automotive upholstery, but can also be used indoors for high-traffic upholstery for home or commercial use. These fabrics can simply be wiped clean as needed.Some of our favorites include: Richloom Fortress Marine Vinyl Outing Royal Marine Vinyl Turquoise Marine Vinyl Silver We hope this guide to outdoor fabrics helps to point you in the right direction. Happy sewing! Click here to shop all outdoor fabrics on fabric.com.

Although very limited in prints, these fabrics get their color from solution dyed fibers before they are spun into fabric, drastically reducing any fading from UV rays. This fiber is often used for outdoor awnings, umbrellas and covers. These fabrics have a higher abrasion resistance (stated in double-rubs) as well, making them perfect for outdoor upholstery, cushions and pillows. Although these fabrics are made to resist the outdoor elements, they should still be brought under cover when not in use to help prolong the life of your project. The price points are usually higher than Polyester fabrics, but for good reason.

One common approach is to mix both of these fabric types together. Utilize acrylic fabrics for your solids which will last much longer, and add Polyester fabrics to add that personal touch to your outdoor space.

Heavy Duty Outdoor Projects

Now letâ€™s talk about more heavy duty outdoor fabrics. If you are working on a project such as poolside or patio chairs, look for fabrics labeled as PVC Mesh. PVC Mesh fabric is commonly used in sling-style outdoor furniture - pool chairs and patio chairs that have a plastic-like basket weave appearance. Water can pass through them, they dry quickly, and most are fade resistant. Because PVC mesh doesnâ€™t stretch, they donâ€™t require any cushioning underneath for support- it can be simply attached to a metal or wood furniture frame. Some of our favorites are:

Phifertex Patio Novelty Blue
Phifertex Plus Dupioni Poolside Outdoor
Abbey Shea 9 oz. 911 Mesh Green

For heavy duty upholstery, such as boat or automotive upholstery, marine vinyl is an excellent choice. The most durable of the outdoor fabrics we are covering today, marine vinyl has been treated for water, stain and UV resistance and has a high abrasion resistance as well.

Marine vinyl typically has a leather-look and can be used for boat or automotive upholstery, but can also be used indoors for high-traffic upholstery for home or commercial use. These fabrics can simply be wiped clean as needed.Some of our favorites include:

Richloom Fortress Marine Vinyl Outing Royal
Marine Vinyl Turquoise
Marine Vinyl Silver

We hope this guide to outdoor fabrics helps to point you in the right direction. Happy sewing!

In today's Designer Spotlight you'll learn all about Rachel Erickson of Citrus & Mint Designs, who designs fabric collections for Riley Blake Designs! ####About Rachel Rachel hails from the always beautiful, and almost always humid, Florida. Like many other designers at Riley Blake, she is a teacher turned stay-at-home mom who discovered illustration while searching for a hobby to maintain her sanity at home with two little children.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/zDSC04682_edit-min.jpg)

Rachel comes from a long line of seamstresses who she constantly disappoints with her aversion to "measuring twice, cutting once." Illustrating is her passion. She is drawn to bright colors and a hand-drawn whimsical style, though she has to remind herself often that not everyone loves orange as much as she does. When she isn't illustrating, you can find her sipping diet coke while playing "kitty tornado water slide" with her son (don't ask), drawing baby animals with her daughter (mostly kitties), or combing the beach for more tiny shells and shark teeth to add to her borderline obsessive collection.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/DSC04529%20crop-min.jpg)

####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for design? Iâ€™ve always loved to create and collect art. I come from a long line of creative matriarchs who crave to make things beautiful, each in their own way. My grandma is a watercolor artist and taught me the basics of art. My mother is an interior designer and taught me the basics of aesthetics and design. I knew how to pick out good art; however I was always frustrated because I didnâ€™t have the skills or tools to create what I saw in my head. Then after I quit my job to stay home with my first child, I discovered Adobe Illustrator and everything clicked. I finally found the medium that allows me to express my ideas in the way that I want them expressed.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/DSC04623-min.jpg)

####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/answer%202.png)

####Your newest collections Lancelot and Guinevere are now available on fabric.com! What was the inspiration behind these collections? I came up with this idea 4 years ago, before I ever thought about designing fabric. My daughter was 3 years old and obsessed with princesses. She woke me up every morning with a different princess dress to wear for the day and sang princess songs in a high Snow White voice. I wanted to create something for her that was more childlike and retro than the standard princess products. I loved what I created and held onto it until the right project came along.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/IMG_5772b-min.jpg)

####You partnered with Riley Blake to launch your line of fabrics. What made them the perfect partner for you? The people working at Riley Blake are the best! I am completely new to the world of fabric design, which means I need a lot of help. They are so encouraging and always willing to walk me through all the steps necessary to accomplish the end goal. ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric or product that youâ€™ve designed, what would it be and why? Probably the main lion print from the Lancelot collection. I wanted him to have lots of character, but I couldnâ€™t get him to look just right (sometimes as adults we overthink art). One afternoon I asked my daughter to sit and draw some lions with me. I took inspiration from her to draw the lions that you see on the fabric, so the credit for his cuteness really goes to her.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/0568763.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in sewing / quilting? I love that embroidery is coming back! Sometimes it adds just the right amount of texture and personality that a piece needs to truly be complete. I find myself adding embroidery to all my quilting and sewing projects. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? This is my first collection, so Iâ€™m still just in awe that it exists and that people want to create with my designs! Thereâ€™s something magical about creativity inspiring more creativity.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/IMG_9646%20cropped-min.jpg)

*Pendant quilt by Mindy Carlson (pattern by Cluck Cluck Sew) and photos by Michelle Salomons ####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? I want to make little button up shirts for my son in every single Lancelot fabric, even though he refuses to wear â€œchurch shirtsâ€ on any day but Sunday. ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? I hoarded some Sarah Jane fabric years before I had kids or even a sewing machine. Just because I loved it. Her illustration style is so personal and imaginative. Thatâ€™s the same reason that I love Heather Ross. She always throws in something ordinary but completely unexpected. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? Thereâ€™s a new fabric collection for Riley Blake Designs called Wild Bouquet coming out this fall that is inspired by my vacation last summer hiking among the mountain wildflowers. Iâ€™m excited to sew all kinds of skirts, shirts, and bags for myself with it! For the spring 2019 collection, my daughter is requesting fabric with â€œall her favorite animalsâ€ which is pretty much every land and sea animal on earth, so sheâ€™s probably going to be a little disappointed.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/lancelot%20and%20guinivere%20wonky%20quilt-min.jpeg)

####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating?

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/answer%201.png)

####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. In high school, my AP art portfolio just barely passed with a 3. My keystone piece was a painting covered in newspaper articles splattered with red and black paint (a la Jackson Pollock) except for a white box on the side which contained a childlike drawing of a family. It represented the family as a protection from the world or something like that. This was "serious" art, haha. My art teacher had a list of forbidden subjects for our projectsâ€”unicorns, rainbows, cats, etc. I wonder what he would think of my art now, which pretty much solely consists of the items on that list.

![Designer Spotlight Citrus and Mint](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Citrus%20and%20Mint/CB-2749_blog_citrusMint_projects.jpg)

Want to check out all of Citrus & Mint's fabrics? Click here to shop!

Created by: Little Fish Apparel Whether you are creating a handmade gift for Fatherâ€™s Day or an oversized boyfriend button down, these basic tips and tricks will help you as you sew menâ€™s collared shirts! Be sure to check out fabric.com's Menswear Shop for all of your upcoming projects!

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/cb-2765_blog_menShirt_image3-min.jpg)

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/cb-2765_blog_menShirt_image2-min.jpg)

####Choosing Fabric For these two button-ups we used Kaufman Classic Seersucker in Stripe Americana and Check Royal. Seersucker is an easy fabric to work with because itâ€™s very stable. This is a great choice of fabric if itâ€™s your first adventure with a button-up and collared shirt. We also chose these seersucker fabrics because they are ideal for the summer since theyâ€™re very lightweight.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/0302142.jpg)

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/DJ-435.jpg)

Two other great alternative fabric options for a collared shirt are Kaufman Oxford and Liberty Fabrics Poplin. ####Supplies Needed * Shirting fabric (determine yardage according to size and pattern requirements) * Collared shirt pattern: We used the Fairfield Button-up by Thread Theory * Glue Stick * Buttons #### Glue your Pockets on

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/2-min.jpg)

This tip is a game changer and can be used on many projects!

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/G1-min.jpg)

1. Get any washable glue stick (basic Elmer's will work). Donâ€™t worry about it being purple upon application. It will all wash out. 2. Once your pockets are prepped and seam allowances are ironed according to pattern directions, glue around the edges of the entire pocket on the wrong side of the fabric. 3. Carefully place and press the pocket into place. Now it wonâ€™t move, and thereâ€™s no need to pin! I find this method MUCH more accurate than pinning when I want to match a pocket perfectly. Also, try this method to match side seams. #### Reinforce the yoke

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/YA-min.jpg)

A rip or tear along the yoke seam of a button-up shirt is common! This is where the most pressure is put on the garment as it is worn. Try this tip to strengthen your seam and save yourself mending time down the road. 1) Shorten your stitch length as you attach the yokes to the shirt back.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/Y1-min.jpg)

2) Strengthen the seam with a second row of stitching, approximately Â¼ inch away.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/Y2-min.jpg)

3) Finally, iron and topstitch the yoke. #### Attach buttons with your sewing machine I donâ€™t have the button sew-on foot for my Bernina, but I used my buttonhole foot and it worked just fine. Any presser foot that allows a zigzag stitch can be used for sewing on buttons.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/B1-min.jpg)

1) Change your machine settings: a. Stich Width: 3-4 b. Stitch Length: 0 c. Needle Position: left d. Feed Control: lowered

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/B2-min.jpg)

2) Place your fabric and button under the foot and lower the needle into the left buttonhole. Lower your foot. 3) The zigzag stitch width is almost always between 3-4 because the distance between holes on a button is standard. Decorative buttons are an exception to this rule. 4) Adjust the zigzag and make a trial stitch by turning the hand wheel. Warning: if you hit the button going quickly, your button will likely break in half.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/B3-min.jpg)

5) Once you have the distance figured out, use the pedal to sew the button on.

![Mens Shirt Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Mens%20Shirt%20Basics/B4-min.jpg)

6) To finish, raise the needle. Set the zigzag width to 0 and sew a few fastening stitches in place. Youâ€™re done! Expert Tip: If you want a looser button, place a needle between the buttonholes (on top of your button) while sewing. #### Attaching a Collar Want to learn how to attach a collar with ease? Check out this quick and easy video tutorial! Thanks for following along! Be sure to check out fabric.com's Menswear Shop for all of your upcoming projects!

posts.markdown:
Created by: Trish Stitched Whether you're road tripping or jet setting, take off on your next getaway in style with this perfectly portable tote bag tutorial. Let's get started!

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0126.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0159.jpg)

####Supplies Needed * 1 yard vinyl (we used Marine Vinyl Gold) * 1 yard cotton (we used Art Gallery Observer Metallic Speck Bronze * 1 yard canvas (or alternative structured lining) * Pellon Fusible Interfacing 808 * 18â€ zipper * Wonder Clips Visit fabric.com to customize your tote bag with our vast selection of fabrics! ####Instructions First, click here to download the PDF pattern for this projectv and print at 100%. Print page 1 first, and measure the test square. If measurements are accurate, continue printing. If not, check your percentage/zoom and print again. #####Additional Pattern Pieces to Cut: * Interior Pockets: 15â€ x 21â€ Main Fabric * Straps: 25â€ x 2.75â€ (x4) Main Fabric * Bottom: 21â€ x 8â€ (1x) Vinyl, (1x) Lining Note: All Seam Allowances Â½â€ unless otherwise noted. Cut all your pattern pieces and interface cotton pieces.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0002-002.JPG)

With a Â½â€ seam allowance, sew vinyl bottoms to cotton tops for bag front, back and sides.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0008-002.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0013-003.JPG)

#####Make Your Straps With right sides together, sew two strap pieces along the long edges, leaving ends open. Turn right side out. Iron and topstitch. Repeat with second strap. Line the center of the strap with the center of the strap detailing, and clip in place. Topstitch around the edges.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3592%5B1380%5D.JPG)

#####Attach Your Straps With erasable fabric pen or chalk, mark where to sew straps on the front of your bag as shown on your pattern piece. Sew around the vinyl base Â¼â€, and again to make straps stronger.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3664%5B1383%5D.jpg)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3666%5B1385%5D.jpg)

#####Sew in Your Zipper Fold each zipper tab in half, wrong sides together. Attach zipper ends to folded edges and sew. Cut zipper piece in half, lengthwise. Sew the zipper in between your zipper band with your zipper foot (1/4â€). Topstitch zipper and trim zipper tabs to even out your zipper band. Sew each zipper band short edge to exterior sides.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0037-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0038-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0039-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0040-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0041-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0043-001.JPG)

#####Finish bag exterior Sew center bag band to front and back, taking extra time to match vinyl bottom seams. Start and end seam 1/2â€ in and backstitch. This will help when attaching the bottom of the bag. Open the zipper â€“ the top of the bag is where you will be able to turn your fabric right side out after attaching the bottom.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3668%5B1366%5D.jpg)

#####Attach the bottom Line up your bag corners with bag bottom corners, and clip along all sides. When attaching bag bottom, sew to corner and pivot, flattening the seam as you go.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3696%5B1376%5D.jpg)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/IMG_3707%5B1377%5D.jpg)

#####Make Bag Lining To make your interior pockets, fold pocket piece in half, wrong sides together, making piece 7.5â€ x 21â€. Iron and topstitch on the fold. Place raw edge of pocket bottom to raw edge of one lining body piece. Mark center and stitch through pocket and lining in the center.

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0026-001.JPG)

![Weekender Bag](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Weekender%20Travel%20Bag/DSC_0028-001.JPG)

Whether you're road tripping or jet setting, take off on your next getaway in style with this perfectly portable tote bag tutorial. Let's get started!

Supplies Needed

  • 1 yard vinyl (we used Marine Vinyl Gold)
  • 1 yard cotton (we used Art Gallery Observer Metallic Speck Bronze
  • 1 yard canvas (or alternative structured lining)
  • Pellon Fusible Interfacing 808
  • 18â€ zipper
  • Wonder Clips

Visit fabric.com to customize your tote bag with our vast selection of fabrics!

Instructions

First, click here to download the PDF pattern for this projectv and print at 100%. Print page 1 first, and measure the test square. If measurements are accurate, continue printing. If not, check your percentage/zoom and print again.

Additional Pattern Pieces to Cut:
  • Interior Pockets: 15â€ x 21â€ Main Fabric
  • Straps: 25â€ x 2.75â€ (x4) Main Fabric
  • Bottom: 21â€ x 8â€ (1x) Vinyl, (1x) Lining

Note: All Seam Allowances Â½â€ unless otherwise noted.

Cut all your pattern pieces and interface cotton pieces.

With a Â½â€ seam allowance, sew vinyl bottoms to cotton tops for bag front, back and sides.

Make Your Straps

With right sides together, sew two strap pieces along the long edges, leaving ends open. Turn right side out. Iron and topstitch. Repeat with second strap. Line the center of the strap with the center of the strap detailing, and clip in place. Topstitch around the edges.

Attach Your Straps

With erasable fabric pen or chalk, mark where to sew straps on the front of your bag as shown on your pattern piece. Sew around the vinyl base Â¼â€, and again to make straps stronger.

Sew in Your Zipper

Fold each zipper tab in half, wrong sides together. Attach zipper ends to folded edges and sew. Cut zipper piece in half, lengthwise. Sew the zipper in between your zipper band with your zipper foot (1/4â€). Topstitch zipper and trim zipper tabs to even out your zipper band.

Sew each zipper band short edge to exterior sides.

Finish bag exterior

Sew center bag band to front and back, taking extra time to match vinyl bottom seams. Start and end seam 1/2â€ in and backstitch. This will help when attaching the bottom of the bag. Open the zipper â€“ the top of the bag is where you will be able to turn your fabric right side out after attaching the bottom.

Attach the bottom

Line up your bag corners with bag bottom corners, and clip along all sides. When attaching bag bottom, sew to corner and pivot, flattening the seam as you go.

Make Bag Lining

To make your interior pockets, fold pocket piece in half, wrong sides together, making piece 7.5â€ x 21â€. Iron and topstitch on the fold. Place raw edge of pocket bottom to raw edge of one lining body piece. Mark center and stitch through pocket and lining in the center.

As with the exterior zipper band, cut lining zipper band in half. Fold center in Â½â€, to make room for the zipper. Attach zipper band ends to bag sides. (Pictured is Â¼â€ but Â½â€ fold results in cleaner finish)

The same as sewing the exterior bag, sew the lining pieces together, and attach lining bottom.

Attaching Lining to Bag

With the bag exterior right sides out, insert the bag lining, wrong sides together. Line zipper exterior with zipper band interior and hand stitch closed.

posts.title: Modern Crosses Quilt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Create a modern crosses quilt featuring trendy plus sign designs that can be used for top of bed quilts, baby blankets and so much more with this quick and easy tutorial! This project is perfect for beginners. It's great for combining solid fabrics with a fun print for the backing and binding, or you can even use a print for the crosses for a bolder look! This tutorial uses 5â€ finished squares for a crib sized quilt, but you'll want to use larger finished squares and rectangles for larger sizes.

![Modern Crosses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Crosses%20Quillt%20Tutorial/IMG_0901.jpg)

Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed #####For the Quilt Top: * 1 Â½ yards of neutral Kona Cotton fabric for the background (we used Kona Cotton White) * 1 1/8 yards of contrasting Kona Cotton fabric for the crosses (we used Navy, Silver and Iron Grey) ####For the Rest of the Quilt * Â½ yard quilting fabric for binding * 3 yards of solid or patterned quilting fabric for backing * Batting * Coordinating Thread ####Cutting From your background (white) fabric, cut (9) 5.5â€ strips by WOF (Width of Fabric). From your contrasting (grey) fabric cut (7) 5.5â€ strips. Subcut the white fabric into (36) 5.5â€ squares and (7) 15.5â€ rectangles. Subcut the grey fabric into (24) 5.5â€ squares and (8) 15.5â€ rectangles. ####Piecing Following the diagram below, piece your squares and rectangles into horizontal rows as shown. Piece rows together, matching seams as you go.

![Modern Crosses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Crosses%20Quillt%20Tutorial/cb-2787_blog_modernCrossesQuilt_diagramRows.png)

![Modern Crosses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Crosses%20Quillt%20Tutorial/cb-2787_blog_modernCrossesQuilt_diagramFull.png)

####Finishing Baste and quilt as desired. We used diagonal rows, using the corners of the squares and rectangles as a guide. Straight line quilting or stippling would also look great.

![Modern Crosses](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Modern%20Crosses%20Quillt%20Tutorial/cb-2766_blog_modernCrossesQuilt2.jpg)

Enjoy your easy and trendy quilt!

posts.title: Sewing 101: Hem Basics for Woven Fabrics
posts.markdown:
In this tutorial, we will show you 3 basic techniques for hemming! The finishing touches on any project secure the construction of the piece as well as provide a clean, functional finished look. Watch the video below for the full tutorial! Tip: Always press a hem before and after sewing for easy stitching and a clean finish. If youâ€™re concerned that the fold of the hem will indent the face fabric once ironed, use a press cloth. ####Topstitch Hem In this example, we used Kaufman Brussels Washer Linen Blend in Ocean.

![Hem Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Hem%20Basics%20Wovens/topstitch.PNG)

The most basic of hems, the topstitch hem is commonly used on a variety of projects including draperies, bedding, slacks, shorts, dresses, skirts, and outerwear. The key to this hem is just making sure the rough edge is secured in some way, whether itâ€™s folding it under, cut with a pinked edge, overlock stitched or serged. Pick your desired length and determine the extra fabric needed for the desired hem-length. For example, if youâ€™re making a skirt, and you want the skirt bottom to finish at 23â€, add 1â€ for a 1â€ topstitched hem, or 1 Â¼â€ for a 1â€ hem with Â¼â€ folded under. ####Narrow Hem For this example, we used Cotton + Steel Lawn in Toy Boat.

![Hem Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Hem%20Basics%20Wovens/narrow.PNG)

Just as common as the topstitch hem, this hem essentially is a top stitch, but with a very narrow fold. This hem is perfect to use for subtle hems that you donâ€™t want to add too much attention to, or delicate fabrics that wonâ€™t support a wider hem well, like very lightweight or sheer fabrics. You can achieve this hem in 1 of 2 ways: Simply fold the fabric under twice Â¼â€ each time, press and top stitch. Or, if the fabric does not cooperate easily with a double fold, edge stitch a wide fold first, trim excess fabric to 1/8â€, the fold again to topstitch a Â¼â€ narrow hem. This technique works really well with alteration hemming since it can easily accommodate excess fabric in the first step. ####Hand Whipstitch For this example, we used Kaufman Lush Velveteen in Royal.

![Hem Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Hem%20Basics%20Wovens/hand.PNG)

Sometimes hand hemming works better than machine sewing for fabrics that have a lot of movement during sewing, embellished fabrics with sequins or a dimensional design, or plush/lofty fabrics that would show obvious stitches like velvet, faux fur or minky. Like the topstitch hem, a very important aspect to this stitch is making sure the edge is finished first- either by serging, overlocking or folding under. With a hand needle and thread, carefully stitch the hem fabric to the back of the face fabric, by catching just a few threads to secure. Repeat this about every 3/8â€ along the hemline. The result is virtually an invisible stitch from the front, and a hemming experience that give you ultimate control.

![Hem Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Hem%20Basics%20Wovens/hand_catch.PNG)

Happy hemming! Click here to shop fabric.com's wide selection of fabrics for your next project.

![Hem Basics](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Sewing%20101%3A%20Hem%20Basics%20Wovens/all_hems.PNG)

Get to know The Scott Brothers, Drew and Jonathan Scott in today's Designer Spotlight Q&A! Find out what sewing projects are inspiring them, their favorite fabrics in their Scott Living fabric collection and some fun facts that may surprise you! ####About The Scott Brothers Multi-faceted entrepreneurs, best-selling authors and twin television personalities, Drew and Jonathan Scott are co-founders of Scott Brothers Global, which includes Scott Living and Scott Brothers Entertainment.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/Drew%20and%20Jonathan%20Scott%20Living%20Fabrics-min.jpg)

Scott Living is Jonathan and Drewâ€™s rapidly expanding collection of home goods, which includes indoor furniture, dÃ©cor, textiles and bedding.The Scott brothers are hosts of multiple top-rated HGTV series including the Emmy-nominated and Canadian Screen Award-winning Property Brothers, Brother vs. Brother and Property Brothers at Home, among others. Their shows are enjoyed by millions of viewers in over 150 countries and their books, Dream Home and It Takes Two: Our Story, are New York Times and Wall Street Journal best sellers. In 2017, the brothers were named Habitat Humanitarians, the highest recognition offered by Habitat for Humanity. ####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for design? JONATHAN: When we were young, probably about five or six years old, we used to rearrange all the furniture in the house whenever Mom and Dad left us with a babysitter. We always had ideas about how to improve or freshen things up. And when I performed as a magician, I also learned woodworking and metalworking in order to build illusions. But it wasnâ€™t until we graduated from high school that we decided to get into investing in real estate.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/Scott%20Living%20Fabrics%201-min.JPG)

####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. DREW: smart, clean, character JONATHAN: cozy, elegantly eclectic ####You partnered with Premier Prints to launch your line of fabrics. What made them the perfect partner for you? DREW: We strongly believe in finding partners who raise the bar like we do. We love working with people who love to work. Premier Prints brings great ideas and excellent quality to our venture. ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric or product that youâ€™ve designed, what would it be and why? JONATHAN: Our Scott Living Canal Luxe Linen Basketweave Vermillion Fabric is the right amount of everything. A beautiful, deep pop of red can add a little edge to any project.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/0581574.jpg)

DREW: I really like the Scott Living Dome Fabric we offer in our collection. Itâ€™s simple and approachable but still elegant.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/0517565.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in sewing / DIY? JONATHAN: You still canâ€™t beat making custom, full-height drapes and similar pillows. Itâ€™s an excellent way to tie a color or pattern throughout the space. DREW: My wife, Linda, has been making reusable cloth bags with our fabrics so that we donâ€™t need to waste plastic. I love them, and they look great.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/20170729-IMG_8540%20%282%29-min.jpg)

####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? JONATHAN: I just love seeing people get creative. Sewing projects are very rewarding because you can get a high-end custom look and itâ€™s not that difficult to pull off if you have the right equipment. Not to mention, you can brag about it every time somebody comes to the house! ####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? JONATHAN: I am making my pups, Gracie and Stewie, their own custom beds right now. Who says the pooches canâ€™t rock a little style too?

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/20170729-IMG_8386%20%282%29-min.jpg)

####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? DREW: Weâ€™re filming Property Brothers and Buying & Selling in Nashville right now. Other than the extreme humidity, weâ€™re having a blast. Youâ€™ll see a lot of incredible properties, and with each design youâ€™ll see at least one completely unique feature. Stay tuned! ####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? JONATHAN: I love to crank the music and surround myself with inspirationâ€”sometimes thatâ€™s other designers, sometimes itâ€™s a beautiful atmosphere. When diving headfirst into the creative process, no idea is a bad one because any idea could lead to a gem.

![Designer Spotlight](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Scott%20Brothers/Photo%20Feb%2019%2C%2011%2054%2033%20AM-min.jpg)

#### Tell us one thing people might not know about you. DREW: I actually went to college for kinesiology. I wanted to be a phys ed teacher or a personal trainer. JONATHAN: Iâ€™m a magician/illusionist and actually took costuming while attending the University of Calgary. I used to sew all my own costumes, curtains and props!

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/Supplies-min.jpg)

####Choosing a Swimwear Fabric It's important to use the right material for swimwear. I typically look for a Nylon Spandex blend with 4-way stretch. You will want to use high quality fabric with coverage. Nylon/Spandex blends are versatile for swim and athletic wear. Prints like this retro gingham and floral print inspire me to want to make my own Swimwear! You will also want to add a liner fabric suited for swimwear to the bottoms and the bust area.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/equipment%201-min.jpg)

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/equipment%202-min.jpg)

####Use the Right Equipment Serger: I am using my Brother Strong & Tough Serger and my Brother SE1900 Sewing and Embroidery Machine. It's ideal to have a serger but not necessary. A sewing machine will do just fine. I usually combine both my serger and my sewing machine.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/zigzag%20and%20serge-min.jpg)

I use the sewing machine to sew the pieces together and the serger to clean up the seam allowance. I find it easier to sew first due to the slippery nature of nylon/spandex materials. Plus if I have a mishap itâ€™s easier unpicking than an overlock stitch. ####Choosing a Pattern: There are plenty of options for swimsuit patterns. I wanted a one piece and went with the Alison Swimsuit from Burda Style.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/pattern%20-min.jpg)

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/pattern%20cutting%20-min.jpg)

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/pattern%20cutting%202-min.jpg)

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/all%20the%20pieces%20cut%20out-min.jpg)

When working with stretchy fabrics like spandex/nylon/polyester (or any knit for that matter), I use pattern weights, a rotary cutter, and mat to cut the pattern out. It's much easier this way, saves time, and great for slippery, stretchy materials like swimwear fabric. *Tip: if youâ€™re having trouble with the material shifting, try cutting the pattern piece 1 layer at a time (donâ€™t use folds). You may have to draft the other side or print out 2 sets but it will be worth it! ####Machine Setup You will want to use a ball point needle when sewing with spandex/knit fabrics or you may get skipped stitches. You will also sew with a zigzag stitch when using your sewing machine or a special stretch stitch that some machines have. I prefer a basic zigzag that is 2.0 wide and 2.5 length. This always does the trick for me. For finishing, I recommend using a twin needle. It has the finish similar of a Cover Stitch machine and a professional result. If using a serger just make sure to test out on the same fabric to get the tension dials correct before the final project. ####Use a Walking Foot This is a bigger foot, and may take some extra steps to secure but is worth it for sewing knits and stretchy materials. The walking foot is a moving feed system that holds and moves fabric between the presser foot's upper feed go and the machine's lower feed dogs to better control difficult fabrics (like knits/spandex/etc) as well as multiple layers of fabric. It came in handy when sewing the thicker layers of the spandex binding along the swimsuit edge.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/walking%20foot-min.jpg)

####Tips for Construction Most Swimwear is sewn with a 1/4" seam allowance- follow your pattern instructions for this. You most likely will be adding elastic leg bands which will keep the leg openings nice and tight around your legs.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/construction%201-min.jpg)

I like to add cups for additional support and coverage in my swimsuits. Follow that pattern instructions for these. I typically insert them in the bodice during construction. Then once I try the suit on for final fitting, Iâ€™ll pin them into proper placement and baste stitch them by hand on the back side (liner).

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/leg%20band%20collage-min.jpg)

For the leg bands you will want to use elastic. I am using Dritz 3/8" elastic. * Measure the opening and subtract 1". This will be the measurement you will want to cut the elastic to equal. Or refer to your pattern measurements. * Sew the elastic in a loop with a 1/2" over lap using a zigzag stitch. * Measure and mark off the quarters on both the leg opening and the elastic. * Pin the the elastic to the wrong side of the leg opening matching the quarter marks. * Sew with elastic on top using a zigzag (2.5 length 2.0 wide) close to the outer edge of the elastic (about 1/16 from the edge). As you sew pull the elastic to meet each quarter mark.

![Tips for Swimwear](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Tips%20for%20Sewing%20Swimwear/fold%20over%20elastic%20hem-min.jpg)

Now turn over the fold. Top stitch the fold into place about 1/4" from the edge or a little less than your elastic width. (make sure your getting the edge of the elastic). As you sew, pull, but also make sure the fabric is running perpendicular and flat or it will wave at the hem. We hope this post inspires you to try sewing your own swimwear! posts.title: Fabric 101: Linen
posts.markdown:
Today we're going to talk about one of our favorite fabrics- linen! Derived from the stem of the flax plant, linen is one of the worldâ€™s oldest textiles. Linen is one of the most breathable and absorbent fabrics, ideal for hot temperatures.

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-696921522-min.jpg)

Easy to sew with, linen is an ultra-versatile fabric that can be used in home dÃ©cor, fashion and even quilting. Watch the video below to learn more! Linen is one of the strongest and most durable natural fibers â€“ the ancient Egyptians used linen for mummification, and the US uses it blended with cotton for dollar bills! Linen fabric is usually a low-thread count even-weave cloth or sometimes knit. It has a natural slub variation in the fiber refinement process, giving the fabric a classic textured look. Linen is notorious for wrinkling, so either have your iron handy or embrace the inevitable.

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-958244098-min.jpg)

####Linen Blends When blended with other fibers, characteristics of linen are then transformed to acquire some characteristics of the joining fiber: * Linen/Rayon â€“ Rayon blended with linen creates a substantially softer fabric with more fluid drape and a subtle sheen from the rayon. * Linen/Cotton â€“ Cotton softens linen but keeps the fullness of linen and reduces the wrinkles drastically, while keeping a crisp look. * Linen/Polyester â€“ Polyester helps linen to wash better, wrinkle less, and retain color-fastness. Depending on the type of fabric, polyester usually softens the feel of linen as well, but in a synthetic way.

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-465073662-min.jpg)

Click here to shop Linen Blends on fabric.com! ####Caring for Linen You can machine wash 100% linen to soften it, or dry clean it to maintain a crisp hand. The more itâ€™s worn, used, or washed the softer it becomes!

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-467847657-min.jpg)

####Linen Versatility/Weights: * Very lightweight linen fabrics could be used for window sheers, a summer blouse, or a handkerchief. * Light to medium weight linens could be made into a classic linen suit, bedding, draperies or tablecloths. Lightweight linen blended with cotton can even be used for quilting. * Heavyweight linen is perfect for pillows or upholstery projects.

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-152514367-min.jpg)

![Fabric 101 Linen](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Fabric%20101%20Linen/iStock-870115020-min.jpg)

Fabric.com has a huge selection of linen fabrics. Shop a variety of solid colors, prints, blends, and weights! Happy Sewing!

posts.title: Retro Camper Pixel Quilt
posts.markdown: Created by Flamingo Toes Hi fabric.com readers! I'm so excited to have a new, fun Pixel quilt to share with you this summer! This Retro Camper Pixel Quilt is super easy to sew up and a great project even if you're a beginner quilter. Plus - who can resist retro campers?! I've used Vintage Adventure fabrics for this quilt - this is my first fabric line with Riley Blake Designs and I'm excited with how it looks with this quilt. The fabrics have vintage bicycles, retro campers, hot air balloons and lots of florals! ####Supplies Needed Quilt Size: 63" x 83" * White Tiny Floral- 1 yardÂ  - Top of Camper * White Solid with Tiny Triangles- 1/2 yardÂ  - Windows and Inside of Tire * Dark Gray- 1/2 yard -Â  Tire and Camper Hitch * Red Floral- 1/2 yardÂ Â  - Â Stripe on Camper * Dark Pink- 1 yard - Outline of Window and Door * Bicycle Light Pink- 1/2 yard - Curtains in Window and Door * Camper Aqua- 1 yard - Base of Camper * Trellis Gray- 3 yards - Background Gray * Trellis Aqua- 1/2 yard - Background Aqua (highlights in background) * Backing - 5 yards - Main Vintage Adventure Print * Binding - 1 yardÂ  - Red Stripe * fabric * Batting * Optional - DMC Pearl Cotton Black No. 8 for detail stitching Click here to shop the entire Vintage Adventure Collection! ####Pattern Download Click here to download the Retro Camper Pixel Layout. Or, if you would like to purchase a low cost, ad free PDF version of this pattern that is designed for easy printing,Â visit my shop.Â Thanks! ####Cutting Print out the quilt layout before you get started. This will help you know where the different colors go and how to sew everything together. I also recommend having a rotary cutter and mat for cutting out your squares. The process will go much quicker and beÂ  more accurate than cutting them out by hand. All the pieces for the quilt are cut at 2 1/2" x 2 1/2" squares. Cut your fabric into 2 1/2" strips, then cut those strips into 2 1/2" squares. Cut the fabrics into the following number of squares: White Tiny Floral - 160 (top of camper) White Solid - 37 (windows and tire) Dark Gray - 31 (tire and hitch) Red - 53 (camper stripe and detail on tire) Dark Pink - 94 (door and outline of window) Light Pink - 22 (curtains) Camper Aqua - 153 (base of camper) Background Gray -574 (background main) Background Aqua - 77 (background highlight) Keep workable stacks of your fabrics near your sewing machine so you can pull each color square as needed. Chain stitching will also make your piecing go much faster throughout the quilt. ####Assembly instructions: *Note: all seams are 1/4â€³ seam allowance Start with the top left block square on the pattern. Sew together the first and second blocks, right sides together, in all five rows of the top left block. Cut the blocks apart. Sew the third blocks in the column to the second blocks in each row. Repeat with columns four and five. You should now have 5 rows of 5 blocks. Press the seams to one side on the back but alternate which side you press to for each row. For example, press the top row to the left, the second row to the right, and so on. This will help the seams nest together. Sew row one to row two â€“ right sides together and meeting seams. Try to get the seams to line up, but also don't worry too much if they're the tiniest bit off. People will be so dazzled with your awesome camper quilt that they won't notice if a few of your seams are off. :) Continue sewing the top row of blocks together, just the way you did with block one. You should have 8 blocks for the first row. Sew the blocks together to form Row 1 of the quilt. Only 5 more to go! You can press the seams open, or press them to the left. If you press them to the side, press the row two seams to the right, and alternate as you continue down the rows so the seams nest together. Refer to the pdf pattern and repeat these steps down each row of the quilt. Because there are so many little squares, I found it easier to assemble each row as I completed the blocks. This keeps each block in the correct row and you can make sure you have the alignment and direction correct. Once you have all six rows finished, begin sewing the rows together. Sew row one to row two, lining up the block seams and pinning. Next, sew row 3 to row 2 and so on down the quilt. Press the long row seams open and give the quilt a final pressing. Quilt and bind as desired. Mine was quilted with an all over orange peel design byÂ Julie Williams. After quilting I decided I wanted my camper to pop a little more so I stitched around the entire outline of the camper with a running stitch using Black DMC Pearl Cotton. I love that it helps the white to stand out a little more on the gray background print! I can't wait to see your versions of the Camper quilt! If you share any photos on Instagram use the hashtag #camperpixelquilt so we can see how great they look! Click here to shop the entire Vintage Adventure Collection!

posts.title: Simple Elastic Waist Skirt Tutorial
posts.markdown:
A simple gathered skirt is a classic wardrobe staple, and they are surprisingly easy to make! Follow these simple steps to create a pattern suited for your measurements, for a flattering, beginner level skirt with an elastic waist. ####Supplies Needed: * 2 yards of fabric of your choice. We used Kaffe Fassett Cactus Dahlias Red cotton print fabric. Cotton prints, poplin, broadcloth, twill, linen, and denim are all great fabric options for this skirt! * Tape measure * Marking pen * 1â€ Knit elastic ####Making the Pattern: Take your waist measurement and measurement from your waist to where you want the skirt hem to finish and add 2â€. Fold your fabric in half, across the grain, right sides together. Along the fold, measure and mark the length of your skirt.

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/fold%20length.PNG)

For the width of the bottom of the skirt, use this calculation:

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/bottom%20formula.PNG)

For the waist measurement, simply divide the bottom line drawn on your fabric, divide by 2:

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/waist%20formula.PNG)

Connect the outer marks for the skirt sides To account for the curve of the body, measure 2â€ down on each line at the fold, and draw a curve.

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/drop%202.PNG)

Your skirt front pattern piece is done! Trace it for the back skirt piece and cut it out. *Tip: Extending the center hem of the back skirt piece 1â€ or more will allow for backside curves

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/pattern%20done.PNG)

In addition to the fabrics mentioned above, this skirt would work up beautifully in chambray, eyelet, lawn, rayon challis, chiffon, lace and more â€“ Just add a lining! Trace and cut 2 more skirt pieces out of the lining fabric, and shorten the skirt liner length by 2â€ ####Sewing the Skirt: Right sides together, join sides with 3/8â€ seams and finish seams as desired (overlock or zig zag stitch).

![Gathered Skirts](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Gathered%20Skirts/sew%20sides.PNG)

Use 1â€ knit elastic, and determine the length using this formula: waist measurement â€“ 2â€. Join the elastic with a Â¼â€ overlap zig zag stitch. Measure and mark the elastic and the skirt into fourths, and pin onto the underside of the skirt. (If adding a liner, place the sewn lining in the skirt before pinning and attaching the elastic.) Use a wide zig zag stitch to over-edge stitch and attach the elastic to the skirt. Stretch as you sew to ensure evenness.

Supplies Needed:

  • 2 yards of fabric of your choice. We used Kaffe Fassett Cactus Dahlias Red cotton print fabric. Cotton prints, poplin, broadcloth, twill, linen, and denim are all great fabric options for this skirt!
  • Tape measure
  • Marking pen
  • 1â€ Knit elastic

Making the Pattern:

Take your waist measurement and measurement from your waist to where you want the skirt hem to finish and add 2â€.

Fold your fabric in half, across the grain, right sides together.

Along the fold, measure and mark the length of your skirt.

For the width of the bottom of the skirt, use this calculation:

For the waist measurement, simply divide the bottom line drawn on your fabric, divide by 2:

Connect the outer marks for the skirt sides

To account for the curve of the body, measure 2â€ down on each line at the fold, and draw a curve.

Your skirt front pattern piece is done!

Trace it for the back skirt piece and cut it out.

*Tip: Extending the center hem of the back skirt piece 1â€ or more will allow for backside curves

In addition to the fabrics mentioned above, this skirt would work up beautifully in chambray, eyelet, lawn, rayon challis, chiffon, lace and more â€“ Just add a lining! Trace and cut 2 more skirt pieces out of the lining fabric, and shorten the skirt liner length by 2â€

Sewing the Skirt:

Right sides together, join sides with 3/8â€ seams and finish seams as desired (overlock or zig zag stitch).

Use 1â€ knit elastic, and determine the length using this formula: waist measurement â€“ 2â€. Join the elastic with a Â¼â€ overlap zig zag stitch. Measure and mark the elastic and the skirt into fourths, and pin onto the underside of the skirt.

(If adding a liner, place the sewn lining in the skirt before pinning and attaching the elastic.)

Use a wide zig zag stitch to over-edge stitch and attach the elastic to the skirt. Stretch as you sew to ensure evenness.

Fold the skirt waist over so that the elastic is concealed and top stitch.

posts.markdown:
In today's Designer Spotlight, meet Heather Givans of Crimson Tate Studios, who designs gorgeous fabrics for Windham Fabrics! ####About Heather Heather Givans is a creative force; fabric designer, quilt designer, national instructor, artist, and art educator. Heather creates community wherever she goes. Crimson Tate : Modern Quilter was born out of an obsession with creating non-traditional quilts from contemporary, modern, and repurposed vintage fabrics. Engineered by Heather Givans, Purdue University graduate of Art History, Art Education, and Fine Arts (Printmaking), Crimson Tate quilts are good design coupled with an attention to detail and craftsmanship.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/CB-2881_blog_heatherGivens_projects-min.jpg)

Heather learned to quilt when helping her mother fulfill a 30-year dream of learning to sew. Together, the two of them set off to quilt camp in the heart of the Midwest, where Heather fell in love with fabric, texture, patterns, and an amazing sea of sewers who possessed an endless wealth of sewing knowledge. With a hot cup of coffee on hand â€“ maybe a little too much cream â€“ and some great folk tunes, Heather began working on new designs in her basement located near Lake Superior in Duluth, MN. There, she enjoyed inspiration from the beautiful scenes surrounding her.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/Headshot_Heather_Givans02-min.jpg)

Today, Heather designs fabric for Windham Fabrics, works on new pattern designs, giggles contagiously, and teaches sewing with her energetic friends and staff among the hustle and bustle of Downtown Indianapolis. You can find her hanging out at 845 Massachusetts Avenue, an open to the public studio. ####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for art and design? As a kid, I loved art more than anything. I created treasure maps, home videos, grew my own flower garden, and surrounded myself with art books from the public library. Henri Matisse was always my favorite. I wanted to learn how to do all kinds of creative works. ####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. Whimsy, tonal, fun!

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/NIGHTHIKE_Final_9R1A8990-min.jpg)

####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release? I have two fabric collections out right now. Let me tell you about them both! Night Hike is an homage to my time at summer camp and also a little love note to my Grandma who lives in Northern Minnesota. The collection is inspired by the colors of the aurora borealis (the Northern lights) with deep purples and greens. I love how the light bounces off of the lake in a vibrant beautiful green hue. The collection contains lake maps, camp maps, tiny pine trees, fire flies, moths, and the night sky. All of these things are quintessential summer.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/NIGHTHIKE_Final_9R1A9367-min.jpg)

I also have a basics collection called JOT and itâ€™s filled with all kinds of blank paper in pale tones. College rule, elementary penmanship paper, scientific grid, ledger, library cards, and date stamps round out the collection. Did I mention that Iâ€™m a paper LOVER?! I love paper so much, almost as much as fabric. This basics collection folds in nicely with other collections as a background player.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/JOT_IMG_0256-min.jpg)

####You teamed up with Windham to create your line of textiles. What about Windham made them the perfect partner for you? Windham cares about art. Windham cares about artists. I am deeply appreciative that Windham Fabrics allows me create fabric collections. I am absolutely respected as an artist. They care about quality of goods and consistency of printing which is also important to me. I love those guys. They have made me feel like part of their family. I canâ€™t imagine a better company to partner with than Windham. Did you see all of those hearts in my eyes as I talked about them? ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric from your entire line, what would it be and why? What a tough question! Way Finding in Light Grey is my absolute favorite right now. It takes me right to the summer lake, standing on the shore fishing with my dad or riding in a pontoon with my grandma. Those memories are so strong in my mind and this fabric transports me swiftly to that place. I love it so much.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/0572893.jpg)

####What are your current favorite trends in sewing? I love improv piecing and quilting. I always am inspired by social justice quilts, too, albeit they arenâ€™t necessarily tending but rather a constant art statement.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/NIGHTHIKE_WishingStarQuilt-min.jpg)

####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? So often I am blown away at what people will make. Of course, I have a set of ideas that I think are awesome that I conceive while designing the fabric, like Wishing Star quilt. I knew I wanted those purples and blues and greys to all hang out together. But when I see someone make something I never would have thought of, Iâ€™m dumbfounded. And to see a project that is constructed for a momentous occasion, too, using my fabrics Iâ€™m humbled and in awe. Thatâ€™s a pretty awesome part of this job.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/NIGHTHIKE_R1A9723-min.jpg)

####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? I am in the midst of making a Personal Library quilt using Night Hike which Iâ€™m super excited about. I am also in the middle of making a more green-centric Wishing Star quilt for a good friend. She doesnâ€™t know about it so letâ€™s not say anything more about it! ;) Next on the list is Latifah Saafirâ€™s Clammy Half Circles quilt pattern made from JOT. Oh yeah! Iâ€™m excited about that one, too. ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? This list is vast and constantly being added to! Right now I am in awe and am inspired by words and works of these artists and authors: Chawne Kimber, Carolyn Friedlander, Christian Robinson, Jandy Nelson, Angie Thomas, Colson Whitehead and Yaa Gyasi. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018? Whatâ€™s next? Iâ€™m teaching workshops and lectures across the United States, which is pretty fun. Also, Iâ€™m always working on new patterns and fabric designs.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/NIGHTHIKE_FootnoteQuilt_Final_Night%20Hike_12-9_3800-min.jpg)

####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? I am OBSESSED with plants, mostly succulents and cactuses. Living in Indiana, Iâ€™ve outgrown my window space for the winter with all of the new plants Iâ€™ve started this summer. Eeeeeek! What am I going to do when cold weather arrives? Oh no.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Heather%20Givans/JOT_IMG_0262-min.jpg)

####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. I taught high school art for nearly 10 years. I love teaching art from painting, drawing, ceramics, printmaking, photography, to graphic design. There are days I miss teaching dearly but Iâ€™m loving riding this wave of awesome. Click here to shop fabrics by Heather Givans for Windham Fabrics!
