posts.title: Snack Pack and Lunch Tote Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Hi, it's Kimberly from Sweet Red Poppy and I'm here to share some back to school sewing inspiration with you today! The Hungry Caterpillar is one of my children's favorite books to read. When I found this fabric on fabric.com I knew I had to have it. It's just too perfect for a lunch tote and snack bag, right?

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_2839.jpg)

####Snack Pack Supplies * 1.5 yards The Very Hungry Caterpillar Fabric * 1 yard Clear Vinyl * 1 Package of Snap Pliers * 1 Package of Babyville Boutique Snaps * 1 Yard of Insul Fleece * 1 Roll of Ribbon * 1 Package of Double Fold Bias Tape * Sewing Machine * Iron

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1315.jpg)

####Snack Pack Instructions Cut two pieces of fabric, two pieces of vinyl and one piece of Insul Fleece 8.5" by 11" You can use a piece of printer paper as your guide for cutting out your fabrics. Lay the clear vinyl on top of the right side of the fabric. Cover with another piece of fabric and use a warm iron to adhere the vinyl to the fabric. Repeat this step for the lining fabric as well. The clear vinyl creates a waterproof barrier that protects the fabric from spills and stains. It can be easily cleaned with a wet washcloth. The Insul Fleece will help the snack bag to retain the inside temperature keeping your snacks cold throughout the day.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1272.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1275-2.jpg)

Layer the fabric with the laminated fabric right side facing down, then the Insul Fleece and then the laminated fabric with the right side facing upwards.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1279.jpg)

Using a rotary square up the edges to make sure all of the fabrics are aligned.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1281-2.jpg)

Use something round like a plate as a guide to trim the corners of the layered stack of fabrics. This will make it easier to apply the bias tape in the following step.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1282.jpg)

Sandwich the layered stack of fabric in between the bias tape. Carefully open the bias tape and slide it onto the fabric so that the edge of the fabric is pressing against the crease of the bias tape. Use plenty of pins to secure the bias tape. Gently pull the bias tape as you go around the corners.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1284.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1285.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1286-2.jpg)

Once you reach the end, fold the end of the bias tape under and press it with a hot iron. Layer it over the beginning of the bias tape. It's best to have the beginning and the ending of the bias tape fall along a straight edge.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1287.jpg)

Use clips or pins around the entire snack bag. I prefer using clips when working with a laminated fabric because it doesn't leave small holes in the fabric or puncture the vinyl.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1288.jpg)

Slowly stitch 1/4 inch from the edge around the entire strip of bias tape.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1290-2.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1293.jpg)

Fold up the bottom of the bag and clip or pin it in place.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1295.jpg)

Sew along the overlapping pieces of fabric to secure the fold in place.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1296.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1298.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1305.jpg)

Using the awl from the plier package make two holes in the front of the flap and two holes directly behind it.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1306.jpg)

Apply the snaps following the directions listed on the packaging.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1307.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1309.jpg)

This snack pack is very eco-friendly! Simply rinsing it out each time will save hundreds of zip locks or paper bags per year with your kids. ####Lunch Tote Supplies * 1.5 yards The Very Hungry Caterpillar Fabric * 1 Roll of Ribbon * Sewing Machine * Safety Pin * Iron

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1330.jpg)

####Lunch Tote Instructions Cutting Chart: Cut 2 12" x 12" Squares Cut 2 4" x 12" Rectangles Ribbon 50 inches

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1330.jpg)

Lay the main bag pieces on top of each other with right sides together. Sew along the sides and bottom with a 3/8th's inch seam allowance leaving the top open. Finish the edges on the bag and the contrast fabric with a zig zag stitch to prevent fraying.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1333-4.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1335.jpg)

Fold the edges of the contrast pieces under 3/8ths of an inch on each short side and press in place with a hot iron.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1337.jpg)

Fold the rectangle in half lengthwise with wrong sides together aligning raw edges and press again with an iron.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1338.jpg)

Align the raw edges of the contrast fabric with the raw edge of the bag. Pin around the entire top of the bag.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1339-2.jpg)

USing a 3/8ths inch seam allowance sew all three layers together.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1342.jpg)

Use a zig-zag stitch along the edge of the fabric to prevent fraying. Align the edge of the fabric with the needles furthermost right position.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1343.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1345.jpg)

With a hot iron, press the contrast fabric upwards and the seam allowance down towards the bag.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1346.jpg)

Thread the ribbon all the way through the contrast fabric until it appears next to where it started.

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_1348-2.jpg)

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_2840.jpg)

Tie a bow with the ribbon. Now you have an adorable lunch tote and snack pack for back to school!

![Designer Spotlight Heather Givans](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Back%20to%20School%20Lunch%20and%20Snack%20Bags/IMG_2838.jpg)

Click here to select the perfect fabric for your back to school projects on fabric.com!

  • 1 yard Clear Vinyl
  • 1 Package of Snap Pliers
  • 1 Package of Babyville Boutique Snaps
  • 1 Yard of Insul Fleece
  • 1 Roll of Ribbon
  • 1 Package of Double Fold Bias Tape
  • Sewing Machine
  • Iron

Snack Pack Instructions

Cut two pieces of fabric, two pieces of vinyl and one piece of Insul Fleece 8.5" by 11" You can use a piece of printer paper as your guide for cutting out your fabrics.

Lay the clear vinyl on top of the right side of the fabric. Cover with another piece of fabric and use a warm iron to adhere the vinyl to the fabric. Repeat this step for the lining fabric as well.

The clear vinyl creates a waterproof barrier that protects the fabric from spills and stains. It can be easily cleaned with a wet washcloth.

The Insul Fleece will help the snack bag to retain the inside temperature keeping your snacks cold throughout the day.

Layer the fabric with the laminated fabric right side facing down, then the Insul Fleece and then the laminated fabric with the right side facing upwards.

Using a rotary square up the edges to make sure all of the fabrics are aligned.

Use something round like a plate as a guide to trim the corners of the layered stack of fabrics. This will make it easier to apply the bias tape in the following step.

Sandwich the layered stack of fabric in between the bias tape.

Carefully open the bias tape and slide it onto the fabric so that the edge of the fabric is pressing against the crease of the bias tape.

Use plenty of pins to secure the bias tape. Gently pull the bias tape as you go around the corners.

Once you reach the end, fold the end of the bias tape under and press it with a hot iron. Layer it over the beginning of the bias tape.

It's best to have the beginning and the ending of the bias tape fall along a straight edge.

Use clips or pins around the entire snack bag. I prefer using clips when working with a laminated fabric because it doesn't leave small holes in the fabric or puncture the vinyl.

Slowly stitch 1/4 inch from the edge around the entire strip of bias tape.

Fold up the bottom of the bag and clip or pin it in place.

Sew along the overlapping pieces of fabric to secure the fold in place.

Using the awl from the plier package make two holes in the front of the flap and two holes directly behind it.

Apply the snaps following the directions listed on the packaging.

This snack pack is very eco-friendly! Simply rinsing it out each time will save hundreds of zip locks or paper bags per year with your kids.

Lunch Tote Supplies

  • 1.5 yards The Very Hungry Caterpillar Fabric
  • 1 Roll of Ribbon
  • Sewing Machine
  • Safety Pin
  • Iron

Lunch Tote Instructions

Cutting Chart:
Cut 2 12" x 12" Squares
Cut 2 4" x 12" Rectangles
Ribbon 50 inches

Lay the main bag pieces on top of each other with right sides together. Sew along the sides and bottom with a 3/8th's inch seam allowance leaving the top open.

Finish the edges on the bag and the contrast fabric with a zig zag stitch to prevent fraying.

Fold the edges of the contrast pieces under 3/8ths of an inch on each short side and press in place with a hot iron.

Fold the rectangle in half lengthwise with wrong sides together aligning raw edges and press again with an iron.

Align the raw edges of the contrast fabric with the raw edge of the bag. Pin around the entire top of the bag.

USing a 3/8ths inch seam allowance sew all three layers together.

Use a zig-zag stitch along the edge of the fabric to prevent fraying. Align the edge of the fabric with the needles furthermost right position.

With a hot iron, press the contrast fabric upwards and the seam allowance down towards the bag.

Thread the ribbon all the way through the contrast fabric until it appears next to where it started.

Tie a bow with the ribbon.

Now you have an adorable lunch tote and snack pack for back to school!

posts.title: Picking the Perfect Upholstery Fabric
posts.markdown:
If you are new to the world of upholstery, choosing the right fabric may seem like an arduous process. With all the fabrics (not to mention the colors and designs) available, how do you choose the one which is right for you? Here is some information on various fabric to help you select the right fabric for your furniture. ####Durability If you are planning to upholster something that will experience everyday wear and tear, durability is important to consider. Upholstery fabricâ€™s durability is determined by how it rates on the manufacturer-administered double rub test, which is a back and forth motion that mimics the wear and tear of someone sitting on an upholstered seat over time. The higher the number of double rubs, (for example 100,000 vs 10,000) the better the indicator of quality and durability. In addition to higher double rubs, look for upholstery fabrics treated for performance, like stain resistance, water repellant, or UV resistance. For upholstery projects that will not be used every day, like decorative or heirloom pieces, performance characteristics might not be as important, which opens up a wider variety including silk, wool, linen, cotton duck, embellished fabrics and more! Just look for home dÃ©cor fabrics in the medium to very heavyweight range. ####Fabric Care Upholstery fabric is often not suitable for traditional washing or dry cleaning once applied to furniture; therefore, you must follow the manufacturerâ€™s instructions and look for stain repellent fabrics for heavier-use pieces. Our recommendation for dry-cleaning is intended prior to upholstering, if cleaning before use is desired. Once upholstered, use spot cleaners intended for upholstery fabric, or upholstery cleaning services. Using a fabric protectant spray over your finished furniture is highly recommended. ####Fabric Types These common, upholstery fabrics come in a variety of weights, colors, fibers, and treatments to ensure you get the fabric you need for your project. * Chenille â€“ Excellent fabric choice for home usage, primarily heavier use pieces. Similar to velvet, it has a cut pile that aids in abrasion resistance and comfort.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/chenille.jpg)

Trend 03345 Chenille Blossom Fabric * Faux suede / Microfiber / Ultrasuede â€“ Typically a polyester multi-weave fabric with a surface abrasion treatment giving it a fuzzy, sueded pile to mimic suede, this fabric is an excellent choice for heavy-use family rooms and pets. Itâ€™s very strong, abrasion resistant and easy to clean.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/faux%20suede.jpg)

Swavelle/Mill Creek Zadak Suede Oat Fabric * Velvet â€“ Velvet has a dense cut pile, making it luxuriously soft with a sheen. Velvet can stand up to heavy usage, and is an attractive choice for most homes. Cleans best when spill or stain is tended to immediately.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/velvet.jpg)

Crypton Home Birch Velvet Peacock Fabric * Basketweave / Tweed â€“ These textured woven fabrics hide stains and wear well, and can be used in any upholstery application depending on their double rub rating. Higher double rubs will reduce pilling and fabric pulls.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/basketweave.jpg)

Crypton Home Garrett Basketweave Aegean Fabric * Faux Leather â€“ Easy to clean and makes a great choice for childrenâ€™s furniture and other high-usage pieces. Clean and condition appropriately to reduce risk of cracking.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/faux%20leather.jpg)

Breathable Faux Leather Espresso Fabric * Marine Vinyl â€“ Made to resist weather and harsh elements, marine vinyl is a leather look vinyl that is extremely durable and easy to clean. Richloom Fortress Marine Vinyl Outing Royal Fabric * Jacquard â€“ Typically a heavier fabric, it has yarn dyed fibers that create a pattern, giving the fabric texture and style. Good fabric choice for home usage, primarily moderate use and decorative pieces.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/jacquard.jpg)

P/Kaufmann Carpet Heirloom Jacquard Peacock Teal Fabric * Duck/Canvas â€“ A strong, plain weave fabric, ideal for printed designs. When made of cotton, this fabric shape can warp over time with heavy-use, so it should be used on moderate-use furniture, decorative pieces or pillow accents.

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/canvas.jpg)

Golding by P/Kaufmann Scout Stripe Canvas Navy Fabric ####Fibers These are common fibers used in upholstery fabrics. They can be 100% or blended with other fibers to join characteristics. These fibers can be made up into a variety of fabric types, which also have an effect on their performance: * Cotton â€“ breathable, comfortable, and budget-friendly. Not fade resistant. * Linen â€“ Very strong and breathable and classic. Less resistant to stains and fading, should not be used for heavy-use, but excellent for heirloom pieces. * Wool â€“ Luxurious, great texture and feel, keeps its shape, less resistant to stains â€“ look for stain resistance treatmemt or a blend. * Silk â€“ Luxurious and strong, but should not be used for everyday. * Rayon / Viscose â€“ Adds softness when blended with other fibers, not durable. * Polyester â€“ Durable, easy to clean, low â€“ moderate abrasion resistance â€“ it can pill if double rub rating isnâ€™t high enough. * Nylon â€“ Durable, high abrasion resistance, easy to clean. * Acrylic â€“ Very durable, color fast, easy to clean, great for heavy-use upholstery. * Olefin â€“ Very durable, color fast, easy to clean, great for heavy-use upholstery. ####Color Your color choice is also dependent upon the type of use your furniture will see. A natural beige color is a popular choice for hiding dirt as well as being a neutral that can go with many different dÃ©cor styles. Consider lighter solid colors to create an airy, inviting mood in a space. Darker colors or patterns are better for hiding dirt and wear. Or you can always select a bright color or a fun, bold pattern to make a statement in your space!

![Upholstery](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Picking%20Perfect%20Upholstery%20Fabric/justina_chair_IG.jpg)

Fabric.com offers over 20K upholstery fabrics online, with swatches available, and free shipping on domestic orders $49 or more. We hope this guide to upholstery fabrics helps to point you in the right direction for your fabric selection. Happy sewing!

posts.markdown:
In today's designer spotlight, meet Maija Loukari! Maija designs home decor fabrics for world famous brand Marimekko.

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/Maija_louekari.jpeg)

Maia has designed many of Marimekko's most iconic prints, like this Rsymatto Cotton Black Fabric.

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/r%C3%A4symatto_190.jpg)

####About Marimekko This Finnish broadcloth fabric features a crisp hand and bold prints that are perfect for mod apparel creations like crisp button-downs, lined dresses and skirts, bags, and lighter home decor uses like curtains, toss pillows, duvet covers, and more. Marimekko's fabric quality is second to none. Check out this behind the scenes look at Marimekko's amazing fabric dye process!

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/Marimekko_dye_2012-16.jpg)

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/Marimekko_dye_2012-8.jpg)

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/Marimekko_dye_2012-14.jpg)

![DS](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Maija%20Louekari%20Marimekko/Marimekko_dye_2012-17.jpg)

###Q&A with Maija Louekari Now let's get to know Maija Louekari! ####When did you realize you had a passion for art and design? There wasnâ€™t a real moment when I realized it. I have always loved everything beautiful in life; like music, colours in the sky or fantastic interior. ####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. Bright colours. 50 shades of white. Flowers. ####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release? The KaalimetsÃ¤ (cabbage forest) fabric I designed for Marimekkoâ€™s Fall 2018 collection is inspired by our own home garden here in Helsinki. We have lots of kale there; it looks like a miniature forest. ####How did you first partner with Marimekko? How has Marimekko helped bring your designs to life on fabric? In 2003 I won a design competition co-organised by Marimekko and the University of Art and Design Helsinki. The pattern that I designed for the competition, HetkiÃ¤ (moments), is still part of Marimekkoâ€™s fabric collection. We designers have a great freedom in designing new patterns with different kinds of hand drawn techniques. Marimekkoâ€™s design studio is located in the same building with the in-house printing factory where 1 million meters of fabric is printed every year â€“ this allows us designers to work closely with the craftsmen printing our designs to fabric step by step. ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric from all of your designs, what would it be and why? That changes all the time as I tend to like the most my latest designs. The dearest Marimekko project for me was the designs I did for Marimekkoâ€™s Oiva (superb) tableware series that was launched in 2009. I first designed the prints that were inspired by small city gardens in Helsinki to match the shapes of ceramics. Later the same prints were scaled for fabrics and other products too. ####What are your current favorite trends in home dÃ©cor or DIY? Functionality first in home dÃ©cor too: anything to hide all the Legos we have currently on the floor at home. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? I love to see customers creating DIY projects with my fabric that are meaningful for them and that bring joy to the everyday life. I would be honored to see for example a blanket created for a newborn baby with one of my fabrics. ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? From home dÃ©cor, I like Danish brand Hay and visit their store always when I have a chance. From fashion, I love Balenciaga and Vetements! ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018/2019? Whatâ€™s next? Marimekkoâ€™s Oiva (superb) tableware and its Siirtolapuutarha (city garden) prints will have their 10th anniversary next year. I have designed a new print to celebrate this milestone and we have other celebratory items in the making too. ####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? Bicycling next to the sea here in Helsinki with my kids and husband. And eat everything colourful, especially now during summer! ####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. Maija: I eat chocolate every day. Click here to shop all Marimekko fabrics!

The dearest Marimekko project for me was the designs I did for Marimekkoâ€™s Oiva (superb) tableware series that was launched in 2009. I first designed the prints that were inspired by small city gardens in Helsinki to match the shapes of ceramics. Later the same prints were scaled for fabrics and other products too.

What are your current favorite trends in home dÃ©cor or DIY?

Functionality first in home dÃ©cor too: anything to hide all the Legos we have currently on the floor at home.

What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)?

I love to see customers creating DIY projects with my fabric that are meaningful for them and that bring joy to the everyday life. I would be honored to see for example a blanket created for a newborn baby with one of my fabrics.

What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most?

From home dÃ©cor, I like Danish brand Hay and visit their store always when I have a chance. From fashion, I love Balenciaga and Vetements!

Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2018/2019? Whatâ€™s next?

Marimekkoâ€™s Oiva (superb) tableware and its Siirtolapuutarha (city garden) prints will have their 10th anniversary next year. I have designed a new print to celebrate this milestone and we have other celebratory items in the making too.

What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating?

Bicycling next to the sea here in Helsinki with my kids and husband. And eat everything colourful, especially now during summer!

Maija: I eat chocolate every day.

posts.title: Rainbow Unicorn Costume Tutorial & Pattern
posts.markdown:
Halloween is just around the corner and itâ€™s our favorite time of year. If you happen to have a little one who is dreaming of Trick-or-Treating as a unicorn, then today is your lucky day! Fabric.com is excited to offer tulle fabric by the bolt in every color of the rainbow!

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/Unicorn4.jpg)

We have just the pattern you need to make her dreams come true. Itâ€™s a Rainbow Unicorn Hood, Skirt, and Hooves that you can use to dress up a shirt and a pair of leggings. Let's get started! ####Supplies Needed * 1/2 yard White knit with spandex * 3 yards Pink Tulle Fabric * 3 yards Purple Tulle Fabric * 3 yards Turquoise Tulle Fabric * 3 yards Green Apple Tulle Fabric * Â½ yard Gold Stretch Lame * Â½ yard medium weight fusible stabilizer * 14â€™â€™ of sew-in hook and loop tape (5/8â€˜â€™ wide) * 24â€™â€™ of Elastic (1â€™â€™ wide) * Small amount of stuffing * Stretch sewing machine needle * Binding clips or safety pins * Rotary cutter and mat ####Pattern Download Click here to download the free pattern for this rainbow unicorn costume! *Note: This pattern is for a size 2T-4T. ####Cutting & Pattern Prep * Print pattern pages and tape them together into a grid as instructed on the PDF file. To assemble the grid, cut one short side and one long side off of each page to make it easier to tape together. Cut out pattern pieces. * Fold the fabric in half to quickly cut out the pieces 2 at a time. Lay all the pieces out on the fabric for placement before cutting. * Pay attention to the â€œstretchâ€ lines on the fabric and place those lines parallel to the direction the fabric stretches the most. * Use pattern weights to hold the patterns in place while cutting. Table knives from your kitchen work great in a pinch. * After cutting, transfer Ear placement markings onto 2 of the Hood Side Panels and transfer the Mane placement markings onto the Outer Hood Center Panels. #####From the white knit fabric cut: 4 pieces using the Hood Side Panel pattern (2 Right Side Hoods, 2 Left Side Hoods) 1 piece using the Hood Lining Center Panel pattern 2 pieces using the Outer Hood Center Panel pattern (1 Right Side panel, 1 Left Side panel) 4 pieces using the Ear pattern #####From the Gold Lame fabric cut: 1 piece using the Horn pattern 4 pieces using the Wrist Hoof pattern 4 pieces using the Ankle Hoof pattern #####From the medium weight fusible interfacing cut: 2 pieces using the Ear pattern 4 pieces using the Wrist Hoof pattern 4 pieces using the Ankle Hoof pattern #####From the Tulle cut: 3 stacks (16 layers thick) of 3â€™â€™ x 5â€™â€™ strips from each color for the Mane (12 stacks total). 4 stacks (16 layers thick) of 3â€™â€™ x 12â€™â€™ strips from each color for the Skirt (16 stacks total). *Tip: Cutting the tulle into 16 layer stacks is easiest done by folding the tulle into 8 layers, cutting two 7 inch strips (14â€™â€™ for the Skirt stacks), and stacking them on top of each other. Then use a rotary cutter and mat to square off the edges and cut the strips. tulle tends to get unruly quickly. Keep it stacked up nicely by clipping the layers together with binding clips on one end. Trim a corner off of each stack to create a curved end on each strip. Note: If the tulle is wrinkled iron it before cutting for best results. Keep your Iron setting low to start with so you donâ€™t melt the tulle.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%201.jpg)

####Sewing Instructions *All seams are sewn with a 1/2â€˜â€™ seam allowance unless otherwise specified. ####Make the Hood Lining With right sides together pin a Right Hood Side Panel to the Hood Lining Center Panel. Sew the panels together.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%202.jpg)

With right sides together, pin a Left Hood Side Panel to the other side of the Hood Lining Center Panel. Sew them together. Press the seams open as much as possible with a warm iron. Set this Hood Lining aside.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%203.jpg)

####Make the Ears Fuse the Medium weight interfacing to the wrong side of two Ear pieces. With right sides together sew a interfaced Ear piece to a plain Ear piece along the curved edges of the triangle with a 1/4â€™â€™ seam. Clip and notch the curves and point. Turn right side out and press. Repeat for the 2nd Ear.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%204.jpg)

Fold each ear in half at the base and tuck the fold in to make a little pleat so that the Ear stands open a little easier.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%205.jpg)

Baste the Ears onto the right side of a Right and a Left Hood Side Panel between the Ear placement marks. Make sure the Ears are facing forward. Set aside.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%206.jpg)

####Make the Mane Set the machine to sew a gathering stitch (5-6mm stitch length). Sew a row of gathering stitches about 3/8â€™â€™ away from the short, straight end of a stack of 3â€™â€™ x 5â€™â€™ strips. Alternating colors, place the next stack right next to the other and continue to sew along the top connecting the stacks together. Alternate stacks in a rainbow pattern and make sure the curved ends are going the same direction. Sew a 2nd row of gathering stitches 5/8â€™â€™ from the edge.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%207.jpg)

Pull the top 2 threads evenly from each side and gather the Mane so that each 3â€™â€™ strip shrinks down to 1â€™â€™.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%208.jpg)

Set the machine back to a regular stitch length (3 mm). With the right side of the fabric facing the Mane, pin the Mane to the straight side of an Outer Hood Center Panel between the Mane placement markings. Make sure the curved ends point toward the Neckline. Sew between the 2 rows of gathering stitches with a 1/2â€™â€™seam.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%209.jpg)

Pin the 2nd Outer Hood Panel to the the mane with right sides together and stitch in place along the same 1/2â€™â€™seam line.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2010.jpg)

####Finish the Hood Sew the Outer Hood together in the same fashion as the Hood Lining. (See steps 1-2). Check every few inches to make sure the layers of the knit lay flat as you sew. It is easy to for them to bunch up underneath if you are not careful. Press all seams open as best as you can.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2011.jpg)

Sew a row of stay stitches in the seam allowance at the base of each Ear with the seam allowance folded toward the Hood Side Panel. This will help the ears to stand up.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2012.jpg)

With right sides together, match the seams of the Hood Lining and the Outer Hood and pin them together around the face opening and all along the neckline. Making sure the Mane doesnâ€™t get caught in the seam, sew around all the edges leaving a 4â€™â€™ opening in the bottom of the neckline for turning.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2013.jpg)

Trim the corners and clip into the seam allowance of the curves.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2014.jpg)

Turn the Hood right side out through the opening and press around the edges so the Hood Lining sits nicely inside the Outer Hood. Pin the opening closed. Sew all the way around the Hood about 1/8â€™â€™ away from the edge. Attach the Hook and Loop tape to the front flaps by stitching around it close to the edge. It is helpful to sew around the tape twice if the Hood is going to be used a lot for dress up. Also, remove any gathering stitches that are showing on the Mane.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2015.JPG)

####Make the Horn Sew a row of stitches 1/2â€™â€™ away from the curved base of the Horn. This marks the line where the Horn will meet the Hood. Sew a row of gathering stitches about 1/4â€™â€™ away from the same edge.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2016.jpg)

Fold the horn in half with right sides together and stitch along the side with a Â½â€™â€™ seam allowance. Clip the corner at the point.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2017.jpg)

Turn the Horn right side out and stuff it. Use small bits at first to help fill up the point. Stuff it just enough for the Horn to be firm but not distorted. Pull a gathering thread to cinch the end a little until the fabric folds along the 1/2â€™â€™ stitch line.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2018.jpg)

Pin the Horn just in front of the Mane, overlapping the Mane about 1/4â€™â€™ Hand stitch the Horn through both layers of the hood coming up with the needle just to the outside of the stitching line on the Horn so it disappears as you sew.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2019.jpg)

####Make the Skirt Cut a piece of 1â€™â€™ elastic to the length of your childâ€™s waist. Using the longer stacked strips of Tulle fold the straight end over the elastic about 1 1/2â€™â€™. Stitch along the edge creating a casing for the elastic. Do not sew on the elastic. Continue to add the strip stacks in a rainbow pattern. Pin the end of the elastic to the first tulle strip so it doesnâ€™t slide out. While keeping the needle down on the machine slide the elastic through the casing to gather the strips of tulle making room for the rest of the strips to be sewn onto the elastic.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2020.jpg)

When all the strips are sewn together, pull out the ends of the elastic and overlap them about 1/2â€™â€™. Stitch the elastic together in a few places using a zig zag stitch. Backstitch a few times to secure. Smooth the gathers out evenly and your skirt is done.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2021.jpg)

####Make the Hooves Fuse a piece of stabilizer to the wrong side of each Hoof piece. With right sides together sew around the Hoof using a 1/4â€™â€™ seam allowance. Leave an opening for turning along a straight side. Clip the corners and the curves.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2022.jpg)

Turn the Hoof right side out and stitch a strip of hook and loop tape to each straight side. Repeat for each of the Hooves. You should have 2 small ones for the wrists and 2 larger ones for the ankles.

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2023.jpg)

I think the Hooves make a fun little detail to finish off the costume donâ€™t you?

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/PHOTO%2024.jpg)

![Unicorn](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Rainbow%20Unicorn%20Costume/Unicorn1.jpg)

Happy costume making!!

posts.title: Tips for Sewing Corduroy Fabric + Jenny Overalls Project
posts.markdown:
Hello everyone! Sara of The Sara Project here, and back with another fun post for you! Letâ€™s start off with a question: what is fall without corduroy? Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of great corduroy garments popping up in the ready to wear world lately. I fell in love with a pair of gold cord overalls I came across at Madewell recently, and headed over to fabric.com to find a similar fabric to copy the look. Oh my goodness, what a gorgeous selection of corduroy options they have! I quickly found the color Cider and knew that this project had to happen. Also, how yummy does the color Cider sound? I think I would wear anything with the name Cider.

![Corduroy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Corduroy%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20and%20Overalls/DSC_0084_2.jpg)

![Corduroy](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Corduroy%20Tips%20for%20Sewing%20and%20Overalls/DSC_0011.jpg)

I looked through a few different overall pattern options for this project, and decided to go with the Closet Case Patterns Jenny Overalls. I love the high waist, and construction details of this pattern. Even better, fabric.com is now carrying some indie sewing patterns, including this one. So exciting! Iâ€™m here today to share my Jenny Overalls plus 8 tips for sewing with corduroy fabrics! ####8 Tips for Sewing with Corduroy These 8 tips will help you know how to choose your fabric, how to treat corduroy fabric and the best ways to use it while sewing. Letâ€™s begin! 1) When purchasing corduroy fabric online, pay attention to the wale count. This will inform you of how many wale stripes can be counted in one square inch and will help you determine if the fabric you are considering has a wider wale stripe or a more narrow wale stripe. This is important to pay attention to when planning out your project, depending on what look you are going for. A wider wale cord is very in style for fall this year, and gives the garment a more vintage vibe. Iâ€™m loving this trend! 2) Make sure to pre-wash your fabric. ![Holiday Baking Aprons](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Baking%20Aprons/photo%2011-min.jpg)

Try on and adjust the length. Fold the hem over by 1â€ twice and sew in place and press. Youâ€™re done! Hope you have many wonderful days of making and creating looking cute in your cross back aprons!

posts.title: 1 Fabric, 3 Ways: Telio Tencel Linen
posts.markdown:
Created by: Self Assembly Required I love the versatility of fabric. People will pick up the exact same materials and imagine completely different ways of using it. Itâ€™s amazing how much something can be made into so many diverse garments! When fabric.com challenged me to using one fabric in three different ways, I leapt at the chance to put my imagination to the test and come up with three gorgeous items! The fabric I chose was from Telio's Tencel Linen Collection â€“ a right on trend gorgeous brick red cupro/tencel/linen mix which has a gorgeous sheen to it. Iâ€™m a big fan of using more eco-friendly fibers like tencel and cupro where I can! Besides being made in environmentally conscious ways, these fibers retain all the goodness of cotton like being moisture wicking, breathable, and soft. This fabric has a bit of weight to it and a lovely drape which made it perfect for the three projects I had in mind! The first of which is the perfect fall skirt! I used the McCallâ€™s 7813 skirt pattern to create a midi length wrap skirt. I chose to make View A which shows of a high waist, A-line shape and a fabric belt. This was a beautifully easy garment to sew up. I opted to use a proper button instead of the sew in metal snap the pattern recommends just so I felt a little more secure in it but itâ€™s covered by the belt either way!

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00004.jpeg)

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00003.jpeg)

The fabric flows beautifully as I walk in this skirt! This skirt, heels and a chunky knit sweater combo is definitely going to be a wardrobe staple this winter.

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00009.jpeg)

My second make with this fabric uses a pattern that Iâ€™ve been planning on making for a very long time. Itâ€™s the Kalle shirt/ shirtdress from Closet Case Patterns! OK, so this make might be a little out of season for the UK right now since itâ€™s getting a little chilly right now but I just couldnâ€™t help it! When you know a pattern and fabric are the right match, sometimes you just have to go for it. I made the dress version of the Kalle with the popover placket. I chose to do the popover over the regular button band for no reason other than to try something new! I love challenging myself and with instructions from Closet Case Patterns, I knew it would be a great opportunity to try a new technique.

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00006.jpeg)

This one will be perfect with sandals or trainers in the summer though I might need to start layering it up because I donâ€™t think I can wait that long to wear it!

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00007.jpeg)

My third (and favourite make) is the jumpsuit I made using the Butterick 5652 pattern. I had a feeling before I started sewing these garments that this would be my favorite and I was right â€“ I always love a jumpsuit! The pattern comes with several different views â€“ a tunic, dress, jumpsuit and pants â€“ all simple and very loose fitted. Itâ€™s one of those patterns where you know in the right fabric and styled well would look amazing! I think mine turned out pretty well!

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00005.jpeg)

I adjusted the pattern slightly on mine to lower the neckline a little. I also finished it with a facing instead of a bias binding. I shortened the torso by an inch and lengthened the leg by 2 inches. Lots of little adjustments to make it just right! It does need to be belted though but luckily Iâ€™d already made a fabric one from my skirt project!

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/jumpsuit2.jpg)

I love how such a simple pattern can be transformed into quite a glamorous looking outfit with the right fabric! So these are my three garments! Theyâ€™re the perfect rust toned additions to my wardrobe that can be worn year round. Iâ€™m so pleased with how theyâ€™ve turned out. Click here to shop all Telio Cupro Tencel Linen!

![1 Fabric 3 Ways](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/1%20Fabric%203%20Ways/image00008.jpeg)

posts.markdown:
In today's Designer Spotlight, meet Dear Stella Designer Rae Ritchie! ####About Rae Ritchie In 2006, Rae Ritchie started out in the fashion industry, designing womenâ€™s and kidsâ€™ fashion accessories for major retailers. â€œIt was creative,â€ she said, â€œbut I most felt alive while creating prints and graphics for those products.â€ She was always drawing and painting on the side, so Rae decided to focus on fabric design and illustration for greeting cards, stationary, gifts and apparel.

![DS Rae Ritchie](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Rae%20Ritchie/IMG_5155-min.JPG)

Rae lives with her husband and her cat Nomi in Minneapolis, MN. â€œMy watercolor and gouache paintings are created in a sunny little room in my home,â€ she said. Rae confesses that sheâ€™s greatly inspired by the lushness of nature, classic children's books and old photographs. ####Q&A ####When did you realize you had a passion for art and design? Being the daughter of a photographer/art teacher and a musician, Iâ€™ve experimented with many art forms from an early age. As a younger child, mom always kept us busy with various projects, from Sculpey clay jewelry and tie-dye to drawing and oil painting. As a young teenager I was obsessed with writing and performing songs, playing guitar, painting and sewing my own clothes. I feel like there was no other option from me than to pursue a career in a creative field! ####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. Magical, antique, lush

![DS Rae Ritchie](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Rae%20Ritchie/Gingko2-min.jpg)

####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release? My favorite of the releases is â€œNatural Historyâ€ which has an interesting inspiration story! In January of this year, I was fortunate enough to travel to Frankfurt, Germany for work! Since I was going over to Europe anyway, I decided to make a 3 day stop in London and museum, HARD! My favorite museum was of course, the Natural History Museum. Everything about it; the building, the specimens, the feeling; I just fell in love. ####You teamed up with Dear Stella to create your line of textiles. What about Dear Stella made them the perfect partner for you? I really enjoy working with Dear Stella. They really took a chance on me, and I couldnâ€™t be more grateful. What I really love is the freedom theyâ€™ve given me to explore my ideas and also their high level of enthusiasm for the quilting industry! ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric from your entire line, what would it be and why? The fungi print from â€œNatural Historyâ€ It reminds me of an old botanical print, invoking moods of victorian apothecaries and William Morris wallpaper.

![DS Rae Ritchie](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Rae%20Ritchie/NatHist2-min.jpg)

Several that have really caught my eye are those using embroidery to artfully add their own illustrative elements to my prints! Itâ€™s an amazing way to collaborate. ####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? I would really like to make a flowy sack dress! I have one that I purchased when American Apparel was closing their stores. Myself and two of my friends all bought the "one sizeâ€ frock, endearingly referring to it as â€œThe Dress.â€ It works for all occasions and I would love to make more! I also always have a good knitting project in the works! Right now Iâ€™m making some warm thigh high heather gray wool socks (I do live in Minnesota after all!). Next, Iâ€™d like to make a cocoon sweater.

![DS Rae Ritchie](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Rae%20Ritchie/IMG_6681-min.JPG)

####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? I love spooky beauty brands! Packaging in general is always very inspirational to me, but my favorite beauty brand is Black Phoenix Apothocary. They make an amazing Alice and Wonderland perfume oil line, as well as a huge Neil Gaiman perfume collaboration, which makes me VERY happy! I also follow a lot of amazing tattoo artists in the etching type of style, like Rachel Hauer and the Lacemakersâ€™ Sweatshop @thelacemakerssweatshop. ####Whatâ€™s coming up for you in 2019? Whatâ€™s next? Iâ€™d really like to continue doing what Iâ€™m doing, but hopefully add in more editorial/book work. Iâ€™ve illustrated for other authors books, but not yet a story of my own. Weâ€™ll see! ####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? One of my favorite pastimes is physical activity! I ran my first (and probably last) marathon in 2017 (Twin Cities Marathon). It was by far the most difficult thing Iâ€™ve ever done! Iâ€™m also an avid cycler, and my favorite new activity in that realm is bike packing/camping. It makes for some great adventures! Iâ€™ve also been having fun doing a little climbing at an indoor bouldering gym here in Minneapolis! Iâ€™m also getting back into knitting recently, which was an activity that dominated my life about 5 years ago. I used to be a cold weather head and hand designer, and also knitted and crocheted sweaters and other items on the side! Now I usually just hand knit socks because theyâ€™re small and useful!

![DS Rae Ritchie](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Rae%20Ritchie/NatHist5-min.jpg)

posts.title: Holiday Mini Quilt Blocks Tutorial
posts.markdown:
Created by: Kristi McDonough of Schnitzel & Boo The holiday season is upon us! Every year it seems to sneak up just a little bit faster, doesnâ€™t it? Every year, I say Iâ€™m going to make something festive for my house and every year I am too busy to do it. This year I decided was going to be different! I knew I had to make something small, something that could be accomplished in small increments, or all in one evening. Here are five fast, simple and cute mini blocks for you to make this season. You can even turn these into mug rugs, table runners, mini quilts, pillows, placemats, and more! Let's get started! *Note: All seams are a scant 1/4â€, unless otherwise stated. Spray starch is strongly recommended, but not required. ####Fabrics Used To create these mini blocks, we combined two of our favorite festive pre-cut bundles:The Riley Blake Crayola Fat Eighth Christmas bundle and the Robert Kaufman Artisan Batiks Snowflakes Fat Quarter bundle.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/0603533.jpg)

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%205%2056%2032%20PM-min.jpg)

You can use any quilting fabric to create these blocks! Click here to shop all quilting fabric and select your favorites. ####Wreath Mini Block

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0557-min.jpg)

From Background Fabric, cut: 1- 3.5â€ square 4- 1.5â€ squares From Green Fabric, cut: 4- 1.5â€ squares 2- 1.5â€x5.5â€ 1- 1.5â€x3.5â€ 2- 1.5â€ squares From Red Fabric, cut: 1- 1.5â€ square Place the 3.5â€ background square right side up. Place one 1.5â€ square of green in each corner; draw a line from corner to corner, as shown, stitch directly on the line.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%206%2026%2017%20PM-min.jpg)

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%206%2028%2036%20PM-min.jpg)

Trim seams, press green corners out.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%206%2031%2020%20PM-min.jpg)

Following the picture as a guideline, stitch the rest of the block, pressing seams as you finish (use spray starch to prevent the pieces from stretching out of shape).

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%206%2033%2035%20PM-min.jpg)

####Tree Mini Block

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0561-min.jpg)

From Background Fabric, cut: 2- 1.5â€x2.5â€ 2- 3.5â€x7â€ From Light Green Fabric, cut: 2- 1.5â€x5.5â€ From Dark Green Fabric, cut: 2- 1.5â€x5.5â€ From a Brown Fabric scrap, cut: 1- 1.5â€ square Using the photo as a guide, stitch the tree pieces together; pressing seams toward the darker fabric.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%206%2059%2022%20PM-min.jpg)

Find the middle of the block by folding in half at the top; make a mark at the center and at 1/4â€ on either side. Measure 1/4â€ up from the bottom of the block on both sides and make a mark.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2006%2042%20PM-min.jpg)

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2009%2032%20PM.jpg)

With right sides facing, align one 3.5â€x7â€ background piece with the bottom left mark and the center mark; stitch 1/4â€ away from the raw edge; trim and press background out. (You might find it helpful to draw the seam line first.)

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2011%2012%20PM.jpg)

Repeat this process on the other side.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2014%2051%20PM.jpg)

Trim square to 5.5â€. ####Bulb Mini Block

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0559-min.jpg)

From Background Fabric, cut: 6- 1.5â€ squares 2- 1.5â€x4.5â€ 2- 1.5x2.5â€ From Light Green Fabric, cut: 1- 3.5â€ square 1- 1.5â€ square 1- 1.5â€x2.5â€ From White Fabric scrap, cut: 1- 3/4â€ square From Light Grey Fabric, cut: 2- 3/4â€x1.5â€ From Dark Grey Fabric, cut: 2- 3/4â€x1.5â€ Using the photo as a guide, and the previous blocks techniques, assemble block as described:

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%208%2021%2015%20PM.jpg)

Place two of the 1.5â€ background squares, right sides together, on bottom left and right of the 3.5â€ bulb square; stitch on the line, trim and press. Place one 1.5â€ background square on the left side of the 1.5â€x2.5â€ bulb section; stitch on the line, trim and press. Place the 3/4â€ square of white (or light grey) on the bottom left 1.5â€ bulb square; stitch on the line, trim and press. Place the remaining 1.5â€ background square on this piece, right sides together. Stitch on the line, trim the side that does not have the white corner; press. Sew this section to the bottom bulb section. Stitch the 1.5â€x4.5â€ pieces on each side of the bulb. Sew the grey pieces together, alternating light and dark, right sides together and pressing after each addition. Attach the 1.5â€x2.5â€ pieces on both sides of this piece. You may need to center it, and trim as necessary. Stitch this section to the top of the bulb; press. ####Gift Box Mini Block

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0565-min.jpg)

From Background Fabric, cut: 5- 1.5â€ squares 2- 1.5â€x2.5â€ From Red Fabric, cut: 2- 2.5â€x3.5â€ From Silver Fabric, cut: 7- 1.5â€ squares 1- 1.5â€x3.5â€ Using the photo as a guide, and the previous blocks techniques, assemble block as described.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2043%2041%20PM.jpg)

With right sides together, stitch red fabric to each side of the 1.5â€x3.5â€ silver strip; press. Draw a line from corner-to-corner on the back of each background square. Place right sides together with three silver squares; stitch, trim and press.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2035%2054%20PM.jpg)

With right sides together, place a background square on top of this piece, making sure the drawn line and the seam are going in the opposite direction (like an X); stitch, trim and press.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%207%2039%2055%20PM-min.jpg)

Stitch one of these sections on each side of the remaining silver square, making sure that the points are facing out; press. Stitch two remaining background squares on each side; press. Sew to top of gift box section. Stitch remaining background pieces, right sides together on each side of the last bow piece, making sure the points are facing up; press. Sew to top of gift box section. ####Candy Cane Mini Block

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0563-min.jpg)

From Background Fabric, cut: 3- 1.5â€ squares 1- 2.5â€x3.5â€ 2- 1.5â€x5.5â€ Using the photo as a guide, and the previous blocks techniques, assemble block as described.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%209%2018%2002%20PM.jpg)

Draw a line on the back of all but one background square. With right sides together, place these with each red square; stitch on the line, trim and press. Use the photo to lay these pieces out correctly. With right sides together, place the remaining background square with the line on top of this piece, making sure the drawn line and the seam are going in the opposite direction (like an X); stitch, trim and press.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%209%2016%2006%20PM.jpg)

With right sides together, stitch the piece you just finished to the last background square; press. Stitch this section to the top of the 2.5â€x3.5â€ background piece; press. With right sides together, stitch the top three pieces of the candy cane together; press. Stitch this section to the top of the background section you just finished.

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/Photo%20Nov%2015%2C%209%2023%2051%20PM-min.jpg)

With right sides together, stitch the candy cane pieces together; press, then stitch to the background section. Attach the 1.5â€x5.5â€ background pieces, right sides together to each side of the candy cane; press. Happy holiday sewing, everyone!

![Holiday Mini Blocks](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Holiday%20Mini%20Quilt%20Blocks/IMG_0554_crop.jpg)

posts.title: Liberty Fabrics Tana Lawn
posts.markdown:
Copy and Imagery courtesy of Liberty Fabrics in conjunction with Fabric.com ####Cotton That Behaves Like Silk This is a cotton that behaves like silk- ultra-fine, with a fluid hand-feel and intense depth of color that is truly unmatchable. An everyday marvel of a dress material, Tana Lawn cotton is soft yet durable, cooling yet warming, and even machine washable. Discover a kaleidoscope array of brilliant colors and intricate patterns in our selection of Tana Lawns, fit for the most imaginative projects you can think up.

![DS Liberty](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Liberty%20Tana/CB-3190_libertyInspired_blog.jpg)

####History Whist travelling the plains of East Africa in the 1920s, Liberty buyer William Hayes Dorell discovered curious cotton fibers close to Lake Tana that sparked his imagination. Back on home soil, the silk-like threads were spun into lustrous form, screen printed with brilliant ink, and turned into a material that would change the textile industry forevermore. It was, of course, Tana Lawn.

![DS Liberty](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Liberty%20Tana/Block%20Printers_liberty.JPG)

Nearly a hundred years on, Tana Lawn has come to be recognized as a unique part of Liberty heritage. Projects created by Yarnspirations with Bernat We are absolutely in love with the new ultra-soft Alize Blanket EZ Yarn from Bernat! These 2 adorable projects can be easily made, with hardly any tools necessary. Using mostly your fingers, crafters of any age can whip these up anywhere! ##EZ Afghan

Skill Level: Beginner Supplies: 6 balls of Bernat Alize Yarn Finished Measurements: Approximately 51" x 60" [129.5 x 152.5 cm] Note: When beginning project, yarn end can start at far right or far left. Instructions are written with yarn end starting on the far right. Please reverse direction throughout the pattern if the opposite is more comfortable. INSTRUCTIONS Notes:
â€¢ Right side of project is facing at all times.
â€¢ â€˜Working yarnâ€™ is held behind stitches throughout work.
â€¢ Loops from working yarn are always pulled through stitches from back to front of work. Count 65 loops for foundation row (noting yarn end is at far right and all loops are facing upwards). 1st row: Working from left to right, pull the 66th loop (from â€˜working yarnâ€™) up through 65th loop (last loop of foundation row) from behind to create a knit stitch. Pull next loop from working yarn up through next loop of foundation. Continue in this manner to end of row. Do not turn work. 65 stitches in row. 2nd row: Working from right to left, pull next loop from working yarn up from behind through last stitch worked on previous row. *Pull next loop from working yarn up from behind through next stitch. Repeat from * across to end of row. Do not turn. 3rd row: Working from left to right, pull next loop from working yarn up from behind through last stitch worked on previous row. *Pull next loop from working yarn up from behind through next stitch. Repeat from * across to end of row. Do not turn. Repeat 2nd and 3rd rows until Afghan measures approximately 60" [152.5 cm], ending on a 3rd row.

![DS Bernat Alize](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bernat%20Alize%20Loop%20Yarn/ending%20on%203rd%20row.JPG)

Bind off row: Working in same direction as last row, pull 2nd stitch through first stitch. Pull 3rd stitch through 2nd stitch. Pull 4th stitch through 3rd stitch. Continue in this manner to end of row. Cut last loop to create a yarn â€˜tailâ€™. Tie to secure and weave in ends.

![DS Bernat Alize](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bernat%20Alize%20Loop%20Yarn/Bind%20Off.JPG)

![DS Bernat Alize](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bernat%20Alize%20Loop%20Yarn/Blanket%20Flat.jpg)

##EZ Baby Bear Hat

![DS Bernat Alize](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bernat%20Alize%20Loop%20Yarn/Baby%20in%20Hat.jpg)

Supplies: 1 ball of Bernat Alize Yarn, 1 safety pin, needle and thread Skill Level: Intermediate Size: One size to fit baby 1-2 yrs. INSTRUCTIONS Notes:
â€¢ Right side of work is facing at all times.
â€¢ â€˜Working yarnâ€™ is held behind stitches throughout.
â€¢ Loops from working yarn are always pulled through stitches from back to front of work.
â€¢ Move safety pin at end of each round to mark end of round.
HAT: Cut first loop of yarn close to base to create a tail approximately 3" [7.5 cm] long. Count 24 loops for foundation round. Tie tail to yarn between 24th and 25th loops to create ring. Place all loops facing upwards. 1st round: Working from right to left, pull first loop from working yarn up through first loop of round (first loop to the left of tie) to create a knit stitch. Pull next loop from working yarn up through next loop of foundation round. Continue in this manner to end of round. Place safety pin between first and last stitches of round to mark end of round. 2nd round: Working from right to left, pull first loop from working yarn up through first stitch of round. Pull next loop from working yarn up through next stitch of round. Continue in this manner to end of round. Repeat last round 6 times more (8 rounds worked in total). Shape Top 1st round: *Place first loop of round on top of second loop creating double loop â€“ treat this double loop as 1 stitch. Pull next loop from working yarn up through double stitch â€“ decrease made. Work next 2 stitches as usual. Repeat from * around. 6 stitches have been decreased. 18 stitches remain. 2nd round: *Make decrease. Work next stitch as usual. Repeat from * around. 6 stitches have been decreased. 12 stitches remain. 3rd round: *Make decrease. Repeat from * around. 6 stitches have been decreased. 6 stitches remain. Close Top: Cut between next 2 loops of working yarn. Cut next loop from working yarn to create tail approximately 3" [7.5 cm]. Pull tail through remaining 6 stitches and pull to close top, bringing tail to inside of Hat. Tie to any stitch at inside of Hat. EARS: (make 2) Cut first loop of yarn close to base to create a tail approximately 3" [7.5 cm] long. Count 6 loops for foundation round. Tie tail to yarn after 6th loop to create ring. Place all loops facing upwards. 1st and 2nd rounds: Work as given for Hat. 3rd round: *Make decrease. Repeat from * around. 3 stitches remain. Cut yarn, closing top as given for Hat. Using sewing thread, sew Ears to Hat as seen in picture.

![DS Bernat Alize](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Bernat%20Alize%20Loop%20Yarn/Hat%20flat.jpg)

Happy finger knitting!

posts.title: Designer Spotlight: Jennifer Adams
posts.markdown:
In today's Designer Spotlight, meet Dear Stella Designer Jennifer Adams! ####About Jennifer Adams: An award-winning designer, author, and TV personality, Jennifer Adams has a passion for calm, mindful living and inspires others to do so with the same authenticity. Home by Jennifer Adams designs and produces quality products that reflect her own breezy, effortless Southern California style, believing everyone deserves to have a space they love coming home to.

![DS Jennifer Adams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Jennifer%20Adams/JenniferAdams%20with%20dogs.JPG)

Jennifer was an on-air designer for HGTV, and the nationally syndicated The Better Show for eight seasons. Her creativity, content expertise, media presence, and recent graduation from Harvard Business School under the OPM Program for entrepreneurship have contributed to her growing international lifestyle business. Jenniferâ€™s home improvement and design guidebook, Love Coming Home, is due out August 2018. ####Q&A
####When did you realize you had a passion for art and design? I came from humble beginnings. Raising a family of four children, my parents had to work hard and be incredibly resourceful. Everything in our home, from our furniture and our clothes, were either handmade by my mom or given to us. She even made our sofa. So from an early age, I learned how to be creative and inventive. I was always rearranging the furniture and the dÃ©cor in my tiny bedroom, one time tacking beach towels to the walls of my room to create a tropical cabana look. I remember one of my wildest, room-refresh ideas was dyeing my yellow and green shag carpet by adding blue dye to a carpet steam cleaner my mom rented from the local market. Luckily for me it wasnâ€™t a total disaster, and the carpet did in fact eventually turn into a lovely shade of blue. I was so proud of my carpet masterpiece! ####Describe your aesthetic in 3 words. Effortless, modern, clean ####What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release? Iâ€™m all about a Southern California, Easy Breazy Boho vibe. Barefoot and effortless is the best! I made sure to reflect this in my latest fabric release. ####You teamed up with Covington to create your line of textiles. What about Covington made them the perfect partner for you? I love the people at Covington. Itâ€™s important to me to find partners who believe in collaboration and creating high-quality products, and the talented staff at Covington do just that. And I especially love that their price points make our fabrics accessible to most. ####If you had to choose one favorite fabric from your entire line, what would it be and why? Weathersfield and Mazinda. I like their boho-chic style. ####What are your current favorite trends in sewing/DIY? I love DIY big, bold accent pillows. The bigger the better, and with clean knife edges. Itâ€™s fun to mix and match decorative pillows in various shapes and sizes, in all areas of your home, they express so much of your unique personality. ####What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)? DIY projects allow great design to be accessible to everybody. Itâ€™s always inspiring to see others take a creative idea and bring it to fruition. It feels good to know that Iâ€™ve played a small part in that.

![DS Jennifer Adams](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Designer%20Spotlight%20Jennifer%20Adams/Jennifer%20Adams%20Window_Curio.jpg)

####What projects are on your â€œmust makeâ€ list right now? Itâ€™s hard to pick a favorite! I love DIY headboards, dining chairs and using fabric on the wall as art. Iâ€™m making my own decorative pillows right now. And, Iâ€™m fascinated with finding objects that I can turn into art pieces (especially from my fabric line!). ####What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most? Designers that inspire me include Emily Henderson, I love her dÃ©cor style and sense of whimsy, and Tammy Price for her clean, California look that uses neutrals layered with textures. I also adore Rebecca Atwood for her unique and beautiful textiles and patterns. These three designers are brilliant, each one a creative force that brings something special to home design. Another big inspiration is Deepak Chopra. For me, home and life are intertwined, and Chopraâ€™s writings and advocacy for healthier, holistic living in your home and environment align with my own love coming home philosophy. I believe home is where your best live begins. ####What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating? Yoga, meditation, and writing. I also love to sit in my backyard, relaxing with my dogs and a glass of wine, dreaming up new and improved ways to do something creative. Creativity ignites my soul and gives me great joy. ####Tell us one thing people might not know about you. Iâ€™m an introverted extrovert. As much as I like to be on TV or do public speaking engagements, Iâ€™m actually most comfortable having time one-on-one. Iâ€™m also addicted to creating Vision Boardsâ€¦ for pretty much everything!

posts.title: What's Inside Counts - Getting to Know Batting and Interfacing
posts.markdown:
A strong foundation is essential in creating something that lasts and looks great. For sewists, that foundation is interfacing for our apparel and craft projects, and batting for beautiful quilts. Get to know the ins and outs of batting and interfacing to help you on your next project.

Batting:

 Batting gives quilts their cuddliness and that oh-so-coveted crinkly texture right when they come out of the dryer. It's improtant to choose the right batting loft and fiber contents for your quilt's end use. For quilts that will see a lot of wear, use a poly blend batting in a low loft that can be washed many times. For an heirloom quilt for cold winter nights, pick a lofty wool. We've put together this handy chart for how to pick the right batting for your project. Of course, your finished result will depend on how it's quilted - but picking the right batting can save you hours of frustration along the way!

![batting](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Batting%20and%20Interfacing/CB-3366_AprilStory_Notions-Batting_blog.jpg)

Interfacing and Stabilizers

 Interfacing has SO many uses - and if you're not familiar with it - it's time to get to know this amazing notion. Batting:

Batting gives quilts their cuddliness and that oh-so-coveted crinkly texture right when they come out of the dryer. It's improtant to choose the right batting loft and fiber contents for your quilt's end use. For quilts that will see a lot of wear, use a poly blend batting in a low loft that can be washed many times. For an heirloom quilt for cold winter nights, pick a lofty wool.

posts.title: Designer + Collection Spotlight: Flower Market by A Beautiful Mess
posts.markdown:
In today's Designer + Collection Spotlight, meet Elsie Larson and Emma Chapman from A Beautiful Mess and their featured collection: Flower Market! ![Beautiful Mess collage 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DS%20A%20Beautiful%20Mess/3H9A8494.jpg)

About Flower Market

Flower Market is an organic quilting cotton collection from Elsie Larson and Emma Chapman, the sisters behind the lifestyle company A Beautiful Mess. The collection is inspired by their love of flowers, vintage, and the 1970s. The designs feature whimsical warm tones in classic patterns anyone can love including florals, stripes, and polka dots. Flower Market is the perfect collection to add some vintage flare to your next sewing project.

Q&A

When did you realize you had a passion for art and design?

Our mom went to school to teach art, but then she had me right as she graduated college. She did eventually teach art in a classroom, but while we were little she did projects with us all the time. Art was a huge part of our childhood. She taught me to make my own fabrics in high school with wax sticks and dye. So I feel like our whole lives we've been very into art- thank you mom!

Describe your aesthetic in 3 words.

Vintage-inspired, cozy, warm.

What was the inspiration behind your latest fabric release?

Our collection was inspired by our love for vintage floral prints. We both collect and wear vintage. One of our first businesses was a vintage shop when we were younger. So we've always been inspired by the sixties and seventies and it really came out through this collection. ![Beautiful Mess collage 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DS%20A%20Beautiful%20Mess/CB-3681_Blog_DF_ABeuaM_Collage1.jpg)

You teamed up with PBS Fabrics to create your line of textiles. What about them made the perfect partner for you?

We loved working with PBS. They helped us to create a more balanced collection and we were so happy they were into the idea of doing an organic collection!

If you had to choose one favorite fabric from your entire line, what would it be and why?

Definitely this large floral print, but I want to pick the rainbow stripes too! ![Beautiful Mess collage 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DS%20A%20Beautiful%20Mess/CB-3681_Blog_DF_ABeuaM_Collage3.jpg) * Flower Market Large Flowers Petals Pink Fabric (0646704) * Flower Market Large Flowers Petals Daisy Fabric (0646705) * Flower Market Large Flowers Petals Olive Fabric (0646703) * Shop the Full Flower Market Collection

What are your current favorite trends in sewing?

We love how there is a resurgence in sewing for your own clothing as well as quilting. We love seeing people use our patterns to make clothing and quilts the most!

What do you love most about creating a DIY project with your fabric (or seeing customers creating DIY projects with your fabric)?

I'm a new mom (Elsie) so I'm pretty inspired by outfits for my little people right now.
![Beautiful Mess collage 3](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DS%20A%20Beautiful%20Mess/CB-3681_Blog_DF_ABeuaM_Collage2.jpg)

What other blogs/brands/designers inspire you most?

We love @elisejoy she sews a lot of her own clothing and is so inspiring to us!

What do you love to do when you arenâ€™t designing and creating?

Painting and we both love baking!

Tell us one thing people might not know about you.

LOL after blogging for 12 years it's hard to think of something people don't know. We're both pretty opinionated and we disagree a lot, but we rarely have a big fight these days. Micro-fights only.
![Beautiful Mess collage 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/DS%20A%20Beautiful%20Mess/biophoto.jpg)

posts.title: Business Spotlight: Juniper Dress Co.
posts.markdown:
Hey there! I am Whitney, founder of Juniper Dress Co. I love making hair accessories and custom clothing. I am a big fan of bright colors, funky patterns, and anything floral. I love making accessories and clothing that are as unique as my clients. Whether it is a hair scarf or custom dress I believe that the right clothing can elevate your everyday look and make you feel special.

![Picture of Whitney](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Juniper%20Dress%20Co/headshot2.jpg)

Q&A

When did you realize you wanted to start a business?

I realized I wanted to start a business when my closet couldnâ€™t hold any more clothes because I was sewing so much! I knew I wanted to keep designing and creating so I thought about sewing for clients. My co-workers kept asking where I purchased my clothes and were always impressed when I told them I had made them. That was when I knew it was time to start selling my own designs.

What was the inspiration behind your products?

I was inspired to make custom clothing while teaching second grade at an orthodox Jewish school in Los Angeles. The schoolâ€™s dress code made it hard to wear clothing from most stores so I went to the fashion district, bought some fabric, and made my own skirts and dresses. I was inspired to start making hair accessories because I wanted to make unique, handmade fashion items at a more accessible price point.

![Picture of Juniper Dress Co. hair scarfs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Juniper%20Dress%20Co/product4.jpg)

If you had to choose one favorite product from your entire line, what would it be and why?

My favorite product is the Black and White Polka Dot Hair Scarf. I love this scarf because the pebble crepe is such a beautiful fabric and the scarf is extremely versatile. Not only does the color go with everything but there are so many different ways to wear it. I like to tie mine around my ponytail and wear it as a headband.

![Picture of Pebble Crepe SKUs](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Juniper%20Dress%20Co/pebblecrepe_skus.jpg)

Featured fabric: TELIO Pebble Crepe

Why do you love working with Fabric.com?

There are three main reasons I love working with Fabric.com:

  • Their selection is incredible! There are so many options when it comes to fibers, colors, and patterns.
  • I also love how reasonable the prices are. You can find beautiful high quality fabrics for a fraction of the cost of major retailers.
  • The last reason is that they offer free shipping on orders over a certain amount. As a small business owner who orders fabric regularly that is such a nice perk!

What is the most unexpected way youâ€™ve worked with fabric?

I recently had my first baby and I used some spandex fabric to make a pumping bra!

What piece of advice do you wish you had before starting your business?

In the past few months I have started listening to Jenna Kutcherâ€™s Goal Digger Podcast. She talks a lot about having a mindset of abundance. That basically means believing that there is enough success, growth, and happiness for everyone. Just because someone else is successful doesnâ€™t mean there is any less success for you.

![Picture of Hair Accessories 1](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Juniper%20Dress%20Co/Product1.jpg)

How do you market your business? What has been the most impactful marketing tool youâ€™ve used and why?

I love to use social media to market my business. I also love to do local craft fairs and handmade markets because I get to meet my customers in person. I think that connecting with people face to face is the best way to market your business!Â 

![Picture of Hair Accessories 2](https://fabric-webdata.s3.amazonaws.com/Images/Blog/Juniper%20Dress%20Co/product3.jpg)
